2001 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ardito


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Bronx County


106 Misc. 2d 100; 431 N.Y.S.2d 311; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2644



August 4, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed motion to suppress all evidence acquired or derived from electronic surveillance in his prosecution for first degree criminal usury and grand larceny by extortion.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with first degree criminal usury and grand larceny by extortion. Defendant filed a motion to suppress all evidence acquired or derived from electronic surveillance that was authorized by court order. Defendant argued the electronic eavesdropping order exceeded the grounds of permissible state regulation as defined by the federal wiretapping laws. The court held a state could not broaden its powers in excess of the standards set forth in title III of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, 18 U.S.C.S. §§ 2510-2520. The crime with which defendant was charged was listed under state law as an offense that warranted investigation by wiretap, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §700.05(8)(e), but was not listed as such an offense under federal law. However, the intent behind the federal statute was to target organized crime. As usury was usually accompanied by extortion, it thus fell within the catch-all phrase of the federal statute regarding other crimes dangerous to life or limb. Defendant's motion to suppress was denied as the state statute allowing eavesdropping in usury cases did not contravene or impermissibly expand the standards of the federal law.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to suppress evidence acquired by electronic surveillance was denied because the state statute allowing electronic eavesdropping in usury cases did not improperly expand the standards of the federal wiretapping law regarding crimes warranting investigation by wiretap.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Eavesdropping Warrants

A motion by a defendant charged with criminal usury in the first degree and grand larceny by extortion to suppress all evidence acquired or derived from electronic surveillance pursuant to a court order is denied, since the warrant was not in derogation of the intent and objective of Congress in providing that a State could not broaden its powers in excess of the standards set forth in the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (see US Code, tit 18, § 2516); the intention of the drafters of that legislation was to protect privacy of wire and oral communications unless the evidence emanating therefrom fell into a category of major offenses that were dangerous to life, limb or property or characteristic of the operations of organized crime, and although usury is a designated offense under the State statute ( CPL 700.05, subd 8, par [e]) and is not so specified under the Federal statute, pre-emption should not be applied as it was in People v Shapiro (50 NY2d 747), since the affidavits supporting the application for the warrant made repeated references to organized crime and extortion is usury's necessary adjunct.

 

2002 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hasenbein v. Siebert


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


106 Misc. 2d 94; 431 N.Y.S.2d 299; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2643



July 31, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff bank director brought a motion by way of an order to show cause requesting a preliminary injunction pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301, which restrained defendants, superintendent of banks, the banking board, and the banking department, from removing him from the board of directors of the bank.


OVERVIEW: The banking department issued a directive that stated that the director was ineligible for election as a board member because of the provisions of N.Y. Banking Law § 397(2), para. b, cl. 3. The director was married to the niece of a member of the board of directors of the bank. The director contended that § 397(2), para. b, cl. 3 was unconstitutional because it was arbitrary, irrational, and overbroad, and because it was an unreasonable exercise of the state's police powers, which violated the director's due process and equal protection rights. The court concluded that the director's rights to due process and equal protection of the law were violated and declared that the statute as it applied to the director was unconstitutional. The court explained that the statute significantly interfered with the exercise of the fundamental right to marry. The court determined that the goal sought to be achieved by the legislature was to eliminate nepotism and the eradication of such an evil could have been accomplished with a less restrictive statute. The court noted that the statute that was too narrow and had gone too far, to the point where the governmental interference became unreasonable.


OUTCOME: This court found that the director's rights to due process and equal protection of the law were violated and declared that the statute as it applied to the director was unconstitutional because it significantly interfered with the fundamental right to marry. The court ordered that the director should be reinstated to the board as soon as possible.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Banks and Banking -- Savings and Loan Associations -- Eligibility for Membership on Board of Directors

Section 397 (subd 2, par [b], cl [3]) of the Banking Law, which provides, inter alia, that no person shall be eligible to election as a director of any savings and loan association if such person or his spouse is the "grandparent, parent, child, grandchild, brother, sister, aunt, uncle, nephew or niece of a director", a more restrictive provision than its Federal counterpart, which extends only to immediate family and their spouses, is unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff, who was a member of the board of such an association, but was removed "under protest" by the board of directors pursuant to a directive issued by the Banking Department stating that plaintiff was ineligible for election under section 397 since he is married to the niece of another board member; plaintiff's rights to due process and equal protection of the law have been violated thereby, since the legitimate State goal sought to be achieved under the statute -- the elimination of nepotism in the mutual savings industry -- can be accomplished with a statute that is less restrictive of his freedom [***2] to marry and his right to practice a profession free from unreasonable government interference. Accordingly, plaintiff should be reinstated as soon as possible.

 

2003 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Farmer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Mount Vernon


113 Misc. 2d 85; 448 N.Y.S.2d 615; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2979



July 30, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the defendant is found "not guilty".


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with failing to supply heat and hot water in violation of the city's housing code.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with failing to supply heat and hot water in his multifamily dwelling in violation of the city's housing code, Mount Vernon, N.Y., Housing Code art. 6, § 4-1(a). Under § 4-1(a), homeowners were obligated to furnish heat unless the failure to furnish heat was caused by circumstances beyond the owner's control or causation. The court found that the evidence established that there was no heat or hot water on the premises for two days and that it was then restored. The evidence further established that the disruption in the heat and hot water was caused by a break in a heat riser pipe as a result of freezing conditions. At the time the furnace was operable and there was adequate fuel oil. Therefore, defendant had no reason to anticipate that the pipe would break. Defendant tried to have plumbers fix the pipe and no one was available until the third day. The court found defendant was not guilty of the crime because the act, which originally deprived the premises of heat, was an involuntary act. The disruption in the heating system was not a result of any overt act or omission on defendant's part.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant not guilty.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Criminal Sanctions in Housing Code for Malum Prohibitum Offense -- Requirement of Voluntary Act

An involuntary act by a defendant is insufficient to sustain his conviction under a statute which imposes criminal sanctions for a malum prohibitum offense; accordingly, defendant was not guilty of failing to provide heat and hot water for a residential building in violation of the Housing Code of the City of Mount Vernon which subjects a violator to potential fines and imprisonment where he had furnished an adequate heating system with sufficient fuel oil, had no reason to anticipate the original disruption of heating service and, despite efforts to furnish immediate repairs, was unable to do so for several days due to circumstances beyond his control.

 

2004 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Braunstein v. Board of Examiners of Nursing Home Adm'rs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


105 Misc. 2d 91; 431 N.Y.S.2d 890; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2501



July 28, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner licensee brought a proceeding, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking review of a decision by respondent Board of Examiners of Nursing Home Administrators to revoke licensee's rights to operate a nursing home based on his misdemeanor conviction in New Jersey.


OVERVIEW: The licensee was convicted in New Jersey of misdemeanor filing of false medical documents. The Board of Examiners in New York notified the licensee that his license to practice nursing home administration was forfeited by reason of the New Jersey conviction because the crime was a felony in New York. The licensee sought review, claiming that forfeiture without a hearing was unconstitutional and that the misdemeanor conviction did not invoke forfeiture. The court disagreed, holding that although the crime was a misdemeanor under New Jersey law, it was a felony in New York. Public Health Law called for forfeiture of a nursing home administration license upon conviction of a crime considered a felony in New York, even if it was a misdemeanor in the jurisdiction that conducted the trial. The offering of a false instrument for filing in the first degree was a felony in New York, which was the equivalent of the New Jersey statute under which the licensee was convicted. The forfeiture without a hearing did not violate due process and was not unconstitutional. The New Jersey order prohibiting consideration of the conviction in any civil proceeding had no extraterritorial effect.


OUTCOME: The court found that revocation of the license was constitutional and that the New Jersey conviction equated to a felony in New York.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Health -- Nursing Homes -- Revocation of Nursing Home Administration License -- Conviction of Felony

Since petitioner's New Jersey misdemeanor conviction for filing false and fraudulent nursing home claims for reimbursement under the Medicaid program constitutes a felony under the equivalent New York statute (Penal Law, § 175.35), respondent may properly revoke petitioner's license to practice nursing home administration in New York by reason of the New Jersey conviction under a statute which calls for the automatic forfeiture of a nursing home administration license upon conviction of a crime which is a felony in New York although not in the jurisdiction where the licensee was convicted (Public Health Law, § 2897, subd 2); revocation of a license based upon a felony conviction is constitutional and a license for the establishment of a nursing home may be revoked upon conviction of crimes involving matters relating to the operation of the home; the New Jersey order prohibiting the consideration of petitioner's conviction as evidence in any civil proceeding has no extraterritorial effect and, in any event, the automatic forfeiture provisions do not relate to any kind of civil [***2] proceeding.

 

2005 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hudson View Properties v. Weiss


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


106 Misc. 2d 251; 431 N.Y.S.2d 632; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2673



July 28, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord brought this holdover proceeding before the court to evict respondent tenant on the ground that she was violating a substantial obligation of her tenancy by living with a man to whom she was unrelated by blood or marriage. The tenant moved to dismiss the landlord's petition for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The tenant, her former husband, and their children moved into a rent controlled apartment under the terms of a lease signed by her former husband. The lease provided that the premises could only be occupied by the named tenant and members of the immediate family of the named tenant. The former husband then moved out of the apartment, and another man subsequently moved in. The landlord sought to evict the tenant for violating the terms of the lease. The court held that the lease could not discriminate against the tenant based on her lack of a legal familial relationship with the male resident. The court held that the language of the N.Y. Exec. Law § 296(5)(a) was manifestly clear and prohibited the landlord from differentiating between those who were married and those who were not married, all other facts being equal. The court held that the portion of the lease attempting to sanction discrimination based upon marital status was unenforceable; therefore, the tenant's motion was granted, and the petition was dismissed.


OUTCOME: The tenant's motion to dismiss the landlord's petition for failure to state a cause of action was granted, and the landlord's petition to evict the tenant was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Discrimination

1. A landlord's petition to evict a tenant under a lease clause prohibiting to unmarried couples from occupying the demised premises must be dismissed pursuant to section 296 (subd 5, par [a]) of the Executive Law and section B1-7.0 (subd 5, par [a]) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which provide that a landlord may not discriminate on the basis of "marital status", since these sections, which must be liberally construed, prohibit landlords from differentiating between those who are married and those who are not married, all other facts being equal; furthermore, the State Division of Human Rights, the body responsible for enforcement of section 296, has consistently taken the position that a refusal to rent to unmarried couples constitutes unlawful discrimination on the basis of marital status and a reasonable construction of a statute by the agency responsible for its administration should be upheld.

Landlord and Tenant -- Discrimination

2. Section 296 (subd 5, par [a]) of the Executive Law and section B1-7.0 (subd 5, par [a]) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which provide that [***2] a landlord may not discriminate on the basis of "marital status", do not violate the contract clause of the United States Constitution since that clause does not subordinate all societal relations to the protection of private contracts and such private rights must give way to the State's responsibility to promote the general good of the public; furthermore, these sections are not violative of the due process clauses of the New York and United States Constitutions by interfering with landlords' property rights since laws such as these, which are proper exercises of the police power of the State and which are reasonably designed to promote the general welfare of society, are not ipso facto unconstitutional because they may affect private property rights; legislative enactments are presumed to be constitutional and market relations between landlords and tenants are legitimate subjects for the exercise of the State's legislative police power.

 

2006 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Deschamps v. Deschamps


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


103 Misc. 2d 678; 430 N.Y.S.2d 966; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2164



July 23, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant husband filed a motion for an amended verified answer against plaintiff wife who filed a cross motion to discontinue her action in a case for divorce on grounds of alleged abandonment regarding the equitable distribution marital law.


OVERVIEW: The husband sought a judgment of divorce from the wife on grounds of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment. The wife remained concerned about the financial security of herself and three children stemming from her role as wife and mother. The husband opposed the wife's motion to discontinue her action, contending that it was merely a device to renew her action under the equitable distribution divorce law. The court held that the equitable distribution and distributive award aspects of the new law were to be applied retroactively. The effect of the entire domestic relations law was to make eligible for distribution property, which prior to the act could not have been subjected to such treatment. The statute was constitutional and did not constitute a deprivation of property without due process of law, in violation of the federal constitution and the New York Constitution. The wife's motion to discontinue her action was denied. The husband's motion to amend was granted.


OUTCOME: The wife's motion to discontinue her divorce action was denied. The husband's motion to amend was granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Dismissal and Nonsuit -- Discontinuance

1. In the absence of a stipulation between the parties, a court order is required to obtain discontinuance of an action by a party asserting a claim after responsive pleadings have been served ( CPLR 3217, subd [b]); an application for leave to discontinue an action may be refused whenever circumstances exist which afford a basis for the exercise of legal discretion, such as prejudice to either party. Accordingly, the court denied plaintiff wife's application, made after defendant husband served responsive pleadings, to discontinue her action for divorce, where plaintiff was motivated by the possibility of financial gain, rather than by any possible reconciliation, and defendant, who wishes to amend his answer and interpose a counterclaim for divorce based on allegations of cruel and inhuman treatment, might be prejudiced if said discontinuance were granted, since, if he prevails on his counterclaim in the existing action, defendant will not have to pay plaintiff any alimony, but if plaintiff's action is discontinued and defendant reasserts his claim, alimony would be available to plaintiff, even if defendant prevails, under section [***2] 236 (part B, subd 6, par a) of the Domestic Relations Law, as recently amended, effective July 19, 1980.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Equitable Distribution of Marital Property

2. Statutes are generally construed as prospective unless the language of the statute, either expressly or by necessary implication, requires that it be given a retroactive construction; remedial statutes constitute an exception to said general rule, but only to the extent that they do not impair vested rights. Accordingly, recently amended provisions of the Domestic Relations Law (L 1980, ch 281), which permit equitable distribution of marital property and distributive award, apply to actions commenced prior to the effective date of the statute, July 19, 1980, in which judgment was not entered and which are still pending, since said result is indicated expressly (Domestic Relations Law, § 236, part B, subd 5) and is, in any event, dictated in order to achieve equity; moreover, although said provisions make eligible for distribution property which, prior to the act, could not have been subjected to such treatment, the statute is constitutional and does not violate the Fourteenth Amendment to [***3] the United States Constitution or section 6 of article 1 of the New York State Constitution.

Pleading -- Amendment

3. Leave shall be given freely to amend pleadings upon such terms as may be just ( CPLR 3025) and, accordingly, defendant's motion to amend his verified answer in a matrimonial action to interpose a counterclaim in advance of trial is granted where there is no prejudice generated thereby at such stage of the proceedings.

 

2007 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Castrovinci


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


105 Misc. 2d 67; 431 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2559



July 23, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Decedent's widow sought the appointment of an ancillary fiduciary in the State of New York against whom the action against decedent could be continued after the Queens County Supreme Court (New York) held that the domiciliary fiduciary could not be substituted in a negligence action by virtue of the North Carolina Statute of Limitations, but that this time bar would not preclude substitution of a New York ancillary fiduciary.


OVERVIEW: Decedent was joined as a defendant in a proceeding in the trial court alleging negligence in the rendition of medical treatment. The alleged negligence took place in Queens and decedent was served with process in New York. Decedent passed away while the action was still pending. At that time, decedent was a domiciliary of North Carolina where his will was probated and his wife appointed executrix. The trial court ruled that the domiciliary fiduciary could not be substituted due to the North Carolina statute of limitations. The widow sought to have a New York ancillary fiduciary appointed. The court granted limited ancillary letters testamentary to the decedent's widow, holding that the liability policy was not the sole basis for jurisdiction. The court held that the acts complained of occurred in New York, and the decedent was both domiciled and served personally in New York State. The court held further that a less stringent test then the jurisdictional prerequisite of ancillary probate under N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 1602 applied and that the only property which could support the court's jurisdiction was the "debt" represented by decedent's liability insurance policy.


OUTCOME: The court granted limited ancillary letters testamentary to the decedent's widow.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Surrogate's Court -- Jurisdiction over Estate of Nonresident Decedent

Under SCPA 206 (subd 2, par [a]), which provides that a Surrogate's Court has exclusive jurisdiction over the estate of a nondomiciliary who left property within that county and no other, an insurer's maintenance of its only New York office in New York County provides a sufficient basis of jurisdiction for a New York County Surrogate's Court to issue, for the purpose of defense of a tort action, ancillary letters testamentary in the estate of a nonresident decedent, who maintained a liability insurance policy with said carrier, despite the holding of Rush v Savchuk (444 U.S. 320) that due process is violated if a court purports to assert quasi in rem jurisdiction solely on the basis of an attached liability insurance policy since, in addition to the insurance policy, decedent's allegedly tortious acts occurred in New York, decedent was domiciled in this State at the time of the acts complained of, and decedent was personally served in New York.

 

2008 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Zagarow v. Zagarow


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


105 Misc. 2d 1054; 430 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2620



July 23, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant has not sustained his counterclaim and the plaintiff is entitled to judgment granting her a divorce and denying the defendant a dual divorce.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife filed an action for divorce from defendant husband. In response, the husband filed a counterclaim seeking a dual divorce.


OVERVIEW: The parties were married in 1970. Almost five years later, the parties began to experience marital difficulties. In spite of the efforts of the wife to save the marriage, the husband became more distant, refused marriage counseling, stated he no longer loved her, absented himself from the home with increasing frequency, and ultimately moved out. In his counterclaim, the husband contended the wife's unwillingness to have children and to engage in sexual intercourse unless he used a contraceptive constituted a defense to her cause of action, and such cruel and inhuman treatment on her part warranted the granting to him of a decree of divorce. The court held the wife was entitled to a judgment of divorce because she demonstrated the husband engaged in a course of conduct constituting cruel and inhuman treatment of the wife to the extent that it endangered her physical and mental well-being and rendered it improper for her to cohabit with him. In addition, the court found the husband had not sustained his counterclaim.


OUTCOME: The court granted the wife's request for a divorce and denied the husband's counterclaim for a dual divorce.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Cruel and Inhuman Treatment

1. A wife's refusal to bear children or to have sexual relations with her husband without the use of contraceptives is not a defense to her cause of action for divorce on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment since her refusal was not provocation which incited the husband's cruel and inhuman treatment.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Refusal to Bear Children

2. A husband is not entitled to a divorce on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment on the basis of his wife's refusal to bear children or to have sexual relations with him without the use of contraceptives since he fails to offer objective proof of physical or mental injury to him caused by her acts.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Refusal to Bear Children

3. A husband is not entitled to a divorce on the ground of constructive abandonment based upon his wife's refusal to bear children in the absence of any express or implied agreement to have children; although such a unilateral [***2] determination may be destructive to marital relations, the constitutional right of a wife to unilaterally terminate a pregnancy is naturally followed by her right to unilaterally determine to prevent pregnancy; since the State Legislature has not found such an action grounds for divorce, a court may not do so.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Refusal to Engage in Sexual Relations without Contraceptives

4. A husband is not entitled to a divorce on the ground of constructive abandonment based upon the wife's refusal to engage in sexual relations with him without the use of contraceptives since the husband did not refuse to have intercourse due to his wife's insistence upon his use of contraceptives; his consent negates the theory of abandonment.

 

2009 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Celli


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Westchester County


105 Misc. 2d 1005; 430 N.Y.S.2d 949; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2611



July 15, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with the crimes of robbery in the third degree and grand larceny in the second degree. In her court appearance, defendant challenged the plaintiff's planned use of her prior felony conviction on grounds that the conviction was for a youthful offender infraction and could not serve as a predicate for several reasons. A hearing was held pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21 (5).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with robbery and grand larceny. At her court appearance, defendant pleaded guilty but challenged plaintiff prosecution's planned use of her prior felony conviction in that it related to a youthful offender crime and thus could not serve as a predicate for several reasons. The prosecution argued that in the absence of an unconditional discharge, she should have been sentenced as a second felony offender. The court held that the prosecution had met its burden of proving that such predicated felony conviction was constitutionally obtained and that a finding by the sentencing court that defendant would derive a benefit from probation had indeed been made under the Federal Youth Corrections Act (Act) 18 U.S.C.S. § 5010 (b). More importantly, the court noted that defendant was charged as a youthful offender under (d) of the Act, rather than state law, and that an offender was convicted until they were unconditionally discharged under that act. The court found that defendant's conviction under that act did not change the nature of defendant's admission to a felony and that her conviction still stood. Thus, defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender.


OUTCOME: The court rejected defendant's argument that the plaintiff could not use her prior conviction as a predicate because it was a youthful offender crime. The court ruled as such by finding that defendant had not been unconditionally discharged under the applicable federal act and her prior conviction did not change the nature of her admission to a felony. Thus, she still stood convicted, and was to be sentenced as second felony offender.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Second Felony Offender

Under the Federal Youth Corrections Act (United States Code, tit 18, § 5005 et seq.), the conviction of a youthful offender is automatically set aside if his conduct following conviction under the act leads to his unconditional discharge from probation or parole prior to the expiration of the maximum period fixed at sentencing; however, prior to the time of unconditional discharge, a youth sentenced under the act stands convicted of a crime and, accordingly, where said crime is a felony, it may then serve as the predicate offense for purposes of sentencing the defendant as a second felony offender in New York (Penal Law, § 70.06), notwithstanding the fact that until the expiration of the maximum sentence imposed for the Federal conviction the defendant remains eligible to have it set aside upon the requisite unconditional discharge.

 

2010 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


International Service Agencies v. O'Shea


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


104 Misc. 2d 1071; 430 N.Y.S.2d 224; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2449



July 7, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding, petitioner charities sought to require respondents, Commissioner of General Services (commissioner) comptroller, and private charities, to permit the charities to participate in the annual solicitation of charitable contributions from state employees through the State Employees Federated Appeals (SEFAs).


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. State Fin. Law § 6-a, state employees were solicited through the State Employees Federated Appeals (SEFAs) to give charitable contributions by payroll deductions. Participation in SEFAs was limited to two agencies. The charities petitioned to require the commissioner, comptroller, and private charities to permit them to participate in the SEFAs. The court noted that although § 6-a granted the commissioner the authority to make rules and regulations governing contributions, no such rules or regulations concerning the procedures by which inclusion in a SEFA might be determined had been promulgated. In addition, private charities, which had the responsibility to determine inclusion in SEFAs, had no articulated procedure for selection. The court held that the participation of a charity in SEFAs should be determined on a rational and fair basis. The court ordered the commissioner to permit the conduct of only those SEFAs that were approved by him after promulgation of procedures articulating an objective standard for selection. The court enjoined the comptroller from authorizing payroll deductions to any SEFA unless it was approved pursuant to those procedures.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the commissioner to permit the conduct of only those State Employees Federated Appeals (SEFAs) that were approved after the creation of procedures containing an objective standard for inclusion of charities. The court enjoined the comptroller from authorizing payroll deductions unless the SEFA was approved pursuant to those procedures.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Charities -- State Employees Federated Appeals - Participation

Where respondent Commissioner of General Services, although empowered to do so, has not promulgated regulations for the steps to be followed in setting forth procedures by which inclusion in the annual solicitation of charitable contributions from New York State employees through the State Employees Federated Appeals (SEFA) may be determined ( State Finance Law, § 6-a), but has delegated this responsibility to the private charities now included in the annual SEFA, which charities have, in fact, no articulated procedure for the selection of a particular federated community campaign, such procedure is arbitrary and capricious as a matter of law, since private parties to which public authority has been delegated are subject to the same constitutional restraints as government officials; while petitioner association of charitable organizations has no absolute right to participate in a SEFA, it does have a right to apply for admission. Accordingly, respondent Commissioner of General Services is directed to permit the conduct of only those SEFAs that have been approved under procedures by which the issue of the participation [***2] of petitioners may be resolved through an articulated objective standard, promulgated by the commissioner or pursuant to delegated authority under section 6-a, and, further, the Comptroller is enjoined from authorizing payroll deductions to any SEFA hereinafter conducted which has not been approved by the Commissioner of General Services pursuant to procedures promulgated pursuant hereto.

 

2011 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Boyer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Syracuse


105 Misc. 2d 877; 430 N.Y.S.2d 936; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2631



July 7, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were charged with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 260.05, criminal nonsupport of a child. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the charges.


OVERVIEW: Defendants sought dismissal of charges of criminal nonsupport of a child on the ground that the accusatory instruments were insufficient, conclusory, and did not comply with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.40. The court granted the motions. The court held that the texts of the instruments did not satisfy N.Y. Crim. Proc. §§ 100.40, 100.15. There were no specific facts constituting the crimes alleged and the allegations were conclusory. The people failed to allege facts of an evidentiary nature to support the conclusory allegations that each defendant willfully failed to provide support for his child, although he was able to do so. A statement of nonpayment was not sufficient alone to permit presumption that such failure to support was willful. Further, the criminal justice system was an unnecessary tool for collection of support. The Family Court was granted exclusive jurisdiction to compel compliance with its own orders and was equipped with ample procedures to do so.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges of criminal nonsupport of a child against defendants.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Nonsupport of Child -- Adequacy of Accusatory Instrument

1. Accusatory instruments charging defendants with criminal nonsupport (Penal Law, § 260.05), which merely repeat the language of the statute, are insufficient misdemeanor informations ( CPL 100.15, 100.40) since they fail to allege facts of any evidentiary nature to support the conclusory allegation that defendants willfully failed to provide child support although able to do so and neither the attached affidavits of the mothers involved nor reference to the Department of Social Services or Family Court support orders can cure the deficiency in the accusatory instrument; any statement by the People that the defendants have failed to obey Family Court support orders are extraneous and immaterial to a determination in criminal proceedings due to the nonfinal nature of such orders and any allegations concerning such orders should not be included in the accusatory instruments; however, the accusatory instruments are valid misdemeanor complaints since a misdemeanor complaint does not require every element of the offense to be actually set forth and, rather than ordering their dismissal as insufficient informations,  [***2] such instruments may be amended to satisfy the information requirements.

Crimes -- Nonsupport of Child -- Double Jeopardy

2. Double jeopardy may act as a bar to a criminal prosecution when the purpose of a prior "civil" administrative proceeding was essentially punitive, thereby placing the defendant in potential jeopardy and, thus, the fact a support proceeding is in Family Court does not automatically exclude the viability of a double jeopardy claim in a criminal nonsupport prosecution (Penal Law, § 260.05) since a support-related proceeding in which a person is entitled to assigned counsel to preserve his rights and is placed in potential deprivation of his liberty through a contempt hearing is not a proceeding that may automatically be regarded as "civil"; in resolving the issue of double jeopardy in a criminal nonsupport prosecution, the three areas to be examined are whether the charges in both cases arise out of "identical transactions", whether the defendant was "in jeopardy" in the first support proceeding and whether the purpose of the first proceeding was punitive and, accordingly, since "identical transactions" are not involved, defendants' claims of double [***3] jeopardy in the criminal nonsupport prosecutions must be denied.

Crimes -- Nonsupport of Child -- Dismissal in Furtherance of Justice

3. Criminal court should not generally exercise jurisdiction over criminal nonsupport prosecutions (Penal Law, § 260.05) since Family Court has exclusive jurisdiction over all support fixing and enforcement proceedings and only the Family Court can adequately investigate allegations of nonsupport and delve into matters determinative of needs of children, means and ability of parents to pay support and the adequacy of payments; based upon the extensive remedies in Family Court to enforce support orders including wage orders, sequestration of property and contempt sanctions (Family Ct Act, art 4), criminal sanctions for nonsupport have become an "obsolete appendage" to the Family Court system and extreme caution should be observed before resort is made to the criminal justice system; accordingly, since Family Court is equipped with a wide range of remedial resources and punitive sanctions and the State's interest in receiving support payments from those able to pay can be adequately safeguarded through the use of the Family Court system and [***4] since maintenance of criminal nonsupport prosecutions would deprive both the defendants and their "victims" of a more meaningful resolution of the nonsupport dilemma, the criminal prosecutions are dismissed in the furtherance of justice ( CPL 170.40).

 

2012 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Marcus v. Baron


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


106 Misc. 2d 71; 431 N.Y.S.2d 627; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2640



July 7, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner incorporators sought a judgment to declare Ramapo, N.Y., Local Law ch. 45, No. 3-1967 (1967), known as the village incorporation law, invalid and to reverse and annul a decision made by respondent city supervisor, who found that the incorporators' petition seeking incorporation was defective, legally insufficient, and not in compliance with No. 3-1967 and N.Y. Village Law § 2 (1973).


OVERVIEW: The incorporators contended that the State had pre-empted the field dealing with the incorporation of villages by virtue of N.Y. Village Law § 2 (1973) and that § 2 was a general law that applied to all villages in the State. The incorporators also claimed that N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(c)(ii) prohibited a local government from adopting local laws which were inconsistent with the provisions of a general law. The supervisors claimed that the supervisor's findings were correct and the court did not have to reach the constitutional question raised by the incorporators. The court held that the incorporators' petition was legally sufficient for a claim under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, and that nothing in N.Y. Village Law § 2 prevented the use of affidavits in their request for incorporation. The court further held that the City lacked the power to enact Ramapo, N.Y., Local Law ch. 45, No. 3-1967 (1967) under the provisions of N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(i) and N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(c)(ii).


OUTCOME: The court granted the incorporators' application, declared that the local law was invalid and unconstitutional, sustained the incorporators' petition for incorporation, and annulled the determination that the petition for incorporation was defective and legally insufficient.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Incorporation of Village

A 1967 town local law which gives the town board, on the basis of the report of the town supervisor, the discretionary power to reject a proposed village incorporation if such incorporation would not be in the "overall public interest", is invalid and unconstitutional since such local law is inconsistent with a general State statute dealing with the incorporation of villages in the State under which the town supervisor merely performs the ministerial function of determining whether the petition for incorporation is legally sufficient (Village Law, art 2); since the State has pre-empted the field dealing with the incorporation of villages throughout the State, any local law inconsistent with such general State law is invalid (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c], par [ii]; Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10, subd 1, par [i]); since the petition for incorporation does in fact contain the valid signatures of at least 20% of the residents of the territory qualified to vote for town officers in a town in which all or part of such territory is located and town-owned property is not excluded by the statute from a proposed village incorporation,  [***2] the supervisor's rejection of the petition as defective and "legally insufficient" is annulled.

 

2013 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of McLeod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Westchester County


105 Misc. 2d 1012; 430 N.Y.S.2d 782; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2612



June 30, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner illegitimate child filed a motion to strike the answer of respondent administratrix, which alleged that the child lacked the required standing under N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 2205 to compel an accounting of decedent's estate, in an action to require the administratrix to file such an account.


OVERVIEW: The child was born in 1959. More than 10 years later, a paternity proceeding commenced. The proceeding concluded with the signing of a filiation order in 1969. The decedent died in 1977. The issue was whether the failure to initiate paternity proceedings within the statutory prescribed two-year period from birth pursuant to N.Y. Est. Powers & Trust Law § 4-1.2(a)(2) barred the child from inheriting from her father, notwithstanding the existence of a duly entered order of filiation declaring paternity. The court determined that the failure to institute paternity proceedings within two years of the child's birth did not deprive the child of her right to inherit. The court held that strict adherence to the two-year limitation offended the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and frustrated the original legislative intent to grant to illegitimate children rights of inheritance on a par of those enjoyed by legitimate children. The court found that the child was a person interested in decedent's estate within the meaning of N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 2205, and as such the child could maintain the proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court granted the child's motion to strike the answer of the administratrix and directed that the administratrix file an account.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Descent and Distribution -- Inheritance by Child Born out of Wedlock from Estate of Father -- Time of Commencement of Filiation Proceeding

The former requirement of EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]) that in order for a child born out of wedlock to inherit from his father, filiation proceedings be initiated during the mother's pregnancy or within two years (now 10 years) of the birth of the child, is unconstitutional under the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution; unlike the further requirement of EPTL 4-1.2 that such proceedings be initiated during the father's lifetime, the time limitation for commencement of the proceedings does not further the enunciated legislative purpose of the statute of establishing a valid procedural safeguard against false claims of heirship. Accordingly, petitioner, whose relationship to decedent has been established in a filiation proceeding brought during the lifetime of the father but more than 10 years after the petitioner's birth, is entitled to inherit from decedent, who died in 1977 when the two-year period applied, and to maintain a proceeding to compel an accounting as a person interested [***2] in decedent's estate within the meaning of SCPA 2205.

 

2014 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wright


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


104 Misc. 2d 911; 429 N.Y.S.2d 993; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2422



June 24, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following a conviction for assault in the first degree, the trial court ordered a hearing pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 400.20 to determine whether defendant should be sentenced as a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10.


OVERVIEW: At issue was whether confessions obtained in violation of Miranda of two murders for which defendant was never brought to trial could be considered by the court in a persistent felony offender proceeding under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10 as evidence of defendant's history and character that would warrant extended incarceration. The court found that testimony at the trial was credible beyond a reasonable doubt and defendant's confession was truthful and voluntarily tendered, untainted by coercion, threats or pressure of any kind. Further, exclusion of the confessions would harm the sentencing process under the balancing test of the exclusionary rule. The court concluded that where there was no evidence that an invalid confession was obtained for the purpose of increasing a sentence and where the reliability of the confession was conclusively established according to legal standards, the confession was to be considered as evidence in a sentencing proceeding. Accordingly, the court held that the confessions were admissible and under the facts of the case, defendant was adjudged a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant's confessions were admissible because the confessions were reliable and voluntarily made despite the Miranda violations; further, defendant was adjudged a persistent felony offender and sentenced to life imprisonment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence

1. A finding by one Judge that a defendant had two prior felonies constitutionally obtained is binding on a later Judge under the doctrine of "the law of the case" since it is a pure legal determination; a finding by one Judge that a defendant is a persistent felony offender is not binding on a later Judge where he is to pronounce sentence inasmuch as that determination is purely discretionary on the part of the sentencing court and may not be based on another Judge's decision.

Crimes -- Sentence

2. A defendant is not entitled to have a sentence promise given by a Judge enforced on the ground that it was not kept solely because the People exerted unethical pressure on the court by exposing the defendant's case and background to the media where there is nothing in the record to indicate that the Judge's change of view was dictated by anything other than the extensive testimony before him at a hearing which unearthed material that was not known to the Judge at the time of plea negotiation and justified the change of position.

Crimes -- Exclusionary Rule

3. To determine the applicability of the exclusionary rule to a particular proceeding,  [***2] a balancing test is employed, i.e., whether or not the deterrent effect on unlawful police conduct outweighs the harm caused to the truth-finding process by the exclusion of such evidence.

Crimes -- Sentence

4. A Judge may consider, pursuant to CPL 400.20 (subd 5), a confession obtained from a defendant in violation of his Miranda rights regarding two murders for which he was never brought to trial, for the purpose of determining whether or not defendant should be sentenced as a persistent felony offender, where there is no evidence that the invalid confession was obtained for the purpose of increasing a sentence, where the court is aware of the underlying violation, and where the reliability of the confession is conclusively established according to legal standards.

Crimes -- Sentence

5. A defendant, who has two prior convictions, one for assault and one for rape, should be sentenced as a persistent felony offender where additional evidence clearly shows that the defendant is a dangerous person who cannot be trusted to function normally in society.

 

2015 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pearson v. Pearson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


104 Misc. 2d 904; 429 N.Y.S.2d 851; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2421



June 23, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former wife brought an action pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 170-a seeking a money judgment from defendant former husband in an amount equivalent to one-third of his estate, of which she was deprived by virtue of a judgment of divorce obtained against her by him conversion of a separation agreement pursuant N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 170(5). The husband sought to dismiss on the ground of his changed circumstances.


OVERVIEW: The wife obtained a judgment of separation from the husband on the ground of abandonment, and seven years later he commenced an action for divorce based upon the separation decree. The wife claimed that the divorce deprived her of economic and property rights in an amount equal to a widow's right to an intestate share as provided by N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 170-a(b), and the husband claimed intervening circumstances based upon his later marriage, the fact that he was three years older than when he commenced the divorce, and that the wife did not sell the marital home as instructed. The court found that the proffered intervening circumstances were insufficient; that the wife did not waive rights expressly granted to persons who had a decree, judgment, or agreement entered or obtained prior to January 21, 1970; and that she was entitled to judgment. The court used the calculation of the husband's net worth immediately before the divorce and awarded the wife $ 550,000. The court did not consider whether her alimony should be modified or terminated because its order was not yet implemented, appealed from, or otherwise terminated.


OUTCOME: The court granted the wife an award of a widow's intestate share of the husband's estate as if he had died immediately before the divorce.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Action for Property Rights of Which Spouse Was Deprived by Virtue of Decree

1. Intervening circumstances which would render an award to a divorced wife inequitable have not been proven by the divorcing husband in an action maintained by the wife pursuant to section 170-a of the Domestic Relations Law to obtain an amount equivalent to a widow's rights to an intestate share in the former husband's estate; the former husband's remarriage, that he is now three years older than at the time of the divorce and that the former wife has failed to sell the marital home as directed by court order do not constitute intervening circumstances sufficient to support a defense to the action, pursuant to subdivision b of section 170-a of the Domestic Relations Law.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Action for Property Rights of Which Spouse Was Deprived by Virtue of Decree

2. In an action maintained by a former wife pursuant to section 170-a of the Domestic Relations Law to obtain an amount equivalent to a widow's right to an intestate share in the former husband's estate, the wife did not waive her rights to bring an action pursuant to section 170-a;  [***2] the wife's institution of her action for a separation decree subsequent to approval of the changes in subdivision (5) of section 170 of the Domestic Relations Law which would allow a conversion divorce and her pursuit of the action subsequent to the effective date of the enactment, when she was or should have been aware of the provision allowing a conversion divorce did not cause her to waive her rights to bring an action pursuant to section 170-a since that section was not enacted until 1975, after the separation decree was obtained, and one cannot waive a right which does not exist; the wife is entitled to pursue her remedy since she obtained a decree of separation prior to the date of the decision by the Court of Appeals in Gleason v Gleason, the cutoff date provided in subdivision a of section 170-a of the Domestic Relations Law, and, as the innocent spouse against whom a decree of divorce was obtained, whose marital rights were unexpectedly lost due to the conversion divorce, she has shown the elements of the cause of action required by statute.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Action for Property Rights of Which Spouse Was Deprived Due to Decree

3. In an action [***3] maintained by a former wife pursuant to section 170-a of the Domestic Relations Law to obtain an amount equivalent to a widow's rights to an intestate share in the former husband's estate, the wife is entitled to an amount "calculated as though defendant died intestate and as if the death of defendant had immediately antedated the divorce" (Domestic Relations Law, § 170-a, subd b); since, at the conclusion of defendant's divorce action, the court determined the husband's total net worth, that amount is adopted as the husband's net worth immediately antedating divorce, and the wife is entitled to one third of that amount.

 

2016 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Spadaro


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Sixth District, Suffolk County


104 Misc. 2d 997; 429 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2435



June 23, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged by the State with operating an airpark without a permit in violation of a zoning provision of the Town of Brookhaven, N.Y., Code § 85-277(c)(5). There was a trial and defendant moved to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: One of the grounds upon which defendant urged that the motion be granted was that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. Defendant's argument was that the term airpark was not defined in the town code and was not a word with a definite, ascertainable, and familiar meaning. What that suggests was that airpark was not a word with an accepted meaning long recognized in law and life. In granting the motion to dismiss, the court found that even considering the definition provided in the ordinance, there was some question as to whether "a small airport" was a definition of sufficient precision to give adequate prior warning. The court held that despite the strong presumption as to its validity, the ordinance was one, which failed to give a person of ordinary understanding prior warning of the conduct proscribed. Accordingly, the court held that a conviction for its violation could not be sustained.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Motion to Dismiss

1. Although a motion to dismiss a criminal action should be made in writing and before trial, such a motion on the ground that the statute or ordinance which the defendant is charged with violating is unconstitutionally vague should be considered by the court even if made after trial, particularly where both parties have argued the merits of the motion in their memoranda of law and no objection to the form of the motion has been made.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Unconstitutionally Vague Statute

2. A statute which employs terms having an accepted meaning long recognized in law and life cannot be said to be so vague and indefinite as to afford the defendant insufficient notice of what is prohibited or inadequate guidelines for adjudication.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

3. The enactments of a municipal legislative body are presumed valid; however, this presumption may be rebutted.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Unconstitutionally Vague Statute

4. A motion by defendant to dismiss an action against him charging him with operating an airpark without a permit in violation [***2] of a town zoning provision is granted, since the ordinance is unconstitutionally vague in that it fails to give a person of ordinary understanding prior warning of the conduct proscribed; the word "airpark" is not one with an accepted meaning long recognized in law and life.

 

2017 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Nothdurft v. Ross


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


104 Misc. 2d 898; 429 N.Y.S.2d 844; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2420



June 19, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the plaintiff's cross motion for summary judgment is denied, and the defendant's motion for summary judgment is granted and the court determines and declares that article 20-B of the Labor Law ( §§ 733 through 739 inclusive) is constitutional and does not violate either the Constitution of the United States or the Constitution of the State of New York.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the Industrial Commissioner for the State of New York, moved for summary judgment in an action initiated by plaintiff examiner for a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Lab. Law §§ 733-739 was void and unconstitutional. The examiner cross-moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to §§ 733-739, it was unlawful for an employer to knowingly administer or participate in the administration of psychological stress evaluator examinations of an employee or prospective employee, and no employer could require, request, or permit an employee or prospective employee to submit to such examination. The examiner was a retired military officer and was highly trained in the use of a mechanical device known as the "psychological stress evaluator" (P.S.E.), but he was not a polygrapher. The examiner contended that §§ 733-739 prevented the use of the P.S.E., but did not prohibit the use of the polygraph or other lie detectors, which created an allegedly arbitrary discrimination. Granting the Industrial Commissioner's summary judgment motion, the court found that there was a distinction between a polygraph and a P.S.E. because an individual could only be subjected to a polygraph with his knowledge and consent whereas an individual could be subjected to a P.S.E. without his knowledge and consent. The evaluator failed to meet the strong burden placed on him to overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Industrial Commissioner's motion for summary judgment and declared that the statute was constitutional. The court denied the examiner's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Psychological Stress Evaluators

1. Article 20-B of the Labor Law, which makes it unlawful to knowingly administer or participate in the administration of psychological stress evaluator examinations of an employee or prospective employee, and provides that no employer or agent shall require, request or permit an employee or prospective employee to submit to such examination, or utilize the results of such tests, is constitutional and does not violate the New York or Federal Constitution, since the Legislature is justified in guarding against evils, both real and anticipated, which would affect a large group of citizens by any legislation which reasonably tends to prevent them, even if certain hardships or difficulties may be felt by a certain individual or group [***2] of individuals in the same class; the Legislature may properly attempt to protect an individual's right to privacy on the ground that psychological stress evaluators, which purport to determine the truth or falsity of statements on the basis of vocal fluctuations or vocal stress, grossly invade the privacy of an individual who is subjected to such device, often without his or her knowledge or consent.

Parties -- Standing

2. Plaintiff, an accredited psychological stress evaluator examiner and operator, has standing to challenge the constitutionality of article 20-B of the Labor Law, which makes it unlawful to knowingly administer or participate in the administration of psychological stress evaluator examinations of an employee or prospective employee, and provides that no employer or agent shall require, request or permit an employee or prospective employee to submit to such examination, or utilize the results of such tests; plaintiff need not be prosecuted under the Labor Law in order to challenge the statutes, since a party need no longer be directly regulated or affected by a statute in order to challenge its constitutionality, and a proper plaintiff must only be substantially [***3] affected by a statute so that he has sufficient interest in the outcome of a declaratory judgment action to provide a degree of adversity which will create a justiciable controversy between the parties.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

3. There is a presumption in favor of the constitutionality of a legislative enactment, and a heavy burden of demonstrating unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt rests upon the one who claims it; the validity of a statute is to be determined solely with reference to constitutional restrictions, not by tests of natural equity or justice, and in determining the constitutionality of the statute, the court need not be absolutely certain as to the motive and intent of the Legislature. The constitutionality will be upheld as long as there is some reasonable and possible basis for the legislation.

 

2018 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gurnee v. Aetna Life & Casualty Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


104 Misc. 2d 840; 428 N.Y.S.2d 992; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2410



June 17, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons stated above it is this court's opinion that Kurcsics is not to be given retroactive application and for that reason defendant's motion for an order pursuant to CPLR 3211 dismissing plaintiff's complaint for failure to state a cause of action is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was defendant insurer's motion for an order, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211, that sought to dismiss plaintiff insureds' complaint concerning the retroactive application of an appellate decision that affected their rights to certain benefits.


OVERVIEW: The insureds filed a complaint against the insurer that sought to recover certain benefits, and they sought retroactive application of an appellate decision that affected their rights. The decision had held that a covered person who had sustained a loss earnings in excess of $ 1,000 per month was entitled to recover as first-party benefits of 80 percent of his actual lost earnings up to a maximum of $ 1,000 per month. In response, the insurer filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The court agreed and granted the motion to dismiss. The court considered all the factors for determining whether or not to grant retroactive application, and concluded that retroactive application could not be granted. The court found retroactive application of the decision was not commanded by the legislature, and also found retroactive application would have produced substantial inequitable results.


OUTCOME: The court granted the insurer's motion to dismiss the insureds' complaint concerning the retroactive application of an appellate decision that affected their rights to certain benefits.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Maximum Recovery for Lost Earnings

A decision of the Court of Appeals ( Kurcsics v Merchant Mut. Ins. Co., 49 NY2d 451), holding that a covered person is entitled to recover as first-party no-fault benefits 80% of actual lost earnings up to a maximum recovery of $ 1,000 per month rather than the $ 800 per month mandated by Insurance Department regulations in effect since 1974 (11 NYCRR 65.6 [n] [2] [xi]), should not, as a matter of equity, be applied retroactively since the decision of the Court of Appeals raised a question of first impression concerning the construction of the phrase "first-party benefits" that could not have been clearly foreshadowed and a retroactive application of the decision overruling the Insurance Department's "interpretive regulations" on maximum potential exposure could possibly jeopardize the solvency of some insurers [***2] and thereby ultimately the benefits of other insured individuals; the failure of the Legislature to interfere with the Insurance Department's construction of the Insurance Law indicates its acquiescence and it cannot therefore be said that a retroactive application is not necessary to insure that future claims up to a maximum of $ 1,000 per month are promptly paid and such retroactive application would produce substantial inequitable results since the insurance companies acted in good faith in following the regulations and they could not recover the losses incurred by a retroactive application of the Kurcsics decision in future ratemaking proceedings.

 

2019 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Anonymous


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Westchester County


104 Misc. 2d 985; 429 N.Y.S.2d 987; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2433



June 16, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent father sought to dismiss a petition by petitioners, the aunt and uncle of the child, to adopt the child. The father held that because he had not consented to the adoption as required by law, it could not proceed.


OVERVIEW: The father was notified, as required by N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(3), and he contested the adoption, arguing that he had not consented to the adoption. The court denied the father's motion to dismiss, holding that N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(2)(d) dispensed with the necessity of the consent of any parent or of any other person having custody of the child who had been deprived of civil rights pursuant to the civil rights law and whose civil rights had not been restored. The court held further that N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79(1) suspended all the civil rights of a person sentenced to a sentence of imprisonment in a state correctional institution for an indeterminate term, having a minimum of one day and a maximum of natural life, and in this case, the father was in fact in prison. The court held that because the father had given up his civil rights to contest this matter it would proceed on the best interests of the child standard.


OUTCOME: The court denied the father's motion to dismiss the adoption petition concerning his child.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

1. The provision of section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law which dispenses with the necessity of the consent of a "parent * * * who has been deprived of civil rights pursuant to the Civil Rights Law and whose civil rights have not been restored" for the adoption of the parent's child, in conjunction with subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which suspends all civil rights of a person serving "a sentence of imprisonment in a state correctional institution for * * * an indeterminate term" does not violate the procedural due process rights of the father of a child born out of wedlock, who is presently serving an indeterminate term of imprisonment since subdivision 3 of section 111 of the Domestic Relations Law requires that notice of the proposed adoption be afforded to a parent whose consent is not required, and decisional law has consistently recognized such parent's right to a hearing on the merits of the adoption; although the hearing is not to determine the parent's unfitness but whether the proposed adoption will be in the child's best interests, the parent whose consent is not required may present [***2] information that will aid the court in determining whether adoption will serve the child's best interests, and evidence regarding the relationship between the parent and child is pertinent thereto; therefore, the father's procedural due process rights have been preserved.

Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

2. The provision of section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law which dispenses with the necessity of consent of a "parent * * * who has been deprived of civil rights pursuant to the Civil Rights Law and whose civil rights have not been restored" for the adoption of the parent's child, in conjunction with subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which suspends all civil rights of a person serving "a sentence of imprisonment in a state correctional institution for * * * an indeterminate term" does not deny the father, a convicted felon, of substantive due process in that he is deprived of an unfitness hearing accorded all other classes of parents prior to termination of his parental rights since, by his own acts, the father has created a presumption of unfitness; the State recognizes the primacy of parental rights unless and until convincing [***3] proof has been submitted that they have been eroded by abuse, misconduct or circumstances, and, in enacting section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law, the Legislature has concluded that a convicted felon, falling within the provisions of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, by his own actions, has sufficiently demonstrated the erosion of his parental rights to permit the State to act without his consent.

Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

3. The loss of civil rights of an imprisoned parent provides a constitutionally valid ground for distinction from other parents in the denial of substantive rights; the State is entitled to determine that imprisoned parents should not arbitrarily withhold from their children the benefit of a stable family environment since it is the prerogative of the State to deprive an individual of certain rights to protect and preserve the rights of innocent citizens.

Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Legitimacy of State Interest in Protecting Children

4. The State's interest in providing for the well-being of children born out of wedlock has been recognized as legitimate, and their well-being often requires adoption [***4] into stable families; although the conceded effect of section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law, which allows adoption without the consent of persons whose civil rights have been removed, is to permit abrogation of a fundamental right of a specific class of persons, the result is constitutionally permissible since the statutory classification is reasonable, not arbitrary and bears a fair and substantial relationship to the object of the legislation, so all persons similarly situated are treated alike.

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parent Rights

5. The State may, when balancing the rights of a parent, whose own conduct has created a situation in which he is unable to provide a stable home for his child, against the interests of the child, reasonably choose to accord the parent's refusal to consent different weight than the refusal of parents not suffering the same disability.

Constitutional Law -- Cruel and Unusual Punishment

6. The application of section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law and subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which deny a father convicted of a felony and imprisoned the right to refuse [***5] to consent to his child's adoption does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment since the Constitution does not forbid resolution of the conflict between the interests of the State in promoting public welfare and the interests of a natural parent in retaining custody of his child in favor of public welfare; parental rights must yield to the best interests of the child and consequently public welfare since it is the prerogative of the State to pass laws depriving an individual of certain rights when he acts contrary to the laws and mores of the State.

Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

7. The best interests of the child, who has fundamental rights, are best served by the statutory sanctions which deny the father, imprisoned for a felony, any substantive rights in the adoption proceeding ( Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 2, par [d]).

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

8. A statute has a strong presumption of constitutionality, which may only be rebutted by demonstrating unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt; if any state of facts justifies the statute, it must be upheld and the burden of proving unconstitutionality rests upon [***6] the attacker.

 

2020 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wei Chen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, White Plains


104 Misc. 2d 1057; 430 N.Y.S.2d 469; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2448



June 16, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 160.50, defendant moved for the sealing of the record and return of his fingerprints and photographs after he had been granted an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal (ACD) with respect to charges of menacing and disorderly conduct, pursuant to an agreement with the prosecutor and as provided by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.55.


OVERVIEW: In exchange for receiving the prosecutor's consent to an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal (ACD) on charges of menacing and disorderly conduct, defendant agreed to execute a waiver of various rights, including the sealing of the record and return of fingerprints and photographs, as allowed under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 160.50, and the right to bring a civil action against law enforcement officers connected with his arrest. A few months after the case was dismissed, defendant moved for the sealing of the record and return of his fingerprints and photographs. In denying the motion, the court noted that defendant had expressly waived his right to any such relief in the presence of and with the advice of counsel. The receipt of an ACD, the court ruled, was not a right, but was dependent upon the prosecutor's consent and the prosecutor could permissibly condition his consent on a waiver without violating defendant's rights or constituting prosecutorial vindictiveness. Such agreements between prosecutors and defendants were analogous to informed plea bargaining and were contractually binding on the parties since they were voluntary.


OUTCOME: The motion was denied because defendant had expressly waived his rights to such relief; making such a waiver a prerequisite to obtaining the prosecutor's required consent for an ACD was neither a violation of defendant's rights nor prosecutorial vindictiveness, especially since the agreement and waiver were the product of defendant's conscious, voluntary, and informed decision in the presence of and with the advice of counsel.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal -- Waiver of Statutory Rights

1. A criminal defendant, who, with the consent of the prosecutor and in the presence of and with the advice of his own attorney, knowingly and intelligently executed at two different times two agreements in order to obtain an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal, each containing a waiver of his CPL 160.50 rights to the return of his fingerprints and photographs, and for a sealing of the record in his case, may not thereafter exercise these rights since, where the execution of an agreement relinquishing fundamental statutory rights is conscious, voluntary and informed, and where the defendant fully understands the legal ramifications of his waiver and has the advice and consent of counsel, the waiver is fully binding; while the best practice would be for the court to conduct a voir dire to assure that a defendant is knowledgeable of the legal effect, meaning and contents of a waiver of statutory or constitutional rights before it is executed, this is not a prerequisite to its enforcement.

Crimes -- Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal -- Waiver of Statutory Rights

2. There [***2] is no constitutionally protected right to have one's case adjourned in contemplation of dismissal and eligibility therefor is always conditioned upon the prosecutor's consent; an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal is a negotiated, arm's length agreement and since there is valuable consideration on both sides, the terms thereof should be enforced like any other contract; furthermore, since a defendant can waive all constitutional rights except the right to a speedy trial during the course of plea bargaining, he may also waive any statutory right, such as the right to a return of fingerprints conferred by CPL 160.50, provided the waiver is knowingly and intelligently made and not the product of coercion or prosecutor's vindictiveness.

Crimes -- Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal -- Waiver of Statutory Rights

3. In determining whether a waiver of statutory rights made pursuant to an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal was coerced, hence invalid, the criterion is whether defendant had a choice of whether or not to accept the prosecutor's offer, and only in the most exceptional cases should a court conclude that the prosecutor's bargaining power so outweighed [***3] defendant's so as to invalidate a waiver; although prosecutorial vindictiveness, the prosecution's vindictive increase in the severity of charges presented to a Grand Jury upon reindictment of a defendant who exercised a procedural right, may invalidate a defendant's waiver of a statutory or constitutional right, it does not pertain to plea bargaining where the prosecutor may bring a more serious charge against a defendant who reneged on his plea bargain.

 

2021 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


104 Misc. 2d 888; 429 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2418



June 3, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner guardian filed a proceeding which required respondent commissioner of social services to show cause why the court should not issue an order directing the commissioner pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 255 and N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 398 to reinstate respondent mother's five person welfare budget, and provide supplemental money to cover food costs for her children's home visits.
