OVERVIEW: The mother was a welfare recipient and parent of four minor children. Two of children resided in a child-caring facility after their remand to a psychiatric institute. During this time, the mother's welfare benefits were reduced to that amount allowed for a three person family and apartment, but she was required to maintain the five person apartment in order for the two children to visit on weekends and holidays. The guardian commenced proceedings requiring the commissioner of social services to show cause why the court should not issue an order directing the commissioner to reinstate the mother's five person welfare budget, and provide supplemental money to cover food costs for her children's home visits. The court ordered the reinstatement of the shelter allowance to that for five persons and to provide supplemental moneys for food expenses during the home visits of the two children, holding that the two children were still considered domiciled with the mother although temporarily away. The court concluded that the reduction placed the mother in a difficult situation given she was required to maintain her current apartment so that the children could be reinstated in the home.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the reinstatement of the shelter allowance for the two children of the recipient mother and to provide supplemental moneys for food expenses during the home visits of the two children.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Temporary Foster Care

Respondent, a recipient of public assistance and the mother of four children two of whom are in temporary foster care under a plan including weekend and holiday home visits, whose public assistance rent and food allowances were reduced from those for a five-person household to those for a three-person household based on the fact that two of the children no longer actually resided in the household, is entitled to have her former shelter allowance based upon a five-person household reinstated, and to be provided with supplemental moneys for food expenses during the home visits of the two children in foster care pursuant to section 255 of the Family Court Act, which authorizes a Family Court Judge to order agencies or institutions which have a child under their care to render assistance and co-operation within their legal authority, since regulations of the Department of Social Services provide for continuation of Aid to Dependent Children grants where a member of the family is "temporarily absent" from the household, and such absence includes temporary foster care (18 NYCRR 349.4 [2] [ii] [a]; 369.2 [c]  [***2] [1] [i] [c]; 369.4 [c] [2]), and the family therefore remains a five-person family.

 

2022 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. City School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Steuben County


104 Misc. 2d 796; 429 N.Y.S.2d 355; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2403



June 2, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court grants the plaintiff's application to preliminarily enjoin the defendant from preventing Ysreen Brown from attending school.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff parent filed an application with a trial court (New York) to enjoin defendant school district from preventing his non-immunized child from attending school.


OVERVIEW: The parent sought to enjoin the school district from preventing his child from attending class due to the fact that the child had never received the immunizations required by N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2164. The parent argued that the religious exemption contained in N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2164(9) relieved him of the obligation to obtain the required inoculations for his child. The court held that the parent was entitled to the § 2164(9) exemption because he had shown the court the sincerity of his religious beliefs and established that there was nothing present that represented a clear and present danger of a particular communicable disease. The court granted the parent's application to preliminarily enjoin the school district from preventing the child from attending school.


OUTCOME: The court granted the parent's application to preliminarily enjoin the school district from preventing the child from attending school on the ground that she had not received her inoculations.


HEADNOTES

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. Every legislative enactment carries a strong presumption of constitutionality; courts strike down statutes only as a last resort, and only when unconstitutionality is shown beyond a reasonable doubt.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Exemption from Vaccination Requirement

2. The free exercise of religion is a fundamental right under the Constitution and, therefore, susceptible of restriction only to prevent grave and immediate danger to interests which the State may lawfully protect; accordingly, a parent or guardian who claims that his school-aged child is exempt from the immunization requirements of section 2164 of the Public Health Law under subdivision 9 of that section, which provides that the immunization requirements shall not apply to children whose parents are bona fide members of a recognized religious organization whose teachings are contrary to the practices required by the statute, must satisfy the court as to the sincerity of the religious belief, and there [***2] must be no circumstance which, in the opinion of the public health authorities, represents a clear and present danger of the particular communicable disease.

 

2023 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pelle v. Pelle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Westchester County


104 Misc. 2d 395; 428 N.Y.S.2d 602; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2286



May 28, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner's attorney sought his fees for services rendered in a proceeding for violation of a support order. The attorney sought the fees from respondent former husband.


OVERVIEW: The former wife's attorney sought his fees from the husband for the attorney's work in a proceeding against the husband for violation of a support order. The court found that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 438 was to be read in an expansive fashion so as to permit either spouse to be awarded attorney's fees in an action brought on his/her behalf or on the behalf of the parties' children. The court examined all of the documents concerning the parties' financial conditions and held that the wife was entitled to have the husband pay one-half of her attorney's fees.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the husband pay one-half of his former wife's attorney's fees.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Counsel Fees

Inasmuch as a statutory scheme awarding alimony to wives only has been held unconstitutional as a violation of the equal protection clause ( Orr v Orr, 440 U.S. 268), and it is the duty of courts to construe statutes so as not to conflict with their legislative intent and to preserve their constitutionality, either spouse may properly be awarded counsel fees pursuant to section 438 of the Family Court Act, which provides for the award of counsel fees to the wife in support proceedings; the purpose of the award of counsel fees is to insure that a person claiming a right of support and who is likely to be financially hard pressed can obtain the services of an attorney, and this purpose is served by determination of the issue solely on economic grounds without resort to any gender-based classification.

 

2024 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gager v. White


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


103 Misc. 2d 586; 428 N.Y.S.2d 808; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2146



May 20, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss plaintiff's wrongful death complaint, upon the grounds that the court lacked jurisdiction over defendant.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff decedent's mother brought a wrongful death action against defendant for an automobile accident that occurred in another state. The mother attached defendant's automobile insurance policy, on the ground that his insurance company had an office in the forum state. While the case was pending, the United States Supreme Court held that such a procedure was not valid and defendant moved to dismiss the complaint. The court denied defendant's motion and the court found that to give the Supreme Court's decision retroactive effect would deprive the mother of a forum because the statute of limitations had already run in the other state. The court concluded that as the legislature and the Supreme Court did not specifically provide that this change in procedure was to be retroactively applied, the court would not so interpret the rule. The court held that the change in procedure was not available to an action, which had been pending for almost a year, where retroactivity would obliterate altogether plaintiff's right to pursue the alleged tort.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attachment -- Insurance Policy of Nonresident

A retroactive application of the United States Supreme Court ruling in Rush v Savchuk (444 U.S. 320) is not available to a foreign defendant regarding an out-of-State automobile accident with plaintiff where plaintiff, who had obtained jurisdiction over defendant by the attachment of his automobile insurance policy, would be deprived of a forum due to the expiration of the out-of-State Statute of Limitations; accordingly, a motion by defendant to dismiss the complaint for lack of jurisdiction is denied.

 

2025 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Old Field v. Introne


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


104 Misc. 2d 122; 430 N.Y.S.2d 192; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2288



May 20, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A motion for summary judgment was filed by defendant, the commissioner of the New York Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities, in a proceeding brought by plaintiff village seeking a declaration that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 41.34 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The village challenged the commissioner's decision to locate a community residential facility for retarded adults within its limits, arguing that its zoning ordinances had been disregarded. Pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 41.34, the commissioner held a hearing and thereafter rejected the village's objections. The village contended that § 41.34 was an unconstitutional delegation of power to an administrative agency and denied it due process and equal protection. The court assumed, for the purposes of the commissioner's summary judgment motion, that the village had standing and that the matter was justiciable, and held that the village's claims lacked merit. Section 41.34 was a constitutional expression of the legislature's intent that mentally disabled persons receive care, treatment, and education in community settings when possible and furnished sufficient standards to guide the commissioner's discretion; it also provided for a hearing and judicial review of the commissioner's decision. To the extent that they conflicted with state law, the village's zoning ordinances were void.


OUTCOME: The court granted the commissioner's summary judgment motion, declaring that the statute was constitutional in general and as applied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parties -- Standing -- Justiciability

1. An incorporated village lacks standing to bring an action seeking a declaration that section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which relates to site selection of community residential facilities for mentally retarded and developmentally disabled persons, is an unconstitutional delegation of powers by the Legislature; such an action is not justiciable since it raises questions of broad legislative and administrative policy which are beyond the scope of judicial correction.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute

2. A legislative enactment carries with it a strong presumption of constitutionality and is presumed to be supported by facts known to the Legislature, and this presumption can be overcome only by proof persuasive beyond a reasonable doubt; courts may not concern themselves with the wisdom or expediency of the legislation, nor may courts substitute their judgment for that of the Legislature, rather, it is only as a last resort that courts will strike down a legislative enactment on the ground that it is unconstitutional.

Mental Health -- Community Residence

3. Section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which [***2] provides a mechanism for site selection of community residential facilities for mentally retarded and developmentally disabled persons, expresses the Legislature's intent to meet the needs of the mentally disabled by providing that such persons remain in normal community settings and receive whatever care, treatment, etc., as may be appropriate, defines a "community residential facility for the disabled", sets forth procedures to air community objections and specifies factors to be considered by the commissioner of the office of the department responsible for the issuance of the license and operating certificate to such facility; therefore, said statute more than meets constitutionally accepted standards regarding legislative delegations of power.

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Objections of Municipality

4. Section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which gives a municipality the right to object to a State proposal concerning the location of a community residence facility, meets both the tests of due process and equal protection of the law where it provides for a hearing and judicial review of the decision of the commissioner responsible for selecting the location [***3] of such facilities, and where it is not even suggested that the statute is without rational basis or differentiates in a palpably arbitrary manner.

Statutes -- Local Laws -- Conflict with State Policy

5. The police power of the State should not be limited by local objection and where a local ordinance conflicts with and hinders State public policy, the local ordinance is void since the test is that if the subject is a matter of substantial State concern, the Legislature may act even though there may be countervailing local concerns, and this is predicated upon broad principles of sovereignty which require that a State or one of its agencies be free of local control in performing a governmental function.

 

2026 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Mendes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


104 Misc. 2d 357; 428 N.Y.S.2d 419; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2280



May 15, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner children's home filed a request to transfer custody and guardianship of two of respondent natural mother's children to the children's home pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b.


OVERVIEW: A children's home filed a petition under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b seeking to have the custody and guardianship of two of a natural mother's children transferred to the children's home. The children's home contended that the natural mother manifested serious mental illness and under § 384-b, which stipulated that where a natural parent was mentally ill and would be for the foreseeable future unable to provide proper and adequate care for the children, termination of parental rights was in order. The court denied the petition, holding that the natural mother had consistently and faithfully visited her children, thus termination was inappropriate. Other arrangements such as foster care were in order. The court held that § 384-b violated the constitutional rights of the natural mother by depriving her of her children solely because of her mental illness.


OUTCOME: The court denied the request of the children's home to transfer custody and guardianship of two of the natural mother's children to the home.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights

1. Vague statutes may offend the Constitution in three ways: (1) they may trap the innocent by failing to give a person of ordinary intelligence a reasonable opportunity to know what is prohibited, so that he may act accordingly; (2) they may result in arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement in the absence of explicit guidelines for their application; or (3) they may inhibit constitutionally protected activity. Impossible standards are not required and lack of precision is permissible as long as the prohibited practice is one commonly understood. Accordingly, in a proceeding brought pursuant to section 384-b of the Social Services Law to transfer custody and guardianship of respondent's children to a public agency on the ground that respondent mother, by reason of her mental illness, is presently and for the foreseeable future unable to provide proper and adequate care for said children, the court rejected respondent mother's constitutional attack on the grounds of vagueness: the statutory requirement that parental inability to meet the child's essential needs must be affirmatively demonstrated negates respondent's notice [***2] argument; the statute does not prohibit any constitutionally protected activity, although fundamental constitutional rights are involved; and, in the instant case, the court found that respondent is in fact mentally ill and will be for the remaining childhood of her children, thus defining the "foreseeable future" with sufficient definiteness on the facts; the parties stipulated to a dispositional hearing, thus avoiding the automatic and arbitrary granting of guardianship and custody to petitioner agency as required by the statute.

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights

2. The strict scrutiny test of review applies to section 384-b of the Social Services Law, which provides for transfer of guardianship and custody of children to an authorized agency, permanently terminating the rights of parents whose consent to the adoption of the child would otherwise be required, but who are presently and for the foreseeable future unable, by reason of mental illness or mental retardation, to provide proper and adequate charge for a child who has been in the care of an authorized agency for the period of one year immediately prior to the initiation of the proceeding, by reason [***3] of the statute's infringement on the fundamental rights of parents; the strict scrutiny test requires, in addition to the State's substantial interest in providing for the placement of foster children in a permanent stable home, that the statute be so narrowly drawn that there appears to be no other reasonable alternative for achieving the legitimate goal which has a less severe impact on the fundamental rights involved. Accordingly, since section 384-b of the Social Services Law exceeds valid and necessary State interests, inasmuch as the time period in which the parent is unable to provide for the child, the "foreseeable future", is the period in which the State has a valid interest in intervening and in which parental rights may validly be superseded, where respondent mother is unable to care for her children because of mental illness, a petition under section 384-b to commit guardianship and custody of her children to petitioner agency and to permanently terminate her parental rights is denied and foster care placement of the children is extended one year.

 

2027 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cunningham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


104 Misc. 2d 298; 428 N.Y.S.2d 183; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2270



May 13, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(h), petitioner sought to vacate the judgment of the Supreme Court of Bronx County (New York), which convicted him of murder and possession of a weapon.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner accused was convicted of murder and possession of a weapon. After petitioner's direct appeal was decided, petitioner sought to vacate the judgment under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(h) and alleged that jury instructions on intent were erroneous because similar jury instructions were found unconstitutional. The jury instructions stated that the law presumed that a person intended the natural consequences of the person's acts and that a person was presumed to intend the person's acts. The court denied petitioner's motion and held that petitioner was required, and had failed, to raise the issue on direct appeal. The denial of petitioner's motion was mandated by § 440.10, because the jury instructions were on the record, the propriety of the instructions was reviewable on direct appeal, and petitioner failed to raise the issue on direct appeal. Petitioner's failure to raise the issue was not justified based on subsequent court rulings concerning the unconstitutionality of the instructions, because the issue was not previously raised and determined in petitioner's case. The court also found that the jury instructions did not create impermissible inferences.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's motion to vacate the judgment and held that petitioner failed to raise the issue of improper jury instructions on direct appeal of petitioner's convictions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Motion to Vacate Judgment -- Unconstitutional Jury Charge on Element of Intent

Petitioner cannot collaterally attack his judgment of conviction by post-judgment motion ( CPL 440.10, subd 1, par [h]) because of an alleged unconstitutional jury charge as to the element of intent, the United States Supreme Court having held subsequent to petitioner's conviction that a jury instruction on the element of intent that "the law presumes that a person intends the ordinary consequences of his voluntary acts" violates the constitutional requirement that the State prove every element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt (see Sandstrom v Montana, 442 U.S. 510), since the claimed constitutional error was apparent on the face of the record and was not challenged by petitioner at trial or on direct appeal and a collateral attack on a judgment is allowed only when a direct appeal is foreclosed because the issue was not presented by the record and cannot be used as a vehicle for an additional appeal or as a substitute for a direct appeal even where the asserted error is of constitutional magnitude; even assuming that Sandstrom constitutes a retroactively effective change [***2] in constitutional law, petitioner is not entitled to relief since a motion to vacate a judgment must be denied where a defendant could have but did not raise an issue on direct appeal, despite a subsequent retroactively effective change in the law controlling that issue; in any event, Sandstrom did not create a substantive change in New York law which has long recognized that such a jury instruction improperly removes from the jury the choice of drawing an inference of intent from the act or rejecting such an inference, and, thus, the claimed error could have been litigated under the law as it existed prior to Sandstrom and his failure to raise the issue on direct appeal was unjustified.

 

2028 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Guardianship of N.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Dutchess County


104 Misc. 2d 263; 428 N.Y.S.2d 178; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2314



May 13, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner county social services department filed petitions under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b against respondent parents seeking the custody and guardianship of two children and the termination of parental rights, and the natural father alleged that the statute violated equal protection.


OVERVIEW: Two children were abandoned by their presumptive father and their mother executed a surrender indicating her consent to adoption. When the county social services department sought to terminate parental rights, the alleged natural father claimed that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384 denied him due process and equal protection by permitting adoption on the mother's consent only. The evidence indicated that the natural father had been involved with the children, but under § 384 he was only entitled to present evidence concerning their best interests. The court found that the natural father was the parent of the two children and held that § 384 violated the Equal Protection Clause to the extent that it permitted the adoption of out-of-wedlock children on the mother's consent alone. The rights accorded a natural father under § 384 mirrored those contained in N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111, which the United States Supreme Court had declared violative of equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court held that the statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Adoption of Out-of-Wedlock Child -- Rights of Unwed Father

Sections 384, 384-b and 384-c of the Social Services Law are unconstitutional, being violative of due process and equal protection, to the extent that they permit the adoption of an out-of-wedlock child upon the surrender of the mother alone and permit the termination of parental rights in a proceeding which significantly differentiates between the rights accorded an unwed mother and an unwed father and severely limit the ability of the unwed father to present evidence at such a proceeding, the unwed father being only entitled to notice of the proceeding and an opportunity to present evidence at the dispositional hearing with respect to the best interests of the child while the parental rights of the unwed mother can only be terminated upon proof of one of the statutorily enumerated grounds; the United States Supreme Court has invalidated section 111 (subd 1, par [c]) of the Domestic Relations Law which permitted the adoption of a child born out of wedlock without the consent of the natural father while requiring such consent from the mother (see Caban v Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380) and there is no significant [***2] difference between the rights which are terminated by an unwed mother who consents to an adoption pursuant to the invalidated statute and the rights which are terminated by an unwed mother who assigns to a social services agency her right to consent to an adoption, the result in each case being identical in that the child is freed for adoption without the consent of the unwed father; in the context of the Caban holding, notice without opportunity to be heard on all relevant issues denies due process and renders such notice illusory.

 

2029 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pierre v. Williams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Kings County


106 Misc. 2d 81; 431 N.Y.S.2d 249; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2641



May 9, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the court grants that branch of respondent's motion for leave to proceed as a poor person, but denies that branch of the motion which seeks leave to file a jury demand.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord instituted a nonpayment action against respondent tenant to recover rent arrears. Respondent's amended answer asserted breach of warranty of habitability and counterclaimed for damages to her apartment as a result of petitioner's failure to make repairs. Respondent filed a motion to proceed as a poor person and to serve a jury demand nunc pro tunc. Petitioner objected to her motion, asserting a jury waiver clause in the lease.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner landlord sought past due rent from respondent tenant, whose counterclaim asserted breach of the warranty of habitability and claimed damages for failure to make repairs. Respondent filed a motion for leave to proceed as a poor person and to request a jury trial. Petitioner asserted that the lease included a jury waiver clause, which continued in effect after the lease expired because respondent remained in possession as a month-to-month tenant under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 232-c. She countered that the premises were subject to the rent stabilization law, while the petitioner cited cases decided under the rent control law. Further, she claimed that petitioner failed to offer her a renewal lease as required by law, although she had continued paying rent. The court agreed with petitioner that nothing in the rent stabilization law barred the projection of terms of a prior expired lease into the subsequent holdover tenancy, and that the jury waiver clause could be invoked against respondent. Her argument that the jury waiver clause was unduly broad and hence unenforceable was rejected. Her motion to proceed as a poor person was granted, but leave was denied for a jury trial.


OUTCOME: The court granted that part of respondent tenant's motion seeking leave to proceed as a poor person, but denied that branch of her motion seeking leave to serve a jury demand nunc pro tunc. The court agreed with petitioner landlord that respondent had agreed to waive her right to a jury trial in the lease, and that petitioner could lawfully invoke the waiver regarding a counterclaim for breach of the warranty of habitability.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Summary Proceeding -- Waiver of Jury Trial in Expired Lease

1. A month-to-month tenant who is the respondent in a summary proceeding is not entitled to a jury trial since the expired lease contained a jury trial waiver clause and the Conciliation and Appeals Board, in implementing the rent stabilization law, has treated month-to-month tenancies created by the landlord's failure to tender a lease renewal as creating a lease identical with the exception of increased rent to the one which expired, retroactive to the expiration date of the original lease; therefore, the terms and conditions of the expired lease survive when the tenant continues to pay the rent set forth in the expired lease and the jury waiver clause, freely agreed to by the tenant, is enforceable.

Landlord and Tenant -- Lease -- Waiver Clause in Expired Lease

2. A jury waiver clause in an expired lease, the provisions of which are continued due to the tenant's month-to-month tenancy is clear,  [***2] legible and printed in accordance with the CPLR, and is therefore enforceable.

Landlord and Tenant -- Warranty of Habitability -- Waiver of Jury Trial

3. A jury waiver clause in a lease may be invoked regarding a tenant's counterclaim in a summary proceeding for breach of the warranty of habitability since section 235-b of the Real Property Law does not specifically prohibit the implementation of jury waiver provisions in trials involving warranty of habitability claims; although the statute prohibits waiver of the right to bring an action for breach of the warranty, it does not negate the fact that the warranty arises out of and by reason of the leasehold and the jury waiver is valid as against all claims arising out of the leasehold.

Landlord and Tenant -- Lease -- Jury Waiver Clause

4. A jury waiver clause in a lease, although very broad, and unenforceable against personal injury or property damage claims (Real Property Law, § 259-c) is enforceable in a summary proceeding, since the all-inclusive element of the clause does not render it void in its entirety.

 

2030 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


R.M. Investors Corp. v. Maggi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Trial and Special Term, Rockland County


104 Misc. 2d 41; 427 N.Y.S.2d 919; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2390



May 5, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff investors corporation (corporation) motioned for summary judgment in its action to quiet title to real property. Defendant property owner cross-motioned for summary judgment and sought an order setting aside the deed to the corporation. The property owner also filed a third-party action against the county to quiet title to the property.


OVERVIEW: The corporation claimed title pursuant to a tax deed issued to it by the county treasurer. The property owner filed a third-party action against the county under N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law § 14, seeking redemption of the deed issued to the corporation. The property owner claimed title to the property as the sole survivor of his mother, who had acquired title to the property pursuant to the last will of her husband, the original owner. The property was at all times listed in the county assessment rolls in the name of the original owner. A public auction of the property was conducted due to unpaid taxes, pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 1018. The court held that statutes and ordinances relating to the sale of property for delinquent taxes must be construed narrowly. In the instant case, strict compliance with N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 1018 was lacking. Specifically, the court held that the property owner presented material issues of fact regarding violations of the notice and filing requirements in N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law §§ 1002, 1110, 1014, 1018, 1020. The court also held that the enabling county resolution was unconstitutionally arbitrary and violated due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court denied the corporation's motion for summary judgment and granted property owner's motion for summary judgment. The court revested title to the property in the county and held that title to the property could be determined in the property owner's third-party action against the county.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Redemption

1. A tax deed issued by Rockland County to plaintiff corporation following a public auction conducted on March 13, 1979 is set aside and title shall revest in the county subject to any jurisdictional defects which can be proven by defendant, the alleged equitable owner of the property whose offer of redemption was rejected by the county legislature after the public auction, since, although the county purchased tax lien certificates for the property for unpaid taxes at annual tax sales for the years 1974-1978 and could have acquired the property by deed from the County Treasurer and sold the property for delinquent taxes at any time after one year from the date of the original tax sale to the county in 1974, the tax deed to the property was not actually issued to the county until March 30, 1979 because of the county's five-year moratorium on the sale of property purchased for delinquent taxes and, thus, the County Treasurer acted in excess of his authority in auctioning property to which the county had not yet acquired title (Real Property Tax Law, § 1018); a 1978 resolution of the county legislature authorizing [***2] the County Treasurer to dispose of property acquired for nonpayment of taxes does not provide a legal basis for the sale of the property since the resolution applies only to property already owned by the county at the date the resolution was enacted and does not operate prospectively; there must be strict compliance with all statutory requirements relating to the sale of property for delinquent taxes and such strict compliance was lacking in this case.

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Presumption of Regularity of Proceedings

2. A tax deed issued by Rockland County to plaintiff corporation following a public auction must be set aside since plaintiff had not yet filed its certificate of incorporation at the time of the auction and was therefore incapable under the law of placing a bid at the auction (General Corporation Law, § 8); title shall revest in the county subject to any jurisdictional defects which can be proven by defendant, the alleged equitable owner of the property who has two years to rebut the presumption of regularity of the proceedings leading to the issuance of the tax deed to the county on March 30, 1979 (Real Property Tax Law, § 1020).

 [***3] Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Standards Governing Tax Sale Procedures

3. A resolution of the county legislature rejecting defendant's offer to redeem his property following a tax sale, such resolution being administrative rather than legislative in nature, is unconstitutionally arbitrary and unreasonable and, thus, violative of defendant's due process rights since due process demands that the county legislature, in exercising its discretionary administrative functions, relate each individual case to articulated standards and state its reasons and findings as far as is feasible; although the statutory period for redemption as of right had expired, once the county agreed to extend the redemption period by imposing a five-year moratorium on tax foreclosure proceedings and agreed to consider defendant's offer of redemption after a bid had been placed and accepted at the public auction, it could not then reject defendant's offer in an arbitrary and unreasonable manner; in accordance with the requirements of due process of law, the county legislature is directed to establish meaningful standards and procedures governing the disposition of property acquired by the [***4] county for nonpayment of delinquent taxes.

 

2031 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Attorney-General of New York v. Katz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


104 Misc. 2d 846; 428 N.Y.S.2d 982; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2411



April 29, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent sellers filed a motion to vacate an order of injunction, which enjoined the sellers from various activities under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 352-e, including further selling of co-operative ownership interest in a certain building and transferring title or interest therein. Petitioner attorney general had filed a motion seeking an ex parte order of injunction, and the buyers had filed a motion for leave to intervene.


OVERVIEW: The sellers submitted a plan to convert a certain building to co-operative ownership. The attorney general accepted the plan for filing on the sellers' representation that it did not contain an excessive number of "long-term" vacancies under § 352-eeee(3)(a), which prohibited "warehousing" in avoiding evictions of tenants. After further investigation revealed certain misrepresentations as to the "long-term" vacancy-requirement, the attorney general obtained an ex parte order of injunction under the Martin Act, enjoining the sellers from further sales of co-operative interest and transferring title or interest in the premises. The sellers sought to vacate the order, and the buyers sought leave to intervene. The court denied the motions and held that: (1) the mere fact that § 352-eeee(3)(a) operated upon events after its enactment even though antecedents of such events preceded the enactment did not render it unconstitutional, and the plan was already on file when it was enacted; (2) during an investigation, the attorney general had discretion to decide upon the remedies which he wished to employ; and (3) intervention was inappropriate because no plenary action had been filed.


OUTCOME: The court denied the seller's motion to vacate the injunction order, which had enjoined the sellers from further sales of co-operative interest and transferring title or interest in the premises. The court denied the buyers' motion for leave to intervene, in the attorney general's injunctive relief action against the sellers.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Conversion of Rental Premises into Co-operative -- "Excessive" Long-Term Vacany Rate

The fact that the statutory provisions prohibiting the conversion of rental premises into co-operative units if the building contains an "excessive" long-term vacancy rate in excess of 10% (General Business Law, § 352-eeee, subd 3, par [a]) applies retroactively to conversion plans filed with the Attorney-General but not yet declared effective, the purpose of the statute being to prohibit landlords from converting premises where they have engaged in the "warehousing" of vacant apartments in order to lower the number of purchasers required to obtain the necessary percentage to declare the co-operative plan effective, does not render the statute unconstitutional; vested property rights are not being destroyed, rather, the statute merely conditions the privilege of converting premises from rental status to co-operative ownership upon the proper performance by the sponsor of the obligations fixed by the Legislature with respect to vacant apartments; accordingly, in light of the "excessive" long-term vacancies and other allegations of fraudulent representations on the part [***2] of the sponsors, respondents are enjoined from further sales of co-operative interests pending the Attorney-General's investigation and since the present proceeding is purely one seeking disclosure in the course of an investigation, intervention in the proceeding by the tenants is inappropriate.

 

2032 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


CC&F Buffalo Development Co. v. Tully


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


103 Misc. 2d 1060; 427 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2254



April 25, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff mortgagor sought a ruling on his motion for summary judgment in his suit against defendants, a county clerk and the New York State Tax Commission, in his suit for declaratory and injunctive relief seeking interest on mortgage tax levied under N.Y. Tax Law § 253, and paid under protest.


OVERVIEW: The mortgagor entered into a building loan mortgage with a national bank. The county clerk refused to record the mortgage until the mortgagor paid mortgage tax in the amount of $ 200,000 pursuant to § 253. The mortgagor applied to the Commission for review of the tax levy, but the Commission did not issue its decision in favor of the mortgagor until eight years later. When the Commission refused to pay interest on the mortgagor's refund, he filed a suit for declaratory and injunctive relief against the Commission and the clerk. The clerk filed a cross-claim against the Commission for indemnity. The court granted the mortgagor's motion for summary judgment, holding that the facts presented a situation so offensive to one's sense of justice that interest on the refund had to be awarded in order to ameliorate that injustice. The court held that the Commission made no explanation for its eight-year delay in making a decision, and such a delay was unconscionable. The court dismissed the clerk's action, holding that it should have been filed in the New York Court of Claims pursuant to N.Y. Ct. Cl. Act § 9.


OUTCOME: The court granted the mortgagor's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- Mortgage Recording Tax -- Interest on Refund

1. Interest at the rate of 3% per annum (General Municipal Law, § 3-a, subd 1) is payable by the County of Erie on a refund of a mortgage recording tax (Tax Law, § 253) which was determined by the State Tax Commission eight years after application for review to be a tax upon a national bank which the State was without power to levy; the fact that the statute was found to have been levied unconstitutionally as opposed to being unconstitutional per se does not make the case one of erroneous collection, where no interest would be payable. Moreover, the facts present a situation so offensive to one's sense of justice that interest on the refund must be awarded to ameliorate the injustice.

State -- Court of Claims

2. A claim over against the State Tax Commission for indemnification in an action for interest on a refund of a mortgage recording tax levied unconstitutionally seeks money damages against the State and, therefore, must be brought in the Court of Claims. (Court of Claims Act, § 9.)

 

2033 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wise


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


104 Misc. 2d 77; 427 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2395



April 25, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss based on Sandstrom (supra) is therefore denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved, pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. 440, for an order setting aside his conviction and either dismissing the indictment or granting him a new trial on the grounds that his constitutional rights were violated because a statement he made during an improper custodial interrogation was admitted at trial, and the jury was improperly instructed regarding a presumption of wrongful intent on the part of defendant.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of felony murder. On appeal, the conviction was set aside, and a new trial was granted. On further appeal, that decision was reversed, and case was remitted. Defendant moved to set aside the conviction and for either dismissal of the indictment or for a new trial. Defendant claimed his constitutional rights were violated when the court admitted a statement he made during an illegal custodial interrogation, and the court improperly instructed the jury that a person is presumed to intend the natural consequences of his act. Defendant claimed he was entitled to relief because changes in the relevant law operated retroactively. The motion was denied because the police acted within the limits of the law in effect when the appellate decision was made, and changes in the law did not operate retroactively. Further, the jury instruction was not improper because, when charge was considered as a whole, the jury could accept or reject the presumption. The charge was, therefore, not unconstitutional because the burden was not shifted to defendant, and the prosecution was still required to prove all elements of the crime.


OUTCOME: The motion was denied because defendant was not deprived of his constitutional rights by the admission of a statement that he made during a custodial interrogation because the police acted within law in effect at the time; and a jury instruction including a statement regarding the presumption of wrongful intent was proper.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Confession -- Custodial Interrogation

1. Where a major purpose of a new constitutional doctrine is to overcome an aspect of the criminal trial that substantially impairs its truth-finding function and so raises serious questions about the accuracy of guilty verdicts in the past, the doctrine has often been applied retroactively; however, with regard to the retroactivity of the exclusionary rule, judicial integrity is not offended if law enforcement officials reasonably believed in good faith that their conduct was in accord with the law even if subsequent decisions have held that conduct of the type engaged in by the law enforcement officials is not permitted by the Constitution. Accordingly, where defendant claimed that at his trial testimony was admitted as to a statement allegedly made by him during a period of illegal custodial interrogation, and the Court of Appeals, in determining this issue adversely to the defendant, found that the police conduct in taking defendant into custody was within the prescribed limits of People v Morales (42 NY2d 129), which was the law at that time,  [***2] defendant may not have his conviction set aside on the ground that Dunaway v New York (442 U.S. 200), which was decided after the Court of Appeals decision in defendant's appeal, and which reversed Morales holding unconstitutional custodial interrogation with less than probable cause (except in certain circumstances), is retroactive; Dunaway is not retroactive, since its holding does not go to the fairness of a trial, and defendant is not entitled to the benefit of Dunaway for at the time of the Court of Appeals decision it was not the law.

Crimes -- Instructions -- Burden of Proof

2. A motion to set aside defendant's conviction on the ground that the jury was instructed that "a person is presumed to intend the natural consequences of his act" thereby unconstitutionally shifting the burden of proof to defendant in violation of Sandstrom v Montana (442 U.S. 510), which was decided after the Court of Appeals reinstated defendant's conviction following the grant of a new trial by the Appellate Division, and which held that a jury instruction that the law presumes that a person intends the ordinary consequences of his voluntary acts violates the requirement [***3] that the State prove every element of a criminal offense beyond a reasonable doubt, is denied; a charge must be read in its entirety, and where the charge read as a whole demonstrates to the jury the permissive nature of the inference, the burden of proof is not shifted.

 

2034 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cornish


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


104 Misc. 2d 72; 427 N.Y.S.2d 564; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2394



April 23, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss his indictment for criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 265.02. Defendant argued that this statute was unconstitutionally vague, denied him equal protection of the law, and violated his constitutional right to due process in that it failed to provide an opportunity to contest the constitutionality of his previous conviction.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 265.02, and charged with possession as a felony rather than as a misdemeanor because of a prior conviction. Defendant moved to dismiss the indictment. The court held that § 265.02 was not unconstitutionally vague. The statute gave a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that since he had previously been convicted of any crime, to possess a weapon was a felony. The phrase "any crime" was clear and unambiguous and was not modified by any phrase. The phrase meant any crime and needed no judicial interpretation. In addition, the statute did not deny defendant equal protection. The New York Legislature could rationally conclude that a person who had been convicted of "any crime" should be prohibited from possessing a gun. Nor did the fact that the conviction of a crime raised the punishment violate equal protection. Lastly, since N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10 provided defendant with a forum in which to challenge a prior conviction as unconstitutional before he obtained a firearm, the firearms prosecution did not open the predicate conviction to a new form of attack.


OUTCOME: Defendant's indictment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. Courts of original jurisdiction should not set aside a statute as unconstitutional unless that conclusion is inescapable; there is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted by the Legislature is constitutional, and in order to declare a law unconstitutional, the invalidity of the law must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt.

Constitutional Law -- Due Process of Law -- Vagueness Doctrine

2. Due process prohibits the States from holding an individual criminally responsible for conduct which he could not reasonably understand to be proscribed, and a statute is unconstitutionally vague if it fails to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that his contemplated conduct is forbidden by statute; the quest for definiteness does not preclude the Legislature from using ordinary terms to express ideas that find adequate interpretation in everyday usage and understanding, and a court may only consider a vagueness challenge on the facts of the case before it.

Crimes -- Criminal Possession of Weapon -- Vagueness Doctrine

3. Subdivision (1) of section 265.02 of the Penal Law, which provides that [***2] a person is guilty of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a felony, when he commits the crime of criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree and has been previously convicted of any crime, is not unconstitutionally vague, since defendant, allegedly having been convicted in 1967 of criminal possession of policy slips, knew that he had been convicted of "any crime"; the phrase is clear and unambiguous and needs no judicial interpretation.

Crimes -- Criminal Possession of Weapon -- Equal Protection of Laws

4. Subdivision (1) of section 265.02 of the Penal Law, which provides that a person is guilty of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a felony, when he commits the crime of criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree and has been previously convicted of any crime, is not a denial of equal protection of law, since the Legislature could rationally conclude that a person who has been convicted of any crime should be prohibited from possessing a weapon, and the fact that the conviction of a crime raises the punishment is not a violation of equal protection.

Crimes -- Possession of Weapon -- Challenge of Previous Conviction

 [***3] 5. The fact that subdivision (1) of section 265.02 of the Penal Law, which provides that a person is guilty of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a felony, when he commits the crime of criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree and has been previously convicted of any crime, does not provide a method for challenging the constitutionality of the previous conviction does not render the statute unconstitutional; CPL 440.10 provides a defendant with a forum under which he may obtain relief from a prior unconstitutionally obtained conviction.

 

2035 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beckford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


102 Misc. 2d 963; 427 N.Y.S.2d 908; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2045



April 18, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted for murder and robbery. A pretrial suppression hearing was held and the judge ruled that defendant's statement to the police at the time of his arrest was admissible. The day before the officer was to testify the United States Supreme Court rendered a decision on the admission of such statements. Defendant immediately renewed his motion to suppress on the grounds that his statement was the fruit of an unlawful arrest.


OVERVIEW: At about 3:00 a.m. four officers went to the apartment where a codefendant had indicated defendant might be. When the person answering the door stated he was the person they were looking for, the officers arrested him. A detective then advised defendant of his rights, whereupon defendant explicitly waived all the rights and voluntarily made a brief exculpatory statement, denying any involvement in the murder. The state sought to offer the statement on rebuttal due to a material contradiction between defendant's statement and the testimony of two witnesses called by defendant, who did not testify in his own behalf. The court found that the police had probable cause to arrest defendant at approximately midnight when the codefendant pointed out the location of the apartment, and that the police had sufficient opportunity to obtain or attempt to obtain an arrest warrant between midnight and 3:00 a.m. It further found that a warrantless arrest was made in good faith reliance on New York law as it was on the date of the arrest. The court held that the time-of-search approach applied; thus the law of the new case did not apply and the admission of the statement was proper.


OUTCOME: The renewed motion to suppress was denied in defendant's trial for murder and robbery.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Arrest -- Warrantless Home Arrest -- Time-of-Search Approach to Retroactivity

1. In general, every case must be decided upon the decisional law that exists when the case is before the court, not necessarily as of the time of the events in controversy except for constitutional decisions which create new procedural safeguards for criminal defendants, overturning past law enforcement practices which had been permitted by prior decisional or statutory law such as the case of Payton v New York (445 U.S. 573) which specifically superseded the law of New York by invalidating warrantless, nonexigent, nonconsensual entry into a defendant's residence to make an arrest ( CPL 140.15, subd 4); however, in such a search and seizure case, the time-of-search approach to retroactivity applies so that the benefits of new constitutional rules apply only to cases in which the constitutional event occurred after the new decision since, in any case involving the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule, law enforcement officers who conform their conduct to the prevailing statutory or constitutional norm cannot be regarded as blameworthy, and, accordingly, since defendant's warrantless arrest [***2] at his residence based upon a codefendant's statements occurred prior to the Payton case and was therefore valid when made, his subsequent statement is admissible and should not be suppressed as the "fruits" of an unlawful arrest.

Crimes -- Arrest -- Warrantless Home Arrest

2. The prosecutor's offer of the statement made by defendant following his warrantless arrest at his residence only as rebuttal of defendant's case does not obviate the necessity of inquiry into its admissibility since defendant did not testify and the rule permitting impeachment use of suppressible evidence applies only where the defendant personally testifies in his own behalf; the rule enunciated in Payton v New York (445 U.S. 573), invalidating warrantless, nonexigent, nonconsensual entry into a defendant's home to make an arrest ( CPL 140.15, subd 4), would apply to the gunpoint seizure of a defendant on the threshold of his apartment in his doorway but such rule is inapplicable herein since defendant's arrest occurred prior to the date of the decision in Payton; however, if Payton had been applicable, the admissibility of defendant's statement would be doubtful since the People failed [***3] in their burden of justifying the warrantless home arrest in view of the intentional three-hour delay in arresting defendant during which time various officers were available to seek an arrest warrant.

 

2036 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nelson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Syracuse


103 Misc. 2d 847; 427 N.Y.S.2d 194; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2205



April 17, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants in two separate, consolidated cases made omnibus motions and moved in part to dismiss the accusatory instrument charging defendants with prostitution and in the alternative, for an evidentiary hearing on the constitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law art. 230, and for discovery and inspection of statistical data.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged N.Y. Penal Law §§ 230.00-.03, alleging an Equal Protection violation in enforcement by the government. The statutes made no distinction between gender or solicitation, but limited analysis to a seller, § 230.00, and a buyer, § 230.02. Thus, it was reasonable to combine both in the category of "others similarly situated." Defendants failed to carry their burden of proof. Defendants failed to show conscious, intentional discrimination on the part of the government. Therefore, the motion to dismiss was premature. Defendants' motion for an evidentiary hearing was premature because there was no evidence of a reasonable probability of success on the merits. Discrimination was not a valid defense. Therefore, the court treated the discovery motion as a motion for dismissal or to quash. Defendants' motion for discovery failed because statistics were not discoverable under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 240.201 and 240.40, and that information did not address the guilt or innocence of the defendants.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss, for an evidentiary hearing, and for discovery because defendants failed to carry their burdens of proof and the motions were premature. The motions were denied without prejudice, allowing defendants to obtain the statistical information through appropriate channels and to then renew their motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Prostitution -- Discriminatory Enforcement of Law

1. In order to establish that a law, valid on its face, is unconstitutionally enforced in a discriminatory manner, one must show not only that the law is selectively enforced, but also that the selective enforcement is deliberately based upon an impermissible standard, which discriminatory intent may be proved by a convincing showing of a grossly disproportionate incidence of nonenforcement against others similarly situated; if a defendant can establish that conscious, intentional discrimination exists in the enforcement of the criminal statute under which he or she is charged, then the defendant is entitled to a dismissal of the prosecution as a matter of law, but the defendant's burden of proof is heavy, partly because there is a presumption that the enforcement of the laws is undertaken in good faith and also because the authorities must be allowed latitude in making law enforcement decisions. Accordingly, although it is reasonable to combine the prostitute and the patron in the category of "similarly situated" persons, the court denied, as premature, defendants' motion for an order dismissing the accusatory instruments [***2] against them charging prostitution where they did not present sufficient evidence to prove their claim that the District Attorney or the city police consciously, intentionally discriminate in enforcing the law proscribing prostitution offenses (Penal Law, art 230) by routinely enforcing section 230.00 of the Penal Law against female prostitutes while they do not enforce section 230.03 against their male patrons.

Crimes -- Discriminatory Enforcement of Law -- Evidentiary Hearing

2. Where defendants have not presented sufficient evidence to demonstrate a reasonable probability of success on the merits of their claim that the prostitution law under which they are charged (Penal Law, art 230) is unconstitutionally enforced by the District Attorney and city police, who allegedly routinely enforce section 230.00 of the Penal Law against female prostitutes, while they do not enforce section 230.03 against their male patrons, the court denied as premature defendants' motion for an order granting an evidentiary hearing, without prejudice.

Crimes -- Discovery

3. Defendants' request for disclosure and inspection of statistical data relating to the arrest and prosecution [***3] of persons for prostitution-related offenses, for the purpose of establishing their claim that the law under which they are charged (Penal Law, art 230) is unconstitutionally enforced by the District Attorney and city police, who allegedly routinely enforce section 230.00 of the Penal Law against female prostitutes while they do not enforce section 230.03 against their male patrons, is denied since it does not fit under the categories of discoverable material described in CPL 240.20 and 240.40, is not discoverable on the authority of Brady v Maryland (373 U.S. 83), as it does not address the guilt or innocence of the defendants, and, moreover, the claim of discriminatory enforcement should not be treated as a defense to the criminal charge, but as an application to the court for a dismissal or quashing of the prosecution upon constitutional grounds; however, if defendants should seek and obtain the data under the Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law, art 6, §§ 85-90), the court will allow them to renew their motions for an evidentiary hearing and for dismissal of the accusatory instruments, if they should then decide that such motions would be appropriate.

 

2037 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Boots


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Franklin County


106 Misc. 2d 522; 434 N.Y.S.2d 850; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2784



April 9, 1980 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] On Reargument, October 20, 1980.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, and in light of all the foregoing, it is hereby ordered that the defendant's motion for renewal, reargument, factual hearing, and reconsideration be and the same hereby is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion for renewal, reargument, factual hearing, and reconsideration that challenged their convictions.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were Mohawk Indians. Defendants contended that New York courts lacked jurisdiction over Mohawk Indians, that the charges against them were the result of selective prosecution, and that the charges were not supported by sufficient evidence. The court held that 25 U.S.C.S. § 232 was a valid surrender of federal criminal jurisdiction over Indians within the borders of New York. The court also held that the Treaty with the Seven Nations of Canada, 1796, not the Canandaigua Treaty of 1794, was the determinative of defendants' rights as residents of the St. Regis Reservation. According to the court, the St. Regis Reservation was not a sovereign territory of the Mohawk nation because the Mohawks physically abandoned New York. The court also held that the court followed the correct dispute resolution procedure. The court determined that no factual hearing was required to be conducted in determining the applicability of the Canandaigua Treaty of 1796. The court held that defendants were not selectively prosecuted. Finally, the court held that there was sufficient evidence to support the charges against defendants.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion for renewal, reargument, factual hearing, and reconsideration.


HEADNOTES

Indians -- Criminal Jurisdiction over Indians

While the Federal Government possesses plenary power over Indians, including the exercise of Federal criminal jurisdiction, by virtue of the dependent, quasi-sovereign status of Indian tribes, and the Federal Government has, by statute, validly ceded to New York its civil and criminal jurisdiction over Indians within the borders of New York State (US Code, tit 25, §§ 232, 233), the St. Regis Indians, by virtue of the 1796 "Treaty with the Seven Nations of Canada", are still possessed of both civil and criminal jurisdiction over disputes involving only tribe members on their reservation within Franklin County even though at present they lack the judicial machinery necessary to exercise it; accordingly, the State of New York has civil and criminal jurisdiction which is concurrent with that of the Indians with respect to members of their tribe and exclusive with respect to all other persons or criminal [***2] acts on or off the reservation and, therefore, the County Court of Franklin County has criminal jurisdiction over the subject Indians.

 

2038 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Garcia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Bronx County


103 Misc. 2d 915; 427 N.Y.S.2d 360; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2221



April 4, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based upon the above disposition of a segment of defendants' pretrial motion, the defendants' remaining requests for a suppression hearing and a Sandoval hearing are denied as moot.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved for discovery of the district attorney's charge to the grand jury, inspection of the charge, and dismissal of the indictment, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 210.20(1)(c), 210.35(5), 190.25(6), and 190.30.


OVERVIEW: After defendants were indicated for criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, they moved for discovery of the district attorney's charge to the grand jury and dismissal of the indictment, alleging that the grand jury was improperly charged regarding the presumption of possession of a weapon in an automobile. In dismissing the indictment, the court concluded that the district attorney improperly instructed the grand jury. The failure to instruct the grand jury concerning the permissible nature of the presumption arising from the presence of a weapon in an automobile to possession by all occupants could very likely have led the grand jury to infer that the presumption was mandatory, thus prejudicing the defendants. The specific charge given was insufficient and misleading and was used to supply the necessary element of possession. The improper charge constituted a defect impairing the integrity of the grand jury proceeding and requiring dismissal.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to dismiss the indictment was granted, as the district attorney improperly charged the jury regarding the permissible nature of the presumption that presence of the weapon in the automobile constituted possession by all of the vehicle's occupants. Because defendants were prejudiced by the misleading charge, dismissal was required.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- Instructions

An indictment charging defendants with criminal possession of a weapon must be dismissed pursuant to CPL 190.30 (subd 6), which requires a District Attorney to properly instruct a Grand Jury as to the significance, legal effect or evaluation of evidence, and CPL 190.65, which requires an indictment to be based on a legally sufficient case, where the District Attorney refused to instruct the Grand Jury as to the permissible nature of the presumption that a weapon present in an automobile is deemed to be possessed by all its occupants (see Ulster County Ct. v Allen, 442 U.S. 140); although a Grand Jury need not be instructed with the same degree of precision required when a petit jury is instructed on the law and in the ordinary case a reading of the appropriate statutes will suffice, the instant case is extraordinary in that the relevant statutory presumption has been unequivocally limited by case law so that a mere reading of the statute would mislead the [***2] Grand Jury as to the applicable law, consequently prejudicing defendants.

 

2039 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ilardo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


103 Misc. 2d 454; 426 N.Y.S.2d 212; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2138



March 21, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Whereas, for reasons of insufficiency of the accusatory instrument and, in the alternative, for the reasons above indicated, the accusatory instrument is dismissed and the defendant discharged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an obscenity charge related to the purchase of a magazine claiming insufficiency of the indictment and denial of his right to a speedy trial.


OVERVIEW: The indictment was insufficient and defendant's U.S. Const. amend. VI right to a speedy trial was violated because nowhere was it sufficiently stated that the material in question was reviewed in relation to a time when the average person, applying contemporary community standards, would find that the material, taken as a whole, appealed to prurient interest. The court held that state statutes designed to regulate obscene materials must be carefully limited and that probable cause was still the touchstone of valid prosecution. The court stated that probable cause must be found and alleged factually for all the elements of obscenity, including for the word "contemporary," especially when such a finding could not be inferred from the facts alleged in the accusatory instrument or as a result of the lapse of seven months from the time of the purchase of the alleged obscene material and the time of the mere review of the material by a judge.


OUTCOME: For reasons of insufficiency of the indictment and for undue delay, the accusatory instrument was dismissed and the defendant discharged.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Obscenity -- "Contemporary" Community Standards

1. State statutes designed to regulate obscene materials applying "contemporary" community standards ( Penal Law, § 235.00, subd 1) must be carefully limited and probable cause must be found and alleged factually for all the elements of obscenity including for the word "contemporary" especially when such a finding cannot be inferred from the facts alleged in the accusatory instrument or as a result of the lapse of time from the purchase of the alleged obscene material and the time of the review of the material by a Judge; accordingly, since "contemporary" means existing during the same time, an accusatory instrument which does not sufficiently state that there was probable cause to believe that the material in question was obscene by the standards of the community on the dates of the sales, a Judge having reviewed the material seven months after the sales, is insufficient for failure to allege facts and probable cause as [***2] to each and every element acquired by law.

Crimes -- Right to Speedy Trial -- "Unreasonable" Preaccusation Delay

2. Dismissals for unreasonable delays are not regulated by reference to a calendar or a counting of specified days, months or years, but rather, the controlling word in dismissals for delays in prosecution is the word "unreasonable" as determined from all the circumstances including the nature of the case itself; accordingly, since the only explanation given by the People for the delay in prosecuting defendant on obscenity charges ( Penal Law, § 235.05, subd 1) was the unsettled state of the obscenity law and no explanation was offered indicating an "investigative" motive for the delay and the very nature of the charge involves "time" or a "contemporary" standard, a preaccusation delay of seven months and a total delay of eight months before arraignment is unreasonable and violative of defendant's due process rights and the public's inherent right to prompt prosecution of suspected criminal activity.

 

2040 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Terwilliger v. Terwilliger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Dutchess County


103 Misc. 2d 371; 426 N.Y.S.2d 684; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2126



March 13, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant husband moved for leave to reargue plaintiff wife's prior application to sever certain counterclaims brought by the husband, with their financial causes of action, from the matrimonial causes of action pleaded in a prior complaint. In the counterclaims, the husband sought to impress constructive trusts upon certain parcels of improved real property now or formerly owned of record by the wife.


OVERVIEW: In a pending action for divorce, the husband interposed an answer asserting counterclaims seeking to impress constructive trusts on certain parcels of improved real property now or formerly owned of record by his wife. In response, the wife successfully applied to sever those counterclaims, with their financial causes of action, from the matrimonial causes of action pleaded in the pending action for divorce. The husband moved for leave to reargue he prior application to sever the counterclaims. Upon review, the court denied the husband's motion for leave to reargue. The court rejected the husband's argument that N.Y. Dom. Rel. § 176 authorized an unconstitutional deprivation of the husband's property rights without due process of law. After a historical review of the sources of § 176, the court stated that § 176 did not have any significance and to interpret it otherwise, as the husband desired, would ignore its legislative purpose as manifested by the record of the past.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husband's motion for leave to reargue the wife's application to sever certain counterclaims, stating that the husband failed to demonstrate that any authority or principle of law was overlooked or that the facts were misapprehended.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Property Rights in Action by Wife

 Section 176 of the Domestic Relations Law which provides that a husband in a divorce action brought by his wife, has, upon the granting of a final judgment dissolving the marriage, no postdivorce claims to personalty left by him with his wife prior to divorce, has neither vigor nor significance today, linked as it is with the consequence of divorce upon the long-abolished estates of curtesy and dower, and, consequently, such statute cannot bar postjudgment prosecution of defendant husband's counterclaims for imposition of constructive trusts upon realty acquired by the parties during the marriage or upon the proceeds of sale of the realty or be used to prevent the severance of defendant's financial counterclaims from the matrimonial causes of action pleaded in the complaint; since the parties were married nearly 40 years after estates by curtesy were abolished and after dower rights were eliminated as to marriages contracted after August 31, 1930, and as to real estate acquired subsequent to that date, the statute for them is no more than an anachronism, a vestigial remnant of a bygone era.

 

2041 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Baby Girl


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Onondaga County


103 Misc. 2d 542; 426 N.Y.S.2d 398; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2174



March 6, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner adoptive parents instituted a proceeding for a final order of adoption.


OVERVIEW: The natural mother abandoned her child to an authorized agency pursuant to statutory procedures. The agency having lawful custody of the adoptive child attempted to give its consent to the adoption pursuant to the provisions of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111-1(d). The court held that at the time of the surrender by the natural mother of the subject child, the rights of the natural father remained inchoate. The court concluded that the father was not entitled to notice of the proceedings because he did not fit into any of the statutory categories set forth in N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-c, nor had the father established a relationship with the mother of the child that would require that he receive notice under New York case law. Accordingly, the court approved the petition for the adoption of the child.


OUTCOME: The court held that there was no need for the agency to procure the consent of the child's biological father, and therefore the court approved the petition for the adoption of the child.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Consent of Father of Out-of-Wedlock Child -- Consent of Authorized Agency

The consent of the father of an out-of-wedlock child to an adoption is not required where the natural mother has abandoned the child by surrendering the child to an authorized agency (Social Services Law, § 384) and where the father has established no relationship with the mother or with the child and is thus not entitled to notice of the adoption under statutory (Social Services Law, § 384-c) or case law; Caban v Mohammed (441 U.S. 380) which declared unconstitutional a gender-based statutory distinction which required the consent to an adoption by the mother of a child born out of wedlock but not the father of the child (Dometic Relations Law, § 111, subd 1, par [c]) is inapplicable since the only consent required herein is that of the authorized agency having lawful custody of the child (Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 1, par [d]), the mother's consent no longer being required by virtue of her having surrendered the child pursuant to statutory procedures; whether the father of an out-of-wedlock child should have his rights come into being at the moment of birth of the child,  [***2] as does the father of a child who is married to the child's natural mother, is a decision that must be left to the Legislature which, in light of the unconstitutionality of the consent statute, must also decide whether or not the consent of both of the parents of a child born out of wedlock is necessary to an adoption or whether the consent of neither parent is required, the court being without power to read the statute as gender neutral.

 

2042 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Apfelbaum v. Clarkstown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


104 Misc. 2d 371; 428 N.Y.S.2d 387; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2282



February 28, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff senior citizens instituted a declaratory judgment action against defendant city to declare unconstitutional provisions of the city's zoning code, Clarkstown, N. Y., Zoning Code §§ 106-16-0-5 and 106-16-0-11(L), as they relate to senior citizen housing.
