OVERVIEW: The senior citizens sought to have the court declare that the town's zoning laws relating to senior citizen housing was unconstitutional, specifically Clarkstown, N. Y., Zoning Code §§ 106-16-0-5 and 106-16-0-11(L). The court denied the motion because it found that the senior citizens failed to meet the heavy burden of demonstrating that the zoning limitations were unconstitutional on their face. The subject limitations were enacted pursuant to Clarkstown, N. Y., Town Law § 261 that permitted the town to impose zoning regulations for the purpose of promoting the general welfare of the community. The ordinances prohibited the construction of more than 106 dwelling units at any one senior citizen housing site, and prohibited construction of such sites within 1,500 feet of each other. The parties disagreed as to their effect. The senior citizens contended that there were few sites in the town, which would qualify for senior citizen housing, thereby discriminating against senior citizens. The town contended that there was an abundance of land available for senior citizen complexes. Clearly, this was an issue that required further development at trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied the senior citizen's motion for summary judgment against the town.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Zoning

The United States Constitution does not require that all persons be treated identically, but it does require that differences in treatment of persons similarly situated be justified by an appropriate State interest, based on whether the classification has a rational relationship to a legitimate State objective; moreover, an exceedingly strong presumption of constitutionality applies not only to enactments of the Legislature, but to ordinances of municipalities as well and, while this presumption is rebuttable, unconstitutionality must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt and only as a last resort should courts strike down legislation on the ground of unconstitutionality. Accordingly, plaintiff failed to meet its heavy burden of demonstrating that town zoning limitations which prohibit the construction of more than 106 dwelling units at any one senior citizens' housing site and prohibit construction of such sites within 1,500 feet of each other are unconstitutional on their face, since the limitations would appear to have a rational basis when viewed as part of the comprehensive plan the town asserts it has formed in order to integrate [***2] senior citizens into the community by providing for "optimum sized" housing throughout the town; it does not appear as irrational and discriminatory that no such restrictions are imposed upon other dwellings erected in multiple residence zones in the town because the remainder of these buildings are erected without regard to considerations of the age of the occupants and will, therefore, be available for the utilization of the entire population, including senior citizens.

 

2043 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


RAM v. Blum


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


103 Misc. 2d 237; 425 N.Y.S.2d 735; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2101



February 19, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, Commissioner of the New York Department of Social Services, filed a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiffs, an unincorporated association of welfare recipients and individual welfare recipients (welfare recipients), that challenged on a constitutional basis the adequacy of the welfare payments provided by N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131(a).


OVERVIEW: The court found that although the action was pleaded in 111 separate paragraphs and supported by voluminous affidavits and exhibits, the fundamental theme of the lawsuit was the simple charge that the legislature had failed to discharge its duty under N.Y. Const. art. XVII. That article provided: "The aid, care and support of the needy are public concerns and shall be provided by the state and by such of its subdivisions, and in such manner and by such means, as the legislature may from time to time determine." N.Y. Const. art XVII, § 1. The court ruled that the action rested entirely on unjusticiable claims. The court found that the state's highest court in construing art. XVII had held that the legislature was vested with discretion to determine the amount of public assistance. The court held that this construction of the state constitution prevented a court from substituting its judgment for that of the legislature in welfare matters; that the writ of any New York court could not be made to run that far. The court held that the reliance of the welfare recipients on a federal constitutional claim would not sustain their complaint either.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss of the Commissioner of the New York Department of Social Services and dismissed as moot the motion of the welfare recipients for a declaration of class action status.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social Services -- Standard of Need -- Constitutionality of Uniform Flat Grant

An action seeking to declare unconstitutional a statute which sets forth a "standard of need" for public assistance based upon the number of needy persons in the applicant's household (Social Services Law, § 131-a) because it lacks "a mechanism" to adjust welfare benefits upwards with the inflation rate to meet subsistence needs and thus fails to discharge the duty of the Legislature to provide "aid, care and support of the needy" as it "may from time to time determine" (NY Const, art XVII, § 1), rests entirely on nonjusticiable claims and must be dismissed since it is a legislative prerogative under the Constitution to determine the amount and allocation of funds for the needy and a court cannot substitute its judgment for that of the Legislature in welfare matters; the uniform flat grant system established by the statute is not violative of the Federal Constitution and, furthermore, the declaratory relief requested does not lie against the State when its proprietary interests are involved; an effective judgment mandating increased welfare payments would result in the complete breakdown of separation [***2] of powers so that any relief must come from legislative and not judicial action.

 

2044 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. United Bus Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


102 Misc. 2d 1097; 424 N.Y.S.2d 1008; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2064



February 13, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, as to the defendant United Bus Corporation the motion to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant individual and defendant corporation were charged with a violation of the Suffolk County, N.Y., Sanitary Code art. 10, § 20. Thereafter, the individual and the corporation filed motions to dismiss the informations.


OVERVIEW: In their motions, the individual and the corporation argued that the present prosecution was barred because they were already prosecuted for the same offense. Previously, the corporation pleaded guilty to a violation for permitting excessive exhaust from one of its buses in violation of the N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 375(28). First, the court denied the individual's motion because the individual was not previously prosecuted for the offense. Next, the court considered the whether the present action against the corporation was barred by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 40.20. The court held that in order to be prosecuted under § 40.20, the accusatory instrument must have been filed with a court. According to the court, the corporation was not technically "prosecuted" for the previous offense because the previous prosecution was before the New York Administrative Adjudications Bureau (AAB) and the AAB was not a court. However, the court held that the action against the corporation was barred because the advantage of being subjected to a civil proceeding in the AAB did not justify denying the corporation the protections afforded by the N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 40.20(2).


OUTCOME: The court denied the individual's motion and granted the corporation's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Former Jeopardy -- Traffic Infractions

A bus company may not be prosecuted for emission of a visible air contaminant from an internal combustion engine subsequent to a plea of guilty in a previous prosecution for permitting excessive exhaust from one of its buses, based on the same transaction, which was heard by the Administrative Adjudication Bureau; although the bureau is not a court, and its orders are civil in nature, the prosecution is barred by CPL 40.20 (subd 2) since it is only an incident of the location of the occurrence which caused the initial charge to be brought before the bureau rather than in a court and the administrative adjudication of traffic infractions in certain localities is intended to relieve the pressure on overcrowded courts; the result of permitting multiple prosecutions bears no rational relation to the goal of reducing court caseloads; therefore, CPL 40.20 (subd 2) must be construed as including a bar to a prosecution subsequent to an adjudication by the Administrative Adjudication Bureau.

 

2045 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Citibank, N.A. v. State


Motion Nos. M-22115, M-22116, M-22117, M-22118, M-22119, M-22120, M-22121, M-22122, M-22123, M-22127


Court of Claims of New York


103 Misc. 2d 348; 425 N.Y.S.2d 932; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2120



February 5, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimants, trustees and executors, filed a series of motions seeking permission to file late claims pursuant to N.Y. Ct. Cl. Act § 10(6) after they paid capital gains taxes on trusts and estates in 1972 in accordance with the "Instructions for Fiduciary Return." Defendant state opposed the motions on the ground that they were untimely.


OVERVIEW: Claimants filed fiduciary income tax returns and paid capital gains taxes on their trusts and estates in accordance with the "Instructions for Fiduciary Return." Six years later, an appellate court held that the instructions inaccurately reflected the provisions of the then N.Y. Tax Law with respect to the computation of the capital gains tax for trusts and estates, so claimants sought to file claims against the state for moneys improperly had and received. The state opposed the motions as untimely, and claimants argued that their causes of action arose after the appellate court decision. The court found that a claim for a tax refund accrued upon payment of the tax and that claimants' argument that they had no a forum within which to bring their causes of action was without merit. The court discussed several avenues of recourse that were open to claimants at the time they paid the taxes and concluded that the claims arose when they paid the taxes, so the claims expired prior to the enactment of § 10(6), and therefore, the series of motions were untimely.


OUTCOME: The court held that the claims against the state for refunds of capital gains taxes on claimants' trusts and estates were untimely because the claims arose when the taxes were paid to the state and not when the tax was struck down.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] State -- Claims for Tax Refunds -- Accrual of Claim

Claims by estate and trust fiduciaries against the State for moneys improperly had and received based upon the alleged overpayment of capital gains taxes for 1972 in accordance with the instructions accompanying the fiduciary income tax returns for the year 1972, the Court of Appeals having subsequently held in 1978 that the instructions relied upon by claimants in filing their returns inaccurately reflected the provisions of the then Tax Law with respect to the computation of the capital gains tax for trusts and estates (see Clarendon Trust v State Tax Comm., 43 NY2d 933), are untimely since the claims arose upon the payment of the taxes by claimants and not when the Court of Appeals struck down the tax; the argument that the Court of Claims alleged lack of jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges to State tax laws left claimants without a forum within which to bring their causes of action is without merit; claimants could have brought simultaneous actions in the Court of Claims and the Supreme Court or refrained from paying the taxes and then moved in Supreme Court to set aside the deficiency assessment; accordingly,  [***2] since the claims expired prior to the enactment of the present statute authorizing the filing of late claims ( Court of Claims Act, § 10, subd 6) there is no need to discuss compliance with the other factors enumerated therein.

 

2046 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Crotty v. New Windsor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


103 Misc. 2d 378; 425 N.Y.S.2d 929; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2127



February 5, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney, citing N.Y. Town Law §§ 20, 23, 24, brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondents, a town, certain officials, and a law firm, to annul the action of the town board in designating as town attorneys the law firm, whose members were not all residents or electors of the town.


OVERVIEW: The town, officials, and law firm averred that the appointment of attorneys to the town was made pursuant to N.Y. Town Law § 20(2)(b), an appointment that they argued was not restricted to electors of the town, unlike the office of town attorney pursuant to § 20(2)(a). The court granted the petition in part and denied it in part. The court found that at the time of the appointment of the law firm, the town had in effect a local law establishing the office of town attorney. The court determined that the resolution of the town board setting forth the term of legal counsel's employment clearly did not spell out the relationship of attorneys to the town but, on the contrary, appointed the office of town attorney. The court found that the appointment of the nonresident attorneys of the law firm as town attorneys was violative of N.Y. Town Law § 23 by reason of there being resident attorneys in the town.


OUTCOME: The court granted the branch of the attorney's petition in his proceeding against respondents that sought a declaration voiding the appointment of the law firm as town attorneys for the town, and it denied the petition in all other respects.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Appointment of Town Attorney -- Residency Requirement

Since the resolution of the town board employing a law firm, all of whose members are not residents or electors of the town, for unspecified legal services and advice amounts to the appointment of the office of Town Attorney (Town Law, § 20, subd 2, par [a]) to provide general legal counsel and not the appointment of attorneys to the town in connection with any particular matters, the appointment of such counsel by the town not being limited to electors of the town (Town Law, § 20, subd 2, par [b]), and since the town, at the time of the appointment of the nonresident attorneys, had in effect a local law establishing the office of Town Attorney for a six-year term, the term of office for a Town Attorney being limited by State law to two years (Town Law, § 24), and had other resident attorneys, it could not lawfully appoint the nonresident attorneys to the office of Town Attorney (Town Law, § 23); reliance by respondents upon the invalidity of the local law establishing the office of Town Attorney is misplaced since courts of original jurisdiction should not declare a legislative act unconstitutional [***2] unless such conclusion is inescapable or in rare cases involving life and property and, further, an invalid part of a statute may be severed from the valid provisions.

 

2047 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Gross


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 1073; 425 N.Y.S.2d 220; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2060



February 1, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner social services agency (agency) sought a court order to transfer custody and guardianship of respondent parents' children to the agency for the purpose of freeing the children for adoption under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b.


OVERVIEW: The agency petitioned the court to transfer custody and guardianship of the parents' children to the agency to free them for adoption after they had been in foster care for a number of years. The children's father was of "dull normal" intelligence and the mother was mildly retarded. The court denied the agency's petition. The court held that the agency did not meet its burden of showing grounds for the termination of the parents' rights. The court found that the agency did not show grounds for abandonment or permanent neglect. The court noted that consent to adoption by the older child, who was 14, was required under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(a)(1), and such consent would not be forthcoming. The older child understood her parents' mental conditions and her circumstances, and did not want to be adopted. As to the younger child, the court ruled that termination of parental rights under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b(4)(c), which stated grounds as mental illness or retardation of the parents, would be unconstitutional. The court held that the statute violated substantive due process rights and the equal protection clause as applied to parents who were mentally ill or retarded.


OUTCOME: The court denied the petition by the agency to commit the guardianship and custody of the children to the agency and extended the foster home placement of the children for one year.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Consent of Child

1. The consent of a child over the age of 14 years is required pursuant to section 111 (subd 1, par [a]) of the Domestic Relations Law in a proceeding to terminate the rights of her parents on the ground of mental illness or mental retardation (Social Services Law, § 384-b, subd 4, par [c]) for the purpose of freeing her for adoption; the court may consider the wishes of the child in determining whether her best interests would be served in this limited instance (Social Services Law, § 384-b, subd 3, par [k]).

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Mental Illness or Retardation

2. Section 384-b (subd 4, par [c]) of the Social Services Law, which provides for the termination of parental rights on the grounds that the "parents, whose consent to the adoption of the child would otherwise be required * * * are presently and for the foreseeable future unable, by reason of mental illness or mental retardation, to provide proper and adequate care for a child" is in conflict with the equal protection clause of the Constitution since the rights involved in familial relationships are fundamental rights, subject to the strict [***2] scrutiny test and there is no compelling State interest for upholding the statute; the legislative purposes of the statute, the welfare of the child and the objective of conservation of State funds cannot be met in this instance because a continuation of the long-term foster care arrangements rather than termination of parental rights would be in the best interest of the children; furthermore, the Constitution recognizes higher values than speed and efficiency.

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Mental Illness or Retardation

3. Section 384-b (subd 4, par [c]) of the Social Services Law which provides for the termination of parental rights on the grounds that the "parents, whose consent to adoption of the child would otherwise be required * * * are presently and for the foreseeable future unable, by reason of mental illness or mental retardation, to provide proper and adequate care for a child" is constitutionally infirm in that it violates the due process clause of the Constitution since the due process clause protects freedom of choice in matters of family life and the State may not deprive a parent of his child on the basis of the status of a person [***3] who suffers from a disease; the State may not force the breakup of a natural family over the objections of the parents and their children, without some showing of unfitness and for the sole reason of the children's best interests.

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Mental Illness or Retardation

4. Section 384-b (subd 4, par [c]) of the Social Services Law which provides for termination of parental rights on the basis of mental illness or retardation is equated with abandonment, which never requires a determination of the best interests of the child; however, even after a finding of permanent neglect, a dispositional hearing must be held to determine the best interests of the child. The drastic disparity of treatment between mentally ill or retarded parents whose rights are immediately terminated by such a finding and their consent to any future adoption dispensed with and neglectful or abusing parents who are entitled to a hearing on the issue of the child's best interests before termination is improper; it violates substantive due process by providing for termination of the mentally ill or retarded parent's rights without fault and violates the equal [***4] protection clause by applying a separate and distinct standard to the mentally ill or retarded.

 

2048 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Katz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Long Beach, Nassau County


102 Misc. 2d 755; 424 N.Y.S.2d 659; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2013



January 28, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons hereinabove given the warrant is vacated and the evidence obtained thereby suppressed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to vacate a warrant and suppress evidence obtained thereby, contending that the search of their residence was unauthorized and illegal. Defendants were charged with violations of zoning, building, and housing codes.


OVERVIEW: Defendants' residence was located in a two-family zone. A building inspector, viewing the exterior thereof, observed three entrances, four separate electric meters, and two mail boxes. He confronted defendants and sought permission to inspect the interior, which was denied. A warrant was issued by the court authorizing a search of the interior of the premises for the purpose of obtaining visual evidence of suspected zoning violations. Defendants were charged with violations of the zoning, building, and housing codes. Defendants contended that the search was unauthorized and illegal. The court vacated the warrant and ordered the evidence obtained thereby suppressed. The court held that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law art. 690 governing search and seizure, did not authorize issuance of a warrant for inspection of real property in order to obtain intangible or visual evidence.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the warrant and ordered the evidence obtained from the illegal search suppressed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Search Warrant -- Administrative Searches

1. Search and seizure under a warrant is restricted to "personal property" ( CPL 690.10) and, therefore, a municipality cannot compel access nor obtain a warrant for an administrative search for the purpose of inspection of real property in order to obtain intangible or visual evidence of violations of building or zoning codes.

Crimes -- Search Warrant -- Pretrial Suppression of Evidence

2. A court retains inherent power to review its own orders at any stage of the proceedings and therefore the court may entertain pretrial review of a search warrant under a Fourth Amendment objection that relates to intangible evidence obtained through a nonconsentual search.

Crimes -- Search Warrant

3. Although CPL 710.10 (subd 2) now provides that "potential testimony" is subject to pretrial suppression pursuant to an improperly issued warrant, whereas only "tangible property" was previously subject to pretrial suppression if obtained pursuant to an invalid warrant, the modification of CPL 710.10 did not enlarge [***2] the court's authority under CPL article 690 to permit an administrative warrant, since no warrant for the purpose of an administrative search is available pursuant to the provisions of CPL 690.10.

 

2049 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Whalen v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Kings County


103 Misc. 2d 449; 426 N.Y.S.2d 380; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2137



January 25, 1980 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employees filed an action against defendant City of New York seeking to recover wages that were due to them.


OVERVIEW: The employees filed an action to recover wages due to them on the terms of a wage deferral agreement entered into by the union and the City of New York. The City of New York contended that the employees had no standing to sue because they were members of a union and that the union should have been the party litigating the issue. The court determined that an employee could maintain an action against his employer because the arbitrator's determination extending the deferral of wages for city employees took place during the period of time when the employees were state employees. The court held state employees were not affected by city legislation. The court concluded the City of New York had no legal right to delegate sovereign and legislative power to an arbitrator and entered judgment in favor of the employees.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of the employees because the City of New York had no authority to delegate the resolution of the dispute to an arbitrator.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Wage Deferral Agreement -- Standing to Sue City Directly

Whether it is appropriate for the courts to overturn judicial precedent depends on several factors, including the nature of the rights and interests at stake and the extent and degree to which action may justifiably have been taken in reliance on the precedent; precedents involving statutory interpretation are entitled to great stability. Accordingly, where the union representing plaintiffs, who were then court clerk employees of the City of New York, negotiated a wage deferral during the period of New York City's financial crisis in 1975, which deferral covered the period July 1, 1975 through June 30, 1976, and was extended in 1978 by an arbitrator who directed that payment by the city be made in 1982, but, as a result of the State "takeover" of the court system, plaintiffs became State employees in 1977, although they continued to perform the same duties, the court, adhering to a recent decision on similar facts, held that plaintiffs have standing to maintain a direct action against their former employer, rejected defendant city's argument that plaintiffs lack standing since their union should [***2] be the party litigating the salary claim and granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, holding that the arbitrator's action, which took place during the period of time when plaintiffs were State employees, was null and void insofar as State employees are concerned; State employees should not be affected by legislation authorizing said arbitration or deferrals enacted by the City of New York, which had no legal right to delegate sovereign and legislative power to render a decision affecting State employees to an arbitrator.

 

2050 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Haverstraw


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


102 Misc. 2d 923; 425 N.Y.S.2d 192; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2038



January 17, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] All motions made during the trial on which the court reserved decision and which are not explicitly referred to herein are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers filed a protest of a tax assessment on certain real property by respondent town for certain years. The taxpayers contended that the denial of the taxpayers' demands to use certain ratios served by the town did not comply with the requirements of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 716. The taxpayers also attacked 1979 N.Y. Laws ch. 126 and 1979 N.Y. Laws ch. 127 on the ground that they denied them due process and equal protection.


OVERVIEW: In a consolidated proceeding the taxpayers sought review of assessments on real property pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art. 7. Additionally, the taxpayers attacked 1979 N.Y. Laws ch. 126 and 1979 N.Y. Laws ch. 127 on the ground that they denied them due process and equal protection. The court denied all of the motions made during the trial on which the court reserved decision and held that the taxpayers' proof fell far short of what was required for the court to accept the bare fact of what the state rate was for the years under review as being of any probative value on the issue of inequality. The court also found that the subject statutes were unconstitutional because they permitted one class of taxpayer to rely on evidence of ratio while prohibiting all others from using the same method of proof. Although the defect took on added dimensions when the statute was also to be applied retroactively to litigants who had a constitutionally vested right to a refund of excess tax payments, the statutes were inapplicable to the proceeding. Therefore, the court reasoned that because of the taxpayers' failure to prove ratio and inequality, the court had to dismiss the petitions.


OUTCOME: The court denied all of the taxpayers' motions in the action that that challenged the assessments on certain real property for certain years by the town.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Demand to Admit Ratio

1. In a proceeding to review a real property tax assessment where petitioner has served on respondent town demands for admission that the percentage of full value at which other real property in the taxing unit is assessed is the percentage specified in the demands, and where respondent served timely notices stating that it did not understand the demands and therefore must deny them, the notices clearly and explicitly denied the alleged percentages and consequently comply with section 716 of the Real Property Tax Law notwithstanding the excess verbiage therein.

Disclosure -- Notice to Admit -- Unsworn Response

2. Where petitioner properly serves a notice to admit pursuant to CPLR 3123 on respondent and respondent fails to serve a timely response or responds with an unsigned and unsworn denial, then the facts set forth in the notice to admit are deemed admitted; CPLR 3123 (subd [a]) requires that a party must respond to a notice to admit by a sworn statement.

Taxation -- Assessment  [***2] -- Evidence of State Equalization Rate

3. In attempting to prove that certain real property was assessed unequally during 1970 and subsequent years, a petitioner may rely exclusively on the applicable State equalization rates, however, petitioner must justify use of State equalization rates by showing that the State rate pertains specifically to the taxing unit and that it is statistically accurate; the party seeking to justify use of the State rate should, among other things, furnish evidence which shows the various parcels included in the sampling by the board of the assessing unit involved and the types of property making up that sampling.

Taxation -- Assessment -- Evidence of Inequality

4. Chapter 126 of the Laws of 1979, which deleted from subdivision 3 of section 720 of the Real Property Tax Law a provision allowing a party bringing an assessment review proceeding to introduce the State equalization rate as evidence of inequality, and chapter 127 of the Laws of 1979, which provides that owners of residential structures containing no more than three dwelling units may introduce any relevant and material evidence to establish the inequality of an assessment, do [***3] not deny due process to an aggrieved taxpayer by arbitrarily denying him the right to present relevant, competent and material evidence, i.e., State equalization rates, in a tax review proceeding; since a litigant possesses no vested rights in a rule of evidence, the Legislature may prescribe new rules of evidence or alter existing rules of evidence so long as it does not transgress due process or equal protection guarantees; there is a strong presumption that any enactment of the Legislature is constitutional.

Taxation -- Assessment -- Evidence of Inequality

5. Chapter 126 of the Laws of 1979, which disallowed introduction of the State equalization rate as evidence of inequality in a tax review proceeding, and chapter 127 of the Laws of 1979, which provides that owners of residential structures containing no more than three dwelling units may introduce any relevant and material evidence to establish the inequality of an assessment, are in violation of equal protection guarantees since they permit one class of taxpayers to rely on evidence of State equalization rates while prohibiting all others from using the same method of proof; furthermore, the provisions of chapter [***4] 127 of the Laws of 1979 making chapters 126 and 127 of the Laws of 1979 applicable to any proceeding commenced after January 1, 1970 are unconstitutional since these statutes may not be retroactively applied to procedural steps already taken.

 

2051 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rego Properties Corp. v. Finance Adm'r of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


102 Misc. 2d 641; 424 N.Y.S.2d 621; 1980 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1997



January 14, 1980 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion to dismiss the petition is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent city finance administrator brought a motion to dismiss petitioner corporation's action insofar as it alleged inequality of assessment. The corporation refused to amend its petition to comply with the requirements of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 307(3) on the ground that the statute violated provisions of both the state and federal constitutions.


OVERVIEW: The court reasoned the constitutionality § 307 had to have been tested against the principle that the power to tax was a legislative power and could not have been delegated to an administrative agency. The court concluded that by the enactment of § 307, the legislature had delegated to administrative officials the power to determine how great a tax burden was placed on a particular piece of property. The court reasoned that the real property tax was largely determined by the classification of property adopted by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. However, the court stated that the agency was given absolutely no standards or guidelines to limit its discretion in classifying property. The court further held that § 307(3) was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power because it in effect gave the assessors unlimited discretion to select the rate at which property would have been assessed, and this was an impermissible delegation of the legislative power. The court concluded that the lack of valid standards in classifying real property for tax purposes resulted in a denial of due process under both the state and federal constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to dismiss the petition.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Standards of Assessment

1. A statute (Real Property Tax Law, § 307, subd 3), enacted to shield local assessing units from the impact of full-value assessments for the period necessary to complete the current reform of the real property tax system which requires a petitioner in a proceeding to review an assessment to prove that the assessment has been made at a higher proportionate valuation than the assessment of other real property of the same major type as determined by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment (SBEA), unconstitutionally delegates the legislative power to determine how great a tax burden is placed on a particular piece of property (NY Const, art III, § 1) to administrative officials in that the real property tax will largely be determined by the classification of property adopted by the SBEA which is given no standards or guidelines to limit its discretion in classifying property (see Real Property Tax Law, § 1200), and the statute gives the assessors unlimited discretion to assess each class of property at a ratio which may vary from 0 to 100% of its full fair [***2] market value and to determine what proportionate share of the tax will be raised from different groups; moreover, the statute does not provide the assessors with any guidelines for assessing one class of property higher than another nor does the statute establish the proper difference among class ratios so that assessors may in a completely arbitrary manner decide to assess commercial property at a higher rate than industrial property.

Taxation -- Assessment -- Standards of Assessment

2. A statute which unconstitutionally delegates the legislative power to tax (NY Const, art III, § 1) to administrative officials by requiring a petitioner in a proceeding to review an assessment to prove that the assessment has been made at a higher proportionate valuation than the assessment of other real property of the same major type as determined by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment (Real Property Tax Law, § 307, subd 3) denies due process of law since there is a substantial departure from the law as to the authority to levy the tax; due process necessitates that a tax statute have a reasonable degree of certainty and definiteness and the statute herein offends due process [***3] since a taxpayer will not know what his tax burden is until the assessors, in their unlimited discretion, fix a rate of assessment; in addition, the statute is violative of equal protection, which requires that a classification of property for tax purposes have a rational basis, since the statute permits any rate of assessment on property, no matter how irrational, as long as the local assessing unit can show that other property of the same type has been assessed at the same rate.

 

2052 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Putland


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


102 Misc. 2d 517; 423 N.Y.S.2d 999; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2903



December 28, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion for removal to Family Court is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted, as a juvenile offender, for second degree murder, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 125.25(1) and 130.50, for forcibly sodomizing and then hanging an eight-year-old boy. Defendant sought to remove his criminal action to Family Court pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.43.


OVERVIEW: Defendant juvenile was indicted for second degree murder and first degree sodomy in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 125.25 and 130.50. The victim was an eight-year-old boy. Defendant filed a motion for removal and contended that the district attorney's ability to block removal pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.43 was unconstitutional because it violated the doctrine of separation of powers. The court denied defendant's motion. The court reasoned that the statute did not constitute an encroachment on separation of powers, because the district attorney was not vested with a judicial function or with a vehicle for trespassing on judicial turf. The removal was inappropriate, because a private trial was not a proper forum for the adjudication of a crime of such proportions. Whether defendant eventually was found innocent or guilty, it was imperative that the proceeding be subject to open scrutiny. The court concluded that removal to Family Court would isolate the proceeding from the community.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders -- Removal to Family Court

1. A statute which vests the prosecutor with the power to grant or withhold consent to remove certain juvenile offender cases to the Family Court ( CPL 210.43) poses no direct or potential threat to the judicial functions under the statute, and is, therefore, not violative of the doctrine of separation of powers; the Legislature, by requiring the prosecutor's preliminary removal consent when certain highly serious designated crimes are charged, has not invested the prosecutor with a judicial function or with a vehicle for trespassing on judicial turf since, if and when a prosecutor does consent, the court must itself, in the interests of justice, and under articulated standards, decide whether removal to the Family Court would be appropriate; by granting the court and the prosecutor the authority to concur in or to reject the defendant's proposed removal, the prosecutorial consent is no different from the "veto power" which resides in the prosecution when it chooses to withhold consent to a lesser plea; the statutory scheme is not irrational since it is [***2] well within the power of the Legislature to insist on superior court trials in cases of serious crimes committed by juvenile offenders and to provide its prosecutorial arm with the means to carry out that objective.

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders -- Removal to Family Court

2. Although a superior court has no statutory authority to remove certain serious charges against a juvenile offender to the Family Court over prosecutorial objection ( CPL 210.43, subd 1, par [b]), since there is language in a decision of the Court of Appeals suggesting that the judicial power to dismiss in the interests of justice may be read to include the power to remove a juvenile crime in the interests of justice over prosecutorial objection (see Matter of Vega v Bell, 47 NY2d 543), the court will make an "inquiry" ( CPL 210.43, subd 3) for the purpose of determining whether murder and sodomy charges against defendant should be removed to the Family Court in the interests of justice based upon the documentation submitted by both sides, a formal hearing not being required; accordingly, based upon consideration of the factors bearing on the issue of removal ( CPL 210.43, subd 2, pars [a]-[h]),  [***3] removal in defendant's case is not warranted since the proof is sufficient for indictment, no mitigating circumstances exist and defendant was not merely a minor participant; furthermore, considering the severity of the crimes charged, the sodomization and murder of a young boy, community safety, welfare and confidence in its legal system overwhelmingly dictate that the State not be compelled to forego a full scale criminal prosecution, with the outcome and result commensurate with legislative and community standards.

 

2053 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Watts v. McGuire


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 711; 424 N.Y.S.2d 327; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2916



December 18, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment is denied and the defendants' motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is granted.

Settle Order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city and police commissioner, and plaintiff police officers both filed motions for summary judgment in the officers' action that sought to invalidate New York City, N.Y., Charter § 822, which provided that every applicant for city employment had to agree that if he became a non-resident, he would pay an amount equal to the resident city income tax.


OVERVIEW: The officers resided outside New York City and were required to pay the amount of their city income tax pursuant to § 822. The court granted summary judgment in favor of defendants because § 822 was not inconsistent with N.Y. Pub. Off. Law §§ 3(2), 30(4) which prohibited a municipality from denying nonresidents appointment to its police force or removing a officer because he was a non-resident. New York City, N.Y., Charter § 822 was a valid condition of city employment, and it did not have a deterrent effect upon non-resident applications because a large percentage of the city employees were non-residents of New York City. Section 822 was not violative of New York Const. art. V, § 6, which required that appointments and promotions were to be made according to merit and fitness, because N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 23(4)(a) provided that residency requirements were consistent with the concept of merit and fitness. New York City, N.Y., Charter § 822 did not impair the officers contract obligations and rights because it did not alter any of the qualifications for the officers that were set forth in the notice of civil service examination.


OUTCOME: The court denied the officers' motion for summary judgment and granted defendants' motion for summary judgment in the officers' action that sought to have a portion of the New York City Charter invalidated which required that applicants for city employment had to agree to pay an amount that was equal to the resident city income tax in the event that they became a non-residents.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Personal Income Tax -- City Tax on Nonresident City Employees

1. Section 822 of the New York City Charter, which provides that all New York City employees who are or become nonresidents of the City of New York shall agree to pay to the city an amount equal to the New York City resident income tax less any city earnings or personal income tax imposed on them during the same taxable period, is a valid condition of city employment and does not constitute a de facto residency requirement as it is common knowledge that a large percentage of New York City employees reside out of the City of New York; consequently, the statute, in and of itself, is not inconsistent with subdivision 4 of section 30 of the Public Officers Law which prohibits certain municipalities from removing a police officer from his office on the grounds of nonresidency, nor is it inconsistent with subdivision 2 of section 3 of the Public Officers Law which prohibits a municipality from denying certain nonresidents appointment [***2] to its police force.

Taxation -- Personal Income Tax -- City Tax on Nonresident City Employees

2. Section 822 of the New York City Charter, which requires New York City employees who are or become nonresidents of the city to pay to the city an amount equal to the New York City resident income tax less any city earnings or personal income tax imposed on them during the same taxable period, does not violate section 6 of article V of the New York Constitution, which mandates that civil service appointments and promotions shall be made according to merit and fitness, since section 822 does not constitute a de facto residency statute favoring less qualified resident civil service applicants over more qualified nonresidents; moreover, assuming arguendo that section 822 does act as a de facto residency statute, it would not be violative of the New York Constitution since the residency restrictions imposed by section 822 do not limit appointment to residents of particular areas less than a recognized political subdivision of the State and since the statute is consistent with the residency provisions of subdivision 4-a of section 23 of the Civil Service Law.

 [***3] Taxation -- Personal Income Tax -- City Tax on Nonresident City Employees

3. Section 822 of the New York City Charter, which requires nonresident New York City employees to pay to the city an amount equal to the New York City resident income tax less any city earnings or personal income tax imposed on them during the same taxable period, does not impose additional qualifications with respect to residency to those residency requirements set forth in the notice of civil service examination and, consequently, section 822 does not unconstitutionally impair the contract obligations and rights of nonresident New York City police officers; section 822 does not prohibit police officers from residing in the counties enumerated in the notice of examination but rather requires that the applicable employees shall be subject to a tax.

 

2054 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Magee


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 345; 423 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2869



December 12, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, The People of the State of New York, filed motions for summary judgment, for permanent injunction, and to punish defendant business owner for contempt of a preliminary injunction in an action brought pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 213-b. The state's action sought to shut down the defendant's activities, which consisted of selling written materials designed to aid students in cheating on college and graduate level academic assignments.


OVERVIEW: The state had obtained a preliminary injunction issued against the business owner, which enjoined the business owner and his agents from selling prepared texts to be palmed off as student-completed work on the state's college campuses. With regard to state's summary judgment motion, the business owner argued that the Education Law prohibited the rendering of assistance for hire, and his products were not "assistance" but rather publications entitled to First Amendment protection. Upon review, the court held that the business owner's arguments were specious and that there was no genuine issue of material fact to preclude the entry of summary judgment. The court found that the materials sold by the business owner did not fall within the exception to subdivision 4 of § 213-b provided for copyrighted materials. The court held that the state was entitled to a permanent injunction and that the business owner had grossly flouted the terms of the preliminary injunction. The court also held that the business owner could not argue that he had insufficient service of the injunction because the evidence showed he had actual knowledge of it and was privy to every stage of the litigation.


OUTCOME: The court directed that a permanent injunction be issued, found the business owner in contempt of the preliminary injunction, and imposed a fine upon the business owner in the sum of $ 1,000, which was the sum of $ 250 on each of the four contempts established.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Colleges and Universities -- Unlawful Sale of Research Papers

1. The State is granted summary judgment permanently enjoining defendant from selling materials designed and tailored for student cheating in the course of preparing college and graduate level academic assignments since there are no triable issues of fact as to defendant's good faith in that the typewritten papers, in a format designed for direct submission as completed works in specific undergraduate or graduate courses, taken together with defendant's seductive sales literature, are full proof of unlawful intended use (Education Law, § 213-b) and the disavowal of plagiaristic intent which the paper buyer ritualistically signs is merely a subterfuge which does not raise a genuine issue of fact.

Contempt -- Service of Certified Copy of Order -- Actual Notice

2. Defendant may be punished for contemptuous defiance of a preliminary injunction (Judiciary Law, § 750, subd A, par 3) prohibiting him from continuing to sell materials designed and tailored for student cheating in undergraduate and graduate courses (Education Law, § 213-b) even though he was not personally served with a certified copy of the [***2] preliminary injunction ( CPLR 5104) since the service of a copy of the order to show cause on defendant's attorney as permitted by statute in civil contempt proceedings (Judiciary Law, § 761; CPLR 2103, subd [b]) is a sufficient foundation for a finding of willful contempt where defendant, by his active involvement in contesting the issuance of the preliminary injunction, had actual notice of the court order, a party having actual knowledge of the mandate of a court being subject to punishment for contempt even though not personally served with a certified copy of the order allegedly disobeyed; in light of the scope of defendant's interstate business and the manner in which he advertised and purveyed his wares, there is "no room for reasonable doubt or dispute" as to the extent of the contempt and, therefore, no hearing is required on the question of his willfulness in violating the temporary injunction.

 

2055 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Zubli v. Community Mainstreaming Associates, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


102 Misc. 2d 320; 423 N.Y.S.2d 982; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2867



December 11, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners brought an action against defendants, adjacent landowners, nonprofit corporation, and others, to permanently enjoin the threatened use by the corporation of the easement over the property owners' driveway for other than its intended use as a means of egress and ingress. The property owners argued, inter alia, that use of the adjacent residence for the mentally disabled violated the terms of the easement.


OVERVIEW: The property owners argued that the use of the adjacent residence as a facility for mentally disabled adults violated the terms of the easement and violated the property owners' constitutional rights. The property owners also argued that the Padavan Law, N.Y. Mental Hyg. § 41.34 was unconstitutional as applied. The adjacent landowners, the nonprofit corporation, and others filed motions to dismiss the property owners' complaint and for summary judgment. The court held that: (1) the property owners' the complaint failed to state a cause of action against the adjacent landowners who conveyed the property to the nonprofit corporation; (2) the nonprofit corporation's proposed use did not violate the easement because there were no words of restriction in the easement other than that it was to be used for egress and ingress; and (3) the Padavan Law was constitutional because the law was an act of general legislation and therefore required neither notice nor a public hearing to effect the desired change. The court concluded that the property owners' action had to be dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the adjacent landowners, the nonprofit corporation, and others in an action by property owners regarding the use of an easement over the property owners' driveway.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Easements -- Violation of Easement -- Proper Parties

1. An action by owners of a servient estate seeking damages and an injunction for alleged violations of an easement is dismissed against the previous owners of the dominant estate since they cannot be enjoined from passing title where they have already done so, and since they made no representations or warranties regarding the easement of which plaintiffs were the beneficiaries; in addition, plaintiffs' cause of action against the mortagee of the dominant estate, who consented to defendant community residential facility's assumption of the mortgage held by the prior owners of the dominant estate, for violation of a mortgage covenant restricting use of the mortgaged premises to a one- or two-family dwelling, is dismissed since plaintiffs have failed to show that they were a party to said mortgage or that they or their grantors were intended to be benefited by the restriction therein; unless a mortgage provides otherwise, covenants in a mortgage bind the heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns of the mortgagor, and inure to the benefit of the heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns of the mortgagee [***2] and there is nothing in the mortgage that expressly provides for any benefit to plaintiffs or their predecessors in title.

Easements -- Scope of Easement

2. In determining whether a community residential facility's use of an easement, previously used by a single-family residence, violates and overburdens the easement, the language of the easement is controlling, and where the easement provides only for "egress and ingress" with no other words of restriction, the dominant estate is entitled to use the easement for egress and ingress as is necessary; a reference in the easement to the right of the occupants of the dominant estate to erect two name signs does not evidence an intention to restrict the dominant estate to one- or two-family use; furthermore, a change in the use of the dominant estate does not, in the absence of any qualifications, change the use of the easement.

Mental Health -- Licensing of Community Residential Facilities -- Due Process

3. Section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which, without providing for notice and a public hearing, sets forth a procedure for site selection and licensing of community residential facilities for the mentally disabled [***3] and deems such facilities family units, does not effectuate a zoning change in violation of constitutional due process since section 41.314 is an act of general legislation and due process notice and hearing requirements are only applicable in quasi-judicial or adjudicatory settings; section 41.314 is not an unconstitutional exercise of local zoning authority by the State but rather an exercise of the State's fundamental police power for the public good and welfare, and as such, the State or its agency is exempt from local regulatory control; in addition, property owners in a particular zone have no vested right in the continuance of a particular zoning classification; statutes are presumed to be constitutional and challenged legislation should not be declared unconstitutional unless it is manifestly invalid.

Mental Health -- Licensing of Community Residential Facilities -- State Taking Without Just Compensation

4. Section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which sets forth a procedure for site selection and licensing of community residential facilities for the mentally disabled and deems such facilities family units, does not provide for an unconstitutional State taking [***4] without just compensation of property adjacent to the residential facilities, or of the rights of property owners subject to established easements benefiting the property on which the residential facility would be situated since there is no "taking" of such property either by physical invasion or by direct legal restraint of its use; adjacent property owners are not deprived of their property because the State's use of a contiguous property decreases neighboring land values; in addition, a property owner is not deprived of his property should the State choose to properly use a valid easement which was established prior to State use of the dominant estate.

Mental Health -- Licensing of Community Residential Facilities -- Reasonableness of Statute

5. Section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which provides a procedure for establishing and licensing community residential facilities for the mentally disabled, is not an unreasonable exercise of the State's police power simply because the statute may have a detrimental effect on plaintiffs in that the property proposed for a residential facility has the benefit of an easement over plaintiffs' property; the statute meets the test [***5] of reasonableness since there is no encroachment on the exercise of private rights without substantial relation to a legitimate governmental purpose; in addition, the appropriate sites for residential facilities are to be determined by the Commissioner of the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities and not the courts.

Mental Health -- Licensing of Community Residential Facilities -- Local Zoning Ordinances

6. Article 7 of the Village Law, which provides that local zoning ordinances, once enacted, may not be changed or amended by the municipality without complying with the prescribed notice and hearing requirements, is not applicable to section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law which provided that community residential facilities shall be deemed family units, since section 41.34 is enacted by the State Legislature.

 

2056 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ass'n of Surrogate's & Supreme Court Reporters v. Evans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


102 Misc. 2d 883; 424 N.Y.S.2d 818; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2928



December 11, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner court reporter's association brought an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondents, Chief Administrative Judge of the State of New York and court administrative officials, to challenge a directive by respondents that barred court reporter II employees from possessing firearms.


OVERVIEW: Respondents issued a directive declaring that all court reporter II employees were barred from possessing firearms. The court reporter's association brought an action to contest the directive and argued that all court reporter II employee's were peace officials under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 1.20(33)(b) and that the directive was arbitrary and capricious and violated the employee's right to equal protection. The court rendered judgment in favor of the court reporter's association and found that although § 1.20(33)(b) was ambiguous, the statute had long been interpreted to include court reporter II employee within the definition of peace officer. Respondents' directive was an illegal attempt to legislate under the guise of interpretation of the statute. The court also found that the directive violated the affected employees equal protection rights because the directive did not apply to court clerks and law clerks who were similarly situated with respect to peacekeeping functions and the carrying of firearms. Finally, the court found that the directive was an improper attempt to regulate the off-premises, off-duty conduct of reporters in a manner unrelated to their employment.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the court reporter's association in their action against respondents and declared respondents' directive barring court reporter II employees from possessing firearms to be null and void.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Nonjudicial Personnel -- Court Reporters

1. Court reporters are officials of the court and, therefore, peace officers pursuant to CPL 1.20 (subd 33, par [b]) who are entitled to carry firearms; CPL 1.20 (subd 33) is a vague and ambiguous statute which may not be construed by administrative directive to operate to the detriment of the court reporters, who may be liable for criminal prosecution pursuant to the administrative interpretation of the statute, a result that is shocking to the judicial conscience; the interpretation of CPL 1.20 (subd 33, par [b]) by administrative directive to prohibit the carrying of firearms by court reporters is unlawful, arbitrary, capricious and an abuse of discretion.

Courts -- Nonjudicial Personnel -- Court Reporters

2. Court reporters, who are similarly situated to law clerks, are equally involved with peacekeeping duties and disparate treatment with respect to the right to carry firearms as peace officers ( CPL 1.20, subd 33, par [b]) is discriminatory and has no rational basis; therefore, the administrative directive prohibiting court reporters from carrying firearms violates the equal protection clause of the New [***2] York State Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, as there is no rational relationship between the distinction drawn between the two classes of employees and the objective of the regulation, public safety.

Courts -- Nonjudicial Personnel -- Court Reporters

3. An administrative directive prohibiting court reporters, who are peace officers pursuant to CPL 1.20 (subd 33, par [b]), from carrying firearms exceeds the scope of lawful governmental purpose and is arbitrary, unreasonable and an abuse of discretion since it does not merely regulate but imposes a blanket prohibition against the use and possession of firearms by court reporters while off duty and off premises; a directive must have a reasonable connection with employment.

 

2057 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rubin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Queens County


103 Misc. 2d 227; 424 N.Y.S.2d 592; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2941



December 6, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the complaint charging him with the unlawful practice of medicine in violation of N.Y. Educ. Law § 6512 on the ground that the statute defining the offense charged was unconstitutional and otherwise invalid pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.35.


OVERVIEW: Defendant offered hair implants for people with baldness. His procedure involved injecting a client's scalp with anesthetic, implanting synthetic hair fibers by attaching fibers to a needle and injecting the needle into the scalp, and removing the needle to leave the fibers in the scalp. Defendant contended that § 6512 defining the unlawful practice of medicine was unconstitutional and that his synthetic hair implantation process was a non-medical procedure. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, finding that § 6512 was a constitutional exercise of the legislature's power to regulate for the protection of the public welfare. The court concluded that the determination of whether defendant's enterprise constituted "the practice of medicine" was a question of fact to be resolved at trial. The court indicated that relevant factors would include the physical setup of defendant's office, the presence of persons who appeared to be nurses or doctors, questions concerning allergies or reactions to anesthetics, the procedure's description, the possible effects of the procedure, and implications from the acts performed such as injections and providing antibiotics for infections.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss. The court found that § 6512 was a constitutional exercise of the legislature's power to regulate for the protection of the public welfare and that the issue of whether the implantation of synthetic hair constituted the practice of medicine was a question of fact to be determined at trial.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Physicians and Surgeons - Unlawful Practice of Medicine - Synthetic Hair Implantation

The statutes proscribing the practice of medicine without a license (Education Law, §§ 6512, 6521, 6522) are a constitutional exercise of the Legislature's power to regulate for the protection of the public welfare and the question of whether or not a defendant has violated the restrictions on the practice of medicine is a question of fact to be determined on all the evidence adduced on trial taking into consideration such factors as whether there was a diagnosis determining a disease, infirmity or physical condition, whether there was a remedy or treatment prescribed, whether the act or acts performed by the defendant were such as to endanger the public health and whether the defendant invaded the territory of the profession by specific actions solely within the province of a duly trained and knowledgeable medical practitioner; accordingly, defendant may properly be charged with the unlawful practice of medicine for performing synthetic hair implants, a potentially dangerous procedure involving actual injection into the scalp of local anesthetics, piercing the scalp with a needle similar [***2] to a suture, implanting of the synthetic fibers within the integrity of the human body, diagnosing the presence or absence of an infection and the providing of antibiotic pills to combat a possible infection, since, the trier of a fact could find a direct or implied holding out by the defendant that he was able to treat patients for physical ills taking into consideration such factors as the physical setup of his office, the presence of persons who appear to be nurses or doctors, questions concerning any allergies or reactions to anesthetics, the description of the procedure to be utilized and the possible results or effects to be anticipated at the procedure's conclusion.

 

2058 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Diaz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 817; 424 N.Y.S.2d 590; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2924



December 4, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The guardian of a child alleged to be the out-of-wedlock child of a decedent petitioned for letters of administration. The mother of the decedent filed a cross petition for letters of administration.


OVERVIEW: No formality of proof that the decedent was the father of the child had ever been established during the lifetime of the decedent. The child's guardian did not present any proof of the execution or filing of any acknowledgment of paternity by the alleged father. In dismissing the application for letters of administration by the guardian of the child, the court found that the out-of wedlock child not formally acknowledged or adjudged to be a child of a decedent could not demand letters of administration in the decedent's estate.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the application for letters of administration by the guardian of the child and granted the cross petition of the mother of the decedent for letters of administration.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Intestate Inheritance from Putative Father

1. An out-of-wedlock child not formally acknowledged or adjudged to be a child of a decedent is precluded from demanding an accounting of the intestate estate of the putative father and cannot demand letters of administration in the putative father's estate. Accordingly, the court dismissed the application for letters of administration by the guardian of such an infant and granted the cross petition of the mother of the decedent for letters of administration.

Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Proceeds of Action for Wrongful Death of Putative Father

2. A formal indication of paternity is not required for a child born out of wedlock to be made a party to an accounting of an action for the wrongful death of the putative father, since wrongful death proceeds do not pass through the estate, but redound directly to those persons who are found to have been supported by the decedent or are entitled to or can expect support by the decedent, and have, therefore, been deprived by reason of the wrongful death of the decedent.

 

2059 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Zongone


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Yonkers, Westchester County


102 Misc. 2d 265; 423 N.Y.S.2d 400; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2857



December 3, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss information charging him with disorderly conduct. Defendant alleged that the information was defective because the statute defining the offense was unconstitutional or otherwise invalid under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a) and 170.35 (1)(c), or that dismissal was required in the furtherance of justice within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and three others were charged with disorderly conduct for cursing in public at a passerby and a police officer. Defendant moved to dismiss the information charging him with disorderly conduct, on grounds that the information was defective because the statute defining the offense was unconstitutional or otherwise invalid under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a) and 170.35 (1)(c), or that dismissal was required in the furtherance of justice within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40. The court denied defendant's motion. The court ruled that the New York statute was constitutional because it was directed against utterances which would or could inflict possible public alarm or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace, and was not limited to speech alone. The court also noted that a complaint charging disorderly conduct need not state the charge with the precision required of an indictment. The court also denied defendant's request pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40, because he failed to show some compelling factor, consideration, or circumstance clearly demonstrating that conviction or prosecution would constitute or result in injustice.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the New York disorderly conduct statute was constitutional because it was directed against utterances which would or could inflict possible public alarm or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace, and was not limited to speech alone.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Obscene Language

1. Subdivision 3 of section 240.20 of the Penal Law, which provides that a "person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof * * * [in] a public place, he uses abusive or obscene language", is constitutional on its face since the Court of Appeals has upheld the statute as it has been consistently applied in New York only to instances involving the use of language which provokes or creates the risk of an "immediate breach of the peace"; furthermore, there is a strong presumption of constitutionality and no unresolvable conflict between the Constitution and the statute exists.

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct

2. A complaint charging disorderly conduct (Penal Law, § 240.20) need not state the charge with the precision required of an indictment; a judgment of conviction will be affirmed if evidence establishes a violation of any of the subdivisions of the disorderly conduct statute.

Crimes -- Dismissal in Furtherance of Justice

3. Defendant is not entitled to dismissal in the furtherance of justice which is permitted [***2] in the discretion of the court when "some compelling factor, consideration or circumstance clearly demonstrating that conviction or prosecution of the defendant * * * would constitute or result in injustice" ( CPL 170.40) upon a motion to dismiss since he has failed to show the prerequisite facts; the questions defendant raises must be resolved by a trial of the issues.

 

2060 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Atkinson v. Ormont Machine Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


102 Misc. 2d 468; 423 N.Y.S.2d 577; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2894



December 3, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, Acme's motion is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant seller filed a motion to dismiss that part of plaintiff employee's fourth cause of action and the entire fifth cause of action as predicated the liability of the seller on the doctrine of breach of warranty in an action involving an alleged defective machine part.


OVERVIEW: The purchaser bought a machine that contained an alleged defective part. Subsequently, the machine and its alleged defective part injured the employee of the purchaser. Thereafter, the employee filed a breach of warranty action against the seller of the alleged defective part. The seller filed a motion to dismiss the employee's fourth cause of action and the entire fifth cause of action. The trial court denied the motions. The court furthered the object, spirit, and purpose of U.C.C. § 2-318 (1962). The court declared that the remedy of breach of warranty of contract was available to the employee, even though he lacked privity and was only an employee user of the goods sold by the seller of the alleged defective part. Accordingly, the seller's motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: In a breach of warranty action involving an alleged defective machine part, the court denied the seller's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Sales -- Warranties -- Third-Party Beneficiaries

Under section 2-318 of the Uniform Commercial Code, as amended (L 1975, ch 774), which strips the privity of contract requirement in actions for breach of warranty and declares that a seller's warranty, whether express or implied, extends to any natural person who is injured by breach of the warranty if it is reasonable to expect that such person may use, consume or be affected by the goods, an employee user of goods purchased by his employer is the statutorily defined "any natural person", and if he is injured by a defective product, he has a cause of action in breach of warranty of contract against the seller even though he lacks privity; the court sitting in original jurisdiction will not annul said statute, since it has not been declared unconstitutional, nor will it assume that the Court of Appeals intended to usurp the function of the Legislature by withdrawing the statutory remedy and substituting in its place one of judicial creation, namely, strict products liability, although the court may grant said remedy in addition thereto.

 

2061 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Y.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 215; 423 N.Y.S.2d 394; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2847



December 3, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is hereby dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: An appellate court vacated a trial court's termination of the respondent parent's rights and remanded the case for a new trial. On remand, petitioner children's agency submitted its case file through a supervisor with no personal knowledge of the case, and the parent submitted the transcript from the prior trial.


OVERVIEW: The agency brought neglect proceedings against the parent and had the daughter placed in a foster home under the agency's supervision. The agency obtained termination of the parent's rights by default, and the foster parents adopted the daughter. The parent unsuccessfully sought to vacate the default, then prevailed in the appellate division. The appellate court vacated the default and ordered a new trial because the trial court terminated her rights based on a "best interests" test and not on N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b. The case was remanded for fact finding through the trial court's observations of the witnesses and the parties. In the new trial, the agency's petition was dismissed, and the court held that the agency failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the parent failed to plan for the future of her child despite diligent efforts of the agency to encourage and strengthen the parental relationship. The court found that the agency failed to meet its obligations to use diligent efforts, to help the parent develop a plan for the child, and to advise the parent of how her parental rights might be terminated.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the agency's petition and found that it failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the parent failed to plan for the future of her child despite diligent efforts of the agency to encourage and strengthen the parental relationship.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Plan for Child's Future

1.
