A child welfare agency which has placed a child in foster care due to the parent's inability to care for the child has an obligation, pursuant to section 384-b (subd 7, pars [a], [f]) of the Social Services Law, to make diligent efforts to assist in the formulation of viable proposals to develop a reasonable plan for the child's future and to encourage and strengthen the parental relationship with the child unless it were to prove detrimental to the child's best interests since the parent is severely disadvantaged, being burdened with economic, emotional, mental and physical problems and the agency has expertise experience, capital and manpower, and efforts correlative to its superiority are obligatory; therefore, the agency having failed to inform the parent of her responsibility to plan for the future of her child or to assist her in developing a plan for the child's future, the agency failed in its duty to the parent and child, the parent's rights to her child may not be terminated due to her failure to plan for the future of her child [***2] (Social Services Law, § 384-b, subd 7, par [a]).

Parent and Child -- Abused or Neglected Child -- Testimony at Hearing

2. There is particular importance in child custody, visitation or neglect proceedings that factual findings be made by the trial court which has the best ability to measure the credibility of witnesses. The court was deprived in this child neglect proceeding of the opportunity to determine credibility through observing the demeanor of witnesses giving testimony by the failure of both the child welfare agency and the mother of the infant to testify before the court, and instead submitting a case record and a transcript from a previous hearing, thereby denying the court the opportunity to consider the appearance, attitude and demeanor of witnesses in testing veracity and determining the weight to be accorded their testimony.

 

2062 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mobil Oil Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Criminal Part, Nassau County


101 Misc. 2d 882; 422 N.Y.S.2d 589; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2783



November 26, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion to dismiss the informations is granted, and the two informations in both above-entitled actions are hereby dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state filed two informations against defendant oil company, alleging that the oil company violated the Nassau County Fire Prevention, N.Y., Ordinance No. 58-1962 because pumps used by the oil company in the transfer of gasoline from underground storage tanks to the dispensing units had no leak detection devices installed on the discharge side of the pumps. The oil company filed a motion for dismissal of the two informations.


OVERVIEW: The state charged the oil companies with violating Ordinance No. 58-1962, and the oil company filed a motion to dismiss the informations, alleging that the informations were jurisdictionally defective because they did not set forth any misdemeanor that was grounded upon a valid provision of law and that the provisions of Ordinance No. 58-1962 were constitutionally defective. The court dismissed the informations and held that the legislature of the county did not merely incorporate the rules or standards of a private association. The county provided that the provisions of the National Fire Protection Association (association) rules and standards, as amended, were deemed part of the ordinance. By enacting the association's amendments, prior to their adoption, the county delegated to the association sovereign and legislative power. The county relinquished all control over the ordinance pertaining to flammable and combustible liquids to the association, which was an improper delegation of legislative authority, and, therefore, it was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the informations against the oil companies in the state's action alleging violations of a county fire prevention ordinance.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Improper Delegation of Legislative Authority

Informations charging defendant with the failure to install leak detection devices on the discharge side of pumps used in the transfer of gasoline from underground storage tanks to dispensing units in violation of a local ordinance must be dismissed since the standards describing the prohibited conduct as set forth in the ordinance are stated to be those standards of the National Fire Protection Association which are currently in effect or as may be amended; the use of such standards, the violation of which becomes conduct malum prohibitum and, therefore, requires both a clear description of the proscribed conduct and strict construction of the ordinance involved, represents an improper delegation of legislative authority to a private agency, in that not only are the standards of such agency definitive of illegal conduct, but also any amendments to those standards which the association chooses to adopt in the future become a part of the ordinance; such a delegation [***2] involves the unconstitutional relinquishment of all control by the local legislature regarding the discretionary determination what is or is not permissible.

 

2063 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Martz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Ulster County


102 Misc. 2d 102; 423 N.Y.S.2d 378; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2830



November 26, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the putative father of a child who was the subject of an adoption proceeding, moved for an order pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 114 opening, vacating, and/or setting aside an order of adoption on the ground of fraud and other sufficient cause. Petitioner contended that N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §§ 111 and 111-a were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The putative father of a child who was the subject of an adoption proceeding, moved to open, set aside, or vacate an order of adoption on the ground of fraud. Petitioner argued that N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §§ 111 and 111-a were unconstitutional. The court held that no notice of an adoption proceeding was required to be given to a putative father who did not qualify under any of the provisions of § 111-a. Further, the court held that since § 111-a did not require any notice to be given of the adoption proceeding, the mother or the adoptive father's knowledge of petitioner's claim to the parentage of the child was irrelevant and without legal significance. That being the case, neither the mother nor the adoptive father could have been charged with committing any fraud upon the court for failing to do that which the law clearly did not require them to do. Because New York had a legitimate state interest in enacting § 111-a and in establishing a putative father registry, the court held that it found no constitutional infirmity in the statute. The court denied petitioner's application to be permitted access to the records of the adoption.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's application to be permitted access to the records of the adoption.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Notice to Putative Father

1. The court in an adoption proceeding involving an out-of-wedlock child is under no obligation to exercise its discretion (Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 3) and require that the petitioning adoptive parent give notice of the proceeding to a putative father who does not fall within any of the seven categories of putative fathers entitled to notice of an adoption proceeding (Domestic Relations Law, § 111-a) and whose consent to the adoption was not legally required (Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 1, par [c]).

Adoption -- Notice to Putative Father -- Information Concerning Mother's Relationship with Putative Father

2. Since no notice of an adoption proceeding involving an out-of-wedlock child is required to be given to a putative father who does not fall within any of the seven categories of putative fathers entitled to notice of an adoption proceeding (Domestic Relations Law, § 111-a), the fact that the natural mother and her husband, the adoptive father, knew that such putative father had instituted a paternity proceeding prior to the signing of the adoption order is irrelevant, without legal significance and [***2] insufficient to vacate a consummated adoption; since the adoptive father, the only real party in interest, is in no way bound by any adjudication that might be made in the putative father's paternity proceeding, he cannot be charged with the legal consequences of knowledge, actual or imputed, of the putative father's asserted claim to fatherhood; neither the mother nor the adoptive father can be charged with committing any fraud upon the court for failing to do that which the law clearly did not require them to do and since information concerning the full extent of the relationship between the mother and the putative father is irrelevant to the decision to approve the adoption as being in the best interests of the child, the mother's failure to disclose such information to the court does not constitute a fraud sufficient to warrant vacating and setting aside the adoption.

Adoption -- Adoption of Child Born out of Wedlock -- Investigation of Relationship between Mother and Putative Father

3. The court is not obligated to require an investigation into the social history of the natural mother and the putative father before approving the adoption of the mother's out-of-wedlock [***3] child by her husband since the areas the preadoption investigation are required to cover only concern the adoptive parents and the adoptive child (Domestic Relations Law, § 116, subd 3) and, even if certain information concerning the mother's mental and emotional instability were revealed by a thorough and in-depth investigation into the illicit relationship between the mother and the putative father, such information, no matter how derogatory, could not in any way be significant or relevant to the court's decision to approve or disapprove the stepfather's application for the adoption of the child, the character and fitness of the adoptive parent being the primary concern in the proceeding and the only role of the child's mother being to grant her consent to the adoption (Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 1, par [c]).

Adoption -- Consent to Adoption -- Constitutionality of Statute

4. Section 111 of the Domestic Relations Law, insofar as it requires the consent of only the mother of an out-of-wedlock child to its adoption, is unconstitutional (see Caban v Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380).

Adoption -- Notice to Putative Father -- Constitutionality of Statutory Notice  [***4] Requirements

5. The fact that section 111-a of the Domestic Relations Law requires that notice of an adoption proceeding involving an out-of-wedlock child be given to seven enumerated categories of putative fathers, but does not require that notice of the proceeding be given to all putative fathers, does not deny due process and equal protection of the laws to those putative fathers not covered by the statute since the statute's classification of putative fathers is rational and reasonable and not palpably arbitrary in that the purpose of the statute is to dispel uncertainies by providing clear constitutional statutory guidelines for notice to putative fathers, establish finality in adoption proceedings, provide an expeditious method for child placement agencies to ascertain those fathers who are entitled to notice and afford concerned fathers of out-of-wedlock children a simple means of expressing their interest and protecting their rights to notice and an opportunity to be heard; in any event, there is no need to pass on the constitutionality of the statute since the putative father would not benefit from a finding of unconstitutionality in this case, he does not fall within [***5] any of the classifications of putative fathers who are affected by the statute and thus lacks standing to attack the statute vicariously by asserting grounds not personal to him and, finally, a court of first instance should not declare a statute unconstitutional except in rare cases involving life and liberty and where the invalidity of act is apparent on its face.

Adoption -- Consent to Adoption -- Retroactive Application of Declaration of Unconstitutionality

6. Even if a decision of the United States Supreme Court ( Caban v Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380), declaring section 111 of the Domestic Relations Law unconstitutional insofar as it requires only the mother's consent to the adoption of an out-of-wedlock child, may be applied retroactively to adoptions consummated without a putative father's consent on the basis of the statute, since the putative father herein did not participate in the adoption proceeding and did not raise the constitutional issue until after the adoption had been consummated just prior to the Caban decision, his application to vacate the order of adoption comes too late and, accordingly, Caban will not be given retroactive application; moreover,  [***6] the trauma that would be inflicted upon the child, mother and the adoptive father argues strongly and persuasively against any retroactive application of the Caban decision to this adoption; the putative father has not shown sufficient "good cause" to inspect the sealed court records of the consummated adoption. (Domestic Relations Law, § 114.)

 

2064 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cully Realty, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Sixth District, Suffolk County


102 Misc. 2d 557; 423 N.Y.S.2d 785; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2906



November 20, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant corporation was charged with having violated a building zone ordinance, Brookhaven, N.Y., Code § 85-23(A), (B), in that it permitted the premises to be used for a nonpermitted use by operating a real estate business in a residential district.


OVERVIEW: The corporation admitted during trial that it operated a real estate business. The corporation argued that the ordinance did not state that the operation of a real estate agency was prohibited. The court concluded that the ordinance failed the void for vagueness test because the corporation was not given sufficient notice that its conduct was prohibited by the ordinance. The court explained that the factual part of the information alleged that the corporation permitted the premises to be used for a non-permitted use, but nowhere in Brookhaven, N.Y., Code §§ 85-23, 85-7 was the operation of a real estate agency defined as a business and the operation of a real estate agency was not prohibited or even mentioned. The court noted that nowhere in the ordinance was it specifically provided that the term "professional person" did not include a real estate agent or broker. The court concluded that the ordinance was impermissibly vague because the corporation was not given prior notice of the ordinance requirements and town investigators and the courts were not given explicit standards by which uniform application of the ordinance could have been effected.


OUTCOME: The court held that certain subdivisions of the ordinance were unconstitutional in violation of due process. The court determined that the corporation could not have been properly charged with the violation of the ordinances, so it was not guilty of the violation charged.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Operation of Real Estate Agency in Residential District

Under the two-pronged void for vagueness test, a statute must first be sufficiently definite so as to provide a fair notice of the required or prohibited conduct, and, second, the statute must provide explicit and objective standards by which a violation may be determined; accordingly, applying such test, a town zoning ordinance which prohibits the operation of a business in a residential district but permits the incidental use of a residence for an office of a "physician, lawyer, architect, teacher or similar professional person residing on the premises", is unconstitutionally vague since defendant realty agency, which is charged with operating a real estate agency from the residence of its sole stockholder in violation of the ordinance, is not given sufficient prior notice that its conduct is prohibited by the ordinance in that nowhere in the ordinance is the operation of a real estate agency defined as a "business" and nowhere is the term "professional person" defined; in order to determine whether defendant violated the permitted accessory use ordinance, the court would have to undertake [***2] a cumbersome analysis to determine whether a real estate agent is a "similar professional person" thereby making objective and uniform enforcement of the ordinance impossible.

 

2065 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re P.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


101 Misc. 2d 918; 422 N.Y.S.2d 570; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2789



November 7, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner maternal grandparents sought to adopt their grandson born out of wedlock. Respondent father opposed the adoption.


OVERVIEW: The mother consented to the adoption. The maternal grandparents' argued that, as a matter of law, the father had no absolute right to veto the adoption of his child and even if he did possess such a right, he forfeited it by abandoning the infant. The father contended that he was in the army and was later discharged for a mental breakdown for which he was hospitalized for six or seven months. He claimed that he visited the baby and phoned to inquire about the child's welfare and thus, did not abandon the child. He contended that in the absence of a finding of abandonment, his consent was required to the adoption. The court found in favor of the father, and held that the maternal grandparents failed to prove abandonment. Thus, the father had the absolute right as a matter of law to veto the granting of the adoption application. While the father's relationship with his child fell short of that of a model parent, there was no proof that he purposefully failed to fulfill his parental obligations and was willing to decline his parental rights.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the father.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Consent -- Right of Nonmarital Father to Refuse Consent to Adoption

1. A nonmarital father has an absolute right to veto the adoption of his child pursuant to section 111 of the Domestic Relations Law, which, interpreted in light of the equal protection clause, must be applied in a manner not based solely on gender classifications, unless his consent is not required because abandonment is proven.

Adoption -- Abandonment

2. A nonmarital father who was separated from an infant's mother at his birth, joined the army and thereafter required months of hospitalization for a nervous breakdown cannot be considered to have willfully abandoned his child pursuant to section 111 (subd 2, par [a]) of the Domestic Relations Law throughout the duration of his mental disability which interfered with the exercise of his parental responsibility and concern; he has attempted to maintain contact with the infant and has indicated a willingness to support the child; therefore, as abandonment has not been established by the preponderance of the credible evidence, the infant may not be adopted without the father's consent.

 

2066 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hale v. Jay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Town of Greenburgh, Westchester County


101 Misc. 2d 636; 421 N.Y.S.2d 802; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2736



November 2, 1979 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Recall of Original Decision, December 11, 1979.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The county filed charges against defendant for violating the county's consumer protection code by making false and misleading representations to a customer. Defendant filed a motion alleging that the code was unconstitutional and requesting an order for a bill of particulars, discovery and inspection, a pre-trial Sandoval hearing, and dismissal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, who ran a water control business, allegedly made false and misleading representations to a customer in connection with eliminating the wetness and flooding in the customer's basement. The county charged defendant with violating its consumer protection code, and defendant challenged the law's constitutionality. Defendant also requested an order for a bill of particulars, discovery and inspection, a pre-trial Sandoval hearing, and dismissal. The court affirmed the constitutionality of the code, granted the request for a pre-trial hearing, and issued a ruling as to the other issues in a separate memorandum. The court held that while defendant was entitled to attack the constitutionality of the code, he was required to overcome a strong presumption that the legislation was valid, and he failed to do so. Even though more precise language could have been used, this by itself did not invalidate the law, and it was an appropriate exercise of police power. However, even in a nonjury trial, defendant was entitled to a pre-trial hearing to obtain an advance ruling as to the use by the prosecution of evidence of defendant's prior convictions and bad acts for impeachment purposes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the constitutionality of the consumer protection code and granted defendant's motion for a pre-trial hearing. The court's determination as to defendant's request for a bill of particulars, discovery, and dismissal was set forth in a separate order.


HEADNOTES

Consumer Protection -- County Consumer Protection Code -- Constitutionality

1. A county Consumer Protection Code, which provides criminal sanctions for certain deceptive trade practices, is a constitutional exercise of police power in that the county has a legitimate interest in the rights of its citizens in their dealings with merchants, particularly where unfair practices may be involved; in addition, there is a fair and reasonable connection between the legislation and the promotion of public health, safety and welfare since the statutory scheme would encourage competent prosecution of offending merchants even where monetary damages are small and would avoid the difficulties involved in enforcing civil money judgments; furthermore, it is not fatal if the enactment incidentally criminalizes traditionally civil wrongdoing since the police power of the State and its subdivisions is broad and comprehensive and in its exercise an individual's conduct is invariably regulated to some degree.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Vagueness

2. A penal law, which must be construed according to the commonly accepted [***2] meaning of its language, is void for vagueness when it fails to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that his contemplated conduct is forbidden, but practical necessities may compel a legislative body to assign broad functions to an agency and leave to it the duty of bringing about the results pointed out by the statute; furthermore, when non-First Amendment rights are attacked, a statute is void for vagueness only if it is vague as applied to the precise circumstances of the individual case, and the fact that more precise language could have been employed in drawing a statute does not alone render it unconstitutional. There is a strong presumption that duly enacted legislation is constitutional and a court of first impression is not bound to set aside a law as unconstitutional unless that conclusion is inescapable and shown beyond a reasonable doubt.

Crimes -- Proof of Prior Convictions -- Nonjury Trial

3. A pretrial hearing to determine the admissibility of proof of a criminal defendant's prior convictions or proof of prior commission of specific criminal, vicious or immoral acts for the purpose of impeaching a defendant's credibility is available in a [***3] nonjury criminal trial, and the pretrial hearing shall be conducted by a Judge other than the one who will be the trier of the facts in order to ensure that the Trial Judge will not be subjected to any unfair influence during the course of the pretrial hearing; should the pretrial hearing result in the exclusion of any of the defendant's prior conviction records, such records should be placed in a specially marked envelope in the defendant's file so that it will not be viewed by the Trial Judge prior to rendering any decision.

 

2067 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


101 Misc. 2d 444; 421 N.Y.S.2d 176; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2698



October 29, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was tried by a jury after being indicted by a Grand Jury on several counts of robbery, grand larceny, and criminal possession of a weapon. The jury was discharged after it became deadlocked. On the eve of the second trial, defendant filed a motion for a hearing on the issue of whether the Grand Jury panel underrepresented Hispanics and women, or in the alternative, adjournment of the trial to await a decision.


OVERVIEW: Defense counsel alleged that he first became aware of a motion pending before a trial court judge that involved the issue of underrepresentation on the eve of the second trial. Defense counsel claimed that although the current motions were brought past the 45-day limit allotted for pretrial motions, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 255.20(3) allowed the court to entertain and dispose of the motion on the merits in its discretion and in the interest of justice. The court denied the motions. Any challenge to a trial jury panel was to be made in writing, and before the selection of the jury commenced, otherwise it was deemed waived. The selection of petit and grand jurors were interrelated and drawn from the same general pool. Therefore, challenges to either one were considered by the same standards. Logic could not accommodate the notion that at a certain point in time defendant lost his right to challenge the composition of the petit jury but retained, forever, the right to challenge the composition of the Grand Jury when both came from the same source. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.10(2) governed all challenges to the jury panel, and the motion was deemed untimely.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motions were denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Grand Jury -- 45-Day Limitation

Since a challenge to the composition of a Grand Jury is subject to the same 45-day limitation allotted for pretrial omnibus motions to challenge a trial jury panel ( CPL 270.10), the selection of petit and grand jurors being interrelated and drawn from the same general pool, an untimely motion to adjourn defendant's retrial pending the outcome of a constitutional challenge to the composition of the Kings County Grand Jury in another case, is denied; assuming, arguendo, that a decision is made that women and Hispanics were underrepresented in the Grand Jury panels due to an improper administration of the Judiciary Law, there is no reason to believe that such decision would be retroactively applicable to a jury impaneled prior to the date of the decision.

 

2068 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Shaw v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


101 Misc. 2d 864; 422 N.Y.S.2d 301; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2777



October 29, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner challenged the manner in which respondent corrections department computed the minimum and maximum term of his sentence for first-degree robbery. The corrections department added delinquent time onto petitioner's sentence and failed to credit him with time served under a prior reformatory sentence pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law art. 75.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner received a reformatory sentence under art. 75, which was later repealed, for a third-degree robbery conviction. Petitioner was later released on parole, was declared delinquent for over five months, and later pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery. The corrections department added the delinquency time onto the minimum sentence for the first-degree robbery conviction and did not credit petitioner with time served on the reformatory sentence. The court declared the date upon which the minimum and maximum sentences for the first-degree robbery conviction began to run and denied petitioner's request for credit for time served under the reformatory sentence. The corrections department conceded that the delinquency time could not be added onto petitioner's sentence because the reformatory sentence statute had been declared unconstitutional. Petitioner was not entitled to credit for time served on the prior sentence because his sentences were not treated as running concurrently. Under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.30(1)(a), credit for time served was allowed if the reformatory sentence were indeterminate and ran concurrently with other sentences.


OUTCOME: The court declared the date upon which petitioner's minimum and maximum terms for his conviction for first-degree robbery began to run, ordered the exclusion of petitioner's delinquent time from the calculation of each term, and denied him credit for the time served on his reformatory sentence.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence -- Young Adult

Since the reformatory sentence statute is unconstitutional, no court has the power to add unserved reformatory time to the maximum term of imprisonment of a defendant's subsequent intermediate prison sentence, nor should such unserved time be added to the new minimum sentence; moreover, where a person is under more than one indeterminate sentence and all such sentences are to run concurrently, the time served in prison under any of the concurrent sentences must be credited against the minimum of all such sentences. Accordingly, unserved reformatory time must be excluded from the calculation of both the minimum and the maximum terms of a defendant's new indeterminate sentence, received after he was paroled on the reformatory sentence; however, where such sentence was to run consecutively with the reformatory sentence, reformatory time already served will not be credited against the minimum term of the subsequent indeterminate sentence, since the applicable statute (Penal Law, § 70.30, subd 1, par [a]) would allow such credit only if the reformatory sentence is treated as an indeterminate sentence and the two sentences are treated as running [***2] concurrently.

 

2069 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Catalano


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Suffolk County


101 Misc. 2d 436; 421 N.Y.S.2d 310; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2697



October 25, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of first-degree criminal sale of a controlled substance and awaited sentencing. The statutory minimum was 15 years to life. His codefendants pleaded guilty to a lesser-included offense of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree and received indeterminate one to three year sentences. Claiming that the disparity violated the U.S. Constitution, defendant moved the court to impose a lesser sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and three others were charged with first-degree criminal sale of a controlled substance and first degree criminal possession of a controlled substance involving slightly less than four ounces of cocaine, both class A-I felonies. It was an amateurish operation from which defendant could make only a few hundred dollars. While defendant claimed that he was entrapped, rejected plea offers, and elected to go to trial (where he was convicted), his codefendants pleaded to lesser-included offenses. While they generally were sentenced to serve one to three years, defendant faced a minimum sentence of 15 years to life. Defendant claimed that the disparity constituted cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Constitution. The court agreed. Considering defendant's culpability and involvement relative to that of his codefendants, the court held that there was a shocking disparity and a gross disproportion between the sentences and that the longer sentence required to be imposed on defendant could not be imposed without violating the Constitution. The court noted, however, that defendant nonetheless was not entitled to the same sentence afforded to those who pleaded guilty.


OUTCOME: The court declared its intention to sentence defendant within the range permissible for an A-II felony, that is, a minimum of three years to life and a maximum of eight years to life.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence -- Gross Disproportionality of Sentences

Although the severity of the sentence structure with respect to class A felonies involving controlled substances does not, per se, constitute cruel and unusual punishment, an individualized case-by-case examination of the breadth of the gap between law and justice or the gross disparity of sentences among like defendants charged with acting in concert with respect to the same offense, is permissible to determine if a sentence imposed in accordance with the applicable statute would constitute a deprivation of defendant's constitutional rights; accordingly, the gross disproportion and shocking disparity between the sentences of defendant, who elected to go to trial on class A-I cocaine sale charges and, as a result, faces a statutory minimum sentence of 15 years to life, and his equally culpable codefendants who pleaded guilty to a lesser class A-III charge and have been sentenced to serve indeterminate terms of one to three years, renders the imposition of the mandated sentence an unconstitutional application of the statute and defendant will, therefore, be sentenced to a minimum of three years to life and a maximum [***2] of eight years to life, the range permissible for an A-II felony.

 

2070 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Georgia v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Broome County


101 Misc. 2d 630; 421 N.Y.S.2d 970; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2734



October 25, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner voters brought an action to compel respondent citizens' committee to file a statement of expenditures in compliance with the N.Y. Education Law.


OVERVIEW: The voters brought an action to compel the committee to file a statement of expenditures in connection with its support of two candidates for election to a school board. The committee contended that the voters had no authority to compel such disclosure. The court entered judgment for the committee, finding that N.Y. Educ. Law art. 32, § 1528(b) did not require a statement of expenditures made by the committee, but only required a statement that the candidates did not approve of the expenditures. The court concluded that the statute did not require anyone other than the candidates to file statements of expenditures.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for the committee and denied the voters' demand that it file a statement of expenditures.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Elections -- Statement of Expenditures

There is no provision in article 32 of the Education Law which requires any person other than a candidate for membership on the board of education to file a statement of expenditures pursuant to section 1528 of the Education Law although one who makes expenditures on behalf of a candidate without his approval must file a statement stating that the expenditure was not approved; in addition, even if the legislative intent of article 32 were that certain noncandidates should be required to file statements of expenditures, subdivision 2 of section 1530 of the Education Law does not authorize a proceeding to compel a noncandidate to file a statement of expenditures in the first instance, but only a new or supplemental statement where the original statement fails to comply with the requirements of article 32.

 

2071 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Ginnan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Steuben County


101 Misc. 2d 853; 422 N.Y.S.2d 1003; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2776



October 24, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent father moved to sever and dismiss the allegations of permanent neglect in the amended adoption petition and to dismiss the petitions for adoption because N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111 was unconstitutional and he did not consent to the adoption.


OVERVIEW: The father killed his child's mother. The father pled guilty to manslaughter and was sentenced to imprisonment with a maximum term of 25 years. The child's maternal great aunt and uncle filed a petition to adopt the child. The parties agreed to dismiss the allegations of permanent neglect in the amended adoption petition. The father argued that § 111 was unconstitutional because it denied him procedural and substantive due process. The court stated that the father had been given notice of the proposed adoption and he appeared in court with counsel to argue his position. The court held that the father's right to procedural due process had been satisfied. The court noted that § 111 provided that in connection with an adoption, the father's consent was not required because he had been deprived of his civil rights because of his prison term. The court held that the father failed to establish the unreasonableness of the statute and that the statute did not violate the equal protection clause. The court held that the child's best interest was served by the statutory sanctions which denied the father his substantive rights in the adoption proceedings.


OUTCOME: The statute in question was constitutional and did not violate the father's equal protection rights.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

1. Petitioner father, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the first degree in connection with the death of his wife and was sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment, was not denied procedural due process (US Const, 14th Amdt) under section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law and subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which provide, respectively, that consent to adoption shall not be required of a parent who has been deprived of civil rights, and that an indeterminate sentence of imprisonment suspends, during the term of the sentence, the civil rights of the person sentenced, in a custody and adoption proceeding involving petitioner's 21-month-old daughter in which the child's maternal great aunt and her husband sought to adopt the child, who had been placed with her great grandfather following her mother's death, since petitioner was given notice of the proposed adoption, was granted every opportunity to be heard, and appeared with counsel and argued his position.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Impingement upon Fundamental Rights

2. The presumption of constitutionality which ordinarily [***2] attaches to statutes can be rebutted by impingement upon essential or basic constitutional rights, such as parental rights; the higher the right is regarded, the more jealously the courts guard it against government intrusion.

Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

3. Petitioner father, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the first degree in connection with the death of his wife and was sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment, was not denied substantive due process (US Const, 14 Amdt) under section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides that consent to adoption is not required of a parent who has been deprived of civil rights, and under subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which provides that an indeterminate sentence of imprisonment suspends, during the term of the sentence, the civil rights of the person sentenced, at a custody and adoption proceeding involving his 21-month-old daughter, whose maternal great aunt and her husband sought to adopt the child, the child having been placed with her great grandfather following her mother's death; although parental rights are among the most basic of rights, petitioner [***3] has demonstrated his unfitness by his own acts, and the best interests of the child are served by denying petitioner substantive rights in the proceeding.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws

4. The State has the power to deny constitutional rights, even the most basic and fundamental of these rights, in order to preserve the constitutional protection and public welfare of the State as a whole, and when the State decides that for the greater good of all a distinction must be drawn between one class of persons and another, it must do so in a manner that will not offend the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution; the classification must be structured in a reasonable manner, must not be arbitrary, and the generalization reflected by the claimed classification must be true of the majority of the members of the class. A State does not violate the guarantee merely because the classifications made by its laws are imperfect, and a statutory discrimination will not be set aside if any state of facts reasonably may be conceived to justify it.

Statutes -- Presumptions

5. It is presumed that the Legislature has investigated [***4] and found facts necessary to support legislation passed by it.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws

6. Equal protection of the law is not denied when all persons are treated alike under like circumstances and conditions, both in the privileges conferred and in the liabilities imposed; the State does not have the power, under the equal protection clause (US Const, 14th Amdt), to legislate that different treatment be accorded to persons placed by a statute into different classes on the basis of criteria wholly unrelated to the objective of that statute.

Adoption -- Consent of Imprisoned Father

7. Petitioner father, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the first degree in connection with the death of his wife and was sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment, was not denied equal protection of the law (US Const, 14th Amdt) under section 111 (subd 2, par [d]) of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides that consent to adoption is not required of a parent who has been deprived of civil rights, and under subdivision 1 of section 79 of the Civil Rights Law, which provides that an indeterminate sentence of imprisonment suspends, during the term [***5] of the sentence, the civil rights of the person sentenced, at a custody and adoption proceeding involving his 21-month-old daughter, whose maternal great aunt and her husband sought to adopt the child, the child having been placed with her great grandfather following her mother's death; the application of section 79 in the instant case is neither arbitrary nor unduly discriminatory, and is a proper exercise of the police power, and moreover, petitioner has not established the unreasonableness of the legislative enactments.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

8. There is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted by the Legislature is constitutional, and for a court to declare a law unconstitutional, the invalidity must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

2072 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Consolidated Edison Co. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


101 Misc. 2d 868; 422 N.Y.S.2d 294; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2778



October 22, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer instituted an action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to review a determination by respondent New York Tax Commission that denied the taxpayer credit for any sales and use taxes for any item purchased by the taxpayer prior to May 31, 1970. The Commission contended that the three-year statute of limitations established in N.Y. Tax Law § 1139(a) was an absolute bar to the allowance of any credit for such taxes.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer reached an agreement with the Commission on June 1, 1973 that modified the taxpayer's method of paying its sales and use taxes for inventory items. That modification provided that the taxes were to be paid as the items were withdrawn from inventory while previously the taxes were paid as the items were purchased. In order to avoid any overpayment the taxpayer filed its next four quarterly tax returns filed after June 1, 1973 with a credit taken for taxes paid on all items that were in inventory as of that date. The Commission issued a notice of determination that demanded payment of all taxes due on those returns on the basis that the credit was barred by the three-year statute of limitations under § 1139(a). The taxpayer instituted a review proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 and the court annulled the determination and remanded the cause to the Commission for further review on the basis that the three-year statute of limitations applied only to refunds or credits of any tax, penalty, or interest erroneously, illegally, or unconstitutionally collected or paid, which was not the case with the taxpayer.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment to the taxpayer and annulled the determination of the Commission. The court remanded the action to the Commission for further proceedings consistent with the court's opinion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- Claim for Credit -- Three-Year Time Limitation

The three-year Statute of Limitations upon claims for a refund or credit of "any tax, penalty or interest erroneously, illegally or unconstitutionally collected or paid" (Tax Law, § 1139, subd [a]) does not bar petitioner, which beginning June 1, 1973, with the consent of respondent Tax Commission, began to pay sales and use taxes directly upon taxable "inventory" items it had purchased as such items were withdrawn from its inventory, from taking a credit for taxes which it had previously paid on "inventory" items purchased prior to May 31, 1970 since the credit sought is not for taxes which were erroneously, illegally or unconstitutionally collected or paid, but for taxes which, at the time they were paid, were due and owing; since the sole issue to be decided is whether respondent correctly interpreted and applied the statute, there is no need to transfer the article 78 proceeding to the Appellate Division because of a substantial evidence issue ( CPLR 7804, subd [g]).

 

2073 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Grejszak


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


100 Misc. 2d 1045; 420 N.Y.S.2d 483; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2604



September 26, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to hold subdivision 3 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law unconstitutional and dismiss thereon is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment against him for driving while intoxicated on the basis that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3) was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with driving while intoxicated in violation of § 1192(3). He filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the basis that the statute was unconstitutionally vague. The court denied the motion, finding that the enactment of § 1192(1), which created the offense of operating a motor vehicle while impaired by the consumption of alcohol, did not create a vagary between the two offenses that was indistinguishable. The elements of the two offenses were identical but the penalties differed. It was within the authority of the legislature to create offenses of differing degrees but identical elements.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on the basis that the charging statute was unconstitutionally vague.


HEADNOTES

Statutes -- Constitutionality

1. The Supreme Court, being a court of original jurisdiction, may accept and act upon a claim of unconstitutionality of a statute only when a conclusion of unconstitutionality is inescapable.

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Vehicle while under Influence

2. Subdivision 3 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law is not unconstitutionally vague, and a motion to hold that statute unconstitutional and to dismiss an indictment charging defendant with driving while intoxicated as a felony is denied, and although the elements of the offense of driving while intoxicated and driving while impaired are identical, there was no legislative intent to create a distinction; consideration of the lesser offense of driving while impaired is permissible (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1196), and the Legislature, in recognizing that the myriad of fact situations which may occur relative to mixing alcohol and driving may range from but mere carelessness to the most heinous, has provided a safety valve mechanism in the judicial [***2] process for cases in which prosecution as a felony is chosen.

 

2074 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Percz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


100 Misc. 2d 1018; 420 N.Y.S.2d 477; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2598



September 21, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss his charges pursuant to N.Y. Vehicle. & Traf. Law § 1192(4), driving while impaired by the use of a drug, upon the grounds that the statute defining the offense was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: In support of his claim, defendant cited a recent case, which held that N.Y. Vehicle. & Traf. Law § 1192(1) and § 1192(3) were unconstitutionally vague in that no standards were enunciated in the provisions, which would enable a court to determine whether a defendant was "impaired" under § 1192(1) or "intoxicated" under § 1192(3). The court held that the case did not apply because it contained no discussion of § 1192(4), the provision under which defendant was charged. Moreover, the rationale of the decision was clearly inapplicable to a violation of § 1192(4), which prohibited operation while "impaired" only and required no differentiation between degrees of drug influence. The court held that § 1192(4) was sufficiently clear so as to warn a person of ordinary intelligence that the conduct contemplated was forbidden by statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charges.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Operating Vehicle while under Influence

Subdivision 4 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, pertaining to driving while impaired by the use of a drug, does not fail for vagueness in that it contains no definition of the term "impaired"; contrary to other statutes, the section violated herein prohibits operation while "impaired" only and requires no differentiation between degrees of drug influence.

 

2075 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Melton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


100 Misc. 2d 991; 420 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2592



September 19, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, based upon the foregoing the petition is granted to the following extent: (a) poor person relief is granted; (b) order No. E907056 of respondent dated July 5, 1979 suspending petitioner's driver's license and registration is vacated; (c) respondent is directed to restore petitioner's driver's license and registration forthwith; (d) respondent shall provide petitioner with a hearing in conformity with the instant decision within 60 days after service of a copy of the judgment to be settled herein with notice of entry thereof upon respondent's counsel; and (e) that in the event the money judgment at issue is vacated and the plaintiff therein appeals, petitioner's license not be suspended if an undertaking is posted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioner driver sought to declare N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 332 unconstitutional, to vacate the order of respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles suspending his driver's license, and poor person relief.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 332, the Commissioner suspended the driver's license for failure to satisfy a default judgment for property damage arising from an alleged accident. The driver did not receive notice of either the suspension or the underlying action because the Commissioner used the driver's old address in spite of being advised of the current one. Due to the suspension, the driver, who worked as a truck driver, lost his source of income. He petitioned the court to vacate the suspension order. The court did not declare § 332 unconstitutional, finding that the driver failed to overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality of an enacted statute. The court did, however, vacate the suspension order, finding that the driver's due process rights were violated by the Commissioner's failure to have a pre-suspension hearing. The court further found it arbitrary that the Commissioner would not restore the driver's license without proof that the judgment was satisfied, proof of a payment schedule to satisfy judgment, or an order vacating the judgment with no potential for appeal, as there was no provision for the posting of an undertaking pending appeal.


OUTCOME: The court granted the driver poor person relief, vacated the Commissioner's order suspending the driver's license and registration, directed the Commissioner to restore the driver's license and registration and provide him with a hearing in conformity with the court's decision within 60 days, and ordered that the driver's license not be suspended pending appeal of the vacation of the money judgment at issue if the driver posted an undertaking.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License

1. While the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles has no discretion under section 332 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which mandates that he suspend the driver's license of a judgment debtor who has failed to satisfy certain judgments for personal or property damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, use or operation of a motor vehicle, said penalty [***2] of suspension should not be imposed without a prior hearing; fundamental due process requires that the hearing be presuspension where the principle thrust of the suspension is to aid the collection of a judgment. Accordingly, in a matter of such seriousness as suspension of the driver's license which is the source of petitioner truck driver's income, based upon a default judgment allegedly entered without actual notice to petitioner, he is at least entitled to minimal due process guarantees prior to the administrative action; after such hearing, there would, however, be only two adjudications respondent commissioner could render -- suspension of petitioner's license if the judgment is valid, or no suspension if the judgment were satisfied and/or invalid -- since section 332 leaves no other option.

Motor Vehicles -- Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License

2. The only circumstances under which the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles will restore petitioner judgment debtor's driver's license after it has been suspended pursuant to section 332 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law upon his failure to satisfy certain judgments for personal or property [***3] damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, use or operation of a motor vehicle -- (1) proof that the judgment was satisfied, (2) proof of a payment schedule to satisfy the judgment, or (3) an order of the judgment court vacating the judgment and either the time to appeal vacatur has expired or stipulation of no appeal has been made -- are arbitrary in that there is no provision for the posting of an undertaking pending appeal.

 

2076 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Angelone v. Rochester


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


100 Misc. 2d 917; 420 N.Y.S.2d 347; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2577



September 18, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After a judicial declaration that defendant city unconstitutionally levied real property taxes, the city passed Ordinance No. 79/307 of the Common Council of the City of Rochester, New York, which authorized refund of the taxes so levied. Plaintiff taxpayers brought an action to declare the city's ordinance unconstitutional and to recover the excess taxes they paid under protest. The taxpayers filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The city argued that the ordinance was constitutional and that it provided for an administrative procedure to settle the claims for overpayment of taxes. The city also argued that the taxpayers were not entitled to a refund for certain tax years because the statutes under which those taxes were levied had never been declared invalid. The court granted the motion and held that the ordinance was patently unconstitutional. The court reasoned that stripped of the verbiage that characterized the ordinance, or "capital levy," as a method to refund to the taxpayers the excess taxes paid by them, the city had actually "robbed Peter to pay Paul." The taxpayers were entitled to establish their rights to repayment of the real property taxes paid in excess of the constitutional limitation. The judicial declaration, which prompted the ordinance, accorded refunds without the necessity of any review by the city's common council, and there was no justification for such a procedure in the present case. Thus, the court awarded judgment to the taxpayers for the excess levies made by the city.


OUTCOME: The court granted the taxpayers' motion for summary judgment and awarded judgment for excess taxes paid, in the taxpayers' action concerning the city's ordinance.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- Real Property Taxes

Ordinance No. 79/307 of the Common Council of the City of Rochester, which ordinance provides for a 1979-1980 "capital levy" as a method to pay for refunds to taxpayers of property taxes paid for the years 1976-1977 and 1977-1978 that were in excess of the real property tax limit set forth in section 10 of article VIII of the New York Constitution, and which provides that the amount of the refund shall be credited against the 1979-1980 tax, essentially creating a situation where such amounts will be equal and the city will not have to pay out any moneys, is unconstitutional where the combined special levy city and school tax for 1979-1980 exceeds the permitted 2% taxing limit by more than $ 50,000,000; moreover, similar illegal levies for the years 1974-1975 and 1975-1976 are also recoverable by petitioners taxpayers who paid such taxes under protest, even though such levies predated judicial invalidation of the 1977-1978 and 1978-1979 taxes, since local subdivisions were on notice at that time that taxpayers' remedies for such patent circumvention of constitutional limitations on the local taxing powers would not be limited to prospective relief [***2] only.

 

2077 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Rodriguez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


100 Misc. 2d 983; 420 N.Y.S.2d 349; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2590



September 18, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner guardian sought letters of administration of a decedent's estate. Respondent decedent's mother opposed the application.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, was guardian of the decedent's property of that of her nonmarital infant son. She and the decedent never married but had a son together. On the child's original birth certificate, no one was listed as the father. Later, both decedent and petitioner executed a form for the purpose of having the decedent named as the father on a corrected birth certificate. Although the form did not contain an acknowledgement and their signatures were not witnessed, a corrected birth certificate was executed. Decedent's mother opposed the application on the ground that N.Y. Est. Powers & Trust Law § 4-1.2 precluded the infant from inheriting from the decedent in the absence of a court of competent jurisdiction having entered an order of filiation declaring paternity of the infant. The court agreed and held that because there has been no judicial determination during decedent's lifetime as to his paternity of the child, the infant could not a distributee who could inherit from decedent. The court dismissed the guardian's petition and ordered that letters of administration be issued to the decedent's mother upon her filing a petition requesting the same and duly qualifying according to law.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the decedent's mother.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Descent and Distribution -- Illegitimate Child

Since there has been no judicial determination during the decedent's lifetime as to his paternity of the nonmarital child, even though the decedent was named as the father on a corrected birth certificate and his signature on this form was sworn to before a commissioner of deeds, the infant is not a distributee who can inherit from decedent and therefore petitioner, in her status as guardian of the infant's property, has no interest in this estate which would entitle her to receive letters of administration; although EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]) as of the date of decedent's death provided that an illegitimate child could inherit from his father only in the event of an order of filiation declaring paternity, the amended EPTL 4-1.2, effective May 29, 1979, which liberalized the inheritance rights of nonmarital children, is of no solace to petitioner because the instrument which decedent executed relating to the corrected birth certificate was neither executed with the formalities required by the statute nor was it filed with the Putative Father Registry; in any event, it does not appear that the Legislature intended to apply,  [***2] or that it could have constitutionally applied, the amendment to the statute retroactively to the property of decedent's dying prior to its effective date, since such distributive interests would have already indefeasibly vested in those entitled to a distributive interest in decedent's property on the date of decedent's death under the statutes existing on that date.

 

2078 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kane v. Kane


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rensselaer County


101 Misc. 2d 143; 420 N.Y.S.2d 627; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2644



September 18, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff husband filed a motion for partial summary judgment as to the cause of action for divorce and for a severance and referral of all other claims to the appropriate family court. Defendant wife cross-moved for permanent alimony.


OVERVIEW: The parties entered into a separation agreement. Provisions in the separation agreement were made for child support and division of property, but no provision was made for alimony for the wife. The wife claimed that she was entitled to alimony because of the length of marriage and her earning capacity. The wife contended that her waiver of support in the separation agreement was invalid by virtue of N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 5-311 which prohibited a husband from contracting to relieve himself from supporting his wife. The court held that § 5-311 was unconstitutional because it advanced a gender-based discrimination that was unable to have withstood the equal protection scrutiny. The court's determination regarding the unconstitutionally of § 5-311 was not to have been applied retroactively. The matter was referred to the trial court for a determination as to the issue of the wife's entitlement to alimony from the date of the separation agreement to the date of the decision declaring § 5-311 unconstitutional and for a determination of any entitlement to attorney fees. The husband's motion for partial summary judgment as to the divorce was granted.


OUTCOME: The court entered a judgment of divorce in favor of the husband and referred the matter to the trial court for a determination of the wife's entitlement to alimony from the date of the separation agreement to the date that the statute entitling her to alimony was declared unconstitutional, along with the issue of attorney fees.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Waiver of Support

 Section 5-311 of the General Obligations Law is an unconstitutional denial of equal protection since it advances a gender-based discrimination and is incapable of a "gender-neutral" interpretation in that it prohibits a husband from contracting to relieve himself from supporting his wife, but prohibits a wife from contracting to relieve herself of supporting her husband only where the wife has sufficient means and her husband is incapable of supporting himself and is likely to become a public charge.

 

2079 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pellnat v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


100 Misc. 2d 848; 420 N.Y.S.2d 459; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2564



September 11, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion for summary judgment, dismissing the complaint of the plaintiffs, is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both plaintiff citizens and defendant city filed motions for summary judgment to decide whether statutes authorizing the promulgation of special equalization ratios were an unconstitutional evasion of the tax and debt-contracting powers of the state's various municipal divisions as set forth in the state constitution.


OVERVIEW: The statutes at issue were enacted to allow certain municipal divisions the ability to tax at the maximum constitutional limit by permitting, for that purpose only, the recalculation of the applicable ratios used in determining "average full valuation." The court granted summary judgment in favor of the city, dismissing the citizens' complaint. The court did not find that the legislature had acted without the letter of the state constitution. The court determined that the ratios, of necessity, were flexible and defied precise accuracy. The court determined, therefore, that there was no constitutional mandate of any set method of determining the equalization ratio. The court concluded that the legislature remained within the letter of the state constitution because it had not stepped beyond the taxing ceiling, but merely exercised its authorized discretion to determine the equalization ratio, which figure, adjustable by nature, constituted one part of the formula used in calculating the constitutional limit itself.


OUTCOME: The city's motion for summary judgment, dismissing the complaint of the citizens, was granted in an action to decide the constitutionality of certain promulgation statutes.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute

1. The presumption of constitutionality afforded all legislative enactments may be rebutted only by a showing beyond a reasonable doubt of constitutional invalidity since courts should avoid conclusions of unconstitutionality if that is fairly possible.

Taxation -- Equalization Ratios -- Constitutional Limit

2. Articles 12-A and 12-B of the Real Property Tax Law, which permit the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to establish special equalization ratios and thereby raise the constitutional taxing limit on real property, are not unconstitutional devices for allowing a municipality to levy more taxes, since section 10 of article VIII of the State Constitution gives the Legislature the authority to determine these ratios and this authority has been delegated to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment which, after reviewing more current, more accurate and fairer information, may recalculate the ratios, which are not final constants, but rather flexible and imprecise factors that make up the taxing [***2] limit; there is no constitutional mandate as to their method of determination.

Taxation -- Equalization Ratios -- Constitutional Limit

3. The decision of the Legislature to adjust only those equalization ratios used in calculating "average full valuation" as applied in levying real property tax and setting debt limits is within its prerogative upon which a court should not presume to impose its opinion.

 

2080 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morning Glory Media, Inc. v. Enright


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


100 Misc. 2d 872; 420 N.Y.S.2d 176; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2570



September 6, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff filed a motion for an order confirming an order of seizure regarding property seized from defendants' without notice, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102.


OVERVIEW: In response to plaintiff's motion to confirm order of seizure, defendants claimed the grant of order of seizure without notice violated constitutional due process requirements. The court found there was a strong presumption of constitutionality that attached to an act of the legislature, and the presumption could have only been overcome by clear and convincing proof, persuasive beyond a reasonable doubt. Procedural due process requirements were met whether an order of seizure was granted after a hearing on notice or without notice with an immediate confirmation hearing on notice. The court held an order of confirming seizure without notice may have been granted only upon a showing of exigent circumstances under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102(d), and if later found unwarranted, plaintiff could have been liable for damages, including attorney's fees under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7108. The record established plaintiff had access to the property prior to and subsequent to the seizure, and there was no intent by defendants to move or dispose or otherwise alter or damage the property. Therefore, the court held plaintiff did not meet its statutory burden and denied its motion to confirm the order of seizure.


OUTCOME: The court denied the plaintiff's motion for an order confirming an order of seizure without notice. The court directed the sheriff to return the chattel to its prior location and, pending a final outcome, granted plaintiff a restraining order so that the chattel would not be removed from its location, transferred, sold, pledged, assigned, or otherwise disposed of or permitted to become of security interest or lien.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute

1. A strong presumption of constitutionality attaches to an act of the Legislature and this presumption can only be overcome by clear and convincing proof, persuasive beyond a reasonable doubt; even if the validity of the enactment is debatable, legislative judgment must control.

Replevin -- Order of Seizure without Notice -- Constitutionality

2. An order of seizure without notice pursuant to CPLR article 71 meets procedural due process requirements that a person be given notice and an opportunity to be heard prior to deprivation of a property interest in aid of a creditor; the order of seizure may be discretionarily granted after a plaintiff has met the burden of establishing all the specific requirements for an order of seizure, an immediate confirmation hearing on notice is held, plaintiff may be liable for damages including attorney's fees if the seizure is later proved unwarranted and defendant has the option of reclaiming a chattel pursuant to CPLR 7103.

Replevin -- Order of Seizure without Notice

3. A motion for an order confirming an order of seizure granted without notice must be denied since the burden [***2] is on the plaintiff to prove that he has met the detailed requirements of CPLR 7102, and that it is probable that he will succeed on the merits, and the court is vested with broad discretion to determine whether replevin relief is appropriate and is also the proper status for the parties pending final outcome of the action, in order to prevent mistaken and unfair deprivation of property; the plaintiff has not met the statutory burden and defendant's defenses may defeat plaintiff's claim to a superior possessory interest in the chattel; therefore, the chattel must be returned to its prior location, but pending the final outcome of the action, plaintiff is entitled to a restraining order preventing removal, transferral or other disposition of the chattel unless defendants transfer their interest in the chattel to the plaintiff.

 

2081 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jenkins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


100 Misc. 2d 935; 420 N.Y.S.2d 262; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2580



September 6, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State petitioned that defendant be sentenced as a persistent violent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.08, based upon his two prior violent felony convictions.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of robbery in the first degree and other lesser crimes that occurred after the effective date of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.08. He had two prior felony convictions. He challenged the constitutionality of using his two prior convictions two determine his sentence as they predated § 70.08 and did not constitute violent felony convictions under the statute. The court found in favor of State and held that the statute permitted the use of defendant's two prior felonies as violent felonies under the statute. Under § 70.08(1)(a), defendant's present convictions were violent felonies under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.02 and his prior convictions were for crimes in which he was aided and abetted by others actually present under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 160.10, 110.00, effective in 1965. The material elements of defendant's prior convictions were contained in penal law offenses in effect prior to September 1, 1967 as required by N.Y. Penal Law § 70.04. N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 was not unconstitutional on either due process or ex post facto grounds insofar as permitting a felony conviction incurred prior to the effective date of § 70.06 to constitute a predicate felony conviction.


OUTCOME: The court permitted defendant to be sentenced as a persistent violent felony offender based upon his prior convictions in conjunction with his latest conviction.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence -- Persistent Violent Felony Offender

A defendant convicted of a violent felony offense may be sentenced as a persistent violent felony offender pursuant to section 70.08 of the Penal Law (eff Sept. 1, 1978) on the basis of crimes committed prior to the effective date of the statute, since section 70.08 defines predicate violent felony offense without limitation as to retrospective treatment, section 70.04 (subd 1, par [b], cl [i]) defines a predicate violent felony offense in part as including a conviction of an offense defined by the Penal Law in effect prior to September 1, 1967 "which includes all of the essential elements of any such felony", and this construction would align section 70.08 with the construction of the second felony offender statute, section 70.06 of the Penal Law, which has been given retrospective application.

 

2082 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wallace v. Teal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Monroe County


100 Misc. 2d 976; 420 N.Y.S.2d 336; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2589



August 31, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner father filed a proceeding in the Monroe County Family Court (New York) for custody of his daughter, a child born out of wedlock to respondent mother.


OVERVIEW: The father filed a petition for custody of the child. The court found that although both parents expressed love, affection, and interest in the child, the father impressed the court as being the parent who would be most able to provide stability in the child's upbringing. The court held that the best interests of the child dictated that custody be awarded to the father. The court also held that the presumption that the natural mother should have been awarded custody, absent a showing of unfitness, yielded to the "best interests" test.


OUTCOME: The court granted custody to the father and directed that the mother was entitled to extremely liberal visitation with the child.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Custody -- Natural Father

Former, well-established case law in New York, under which the natural mother of a child born out of wedlock was prima facie entitled to custody, as opposed the child's father, unless it could be shown that she had abandoned her right or was not a proper and suitable parent, is no longer valid, based upon the United States Supreme Court's clear position against any gender based distinction as applied to children born out of wedlock for any and all aspects of future child custody cases; the presumption that the natural mother should be awarded custody, absent a showing of unfitness, must yield to the "best interests" test. Accordingly, custody of a child born out of wedlock was awarded to her unmarried father, who had openly acknowledged paternity and maintained an ongoing relationship with the child, with liberal visitation rights to the mother, where the best interests of the child indicated that custody should be given to the father, even though the mother had not abandoned her right to custody and was not shown to be unfit or improper as a parent.

 

2083 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wood v. Rocker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Onondaga County


100 Misc. 2d 890; 420 N.Y.S.2d 330; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2572



August 29, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed a petition seeking an upward modification of the terms of the support agreement due to her child no longer receiving public assistance. Respondent putative father filed a motion to dismiss on the grounds that counsel during the earlier proceedings had not represented him and the order of filiation had been obtained after the statute of limitations had expired with regard to the mother of the infant.


OVERVIEW: The unmarried mother filed a petition applying for public assistance, and assigned her support rights to the commissioner. The commissioner filed a paternity petition against the putative father. The putative father was ordered to pay support per week, disbursed to the commissioner. Later, the mother filed a petition because the child was no longer receiving public assistance, seeking an upward modification of the support agreement. The putative father filed a motion to dismiss the petition on the grounds that (1) he was not represented by counsel during the prior proceedings, and (2) the order of filiation was obtained after the statute of limitations. The court dismissed the petition to modify the commissioner's order of support, and vacated the order awarding payment of support to the commissioner. The court held that the mother had to file an action under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 413 seeking support and alleging that the putative father was the father of the child. The court found that the lack of representation by counsel was not an adequate ground for the dismissal because the putative father had chosen to appear without counsel and to admit the allegations of the petition.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the mother's petition to modify the commissioner's order of support. The court vacated the order awarding payment of support to the commissioner.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Filiation Proceeding -- Right to Support upon Termination of Public Assistance

1.
