When a timely paternity proceeding is brought by the Commissioner of Social Services (Family Ct Act, § 517, subd [b]) two or more years after the birth of the child and thus after the two-year Statute of Limitations has expired with respect to the commencement of a paternity proceeding by the mother (Family Ct Act, § 517, subd [a]), the mother, upon termination of public assistance benefits to the child, is not automatically entitled to have the support payments which were awarded to the commissioner paid to her pursuant to a statute which provides that payments on the support order are to be made to the person or family upon the termination of the assignment of support rights (Family Ct Act, § 571, subd 3, par [a]) but is instead entitled to a de novo hearing on the issue of support (Family Ct Act, § 571, subd 3, par [b]) in order to avoid an unconstitutional taking of property without due process of law and afford the putative father his right to assert the defense of the Statute of Limitations; since petitioner had assigned all of her support [***2] rights to the commissioner, the right to support, which does not arise until the right has been established through a paternity proceeding, was beyond petitioner's power to exercise at the time it came into being, the commissioner having sued to enforce his assigned right to support.

Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Waiver of Right to Counsel

2. Respondent putative father, by choosing to appear at a paternity proceeding without counsel and admit the allegations of the petition after having been given an adjournment in order that he might consult with counsel, waived the right to counsel and the lack of representation by counsel is not, therefore, an adequate ground for the dismissal of the petition.

 

2084 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Middlemark


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Third District, Nassau County


100 Misc. 2d 760; 420 N.Y.S.2d 151; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2542



August 28, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the State of New York, brought an action against defendant residents for permitting free-standing political signs to be on their premises in violation of the North Hempstead, N.Y., Code § 70-201 and for permitting a political wall sign to be maintained without having obtained a permit in violation of Hempstead, N.Y., Code § 70-201(F).


OVERVIEW: The state brought an action against the residents for allowing political signs on their properties. The state contended that its enactments were permissible since they reflected valid legislative concern for aesthetic interests and that the regulations fell within the time, place, and manner limitation on speech. The residents claimed that the ordinance violated the equal protection clause and infringed on First Amendment rights. The court ruled in favor of the residents, declaring the ordinance void. The court held that because the ordinance made an arbitrary distinction between political and nonpolitical signs, analysis in terms of the equal protection clause was in order. The court found that the ordinance was unnecessarily restrictive and predicated upon a discriminatory scheme of classification. The court held that the scheme was restrictive of fundamental rights and unsupported by compelling state interests and, thus, was unconstitutional. The state did not show that there was an appropriate government interest furthered by the differential treatment and absent a compelling justification for such classification, such disparate treatment was impermissible.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of the residents and declared the ordinance prohibiting political signs to be unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of Outdoor Advertising

1. A town may regulate outdoor advertising signs under its police power, and while signs are a form of speech protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution, local government has the power to regulate the time, place and manner of speech.

Constitutional Law -- Police Power

2. The police power may be exercised in a manner designed to promote aesthetic purposes.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Restriction on Time, Place or Manner of Speech

3. An ordinance restricting the time, place or manner of speech must, in order to be legitimate, be justified without reference to the content of the regulated speech, serve a significant governmental interest, and permit alternative channels of expression to remain open; when ordinances attempt to regulate content, courts are swift to hold them unconstitutional.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Political Signs

4. An ordinance making it unlawful to erect and/or maintain any free-standing political sign is unnecessarily restrictive in that it stifles personal liberties in a manner too broad [***2] for the protection of legitimate interests, it is predicated upon a discriminatory scheme of classification, unsupported by compelling State interests, and is therefore unconstitutional; there is no showing that reasonable political signs constitute a greater blemish on the landscape than other signs, and the First Amendment rights of candidates and political organizations are infringed upon. Additionally, although the provision of the ordinance calling for permits as a precondition to the erection of political wall signs is a valid exercise of the police power, the fee structure contained therein is unconstitutional by virtue of the differential treatment accorded to political signs as opposed to nonpolitical signs.

Constitutional Law -- Restrictions upon First Amendment Rights

5. Incidental restrictions upon the exercise of First Amendment rights may be imposed in furtherance of legitimate governmental interests if that interest is unrelated to suppression of expression and is substantial in relation to the restrictions imposed, and if the restrictions are no greater than necessary.

 

2085 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re K.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Richmond County


100 Misc. 2d 796; 420 N.Y.S.2d 135; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2550



August 23, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, it is ordered (1) that respondent's motion is granted; (2) that the above-captioned matter is dismissed without prejudice; and finally (3) that respondent is released from remand forthwith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Law Guardian for respondent juvenile sought to dismiss proceedings brought on a delinquency petition filed against the juvenile under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 371, subd. 3, and a criminal court order of removal that transferred the matter to the court. The Guardian charged that the petition was defective in that it failed to fulfill the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 725.05, subd. 2, and gave inadequate notice of the pending charges.


OVERVIEW: The Law Guardian sought to dismiss the removal petition claiming that it failed to fulfill the statutory requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 725.05, subd. 2. He argued that it afforded inadequate notice to the juvenile, therefore requiring dismissal. In response, the State claimed that assuming that any deficiency as to notice existed, it was subject to cure by the filing of additional pleadings. The court granted the motion. Noting that strict construction of the relevant statutes was required, the court held that the petition was infirm because it did not provide notice in conformity with minimum procedural due process standards. Rejecting the claim that the attack on the petition related to a "mere technicality," the court held that it was the petition and the petition alone that constitutes the pleading to which the juvenile had to respond and that the petition, therefore, had to meet constitutional due process standards. Because the petition was the sole source of notice for the proceedings for constitutional purposes, the fact that clarifying information might be found in other files did not and could not remedy the defect which required dismissal of the petition.


OUTCOME: The court granted the juvenile's motion, dismissed the matter without prejudice, and ordered the juvenile released from remand.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders -- Notice of Charges

1. A Family Court juvenile offender proceeding is dismissed, the proceeding having been commenced following a criminal court order of removal, since the petition failed to fulfill the statutory requirements of CPL 725.05 (subd 2), which requires that an order of removal specify the act(s) the court found reasonable cause to believe the defendant did, and therefore did not provide a notice of charges which conformed to acceptable standards of procedural due process; a juvenile has a constitutional right to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation against him, and an order of removal, as part of the delinquency petition under subdivision 3 of section 731 of the Family Court Act, must provide a clear and precise statement of the nature and cause of the Family Court proceedings to be commenced. At a minimum, details must be furnished as to the date, time and place of the alleged incident, and even if the criminal [***2] court pleadings and proceedings filed with the Family Court were to remedy a defective order of removal, such a remedy is not constitutionally available under the statute.

Crimes -- Indictment -- Due Process

2. The requirement that an indictment and an information must state the crime with which a defendant is charged, and the particular acts constituting that crime, is more than a technicality; it is a fundamental, a basic principle of justice and fair dealing, as well as a rule of law.

 

2086 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Reiner-Kaiser Associates v. McConnachie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Housing Part, Queens County


104 Misc. 2d 750; 429 N.Y.S.2d 343; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2957



August 13, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord brought a holdover proceeding to remove respondent tenant from possession of an apartment that had been converted to a co-operative.


OVERVIEW: The apartment was part of a co-operative plan that was declared effective in September 1978. The tenant had been given the right to purchase her apartment, which she refused, and had been given the right to match any offer, which she also refused. The tenant, pursuant to the requirement of the rent stabilization guidelines, was allowed to remain in her apartment until either the end of her lease, or one year from date of issuance of the formal prospectus, whichever was longer. The longer period expired on June 2, 1979. The tenant refused to leave, claiming that she was protected by 1979 N.Y. Laws ch. 432. The court found the new law constitutional, noting that its protection of persons of low income who were more than 62 years old was valid. However, the new law did not affect co-operative conversion plans that were declared effective before its enactment and it could not be interpreted to have any retroactive effect. Thus, the landlord was entitled to possession.


OUTCOME: The court granted final judgment to the landlord for possession only.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Condominiums and Co-operatives -- Eviction of Senior Citizens upon Conversion to Co-operative

1. Chapter 432 of the Laws of 1979, which seeks to protect senior citizens and other tenants in the conversion of residential real estate from rental status to co-operative or condominium ownership in the City of New York by providing that a tenant who is 62 years of age or older and has been living for two years within an apartment that is being converted and who has an annual income of less than $ 30,000 cannot be evicted, is constitutional; in establishing this special senior citizen category, the Legislature acted in the matter of public interest and, accordingly, the statute is both rational and reasonable and any discrepancies in treatment which result do not amount to a denial of equal protection.

Condominiums and Co-operatives -- Eviction of Senior Citizens upon Conversion to Co-operative

2. Chapter 432 of the Laws of 1979, which seeks to protect senior citizens and other tenants in the conversion of residential real estate from rental status to co-operative or condominium ownership in the City of New York by providing that a tenant who is 62 years of age or older and [***2] has been living for two years within an apartment that is being converted and who has an annual income of less than $ 30,000 cannot be evicted, may not be applied retroactively; accordingly, where a conversion plan was declared effective prior to July 5, 1979, the effective date of chapter 432, such law is inapplicable to a tenant who would otherwise have qualified for the senior citizen exemption.

 

2087 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ryals


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


100 Misc. 2d 551; 420 N.Y.S.2d 257; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2504



August 9, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss an indictment pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20, subd. h. As grounds, he claimed that N.Y Penal Law §10.00, subd. 18, N.Y. Penal Law § 30.00, and N.Y. Penal Law § 720.10 were unconstitutional because they denied him equal protection of the laws. He also claimed that because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75 failed to provide specific procedures and standards, he was denied due process of law as a result thereof.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, aged 14, was charged with crimes including second degree murder. He sought dismissal of the indictment on constitutional grounds but the court found no merit to his claim and it denied the motion. Noting that there was no constitutional right to be treated as a juvenile, it held that the challenged laws were not directed to any class of persons based on race, national origin, religion, or sex. It ruled that the "rational basis" test was applicable; that the gravity of the crime charged was a rational basis for distinguishing treatment; and that the legislative classification, treating juveniles charged with serious crimes differently than those charged with nonserious crimes, did not violate defendant's constitutional rights. The court also rejected attacks on the constitutionality of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75. Because defendant had been accorded all of his constitutional rights, he was not entitled to challenge it. Moreover, a claim that the law lacked standards was baseless because the critical standard, whether transfer was in the interests of justice, was clear. A related equal protection challenge based on differences in penalties was rejected as premature.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on constitutional grounds.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders

1. Where a statute is attacked as violative of equal protection of the law, the courts have applied either the strict scrutiny or the rational basis test, determining first whether the statute operates to the disadvantage of some specific class or impinges upon a fundamental right explicitly or implicitly protected by the Constitution, thereby requiring strict judicial scrutiny, and then, if it does not, whether it rationally furthers some legitimate, articulated State purpose and therefore does not constitute an invidious discrimination in violation of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Accordingly, since there is no fundamental right for a youth charged with criminal conduct to be treated as a juvenile, and since the juvenile offender law (L 1978, ch 481; Penal Law, § 10.00, subd 18; § 30.00), which makes persons between the ages of 13 and 15 criminally responsible for certain specified crimes, was not directed at any class of individuals on account of race, national origin, religion, or sex, the rational basis test is appropriate to test the constitutionality of [***2] such statute; the juvenile offender statutes do not violate a youthful defendant's right to equal protection of the law since the Legislature has classified the treatment of defendants based upon the seriousness of the crime, with the intention that those young persons who commit serious violations of the Penal Law be treated differently than those young persons who commit nonserious violations, a rational basis for the distinction in treatment.

Constitutional Law -- Standing

2. In determining whether a petitioner has standing to sue, it must be shown that petitioner's personal or property rights will be directly and specifically affected by the matter in controversy; a petitioner making a general attack on legislative or administrative action or inaction must demonstrate special damages distinct from that suffered by the public at large. Accordingly, where a juvenile offender has been afforded all of the rights that he claims are not provided by CPL 180.75, the statute permitting removal of an action against a juvenile offender from a criminal court to the Family Court under certain circumstances -- adequate notice to the parent and child of the charges, the opportunity [***3] to retain counsel and the right to call witnesses on his behalf -- he lacks standing to challenge the constitutionality of the statute on those grounds as violative of procedural due process and equal protection under the Fifth, Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders

3. The burden of showing the unconstitutionality of a statute is on the party asserting it, who must demonstrate such fact beyond a reasonable doubt; the courts are guided by the principle that an inferior court should exercise restraint in declaring a statute unconstitutional, using such power only in rare cases involving life and liberty, and where the invalidity of the act is apparent on its face. Accordingly, the contention that CPL 180.75, which makes persons between the ages of 13 and 15 criminally responsible for certain specified crimes, but permits removal of an action against a juvenile offender from a criminal court to the Family Court where it is determined that to do so would be in the interests of justice, fails to provide specific standards and criteria to control the court in its decision to transfer or to retain jurisdiction is without [***4] merit, since the possibility that some juveniles would be arbitrarily transferred to the adult criminal justice system, thereby subjecting them to significantly harsher potential penalties than could be imposed upon the majority of juveniles who engaged in similar antisocial behavior in violation of their constitutional rights, is not present in the New York plan, under which all juveniles accused of certain designated crimes are subject to the adult criminal system, except in those unusual cases in which treatment as a juvenile is deemed appropriate; moreover, there is no violation of defendant's right of due process under the juvenile offender law when he is not afforded a removal hearing in the criminal court, because the superior court has the inherent power to transfer the case to the Family Court in the interest of justice pursuant to CPL 210.40 when it becomes aware of exceptional circumstances that would warrant transferring the case to the Family Court, nor is said interests of justice standard constitutionally infirm, since legislative enactments permitting the courts to make a variety of determinations based on this standard have been an integral part of the criminal procedural [***5] process for many years and criteria thereunder have been set forth by various courts.

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders

4. The contention that the juvenile offender law (L 1978, ch 481) violates the equal protection clause of the Constitution in that a person under the age of 16 who is convicted of the same crime as a person between the ages of 16 and 19 may not receive youthful offender treatment while the latter group may, is premature when raised by a juvenile defendant who has not been tried and convicted. Accordingly, the court will not pass on that issue.

 

2088 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Di Raffaele


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Suffolk County


100 Misc. 2d 634; 420 N.Y.S.2d 109; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2519



August 9, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with making criminally usurious loans, sought to dismiss the charges against him on the grounds that N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and charged with having committed the crime of criminal usury. He moved to declare the statute under which he was charged, N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42, unconstitutional on the grounds that it was void for vagueness. Defendant claimed the statute failed to define what would constitute a "scheme or business" of making usurious loans. The trial court denied the motion, upholding the constitutionality of § 190.42, reasoning that § 190.42 specified that one committed criminal usury when he knowingly charged interest on any loan at a rate exceeding 25 percent. A strong presumption of validity attached to statutes and all legislative enactments were deemed to be constitutional until the invalidity of the law had been proven beyond a reasonable doubt. The prohibition against excessive vagueness did not invalidate every statute that a reviewing court believed could have been drafted with greater precision. Under the circumstances, the conduct barred by § 190.42 was reasonably clear, and thus it passed constitutional muster.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss the charges of criminal usury was denied. The statute was not held unconstitutionally vague since it informed a reasonable person of the prohibited conduct.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. A strong presumption of validity attaches to statutes and all legislative enactments are deemed to be constitutional until the invalidity of the law has been proved beyond a reasonable doubt.

Constitutional Law -- Due Process of Law -- Statutory Vagueness

2. A criminal statute should be narrowly construed since the citizen is entitled to an unequivocal warning before conduct on his part, which is not malum in se, can be made the occasion of a deprivation of his liberty or property; however, this prohibition against excessive vagueness does not invalidate every statute which a reviewing court believes could have been drafted with greater precision, for in most English words and phrases there lurk uncertainties. Accordingly, section 190.42 of the Penal Law, which criminalizes conduct that is part of a "scheme or business" of making or collecting usurious loans, is not so vague or standardless that it fails to meet due process requirements; it does not leave the public uncertain as to the conduct it prohibits or Judges and jurors free to decide, without legally fixed standards, what is prohibited and what [***2] is not in each particular case.

 

2089 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hempel v. American Airlines, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


102 Misc. 2d 563; 423 N.Y.S.2d 778; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2907



August 9, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant airlines filed a motion to dismiss the cause of action for punitive damages by plaintiff, a survivor of a deceased passenger, in the survivor's action for wrongful death.


OVERVIEW: The survivor of the deceased passenger took the position that the wrongful death statute, N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-4.3, could have been construed to permit recovery of punitive damages. The court disagreed. Punitive damages were not recoverable under § 5-4.3. The language of the statute made clear that pecuniary injuries included payment of expenses resulting from the accident born by the survivor. It did not broaden the compensatory nature of the recovery to include punitive damages. Neither was there any basis to support the survivor's contention that the language of the statute evidenced a legislative intent to permit recovery of punitive damages. To the contrary, the statute expressly used the word compensation. Compensatory damages and punitive damages were mutually exclusive.


OUTCOME: The court granted the airline's motion to dismiss the cause of action for punitive damages brought by the survivor of the passenger in the wrongful death action.


HEADNOTES

Damages -- Punitive Damages in Wrongful Death Cases

1. The New York wrongful death statute ( EPTL 5-4.3) specifically limits recovery to "compensation for the pecuniary injuries resulting from decedent's death to the persons for whose benefit the action is brought"; punitive damages are not recoverable under EPTL 5-4.3 since the statute expressly uses the word compensation and compensatory damages and punitive damages are mutually exclusive; the survival statute's specific prohibition against the recovery of punitive damages is consistent with the compensatory nature of the wrongful death statute and indicates a legislative intent that heirs and distributees not succeed to the decedent's right to recover punitive damages.

Damages -- Punitive Damages in Wrongful Death Cases

2. A construction of New York's wrongful death statute ( EPTL 5-4.3) which prohibits recovery of punitive damages does not constitute a denial of equal protection since two classes of persons are involved -- injured plaintiffs and decedents' heirs and distributees -- and all persons similarly situated are treated alike; furthermore, the Legislature created [***2] a right unknown at common law and it cannot be unconstitutional to create a right with certain limitations.

 

2090 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schnapp v. Lefkowitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


101 Misc. 2d 1075; 422 N.Y.S.2d 798; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2814



August 8, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] As the court has found each constitutional challenge to be frivolous and no issues of fact have been shown to exist, summary judgment is granted in favor of defendants declaring the statute to be constitutional and dismissing the complaint insofar as it seeks injunctive relief.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff dog owners filed an action against defendant state to set aside N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1310 as unconstitutional. The case went before the court on the dog owners' plea for injunctive relief and the state's motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: Section 1310 required persons who walked dogs in New York cities with populations of 400,000 or more to remove feces left by the dogs and deposit the feces in a suitable container. The dog owners attacked § 1310 on various constitutional grounds, including interference with the right to own property and vagueness. The dog owners, among other things, asserted that § 1310 discriminated against Jews, who were not permitted to work on the Sabbath. The dog owners filed an action to have § 1310 declared unconstitutional, and the case went before the court on the parties' competing motions. The court dismissed the complaint insofar as it sought injunctive relief and granted summary judgment to the state, declaring the statute to be constitutional. The court held that a statute designed to foster the health and welfare of a state's people was a reasonable and proper exercise of the state's police power. Section 1310 did not in any way strain the bounds of constitutionality. Section 1310 was sufficiently specific, and it did not intrude on the religious freedom of Jewish citizens. Even where a recognized religious practice was inimical to public health, such practice could be overridden.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state summary judgment, declared that the state law was constitutional, and dismissed the dog owner's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Health -- "Pooper Scooper Law" -- Police Power

1. The "Pooper Scooper Law" (Public Health Law, § 1310), which requires each dog owner in cities with a population of 400,000 or more persons to "remove any feces left by his dog on any sidewalk, gutter, street or other public area", is constitutional since the police power of the State may properly be invoked to require a more sanitary disposition of dog droppings on the streets and sidewalks of the major cities in the State in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare; even if the statute is grounded solely on sanitation and aesthetics, it would still be upheld since a statute which proscribes conduct which is unnecessarily offensive to the sensibilities of the average person is a valid subject of regulation under the police power.

Health -- "Pooper Scooper Law"

2. The fact that the "Pooper Scooper Law" (Public Health Law,  [***2] § 1310), which requires each dog owner in cities with a population of 400,000 or more persons to "remove any feces left by his dog on any sidewalk, gutter, street or other public area", applies only to New York City and Buffalo does not constitute a denial of equal protection of the laws to the residents of those cities since, whenever density of population creates special metropolitan needs relating directly or even indirectly to health and safety, the Legislature may act to meet such needs, because the health and safety of diverse population are matters of State concern; the statute is not defective by reason of vagueness or ambiguity since a person of ordinary intelligence need not guess or speculate as to the meaning of the statute; the fact that Orthodox Jews are forbidden to pick up litter on the Sabbath does not render the statute violative of the constitutional guarantees of freedom of religion since the right to practice religion freely does not include the liberty to expose others to disease or death; the fact that infirm and disabled dog owners might be inconvenienced is likewise, not grounds for invalidating the statute.

Health -- "Pooper Scooper Law" -- Municipal  [***3] Home Rule

3. The "Pooper Scooper Law" (Public Health Law, § 1310), which requires each dog owner in cities with a population of 400,000 or more persons to "remove any feces left by his dog on any sidewalk, gutter, street or other public area", does not violate the principles of municipal home rule since matters of public health do not relate to the "property, affairs or government" of a locality, and the State is not pre-empted from taking appropriate action, even though the problem may be localized.

 

2091 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. Board of Assessment Review


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


104 Misc. 2d 128; 427 N.Y.S.2d 665; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2952



August 6, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Board of Assessment Review of the City of Albany (board) filed a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiffs, not-for-profit corporation and property owners (taxpayers), on grounds that the complaint failed to state a cause of action under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51 and that the complaint did not support the relief sought. The taxpayers filed an action based on certain alleged illegal practices by the board.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers filed a complaint seeking a declaration that certain practices by the board were illegal and unconstitutional, injunctive relief prohibiting the continuation of the practices alleged, and a declaration that the entire 1978 tax roll in the city was illegal. The court granted the board's motion for an order dismissing the action to the extent of dismissing the not-for-profit corporation as a party plaintiff to the action. The not-for-profit corporation lacked capacity to sue because it was not a taxpayer within the meaning of § 51. The court agreed with the board that the portion of the complaint that sought to vacate the entire 1978 tax roll of the city should be stricken. The court denied the board's motion in all other respects, reasoning that the court would uphold any fair and nondiscriminatory assessment method that appeared most likely to ensure that the existence of varied patterns of land use and ownership would not frustrate the design that each contribute equitably to the public fisc. The court held that the causes of action charging the board with employing methods of assessment that resulted in a lack of uniformity had stated legally cognizable claims.


OUTCOME: The court granted the board's motion for an order dismissing the action in part, dismissing the not-for-profit corporation as a party plaintiff to the action. The court granted the board's motion for an order striking that portion of the taxpayers' complaint that sought to vacate the entire 1978 tax roll of the city. The court denied the motion to dismiss in all other respects.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- Assessments -- Standing to Maintain Taxpayer's Action

1. Since plaintiff New York Public Interest Research Group, a not-for-profit corporation whose purpose is to advocate the interest of consumers and taxpayers of the State, does not own any property or pay any taxes within the City or County of Albany, it is not a taxpayer and it therefore lacks standing to maintain a taxpayer's action (General Municipal Law, § 51) attacking the manner in which real property assessments in the City of Albany are determined; the fact that some of plaintiff's members are taxpayers does not allow plaintiff to maintain the action on behalf of its members since, although section 51 is to be liberally construed, no matter how broadly the language is construed, the statute still requires that for a potential litigant to come within its purview, the litigant must be a taxpayer.

Taxation -- Assessments -- Taxpayer's Action Challenging Method of Assessment

2. A taxpayer's action (General Municipal Law, § 51) which alleges that the Albany assessor is employing methods which fail to produce a uniform rate of assessment for every type of property throughout the tax unit as required [***2] by law (Real Property Tax Law, § 306) states a legally cognizable cause of action and sufficiently charges a waste of public funds; the availability of relief to aggrieved taxpayers under article 7 of the Real Property Tax Law is irrelevant to the commencement and maintenance of a taxpayer's action attacking the methods of assessment used by the assessor since such taxpayer's action is the proper vehicle to test the alleged unlawful method utilized in the preparation of an assessment roll and is not incompatible with or barred by the pendency of separate article 7 proceedings; the 700 taxpayers who were allegedly illegally granted assessment reductions based upon incomplete forms submitted by Democratic Party officials are not necessary parties to the action and thus the failure to join them is an insufficient basis to dismiss the action; however, the portion of the complaint which seeks to vacate the entire 1978 tax roll of the City of Albany should be stricken since the relief to be afforded in actions of this nature should be prospective only in order to avoid unnecessary disorder and confusion in public affairs caused by the threat of vacating past tax rolls.

 

2092 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. New York v. Macbeth Realty Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 926; 420 N.Y.S.2d 252; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2579



August 3, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of all the foregoing, the court finds for the defendants and denies injunctive relief and monetary damages.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, People of the State of New York ex rel. City of New York, instituted an action for permanent injunctive relief and monetary damages alleging that defendants, realty company and associated individuals, operated a single-room occupancy hotel as a nuisance.


OVERVIEW: Claiming that defendants' hotel was operated as a house of prostitution and thus was a nuisance, the city filed an action against defendants seeking a permanent injunction and monetary damages. Defendants contended, inter alia, that the action constituted discriminatory and selective prosecution. The court found as fact that three arrests for prostitution were effected in the hotel leading to convictions for prostitution within one year of the commencement of the action, thus giving rise to statutory presumptions under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2324-a and New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § C16-2.2(a) that the premises were used for the purposes of prostitution. The court determined that the statutes were not facially unconstitutional on due process grounds but that the statutory presumption was weak and was rebutted because under the evidence, while acts of prostitution occurred within the hotel, it was not operated as a house of prostitution. The court also concluded that defendants did not meet their heavy burden of showing discriminatory enforcement.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of defendants and denied injunctive relief and monetary damages in the city's action for permanent injunctive relief and monetary damages alleging that defendants operated a single-room occupancy hotel as a nuisance.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Prostitution -- Acts Constituting Prostitution

1. In an action for permanent injunctive relief and monetary damages wherein it was alleged that the defendants operated a New York City hotel as a house of prostitution, and established that three arrests for prostitution, which led to convictions, were effected in the hotel within one year of the commencement of the action, "acts" constituting the crime of prostitution occurred within the hotel although all the verbal solicitations to perform acts of sex occurred outside of the hotel, since the directing and accompanying of the "Johns" into the hotel to attempt to consummate the illicit sex act and exchange of money are part of the continuation of acts constituting the crime of prostitution.

Statutes -- Presumptions -- Maintenance of House of Prostitution

2. Section 2324-a of the Public Health Law, which provides that two or more convictions within one year for various enumerated offenses involving prostitution arising out of conduct engaged in at the same dwelling shall be presumptive [***2] evidence of conduct constituting use of the premises for purposes of prostitution, and subdivision (a) of section C16-2.2 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which contains a similarly worded presumption, are not facially unconstitutional since there is a minimal rational connection between arrests and convictions for prostitution and the maintenance of a house of prostitution, and, moreover, since there is a patent and justifiable right on the part of the State and city in controlling and eliminating houses of prostitution, it is not unreasonable to assign the burden of persuasion to those who own, operate, lease or reside in property within New York City.

Crimes -- Prostitution

3. In an action for permanent injunctive relief and monetary damages based on section 2324-a of the Public Health Law, which provides that two or more convictions within one year for various enumerated offenses involving prostitution arising out of conduct engaged in at the same dwelling shall be presumptive evidence of conduct constituting use of the premises for purposes of prostitution, and subdivision (a) of section C16-2.2 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York,  [***3] which contains a similarly worded presumption, wherein it was alleged that the defendants operated a New York City hotel as a house of prostitution, relief is denied to the plaintiffs, since although there were three arrests and convictions for prostitution within the requisite one-year time period, the overt solicitations did not occur within the hotel, an area theoretically under the control of the defendants, but on a public street blocks away from the hotel, and there were no arrests or convictions for promoting prostitution; a conviction for promoting prostitution demonstrates not only presumptive evidence of the nuisance but prima facie evidence of knowledge, acquiescence, and participation by the defendants within the purview of the statute, and as applied to all the facts in the case, the statutory presumption is weak and is rebutted.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Selective Enforcement

4. While intentional or purposeful discrimination in the administration of an otherwise nondiscriminatory law violates equal protection, one who alleges discriminatory enforcement must meet the heavy burden of showing conscious, intentional discrimination, or a [***4] consciously practiced pattern of discrimination; the conscious exercise of some selectivity in enforcement of the law is not in itself a constitutional violation.

 

2093 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Coeymans v. Malphrus


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


100 Misc. 2d 589; 419 N.Y.S.2d 833; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2511



August 2, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The judgments of conviction herein are reversed and this case is remitted to the Town of Coeymans Town Court for proceedings consistent with this decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review of an order of the Town Court of the Town of Coeymans (New York), which convicted landowner of violating the town zoning ordinance and a town local law for operating a junkyard on his land.


OVERVIEW: A landowner operated a junkyard on his property. Respondent town charged the landowner with four counts of violating a town zoning ordinance and one count of violating a town local law for operating the junkyard. The landowner was ordered to remove all the junk from his premises, cease and desist operation of the junkyard, and was fined. The landowner sought review. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held: (1) the initial zoning ordinance was invalid because of procedural defects in its adoption; (2) the curative statute did not validate the zoning ordinance retrospectively because the application of the curative statute in the present case would have created an ordinance when none existed, and would have conferred the town to do something during a period it had no jurisdiction to do; and (3) the landowner had a vested right to operate a junkyard, and the curative statute could not operate to divest that right retroactively.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court that convicted landowner of violating town ordinance and a town local law for operating a junkyard on his property.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning

1. A curative statute enacted by the State Legislature (L 1978, ch 377) to validate a Town of Coeymans zoning ordinance which, when originally enacted in 1961 was invalid and inoperative because of procedural defects in its adoption, validates the local zoning ordinance prospectively only from the effective date of the curative statute, June 19, 1978; although curative statutes traditionally constitute an exception to the general rule against retroactive application, to allow retroactive application of this curative statute would "create" an ordinance at a time when none existed, would confer upon the Town of Coeymans jurisdiction to do something during a period of time it had no jurisdiction to do it, and to divest defendant of a vested right without compensation; accordingly, since defendant purchased his land in 1970 to operate a junkyard, the junkyard is a prior nonconforming use.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning

2. Defendant's junkyard, which is a prior nonconforming [***2] use, does not violate the three-year amortization period contained in a Town of Coeymans zoning ordinance, originally enacted in 1961 and validated effective June 19, 1978 by a curative statute enacted by the State Legislature pursuant to a home rule request (L 1978, ch 377) and, accordingly, defendant's convictions for violating said ordinance are reversed; such amortization periods are not per se unconstitutional, their constitutionality in a particular case being a factual question involving the specific impact of such legislation in the specific situation involved.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning

3. Defendant's junkyard, which is a prior nonconforming use and does not presently violate a Town of Coeymans zoning ordinance, originally enacted in 1961 and validated effective June 19, 1978 by a curative statute enacted by the State Legislature pursuant to a home rule request (L 1978, ch 377), has not been shown to be other than a lawfully operated business enterprise, and defendant's conviction for violating Local Law No. 2 of 1970 of the Town of Coeymans which provides that there is no violation if keeping abandoned motor vehicles is necessary for the operation of a business [***3] enterprise lawfully upon the premises, is reversed; moreover, since Local Law No. 2 of 1970 provides remedially only for the removal of abandoned vehicles kept in violation thereof and does not provide for the levy of a fine, nor does the Coeymans Town Court have equity jurisdiction, the levy of a fine and the order to cease and desist was improper.

 

2094 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Woodworth v. Woodworth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Monroe County


100 Misc. 2d 456; 419 N.Y.S.2d 39; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2484



July 31, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner wife filed an application for an order of support from respondent husband. The husband subsequently filed a motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act Law § 412 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: After the wife's application was filed, the United States Supreme Court declared unconstitutional an Alabama statute imposing support obligations on husbands but not on wives as violating the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. In his motion to dismiss, the husband argued that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act Law § 412 had the same discriminatory gender-based classification. While the court ruled that § 412 was discriminatory in nature, it also ruled that the court had the inherent power to remedy the discrimination without invalidating the statute. As such, the court read § 412 in a gender-neutral manner and interpreted it to afford equal eligibility to support for husbands and wives. In so ruling, the court noted the problems that invalidating the statute would have caused. The court also emphasized that gender-neutral support eligibility was available elsewhere in the law, including N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act Law § 415.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husband's motion to dismiss the application. The court also referred the issues to the hearing officer.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Support -- Husband's Duty to Support Wife

In order to preserve the constitutionality of section 412 of the Family Court Act which, on its face, contains a discriminatory gender-based classification imposing support obligations on husbands but not on wives (see Orr v Orr, 440 U.S. 268), the statute is interpreted in a gender-neutral manner to afford equal eligibility to husbands and wives to orders of support pursuant to the court's inherent power to remedy the discrimination.

 

2095 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Martin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 774; 420 N.Y.S.2d 318; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2544



July 27, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint filed against them for violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 23.15, and argued the statute was unconstitutional in that it violated the provisions of the U.S. Const. amend. XIV, was vague and overbroad.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with obscenity, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05, in connection with the performance by two of defendants of alleged obscene dances while the third acted as manager of the premises during the performance. Defendants unsuccessfully argued the obscenity statute was subject to a strict scrutiny analysis, it was unconstitutional, and argued unconstitutionally of the affirmative defenses under section 235.15(2). The court held that obscenity was not protected by the U.S. Const. amend. I, and it was not entitled to a strict scrutiny analysis. The affirmative defenses challenged in section 235.15(2) were argued prematurely as they did not come into play until a factual determination of obscenity had been made. The burden of proof was on defendants to establish invalidity of the statute beyond a reasonable doubt, and only a clear violation of the U.S. Constitution justified the court to overrule legislative will.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed defendants' motion to dismiss the complaints because they failed to meet their burden of establishing the unconstitutionality of the legislation beyond a reasonable doubt. The constitutionality of the affirmative defenses contained in the statute did not come into play prior to the determination of obscenity.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Obscenity -- Affirmative Defense

1. Subdivision 1 of section 235.15 of the Penal Law, which provides that it is an affirmative defense in a prosecution for obscenity that "the persons to whom allegedly obscene material was disseminated, or the audience to an allegedly obscene performance, consisted of persons or institutions having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing or viewing the same", is not so vague or overbroad as to be unconstitutional, and, accordingly, defendants' motion to dismiss misdemeanor complaints charging them with obscenity is denied.

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Affirmative Defense

2. In a prosecution for obscenity, where defendants were two dancers who performed allegedly obscene dances and the manager of the premises where the performances took place, they lack standing to challenge the constitutionality of subdivision 2 of section 235.15 of the Penal Law, which provides that it is an affirmative defense in a prosecution for obscenity that the person charged was a projectionist, cashier, doorman, usher or other non-managerial or nonsupervisory employee in a motion picture theatre with no financial [***2] interest other than his employment, since they are not persons of the class with which the statute is concerned.

 

2096 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Simms v. Roosevelt Union Free School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


100 Misc. 2d 827; 420 N.Y.S.2d 96; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2557



July 27, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff grandmother filed a motion for summary judgment in her action against defendant school district for a declaratory judgment, a permanent injunction, and damages. The school district also sought summary judgment. A trial court justice found that the grandmother was a custodian of her grandchildren under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3212(1) and granted a temporary injunction against the district, ordering it to enroll her grandchildren in school.


OVERVIEW: The district denied enrollment to the grandchildren on the ground that their grandmother could not establish she had been judicially appointed their legal guardian. The grandmother sought a declaration that Roosevelt Union Free School District No. 8, Policy Bulletins Nos. 501 and 502 were unconstitutional and invalid in that they purported to exclude from admission any child who resided with a person other than his parent or legal guardian. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the grandmother on the issue of her grandchildren's right to enrollment. Although the written policy did not violate § 3212(1), the school district's more restrictive interpretation of the policy did violate § 3212(1). The court held that any policy interpretation that limited registration to only those children for whom a legally appointed guardianship had been obtained was invalid and unenforceable. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the district as to the grandmother's request for a permanent injunction and damages. The situation required legal redress, which the justice's order had already provided, not compensation.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the grandmother as to the enrollment of her grandchildren in the school. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the district as to the grandmother's request for a permanent injunction and damages.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Responsibility for Child's Attendance -- Enrollment of Child Not Residing with Parent or Legal Guardian

The stated policy of defendant school district, which provides for latitude with respect to the enrollment of children who do not reside with their parents or legal guardians into the district's schools, is not violative of a statute which places the duty of "causing a minor to attend" school upon the person standing in parental relationship to the minor ( Education Law, § 3212, subd 1), which relationship encompasses more than parenthood and judicial guardianship; however, any interpretation of the district's policy which has the effect of limiting registration to only those children for whom a legally appointed guardianship has been obtained, is invalid and unenforceable; a permanent injunction has been rendered academic by virtue of a court order requiring defendant to enroll plaintiff's grandchildren in its schools and a determination with respect to damages arising from the district's refusal to enroll the children is inappropriate since the situation required legal redress and not compensation.

 

2097 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Olsen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


100 Misc. 2d 947; 420 N.Y.S.2d 314; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2582



July 25, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought a ruling on his pretrial motion for an order declaring the notice of alibi statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.20, unconstitutional, or, in the alternative, for full reciprocal discovery under the statute.


OVERVIEW: After the prosecution served a demand for notice of alibi upon defendant, defendant filed a pretrial motion for an order declaring the notice of alibi statute (statute), N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.20, unconstitutional because it required defendant to disclose its alibi witnesses but did not require the prosecution to disclose any witnesses who would place defendant at the scene of the crime. In the alternative defendant requested an order for full reciprocal discovery under the statute. The court denied the motion, holding that the statute was constitutional and did not violate due process. The court found that the statute required reciprocal discovery because it required the prosecution to provide a list of all witnesses to be offered in rebuttal of defendant's alibi defense. The fact that the prosecution was not required to disclose witnesses who would place defendant at the crime scene did not violate due process because these witnesses were part of the prosecution's direct case.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for an order declaring the notice of alibi statute unconstitutional, and denied defendant's motion for full reciprocal discovery.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Alibi -- Constitutionality of Notice-of-Alibi Statute

1. CPL 250.20, which requires the prosecutor, within a reasonable time after receiving defendant's list of alibi witnesses, but not later than 10 days before trial, to serve upon defendant a list of witnesses, with related information, he proposes to offer in rebuttal to discredit defendant's alibi, and which excludes disclosure of a witness who will testify that the defendant was at the scene of the crime as an alibi rebuttal witness, is not unconstitutional, since there is no due process requirement that the prosecution disclose before trial its witnesses who will testify on its direct case; due process requires only reciprocal discovery of those witnesses the People intend to offer in rebuttal of defendant's alibi defense, and evidence which places a defendant at the scene of the crime is part of the People's direct case and cannot be presented for the first time in rebuttal of an alibi defense.

Statutes -- Constitutionality

2. A strong presumption of constitutionality attaches to any statute duly enacted by the Legislature, and in order to declare a law unconstitutional, the invalidity of the law [***2] must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

2098 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Southern Tier Legal Services


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Steuben County


100 Misc. 2d 1068; 420 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2610



July 24, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner legal services, on its own behalf and on behalf of all persons who were their clients or who had an actual attorney-client relationship with it, sought a judgment declaring that each of its clients was an indigent person within the meaning of N.Y. Jud. Law § 35 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 11, and granting to each of its clients, by this single application, all of the privileges set forth in the statute and the rule.


OVERVIEW: The court denied the legal service's request for relief under N.Y. Jud. Law § 35. The court also granted the State's motion for judgment dismissing the claims under § 35 on the ground that this claim, as pleaded, failed to state a cause of action. The court also denied the demand for a change of venue. The court also held that the "blanket" relief requested herein could not be granted under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 11.The court noted that compensation and reimbursement under N.Y. Jud. Law § 35 was available only to court-appointed counsel, and that no such compensation could properly be awarded on the instant application.


OUTCOME: The court denied the request for relief. The court granted the State's motion for judgment dismissing the claims without prejudice to future applications. The court also denied the demand for a change of venue.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attorney and Client -- Legal Services Corporation -- Blanket Poor Person Relief

1. Petitioner legal services corporation is not entitled to blanket poor person relief granting its clients all of the statutory privileges afforded to poor persons in regards to the appointment and compensation of counsel, psychiatrists, certified psychologists and physicians (Judiciary Law, § 35) and payment for stenographic transcripts ( CPLR 1102, subd [b]), since compensation and reimbursement under the statute is available only to court-appointed counsel and a blanket order appointing counsel to represent persons who have an actual attorney-client relationship with petitioner would be grossly improper, the appointment of medical specialists can only be done on a case-by-case basis and a determination of whether a transcript should properly be ordered can only be made after a particular hearing or trial has been held thus making an award of blanket relief inappropriate.

Counties -- Venue of Special Proceeding -- Application for Blanket Poor Person Relief

2. A proceeding instituted by petitioner legal services corporation seeking blanket poor person relief ( CPLR art 11) for its [***2] clients may be brought in one county in a single suit against all the counties against which relief is requested in order to avoid a multiplicity of actions and inconsistent decisions; a change of venue is not mandated since the proceeding involves only issues of law and does not require the presence of any county representatives except their attorneys; notice of the application given to respondent counties through their respective County Attorneys is sufficient ( CPLR 1101, subd [c]) and there is no requirement that the county clerks, court clerks and Sheriffs be named as parties and each separately served with notice.

Attorney and Client -- Legal Services Corporation -- Blanket Poor Person Relief

3. Petitioner legal services corporation is entitled to relief against those counties which did not oppose its application for blanket poor person relief ( CPLR art 11) for its clients except that the nonopposing counties shall not be required to furnish any stenographic transcripts ( CPLR 1102, subd [b]) since a determination of whether there will be merit to a particular client's appeal cannot be made at this time and relief cannot be granted with respect to the assignment [***3] of counsel ( CPLR 1102, subd [a]) since the application is made on behalf of persons who have an actual attorney-client relationship with petitioner.

Attorney and Client -- Legal Services Corporation -- Blanket Poor Person Relief

4. Petitioner, a legal services corporation subject to Federal income eligibility regulations (45 CFR Part 1611), is not entitled to blanket poor person relief ( CPLR art 11) on behalf of its clients over the objection of respondent counties since there is no way to determine that client eligibility standards for a particular Federally funded legal services corporation entitle all clients of that agency to proceed as poor persons and in any event, petitioner has failed to submit a copy of the project eligibility guidelines it is required to establish nor has it established that there is merit in each of its clients' actions; the statute contemplates individualized applications for poor person relief showing the movant's financial condition, and the inherent plenary power of the court to grant limited relief to a litigant separate and distinct from that available under CPLR article 11 does not encompass the relief requested by petitioner; new legislation [***4] is required to afford poor person relief to persons represented by legal services organizations.

 

2099 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Corbett v. Corbett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Queens County


100 Misc. 2d 270; 418 N.Y.S.2d 981; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2450



July 12, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  The court granted the motion of the administratrix and dismissed the petition.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed a paternity proceeding against respondent, the administratrix of the putative father's estate, alleging that the decedent was the natural father of her daughter. The administratrix filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7) for an order dismissing the petition for failure to state a cause of action, relying upon N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 4-1.2(a)(2)(A), which governed inheritance by illegitimate persons.


OVERVIEW: The administratrix claimed that under § 4-1.2(a)(2)(A), the court could not enter a filiation order where the putative father had died prior to commencement of the action. The administratrix argued that § 4-1.2(a)(2)(A) required an order of filiation to be entered declaring paternity during the lifetime of the putative father in a proceeding instituted during the mother's pregnancy or within two years from the child's birth. The mother argued that she was not asking for a finding that the child was entitled to share in the decedent's estate, but only for an adjudication of paternity and an order of filiation. Examining the legislative history, the court found that the statute was not intended to impair the family court's jurisdiction; thus, it did not per se prohibit the family court from entering an order of filiation subsequent to the putative father's death. However, the court found that the family court was a creation of statutory law, possessing only those powers vested in it by the Legislature, and that there was no statute authorizing it to make such a finding. Thus, the court was required to follow the common law rule of abatement upon the putative father's death.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the administratrix and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Family Court -- Jurisdiction

1. EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2], cl [A]), which requires an illegitimate child to obtain an order of filiation during the lifetime of the putative father in order to inherit from him, is substantially related to the permissible State interest of fostering orderly estate administration and was not intended to impair the jurisdiction of the Family Court, which has no jurisdiction over estate administration, and, therefore, does not prohibit the Family Court from entering an order of filiation subsequent to the death of the putative father.

Abatement and Revival -- Paternity Proceeding

2. A paternity proceeding against a putative father who died prior to the commencement of the proceeding must be dismissed since there is no statutory authority in article 5 of the Family Court Act to abrogate the common-law rule of abatement upon the death of the putative father.

 

2100 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shapiro


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 662; 418 N.Y.S.2d 892; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2523



July 10, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged use of an earlier methadone conviction as a predicate felony conviction.


OVERVIEW: The court noted that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 was amended in response to complaints that it treated citizens who committed offenses out of state more harshly than those who committed the identical offense in New York. Under the amended version, only foreign offenses that were presently considered serious transgressions of New York law were to be considered predicate felonies. Because the statute did not provide that a prior New York conviction needed to be similarly based on an offense that was presently a felony in New York, a person who committed a prior offense in New York would be judged by the community norms of New York prevailing at the time of the offense, whereas a person committing the same offense in New Jersey would be judged by the current norms of New York. The court noted that defendant's prior methadone conviction was based on an offense that was at that time, and for a brief period thereafter, a felony and that it was now a misdemeanor. There was no rational basis for treating defendant more harshly than someone with a similar out-of-state conviction. To do so denied him the equal protection of the laws.


OUTCOME: The court found that defendant was not subject to a predicate felony conviction by reason of his methadone conviction.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence -- Predicate Felony

1. Section 70.06 of the Penal Law, in defining predicate felonies, creates an unjust classification which lacks any rational relationship to a legitimate State interest in its treatment of persons with prior felony convictions obtained against them in New York State, in that a crime committed in this State is not to be viewed in light of the felony norms that existed at that time, while a crime committed in another jurisdiction is to be viewed in light of the felony norms that presently exist in this State; accordingly, a defendant who was convicted in this State of possession of methadone, when that was a felony, would have that conviction counted against him as a predicate felony even though that crime is now a misdemeanor, whereas had he been convicted of that same offense in another State, that conviction would be treated as a misdemeanor and would not be considered a predicate felony; therefore, a defendant with a prior New York conviction receives harsher treatment solely because of the geographical location of his crime, which is not only a denial of equal protection of the law, but contrary to the Legislature's intent to reduce [***2] the punishment for possession of methadone.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Predicate Felony

2. The conviction for an act, possession of methadone, that was erroneously classified as a felony by the Legislature, which quickly amended and reclassified it as a misdemeanor, may not be used against a defendant as a predicate felony, since the revival of its felony status would be contrary to both the legislative intent and the basic principles of justice and fairness.

 

2101 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re "R" Children


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 248; 418 N.Y.S.2d 741; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2446



July 5, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent unwed father (father) filed a motion for a stay of judgment on a petition of petitioner, the New York Commissioner of Social Services (commissioner), to remove the father as a party in the parental termination proceedings for his out-of-wedlock children, until it was determined whether N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §§ 384 (1)(c), 384-c (3) and N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111 (1)(c) unconstitutionally disqualified him on the basis of sex.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner filed a motion to delete the cause of action for permanent neglect against the father and to remove him as a party respondent to parental termination proceedings of his out-of-wedlock children. The father contended that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §§ 384 (1)(c), 384-c (3) and N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111 (1)(c) were unconstitutional, that the commissioner's petition should have been dismissed for failure to state a cause of action or that the father should have been allowed to intervene as a party respondent, and that the amended petition could not be granted without either the consent of the father or a finding that he permanently neglected his children. The court concluded that the father could not be disqualified, solely on the basis of sex, as a party respondent in the proceedings because he had the right to consent to the adoption of his out-of-wedlock children. The court held that any distinction between the rights of unmarried mothers and the rights of unmarried fathers was not substantially related to an important state interest and that the commissioner could not terminate the father's parental rights without a finding that he permanently neglected his children.


OUTCOME: The court denied the commissioner's motion to remove the father as a party respondent in the parental termination proceedings regarding the father's out-of-wedlock children.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Rights of Unwed Father in Termination Proceeding

A decision of the United States Supreme Court declaring the gender-based statutory distinction in adoption proceedings between an unmarried mother, whose consent is required (Domestic Relations Law, § 111, subd 1, par [c]), and an unmarried father, who is disqualified solely on the basis of his sex even after the entry of an order of filiation and notwithstanding a clearly established relationship with his children, to be unconstitutional as being unrelated to legitimate governmental objectives (see Caban v Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380), mandates that an unwed father be made a party respondent to a termination of parental rights proceeding (Social Services Law, § 384-b) since he now has a right to consent to the adoption of his out-of-wedlock offspring.

 

2102 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mid-Hudson Nuclear Opponents, Inc. v. Consolidated Edison Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Dutchess County; Columbia County


100 Misc. 2d 158; 418 N.Y.S.2d 883; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2432



July 2, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant Con Edison's motions are granted and the complaints in these suits are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff activists, political officials, and township residents (opponents) filed actions against defendant utility company for a declaratory judgment and an injunction on the grounds that the utility company's activity in conducting studies in order to determine whether the land would have been appropriate for nuclear-powered or coal-fired steam facilities constituted a public and private nuisance and violated N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 65(3).


OVERVIEW: The actions were consolidated and the utility company filed motions for summary judgment, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212. At issue was whether the complaints presented genuine controversies that were ripe for a final determination of rights. The court held that the opponents had failed to come forward with proof that any act was done by the utility company, or was threatened or imminent, which could have caused material special injury to them. The court determined that from the evidence it was clear that the events which the opponents feared were at least several years away and that they may never have come to pass. Therefore, the opponents were before the court with a controversy which was far from being ripe for adjudication and the court granted the utility company's motions for summary judgment and dismissed the complaints.


OUTCOME: The court granted the utility company's motions for summary judgment and dismissed the opponents' actions for declaratory judgments and an injunction.


HEADNOTES

Public Utilities -- Location of Future Generating Facilities

An injunction to stop feasibility studies by a utility on two tracts of utility-owned land for the purpose of determining their appropriateness as sites for nuclear-powered or coal-fired steam electric generating facilities, will not be granted where there is no proof that any of the utility's acts presently are causing material injury, and where those seeking the injunction have only alleged fears that some day a nuclear-powered facility will be built near them, and have offered only sparse evidence that this possibility has tended to depress the local real estate market, and since the erection and operation of a nuclear facility is years in the future, if it occurs at all, this issue is far from being ripe for adjudiciation and is, therefore, prematurely brought, as the facility's construction is a future event beyond the control of the utility which must first receive the approval of several State and Federal regulatory agencies.

 

2103 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Williams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


100 Misc. 2d 183; 418 N.Y.S.2d 737; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2437



June 29, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reason, this motion of the defendant to dismiss the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following his plea of guilty, defendant, a juvenile, filed a motion to dismiss an indictment on the grounds that the sentencing provisions of 1978 N.Y. Laws ch. 481 were violative of his constitutional rights to equal protection of the laws and to due process of law as well as to his rights to be protected against cruel and inhuman punishment.


OVERVIEW: The State opposed defendant's motion, asserting that ch. 481 suffered from no constitutional deficiencies as they related to defendant. The court treated the motion as one requesting that the alleged unconstitutional portion of ch. 481 be disregarded for purposes of sentencing, and that defendant be considered as eligible for youthful offender treatment.The court noted that given the presumption that the grand jury performed its duties in accordance with law, the question of removal to family court was already considered but rejected. In addition, there was no constitutional right to youthful offender treatment. While defendant was not eligible for youthful offender adjudication, he did have available comparable ameliorative treatment under ch. 481. He was subject to the prospects of greater relief and greater opportunity for such relief. There was thus no basis for a finding of a denial of equal protection of law or due process.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Sentencing Statute

1. Where a 14-year-old juvenile offender, following his plea of guilty to a violent felony offense (Penal Law, § 30.00, subd 2), moves to dismiss the indictment against him on the grounds that the sentencing provisions of chapter 481 of the Laws of 1978 are violative of his constitutional rights to equal protection of the laws, due process of law and protection against cruel and inhuman punishment in that, because of the classification scheme created by such laws, he is being denied consideration for youthful offender treatment solely because of his age and he will be subject to a mandatory period of imprisonment if a simultaneous motion for removal to Family Court is not granted (Penal Law, § 70.05, subd 4), such grounds do not set forth a basis for dismissal of the indictment, particularly since the court has the option on sentencing to construe the challenged statute in a constitutional manner. Accordingly, under such circumstances, the court will treat the motion as one requesting that the allegedly unconstitutional portion [***2] of the statute be disregarded for purposes of sentencing, and that the defendant be considered as eligible for youthful offender treatment.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute

2. Legislative enactments are presumptively constitutional, and a heavy burden rests with the defendant asserting the contrary to be true; if there is any doubt as to the constitutionality of a statute, the enactment should be upheld. Accordingly, a trial court should not set aside a legislative enactment unless such conclusion of unconstitutionality is inescapable.

Infants -- Juvenile Offenders

3. The sentencing provisions of chapter 481 of the Laws of 1978 are not violative of the constitutional rights of a 14-year-old juvenile offender, who pleaded guilty to a violent felony offense (Penal Law, § 30.00, subd 2), to equal protection of the laws and due process of law as a denial of consideration for youthful offender treatment ( CPL art 720) based solely on his age, or the right to be protected against cruel and inhuman punishment in that he will be subject to a mandatory period of imprisonment if a motion for removal to Family Court ( CPL 330.25) is not granted (US Const, 5th,  [***3] 8th, 14th Amdts), since the provisions of chapter 481 of the Laws of 1978 contain a number of ameliorative mechanisms providing for removal to Family Court at four different stages of the proceeding with the same practical consequences as attach to an adjudication as a youthful offender under CPL article 720, namely, sealed records and the potential of substantially reduced incarceration for the offender; moreover, there is no constitutional right to youthful offender treatment, which treatment is afforded only upon a favorable exercise of discretion by the sentencing court, the same possibility or opportunity for ameliorative relief which is afforded under the provisions of chapter 481; nor does such legislation reflect invidious discrimination because of age, but rather reflects a reasoned response in defining the penal responsibility of such offenders, since such juvenile offender may receive a substantially lesser period of imprisonment than a nonjuvenile violent felony offender.

 

2104 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Andrews v. Mensch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


100 Misc. 2d 79; 418 N.Y.S.2d 527; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2417



June 28, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In accordance with the foregoing, summary judgment is granted in favor of plaintiffs Francis Popp and Anna Schreiber on their second cause of action for punitive damages of $ 460 and $ 440 respectively against the defendants Max Mensch and Harold Marcus.


CASE SUMMARY:
