PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, residents of an adult home, filed an action to recover their Supplemental Security Income personal allowances, which were withheld by defendants, owners of the adult home, in violation of N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-o. The residents filed motions for summary judgment and for the appointment of a guardian ad litem for other plaintiff residents. The owners opposed the motion and sought to dismiss certain defendants.


OVERVIEW: First, the court determined that the owners had belatedly disbursed the residents' personal allowances to them. Thus, the first count of the complaint was dismissed. Secondly, the court determined that two defendants were not owners of the home and dismissed them. Third, the court denied the residents' motion to appoint a guardian ad litem for other residents, because they had not received the required notice. Fourth, the court granted summary judgment to the residents on their claim that the owners wrongfully withheld their personal allowances in violation of § 131-o. The owners alleged that they placed a certain portion of the $ 30 personal allowance in an escrow account, upon advice of counsel, until such time as a pending court case regarding the validity of § 131-o was decided. The court held that the owners did not have a right to withhold the funds, which were to be disbursed monthly. The residents were injured in not having access to money to purchase personal items when needed, which was the intended purpose of the allowance. Pursuant to § 131-o(3), the residents were entitled to punitive damages in an amount equal to twice the amount that had been withheld.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed count one of the complaint and granted summary judgment to the residents on their second cause of action, the claim that their personal allowance had been wrongfully withheld. The court granted the owners' request to dismiss two defendants, denied the residents' request to appoint a guardian ad litem for other residents, and awarded punitive damages to the residents.


HEADNOTES

Guardian and Ward -- Notice of Appointment

1. A motion to have a guardian ad litem appointed is dismissed where plaintiffs have not complied with CPLR 1202 requiring that notice be given to the persons to be represented.

Parties -- Proper Parties

2. A complaint seeking moneys due from owners of an adult home is dismissed against stockholders of the corporation which leases the building to the adult home for plaintiffs' failure to show that the stockholders were involved in the withholding of the moneys.

Social Services -- Residential Facilities -- Payment of Personal Allowance to Residents

3. Defendants' failure to comply with subdivision 7 of section 131-o of the Social Services Law, which requires residential facilities to make specified income available to residents, subjects them to double punitive damages ( Social Services Law, § 131-o, subd 3) since such funds were "withheld to other than [***2] the intended use" in that the allowance was not made available for the residents' personal use for one year; defendants' reliance on a Supreme Court decision holding subdivision 7 of section 131-o unconstitutional is unjustified since the decision had no res judicata effect on the defendants in this case and, in addition, defendants began withholding the moneys in controversy one year prior to the ruling; defendants' reliance on the advice of counsel in withholding the funds is not a defense to punitive damages where malice is not an element of the punitive damages cause of action.

Social Services -- Residential Facilities -- Resident Allowance Accounts

4. A residential facility's failure to comply with subdivision 4 of section 131-o of the Social Services Law requiring detailed documentation of all transactions involving personal allowance accounts is grounds for summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs.

 

2105 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Elsberg v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


99 Misc. 2d 1101; 418 N.Y.S.2d 273; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2400



June 22, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner principal brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding for an order vacating and annulling the actions of respondent board of education in removing the principal from his position as principal.


OVERVIEW: The principal was granted tenure as an assistant principal and was assigned as acting junior principal at two schools in succession. The board terminated the principal's employment as principal at the end of a probation period at the second of the schools. The principal asserted that the board's by-laws required him to be continued in his position as principal after three years of service until the position was abolished or vacated, and that in addition he had reached an agreement with an assistant superintendent that the new assignment was to be considered as continuous with his previous one. The board contended that the by-law benefited the principal only while he was at the first school under his assistant principal license and that the by-law was unconstitutional. The court found no merit to the board's contentions. Reclassification that conformed the civil service structure to the realities of an agency's operations prior to reclassification was valid. The principal received a permanent appointment by virtue of the by-law. He was in the position for nine years, and equitable estoppel thus applied against the board.


OUTCOME: The court found that the board had no basis in law to remove the principal from his position.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Principals -- Tenure

1. A board of education by-law which grants tenure to assistant principals who have served as heads of special schools for three years does not violate section 6 of article V of the New York Constitution; in addition, an agreement between petitioner, a school principal, and an assistant superintendent providing for a transfer of petitioner's tenure upon his assumption of a new position does not violate section 6 of article V of the New York Constitution and is legally enforceable.

Constitutional Law -- Tenure for School Principals

2. In a proceeding to annul a determination of the board of education removing petitioner, a tenured assistant principal, from his most recent position as principal of a special school due to his failure to be granted tenure in this position, the requested relief is granted on the grounds that petitioner received a permanent appointment in 1970 by virtue of a board of education by-law which grants tenure to assistant principals who have served as heads of special schools for three years, and by virtue of an agreement made between petitioner and an assistant superintendent assuring petitioner that his assignment [***2] as principal of the special school would be considered continuous with his former position; furthermore, petitioner, in that he has served as a principal for nine years, is entitled to apply the doctrine of equitable estoppel against the board of education.

 

2106 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Nicholson v. State Com. on Judicial Conduct


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 62; 418 N.Y.S.2d 265; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2414



June 21, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In the investigation of a judicial election, respondent State Commission on Judicial Conduct (New York) filed a motion for orders compelling petitioner witnesses to continue to testify, pursuant to subpoenas. The witnesses claimed that the questions of the Commission exceeded the scope of its investigation and sought to consolidate their motions with a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding brought by respondent judge.


OVERVIEW: The Commission initiated an investigation of the conduct of a judicial candidate related to a fund raising meeting. The witnesses were subpoenaed to testify before the Commission, but refused to answer questions that exceeded the scope of the original complaint. The Commission filed a motion to compel the witnesses' testimony. The witnesses sought to join their motions for a protective order with an art. 78 proceeding instituted by the judge. The trial court granted the witnesses' motion to join the art. 78 proceeding, as the factual issues and principles of law were interrelated. It further granted the motion of the Commission to compel the witnesses to testify. It explained that the original complaints to the Commission had concerned the fund raising meeting and that a wide-ranging investigation of those complaints had produced additional information. However, a newly filed complaint of which the witnesses were unaware, had been based on information from third parties, not from the investigation of the initial complaint. Thus, the new complaint was a proper foundation for the Commission's ongoing investigation, and the witnesses were required to answer questions related to it.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted the motion of the Commission to compel answers and granted the motion of the witnesses to consolidate their motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Proceeding against Body or Officer -- When Remedy Available -- Challenge to Investigatory Action

1. An article 78 proceeding is the appropriate procedure to challenge the authority of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct to obtain from subpoenaed witnesses the names of contributors to a judicial election campaign and the reasons for their contributions to the campaign and whether they had contributed to other judicial campaigns since, although prohibition does not usually lie when the investigatory action by an administrative agency is being challenged as being beyond the scope of its authority, since such a grievance is ordinarily correctable on appeal after final determination, such is not the case when a continuance of an unauthorized act might result in grievous harm, and, while the names and addresses of contributors are available as a public record (Election Law, § 14-102), any abuse of that requirement which might cast a chill over the right and freedom of people to associate for proper purposes, must be struck down before the effect of that abuse can be felt.

Judges -- Investigation by State Commission on Judicial Conduct

2. A complaint received by [***2] the State Commission on Judicial Conduct triggers the exercise of the commission's power and sets the proper bounds to the exercise of that power, and since the complaint may not be disclosed to any person except to the Judge involved, the witnesses called to testify before the commission in connection with an investigation have no remedy to determine whether or not their interrogation is within proper bounds except through an article 78 proceeding.

Judges -- Investigation by State Commission on Judicial Conduct

3. Although a wide-ranging investigation of a Judge conducted by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, not limited to the original complaint which was addressed to the propriety of a particular fund-raising meeting in the judicial election campaign, was beyond the scope of the original authority, a subsequent administrator's complaint filed against the Judge based on other information which had been obtained by the commission from third parties and not from the overly broad investigation of the original complaint, is a proper foundation for the investigation being conducted.

Judges -- Investigation by State Commission on Judicial Conduct

4. The investigation [***3] conducted by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct into the planning of a judicial election campaign and its fund raising and expenditures may properly continue insofar as it relates to alleged improper conduct by, or at the direction of the Judge; the question of whether the Canons of Judicial Ethics may be improper as violative of the right of judicial candidates to obtain support for their candidacies is premature since the complaint does not specify violation of the canons and until the facts are assembled and analyzed through the administrative process no firm conclusions can be drawn.

 

2107 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re L.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 173; 418 N.Y.S.2d 859; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2435



June 20, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the instant petition is dismissed and the foregoing is deemed the final decision and order of this court under the above-captioned matter.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner commissioner of social services petitioned to declare respondent juvenile, a runaway from Florida, a person in need of supervision (PINS) within the meaning of N.Y. Family Ct. Act § 712(b). When the juvenile failed to return to the trial court on an adjourned date, the juvenile's law guardian filed a motion to dismiss the petition, and the commissioner requested a warrant for the juvenile's arrest.


OVERVIEW: The juvenile, aged 15, ran away from her home in Florida. The commissioner filed a PINS petition to facilitate her return in accordance with the Interstate Compact on Juveniles. The juvenile did not wish to return home, and the trial court remanded her to the commissioner's care. When the juvenile failed to appear for an adjourned hearing date, her law guardian filed a motion to dismiss the petition, and the commissioner sought a warrant for her arrest. The trial court dismissed the petition. It explained that the juvenile had been a resident of Florida and had run away from her home in that state. At the time she ran away, there had been no contact by any interested party, child, or parent with the State of New York. Thus, New York could not detain the juvenile and charge her with being "incorrigible, ungovernable or habitually disobedient," under N.Y. Family Ct. Act § 712(b), for an act committed in another jurisdiction. It held that the action taken by New York was an unconstitutional assault on the right of the juvenile to travel unimpaired between the various states and contravened the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.


OUTCOME: The trial court dismissed the petition to find the juvenile a person in need of supervision.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision -- Interstate Compact on Juveniles

1. A petition seeking both that respondent be adjudicated a person in need of supervision and that she be dealt with in accordance with the Interstate Compact on Juveniles in an attempt to fuse two separate and distinct legal procedures is insufficient on its fact to afford relief under either procedure.

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision -- Runaway

2. A single act of running away from home does not make a child incorrigible, ungovernable or habitually disobedient within the meaning of subdivision (b) of section 712 of the Family Court Act, and even if the child absconded on several occasions, she could not be adjudged a person in need of supervision absent proof that the child so behaved without just cause.

Courts -- Family Court -- Runaway

3. A New York Family Court does not have jurisdiction over an alleged runaway, presently detained in New York for the purpose of adjudicating her a person in need of supervision,  [***2] where the child and her parents were residents of Florida and where the child allegedly ran away from her home in that State; in the case of a child who is mature enough to express potentially conflicting desires, the presumption that she has run away from home, based solely on the observations that she is away from home and unaccompanied by a parent, is constitutionally impermissible; such a presumption may not serve as a jurisdictional basis to adjudicate the juvenile a person in need of supervision in that it unreasonably and unnecessarily prejudices her right to travel under the privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

Courts -- Family Court -- Runaway

4. A New York Family Court does not have jurisdiction over an alleged runaway solely on the basis of her dependent status in this State; to subject respondent to the stigma and legal consequences of a PINS adjudication based only on her status in this State as a dependent child would constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.

 

2108 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kroul v. Kroul


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


99 Misc. 2d 1031; 417 N.Y.S.2d 847; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2383



June 15, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife instituted an action against defendant husband for payment of arrears under a contract the parties entered into, which modified alimony and child support provisions of their divorce decree. The wife was granted summary judgment by the district court (New York) and the husband filed a motion to vacate the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The husband claimed that the court was prohibited from enforcing the alimony decree because the United States Supreme Court had found an alimony statute in Alabama unconstitutional because it used gender as a basis for classification without the necessary exigent circumstances being present. The court stated that N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236 was construed to afford equal eligibility to both spouses for alimony. Assuming arguendo that the entire section was unconstitutional, the effect of such was prospective only. Accordingly, the court found that the Supreme Court's decision did not bar the enforcement of the husband's alimony obligations. The court did find, however, that N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 5-311 did circumscribe the husband's rights to contract concerning his obligation to support his wife and provided an entirely different standard to the wife's contractual rights. Thus, the court held that this was unconstitutional. While the court was of the opinion that § 5-311 was unconstitutional, it did not so hold because the husband had not directly challenged its constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husband's motion to vacate the summary judgment order in favor of the wife. The wife was allowed to enter judgment in the amount of $ 6,000 plus interest, costs, and disbursements.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Alimony and Allowances

1. Section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides for the payment of alimony to the wife in an action for divorce, is repugnant to the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution in that it employs sex as a basis for classification without the necessary exigent circumstances being present; accordingly, section 236 must be rendered gender neutral and construed to afford equal eligibility to both spouses for alimony.

Husband and Wife -- Agreement to Relieve Husband of Liability to Support Wife

2. Section 5-311 of the General Obligations Law, which provides that a husband and wife cannot contract to relieve the husband of his liability to support his wife, does address the wife's contractual rights but provides an entirely different standard and, in the absence of any clear governmental objectives to be served by the classification, would appear to be unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution.

 

2109 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gold v. Gartenstein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


100 Misc. 2d 253; 418 N.Y.S.2d 852; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2447



June 14, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Respondent having failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the statute is unconstitutional, the writ of prohibition is granted, and the stay is vacated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner district attorney filed a proceeding to prohibit respondent, a judge of a criminal court, from enforcing an order directing that defendant, a juvenile, and a person entitled to mandatory youthful offender treatment, receive a jury trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with petit larceny and criminal possession of stolen property arising out of an alleged purse snatching. He was an eligible youth within N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10. The criminal court judge granted defendant's motion for a jury trial, finding that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(7), which provided that defendants charged with misdemeanors were not entitled to a jury trial, was unconstitutional. The district attorney sought to prohibit the judge from enforcing his order. Granting the writ, the court held that (1) prohibition was proper where the judge had acted in excess of his power in directing a jury trial in contravention of § 340.40 and where no constitutional right existed; (2) petit larceny was a crime which was malum in se, thus, the common law treatment or nature of offense plus punishment standard applied to determine whether defendant was entitled to a jury trial; (3) applying that test, larceny was a "petty offense"; thus, § 340.40(7) did not violate defendant's right to a jury trial; and (4) defendant had no right to treatment because the State was not seeking to incarcerate defendant for noncriminal acts for the purpose of treatment.


OUTCOME: The court granted the writ of prohibition.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition

1. Constitutional issues involving errors of substantive or procedural law may not be raised by way of prohibition since that remedy is available only when a court acts or threatens to act without jurisdiction in a matter over which it has no power over the subject matter, or where it exceeds its authority in a proceeding over which it has jurisdiction.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition

2. The gravity of the harm, alternative remedies, and the magnitude of the problem are factors that a court may consider in determining whether to permit the remedy of prohibition, since that remedy is discretionary, not mandatory.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition

3. A Judge of an inferior court who ordered a jury trial for a youthful offender facing misdemeanor charges in violation of CPL 340.40 (subd 7), and who declared that statute unconstitutional despite the fact that there is a rational basis for its constitutionality [***2] and despite the fact that lower courts should exercise restraint in declaring statutes unconstitutional, did not merely make an error in deciding the constitutional issue, but acted in excess of his authority, for which the granting of a writ of prohibition is proper.

Crimes -- Right to Jury Trial

4. Although the right to a jury trial is constitutionally guaranteed to defendants in State criminal trials, that right is not absolute and does not extend to trials for "petty" offenses.

Crimes -- Right to Jury Trial

5. There is a right to a jury trial for crimes that are malum prohibitum if the defendant faces a period of incarceration greater than six months, and, therefore, the offense is considered serious; if such a defendant faces a period of incarceration of six months or less, then the offense is classified as petty and no jury trial is required. To determine the right to a jury trial for crimes that are malum in se, the offense should be examined either according to the common-law treatment or nature of the offense plus the punishment imposed, in order to classify the offense as serious or petty, with the former requiring a jury but not the latter.

 [***3] Crimes -- Right to Jury Trial

6. The crime of petit larceny is one which is malum in se requiring either an examination of its common-law treatment of nature offen offense plus punishment test to determine a defendant's right to a jury trial; however, if a defendant is a youthful offender, inquiring into the common-law treatment is inappropriate since the status of youthful offender was unknown to the common law which treated infants in the same manner as adults.

Infants -- Youthful Offenders -- Right to Jury Trial

7. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which mandates nonjury trials for first-time youthful offenders, is not an unconstitutional violation of the youthful offender's right to a jury trial for the crime of petit larceny, since the nature of the offense is such that a youthful offender adjudication is not a judgment of conviction for a crime, and conviction as a youthful offender is not criminal in nature, thereby permitting the youthful offender proceeding to be summarily conducted, and since the maximum period of incarceration for such a youthful offender is six months, the crime of petit larceny can be classified as a petty offense when committed by such a youthful [***4] offender, and, therefore, does not require a jury trial; the fact that such a youthful offender may be placed on probation does not change the offense from petty to serious.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Predicate Nature of Youthful Offender Adjudication

8. The predicate nature of a conviction of a youthful offender for petit larceny without a jury trial pursuant to CPL 340.40 (subd 7) does not render that statute unconstitutional since such a conviction was constitutionally obtained and may validly serve as a basis for different treatment and/or punishment in a subsequent proceeding.

Infants -- Youthful Offenders -- Right to Treatment

9. CPL 340.40 (subd 7) does not violate a youthful offender's constitutional right to treatment since that right only applies where the State seeks to incarcerate a person through noncriminal procedures for noncriminal acts for purposes of treatment, and the statute does not have that purpose, but rather is designed to incarcerate a youthful offender for his illegal activity.

Infants -- Youthful Offenders

10. The youthful offender statute ( CPL 720) does not violate the equal protection clause of the Constitution.

 

2110 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. L.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 922; 417 N.Y.S.2d 655; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2361



June 13, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claiming prosecution for consensual sodomy under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.38 violated the right to equal protection because the statute was inapplicable to married couples, defendant moved to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


OVERVIEW: After police observed a female performing fellatio upon defendant in a parked van, defendant was arrested and charged with consensual sodomy, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 130.38. Following defendant's conviction, defendant sought review, claiming § 130.38's exemption for married persons who engaged in consensual sodomy denied unmarried consensual sodomites equal protection of the law. In affirming, the court held § 130.38's exception had been based on the privacy attached to marital relationships. The court also held that an essential prerequisite for constitutional protection of a consensual sexual act was that the act be performed in private. Because defendant had performed the act of consensual sodomy in a van parked on a public street and open to public view, the court held defendant could not claim constitutional protection for the act.


OUTCOME: In rejecting defendant's claim that prosecution for consensual sodomy violated the right to equal protection because the crime was inapplicable to married couples, the court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute

1. A legislative enactment is entitled to a strong presumption of constitutionality which must be rebutted beyond a reasonable doubt by the person attacking the statute on constitutional grounds, and courts of original jurisdiction should not strike down a statute unless its invalidity is patent and it is shown that no constitutional interpretation is possible.

Crimes -- Consensual Sodomy

2. An unmarried defendant engaged in consensual sodomy in violation of section 130.38 of the Penal Law, while in a van parked on a city street in the early morning hours, cannot successfully challenge the constitutionality of that statute as a denial of equal protection, although acts of consensual sodomy between a married couple are not proscribed by the statute (see Penal Law, § 130.00, subd 2), since the defendant has failed to meet the initial requirement that such acts must be performed privately and circumspectly in order to claim constitutional protection for the act.

 

2111 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ardsley Constr. Co. v. Port of New York Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 945; 417 N.Y.S.2d 649; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2365



June 12, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Those branches of plaintiff's motion to establish June 13, 1967 as the date of the accrual of the claim and to amend the caption to reflect the proper name of the defendant as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are granted; that branch of the motion seeking to declare unconstitutional chapter 585 of the Laws of 1939 is denied and plaintiff shall have judgment against defendant for $ 92,672 with interest at the rate of 4% from June 13, 1967.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff contractor filed an action against defendant public corporation to recover damages for breach of a contract to repair a public bridge. The jury returned a verdict in favor of the contractor. The contractor then filed a post-trial motion to fix the date from which interest was to be computed and to have 1939 N.Y. Laws 585, which limited interest on breach of contract claims against public corporations, declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The contractor argued that the interest limitation of 1939 N.Y. Laws 585 on contract claims was both a denial of its right to equal protection of the law and a taking of its property without just compensation. The court granted the contractor's motion with respect to the date of accrual for purposes of the interest calculation because the appellate court had acknowledged that the date sought by the contractor was the correct date. The court denied the contractor's motion to have 1939 N.Y. Laws 585 declared unconstitutional because the statute did not create an invidious classification, nor did the establishment of the maximum rate of interest on contract claims constitute a taking of the contractor's property. The contractor failed to establish that its constitutionally protected rights under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses were violated. Any classification created by 1939 N.Y. Laws 585 was not palpably arbitrary and capricious and the distinction for actions for breach of contract served a rational governmental purpose and was therefore immune from attack as a denial of equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court granted the contractor's motion to establish the date of the accrual of the claim for the purpose of calculating interest in its judgment against the public corporation. The court denied the contractor's motion seeking to declare unconstitutional the statutory limitation for the rate of interest in breach of contract actions against public corporations.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statutory Classifications

1. The Legislature has wide discretion in fashioning classifications which are reasonably related to a valid object of legislation and the question of constitutional validity disappears when it cannot be said that no state of facts reasonably justifying the classification can be conceived, the burden resting with one who challenges the classification to show that it does not rest upon any reasonable basis but that it is palpably arbitrary and capricious.

Interest -- Contract Claim against Public Corporation -- Equal Protection

2. A statute limiting the interest on breach of contract claims against public corporations to 4% (L 1939, ch 585), while interest [***2] on condemnation claims is 6%, does not create an irrational distinction that is presumptively arbitrary and capricious since it is within the discretion of the Legislature to set the rate of interest for claims against public corporations; although statutes which differentiate between different classes of owners in condemnation cases and allow differing rates of interest depending on the governmental unit involved deny equal protection, the establishment of the rate of interest for claims against a public corporation insofar as that rate differs from the rate established for condemnation actions could be based upon the reasonable legislative determination that public corporations should have a favorable status under the law and therefore the distinction made between condemnation proceedings and contract actions does serve a rational governmental purpose and is therefore immune from attack as a denial of equal protection.

Interest -- Contract Claim against Public Corporation -- Due Process

3. Payment of interest on a breach of a contract claim against a public corporation at the statutory rate of 4% (L 1939, ch 585), rather than at the 6% rate for condemnation cases, does [***3] not constitute a taking of plaintiff's property in derogation of plaintiff's right of due process since a mere breach of contract neither impairs contractual obligations nor constitutes a taking of property sufficient to satisfy due process and, therefore, not all damages incident to a breach of contract are constitutionally protected; plaintiff's property right is in the compensation for work performed under the contract and not in the interest rate to be paid on the claim and, even assuming that plaintiff's property was taken, the rate of interest established by statute is presumptively reasonable and should be applied by the courts in the absence of evidence sufficient to rebut that presumption.

 

2112 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Coalition against Rent Increase Passalongs v. Rent Guidelines Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


104 Misc. 2d 101; 427 N.Y.S.2d 660; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2960



June 11, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, rent stabilized tenants and tenants' associations, applied for an order enjoining the issuance and enforcement of any surcharge order or other addition to any rent guidelines order and to enjoin defendants, rent guidelines board, appeals board, and chairman, from enforcing New York City, N.Y. Rent Guidelines Order Nos. 10A and 10B. Defendant appeals board and defendant chairman filed a cross-motion to dismiss the complaint as to them.


OVERVIEW: The rent stabilized tenants and the tenants' associations filed a motion for an order enjoining, pendente lite, the issuance and enforcement of any surcharge order or other addition to any rent guidelines order and collecting any surcharge or other increase pursuant to New York City, N.Y. Rent Guidelines Order Nos. 10A and 10B and to enjoin the rental guidelines board, appeals board, and appeals board chairman from issuing and enforcing Orders 10A and 10B and collecting any rental pursuant to the orders. The appeals board and its chairman filed a cross-motion to dismiss the complaint as to them. The court denied both the motion and the cross-motion. The court held that: (1) the meetings at which the orders were adopted were not procedurally defective; (2) the attack on the rent guidelines board for taking into consideration data of events later than the year 1977 was no basis for a preliminary injunction; (3) administrative agencies were not required to ignore realities that were apparent at the time of adoption of regulations, rules, or guidelines; (4) the tenants and associations failed to demonstrate irreparable injury if the motion for an injunction should be denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of the tenants and tenants' associations for an order enjoining enforcement of rent guidelines orders. The court denied the cross-motion of the appeals board and the chairman to dismiss the complaint as to them.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulations -- Rent Guidelines Order

1. Plaintiffs, rent stabilized tenants and various associations of tenants, are not entitled to a preliminary injunction enjoining the enforcement of certain rent guidelines orders promulgated by the Rent Guidelines Board for leases entered into during the 12-month period beginning July 1, 1978 since the meetings at which the guidelines were adopted were not procedurally defective (Administrative Code of City of New York, § YY51-5.0, subd b; Public Officers Law, art 7) and the issue of whether or not tenants were given sufficient opportunity to present data relating to the fuel surcharge guidelines order is a matter which is open to question and cannot be a basis for a preliminary injunction; questions relating to defects and shortcomings alleged to exist in the board itself and its staff have no bearing on an application for a preliminary injunction and are matters for the city legislature and executive and not for the courts.

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulations -- Rent Guidelines Order

2. The fact that the Rent Guidelines Board for the City of New York, in promulgating rent guidelines orders [***2] for leases entered into during the 12-month period beginning July 1, 1978, considered data relating to costs incurred subsequent to July 1, 1979, the board's determinations having been delayed long after July 1, 1978 because of procedural defects in its initial guidelines order (see 98 Misc 2d 312), is no basis for the issuance of a preliminary injunction since although the board is required to file "its findings for the preceding calendar year" no later than July 1 of each year (Administrative Code, § YY51-5.0, subd b), there is nothing in the statute to suggest that only findings for the preceding year shall constitute a basis for the board's holding in the following year beginning July 1; the law does not require administrative agencies to ignore realities which are apparent at the time of adoption of regulations, rules or guidelines; what the board is engaged in prior to July 1 of each year is prediction of the economic facts of the ensuing three years and if the board at the time of adoption of rent guidelines has available to it further data which will help it refine those predictions, there is no reason in law to deny it such opportunity.

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent  [***3] Regulations -- Rent Guidelines Order

3. The Rent Guidelines Board for the City of New York had the power to include a "reopener clause" for fuel costs in its rent guidelines order for leases entered into during the 12-month period beginning July 1, 1978 and to thereafter promulgate a second order allowing landlords a further rent increase because of the rapid rise in fuel costs since the statutory requirement that the board establish rent guidelines "annually" (Administrative Code, § YY51-5.0, subd b) does not prohibit the board from reviewing the circumstances of the residential real estate industry more than once during the course of a year; in adopting the requirement that the board review the guidelines "annually", the city council did not intend to limit the board but to mandate the board to review rentals and stabilize housing not less frequently than once each year and in order to achieve one of the purposes of rent control of conserving and improving housing, the board must necessarily have the power to deal with near catastrophic changes in the real estate industry; the board's right to reopen a rent guidelines order during a 12-month period is not an unconstitutional [***4] invasion of the contractual rights of landlords and tenants since said fuel surcharge order applies only to leases thereafter executed and, in any event, questions as to the implementation of the order do not constitute grounds for a preliminary injunction.

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulations -- Rent Guidelines Order

4. Plaintiffs, rent stabilized tenants and various associations of tenants, although stating a cause of action, are not entitled to a preliminary injunction enjoining the enforcement of certain rent guidelines orders promulgated by the Rent Guidelines Board for leases entered into during the 12-month period beginning July 1, 1978 since they failed to demonstrate any irreparable injury should their application for an injunction be denied and, except for the board's failure to file its findings and explanatory statement concerning the guidelines order allowing landlords a further rent increase because of rising fuel costs (Administrative Code, § YY51-5.0, subd b), plaintiffs have not demonstrated clearly that they are likely to succeed in the action; however, since the board's failure to comply with statutory mandates cannot be ignored, the motion is denied [***5] with leave to renew as to the fuel surcharge order when the explanatory statement is filed or by June 20, 1979 irrespective of the explanatory statement.

 

2113 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tinneny


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


99 Misc. 2d 962; 417 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2369



June 7, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a motion to suppress physical evidence obtained from the premises of his automobile salvage business, defendant questioned the constitutionality of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5) and the manner in which the police engaged in an inspection of defendant's junkyard under color of the challenged statute.


OVERVIEW: Police engaged in a warrantless inspection of defendant's junkyard, pursuant to the state vehicle dismantlers law, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a. Defendant was indicted and charged with several counts. Plaintiff moved to suppress evidence seized by the police during the search. The court concluded that defendant's consent to search was a reluctant acquiescence and submission to authority. Accordingly, the legality of the search and seizure was to stand or fall upon statutory authorization. The court held that the warrantless search of defendant's business premises, under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a, and the seizure of the allegedly stolen automobile parts found therein, as well as the seizure of a taillight assembly, were legal. Inspection for compliance with the dismantlers law, as an administrative search related to a pervasively regulated industry, posed only a limited threat to defendant's expectations of privacy. Further, the seizure of the taillight was upheld, as it was in plain view and seized incident to an arrest. Finally, the court held that Miranda warnings were unnecessary, as defendant was not in custody.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Warrantless Administrative Search of Automobile Junkyard

1. While a search warrant issued upon probable cause is not required when a search is conducted pursuant to consent, the court is required to indulge every reasonable presumption against the waiver of constitutional rights and a prosecutor seeking to rely upon consent to justify the lawfulness of a search has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that the consent was unequivocal, voluntary and freely given; accordingly, since defendant's consent to a search of his automobile junkyard by plain-clothes police officers after being advised that a search warrant was not required to inspect his business premises and the records he was required by statute to maintain as a licensed auto dismantler (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 415-a), was merely a reluctant acquiescence and submission to authority, he did not voluntarily consent to the search and the legality of the search and resulting seizure of allegedly stolen automobile parts must stand or fall upon the statutory authorization with the initial burden of going forward to show the legality of the police conduct being [***2] upon the People but the accused shouldering the burden of persuasion to suppress the evidence.

Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Warrantless Administrative Search of Automobile Junkyard

2. The warrantless search of defendant's automobile junkyard pursuant to a statute which authorizes administrative inspection of books and records upon the premises of a licensed auto dismantler during usual business hours (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 415-a), and the resulting seizure of allegedly stolen automobile parts found on defendant's premises are lawful since warrantless searches for "pervasively regulated" businesses "long subject to close supervision and inspection", such as defendant's type of business, carefully limited in time, place and scope, are exceptions to the rule that warrantless administrative searches are constitutionally impermissible; the authority to inspect records includes the authority to physically inspect the inventory for compliance since, without the ability to substantiate statutory compliance by visual examination of the inventory, the intent of the statute of deterring the acquisition and disposition of stolen items would be frustrated; the statute [***3] gives adequate notice of what is required of a person operating an auto dismantling business and inspection for compliance with the law poses only a limited threat to expectations of privacy.

Crimes -- Warrantless Search Incident to Lawful Arrest

3. A search without a warrant is lawful if incident to a lawful arrest and if it is substantially contemporaneous with the arrest and is confined to the immediate vicinity of the arrest, the lawfulness of the search depending upon the existence of probable cause to arrest; accordingly, since defendant was lawfully arrested based upon an inspection of his automobile junkyard for compliance with statutory record-keeping requirements (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 415-a) just prior to the observation and seizure of a stolen taillight assembly, such assembly, in plain view, could legally be seized as incident to defendant's arrest; when a person engages in such a pervasively regulated business, operable only by licensees, he does so with the knowledge that his business records and inventory will be subject to effective inspection.

Crimes -- Search of Automobile Junkyard -- Miranda Warnings

4. Miranda warnings were not [***4] required where defendant conversed with police officers during the course of an inspection of his automobile junkyard for compliance with statutory record-keeping requirements (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 415-a) and prior to his arrest since defendant was not in custody nor was there present at any time an aura of custodial interrogation prior to defendant's arrest.

 

2114 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ystueta


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


99 Misc. 2d 1105; 418 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2401



June 5, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an elected school board official and a member of the school district, were charged with obstructing governmental administration and criminal trespass in the District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 195.05, 140.10.


OVERVIEW: On the charge of obstructing governmental administration the defendants allegedly interfered with a school board meeting by recording a session of the board's meeting contrary to a by-law of the school board. Concerning the criminal trespass charge, the defendants allegedly refused to leave the board's meeting upon request to do so. One defendant was an elected member of the school board, and the other defendant was a member of the school district. The court dismissed the charges holding that the recording in contravention of a by-law was not obstructing governmental administration. The practical effect of not allowing the meeting to be recorded would be to oust an elected representative from a school board meeting. The by-law could not be given effect because it would result in a diminution of freedom and a lessening of public confidence. The by-law violated the public policy and principles expressed in N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 95, and the informations based thereon were insufficient as a matter of law.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges of governmental obstruction and criminal trespass against defendants.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Open Meetings Law -- Use of Recording Devices

1. The State Comptroller's opinion allowing school boards to prohibit the use of recording devices at regular meetings is not binding on the courts.

Schools -- Open Meetings Law -- Use of Recording Devices

2. A board of education by-law prohibiting the use of recording devices at open school board meetings violates the public policy and principles expressed in section 95 of the Public Officers Law; it is the stated intent of the Legislature to insure that the public be fully aware of the performance of public officials.

Schools -- Board Meetings -- Right of Board Member to Attend

3. A charge of criminal trespass does not lie against a duly elected member of the board of education who refused to leave a board meeting after violating a school board by-law prohibiting the use of recording devices at meetings; defendant had a legal right to be present at the meeting.

 

2115 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


First v. Lewis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Queens County


99 Misc. 2d 761; 417 N.Y.S.2d 194; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2331



June 1, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother brought a paternity action against respondent alleged father.


OVERVIEW: The mother and the alleged father entered into a long and impassioned love affair from 1971 until 1976. The child at issue was born in 1974. The hospital bills were paid by medical coverage paid for from the alleged father's salary check, which deduction continued for approximately two and one-half years after the birth. Both the alleged father and his mother acknowledged the child as their own daughter and granddaughter. The court entered a finding of paternity, concluding that the alleged father and his family recognized and admitted paternity until the alleged father came to realize that he faced financial responsibilities as a result. The court rejected the alleged father's argument that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 5 was unconstitutional because it benefitted only women. The court held that art. 5 benefitted children and that proceedings under art. 5 could be brought by both men and women. Finally, the court rejected the argument that it was unconstitutional to require a man to support his children so long as the law did not grant that man an absolute right to require the mother to undergo an abortion.


OUTCOME: The court entered an order of filiation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Filiation Proceeding

1. A finding of paternity is made where there was clear and convincing evidence that petitioner and respondent were involved in a love affair for over four years, that they engaged in sexual relations on a frequent and ongoing basis during this period, that the hospital bills in connection with the child's birth were paid by medical coverage paid for from respondent's salary check, that there was no credible evidence that petitioner engaged in sexual relations with any other man during the critical period and that respondent never questioned his paternity until after the paternity proceeding was commenced; additionally, respondent's affirmative defense of the Statute of Limitations is dismissed on the grounds that the Commissioner of Social Services is a proper party petitioner and thus the 10-year statute applies, and respondent acknowledged paternity in writing on a birthday card and more significantly on the child's baptismal certificate.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Filiation Proceedings

2. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that it is of benefit [***2] to one sex only, since article 5 is of benefit to the child, regardless of gender, it provides for support of the child by both of the parents, regardless of gender, and it is not unconstitutionally discriminatory for the State, in securing economic rights for its most helpless citizens, to recognize the biological fact that the identity of the mother does not generally require a judicial proceeding to determine. Additionally, proceedings under article 5 may be, and have been, brought by both men and women.

 

2116 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hardenburgh v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Ulster County


99 Misc. 2d 1036; 418 N.Y.S.2d 503; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2385



May 22, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is granted, the plaintiffs' cross motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State of New York filed a motion to dismiss, for lack of legal capacity to sue, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(3), and for failure to state a cause of action, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7), the action by plaintiffs, town officials and landowners, seeking declaratory relief that N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 436, as amended by 1978 N.Y. Laws 738, was unconstitutional. Plaintiffs filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(c).


OVERVIEW: The state passed a new version of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 436, which required the minister or clergyman of a church to hold the property in trust for the benefit of the members in order for the property to qualify for a tax exemption. The landowners would have to change the way they held the church property in order to qualify for the exemption, even though they had previously qualified. The landowners and the town officials filed the action for declaratory judgment. The court dismissed the complaint and denied plaintiffs' cross-motion. The court found that the town officials lacked standing because, as a political subdivision of the state, they could not sue the state. The court found that there was a justiciable controversy. The court found that legislation was presumed to be constitutional and required proof persuasive beyond a reasonable doubt to find it unconstitutional. The court found that there was no restriction in the statute that was related to the landowners' religious beliefs and that the landowners had failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality. The court held that § 436 was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state's motion to dismiss the complaint and denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in plaintiffs' action for a declaratory judgment that the tax statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Standing to Challenge Legislative Act

1. Town officials lack standing to challenge the constitutionality of a 1978 statutory amendment which requires that a minister or clergyman hold real property in trust for the benefit of the members of the church in order for such property to be entitled to a tax exemption ( Real Property Tax Law, § 436) since a political subdivision of the State may not challenge the constitutionality of an act of the State Legislature restricting its governmental powers.

Actions -- Justiciable Controversy -- Tax Exemption for Property Held by Clergymen

2. A declaratory judgment action testing the constitutionality of a 1978 statutory amendment, which requires a minister or clergyman to hold property in trust for the benefit of the members of the church in order for the property to be entitled to a tax exemption ( Real Property Tax Law, § 436), presents a justiciable controversy ( CPLR 3001) and does not seek a prospective ruling since the individual plaintiffs who were granted exemptions under the prior law and desire to retain ownership in the manner [***2] which previously entitled their properties to exemption, no longer enjoy an exemption thus requiring the court to decide the validity of the statute.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

3. There is a presumption that a legislative act is constitutional and such presumption can be upset only by proof persuasive beyond a reasonable doubt and a further presumption that the Legislature has investigated and found facts necessary to support the legislation as well as the existence of a situation showing or indicating its need or desirability; courts of original jurisdiction should not set aside a statute as unconstitutional unless that conclusion is inescapable.

Taxation -- Real Property Tax Exemption -- Property Held by Clergymen

4. A 1978 statutory amendment which requires a minister or clergyman to hold real property in trust for the benefit of the members of the church in order for such property to be entitled to a tax exemption ( Real Property Tax Law, § 436) is constitutional in light of the absence of any allegation of specific restriction on the free exercise of the individual plaintiffs' religious beliefs, the generally restrictive interpretation [***3] to be given real property tax exemptions and the continual shrinkage of the tax base; the purpose of the amendment was to clarify the original legislative intent in enacting the statute and not to change any substantive rights.

 

2117 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Izsak


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 543; 416 N.Y.S.2d 1004; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2275



May 21, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons stated above, the defendants' motions seeking dismissals in the interests of justice are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants charged with patronizing a prostitute in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 230.03 sought dismissal in the interests of justice pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were individuals charged with patronizing prostitutes in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 230.03. Each defendant moved for dismissal of the charges in the interest of justice pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40. The court noted that the legislature had increased the penalty for the crime and that the prosecutor had adopted a "no plea bargain" policy as efforts to deter this particular crime. The court considered and applied the following factors: (a) nature of the crime; (b) available evidence of guilt; (c) prior record of each defendant; (d) punishment already suffered; (e) purpose and effect of further punishment; (f) prejudice resulting to defendants by the passage of time; and (g) impact on the public interest. Although dismissal was discretionary with the court, the court said that defendants must demonstrate compelling factors to justify dismissal. The court found ample evidence of guilt and no compelling factors in each of these cases. Although the court noted that it was disturbed by the prosecutor's "no plea bargain" policy, it did not find any evidence of discriminatory treatment of defendants on improper grounds.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss the charges against them in the interests of justice because the prosecutor had wide discretion in determining which crimes to prosecute, defendants did not demonstrate any improper discrimination, and defendants failed to show any compelling factors which justified exercise of the court's discretion to dismiss the charges.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Patronizing Prostitute -- Dismissal in Interests of Justice

1. Factors to be considered in dismissing an information in the interest of justice ( CPL 170.40) are: the nature of the crime; the available evidence of guilt; the prior record of the defendant; the punishment already suffered by the defendant; any prejudice resulting to the defendant by the passage of time; and the impact on the public interest of a dismissal; accordingly, dismissal of misdemeanor charges of patronizing a prostitute (Penal Law, § 230.03) against each defendant for allegedly approaching an undercover policewoman and seeking sexual intercourse, in the interest of justice, is not warranted since defendants' cases are not those which cry out for "fundamental justice beyond the confines of conventional considerations" in light of the legislative "get tough policy" raising the penalties faced by "Johns" in an effort to diminish street prostitution and the fact that defendants have suffered no more than any other defendants accused of misdemeanor offenses and the impact to the [***2] public if dismissal were granted would be adverse.

Crimes -- Patronizing Prostitute -- Refusal to Grant Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal or Accept Plea

2. The policy of the District Attorney in not granting adjournments in contemplation of dismissal ( CPL 170.55) as to the crime of patronizing a prostitute (Penal Law, § 230.03) and refusing to allow any defendants charged with such offense to take a plea in an attempt to deter street prostitution by placing increased possibilities of incarceration and penalties against "Johns", although unnecessarily rigid bordering on harassment, does not, however, constitute unconstitutional discrimination since an accused does not have a fundamental constitutional right to plead to reduced charges and the District Attorney is merely exercising his substantial prosecutorial discretion to determine "whom, whether and how" to prosecute crimes; although the People's intransigent stand is not the solution to the issue of prostitution, the judiciary should not impede an otherwise legitimate prosecutorial policy unless the most compelling circumstances dictate such intervention.

 

2118 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Anonymous


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Albany County


97 Misc. 2d 927; 416 N.Y.S.2d 729; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2019



May 18, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner father filed an action seeking custody of his infant daughter who was born out of wedlock. Respondent mother filed a cross-petition for custody.


OVERVIEW: The infant daughter was in the care of foster parents, having been placed there by the mother. The father appeared at the proposed adoption proceeding and indicated his intention to oppose the adoption and seek custody of his child. The mother then withdrew her proposed surrender for adoption and instead elected to oppose the father's effort to obtain custody by filing her own petition for return of the infant daughter to her custody. The court determined that the mother's actions constituted extraordinary circumstances, thereby invoking the "best interests of the child" test. The court ruled that based on the evidence it was in the best interests of the infant daughter to be in the care and custody of her father. The court found that the mother was not ready to assume parental responsibility, while the father was. The court determined that to hold the unwed mother had a prima facie right to custody over the father denied equal protection of the law to the father and irrationally prevented the court from doing what was best for the infant daughter.


OUTCOME: The court awarded custody of the infant daughter to the father, holding that it was inconsistent and inequitable not to legally recognize the rights of the father who vigorously sought custody.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Child Born Out of Wedlock -- Custody Rights of Natural Father

1. Section 70 of the Domestic Relations Law which provides that in "all cases there shall be no prima facie right to custody of the child in either parent" applies to unwed as well as to wed parents since to hold that the unwed mother has a prima facie right to custody over the unwed father would deny equal protection of the law to the father, irrationally prevent the court from doing what is best for the child, and could also do irreparable harm to unwed fathers who might otherwise be encouraged to take an active role in the rearing of their offspring; furthermore, even if such a gender-based distinction between unwed parents is constitutional, any prima facie right to custody is negated where the unwed mother intends to place the child up for adoption and, in such case, her actions constitute extraordinary circumstances, thereby requiring that issue of custody be determined according to the "best interests of the child" without any gender-based distinctions.

Child Born Out of Wedlock -- Custody Rights of Natural Father

2. The "best interests" of an out-of-wedlock child require that custody be awarded [***2] to petitioner unwed natural father in light of the fact that petitioner has continually and consistently sought custody of his child and has been anxiously willing, able and ready to assume the full responsibility of parenting his daughter with the supportive help of his parents while, at the same time, respondent mother has continually and consistently sought to place her child up for adoption and has not been willing or ready to assume parental responsibilities and would not be seeking custody if petitioner had not asserted his rights; the mother's decision to give her child up for adoption is not within her option without the concurrence of the father whose rights are properly protected because of his consistent desire to meet his duties and obligations; the public policy of the State, while not encouraging nonmarital relationships or out-of-wedlock children, does encourage that an illegitimate child not be abandoned by a natural parent and strongly supports parental responsibility and seeks to protect and support family ties, married or unmarried.

 

2119 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


K. v. B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


99 Misc. 2d 720; 417 N.Y.S.2d 182; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2324



May 15, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent father filed a motion for an order declaring the paternity provisions of Fam. Ct. Act art. 5 unconstitutional, and sought dismissal of petitioner mother's petition to establish the paternity of the child.


OVERVIEW: The court determined that the relationship between mother and child was biologically established from the point of conception, and that Fam. Ct. Act § 513, which outlined the financial responsibilities owed to an illegitimate child, was applicable to the natural father only after his paternity had been conclusively resolved. The court explained that if there was any disparity evidenced by the application of Fam. Ct. Act § 514, it was mitigated by the fact that the operation of the section was intended to preserve the child's welfare, and any alleged inequity was palliated as a consequence of the limited duration of the father's liability under that section. The court noted that a provision concerning the ability of the father to enter a compromise was unwarranted because a father who wished to voluntarily support his offspring could have done so by either initiating judicial proceedings himself, provided under Fam. Ct. Act § 522, or by entering into a private compact with the mother. The court concluded that the statute did not place child support obligations solely on one class of people and did not discriminate on the basis of sex.


OUTCOME: The court declined to declare the statute unconstitutional. The court denied the father's motion to dismiss the mother's petition to establish the paternity of the child.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

1. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that no provision is made for a male, or father, to bring a proceeding to establish the maternity of a child, although the reverse is true, since at common law a putative father owed no duty of support to a child born of an illicit relationship and the purpose of article 5 is to determine paternity in order to secure support for the child; no separate proceeding to determine maternity and hence maternal obligations is necessary since the relationship between mother and child is biologically established from the point of conception, and the equity of article 5 is apparent when one considers that section 513 of the Family Court Act, which outlines the financial responsibilities owed to an illegitimate child, is applicable to the natural father only after his paternity has been conclusively resolved.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

2. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that the father may be required to pay the expenses of the mother's [***2] confinement and recovery (Family Ct Act, § 514), although no provision is made making the mother also responsible for her confinement and recovery, since section 514 is aimed at ensuring that the child's welfare is safeguarded and the statute attempts to ascertain who is in the best position to meet the child's needs and delegates responsibility accordingly; a woman who has just undergone the rigors of childbirth is not in a superior position to furnish necessaries for either herself or her child, absent some independent source of income provided for her, and under the statute, the court is afforded discretion in determining the "reasonable expenses" for which the father is liable. There is no arbitrariness underlying the imposition of the obligation because a finding of paternity is a prerequisite for an award of expenses to the mother, and furthermore, the father's responsibility under section 514 is limited to the term of the mother's confinement and recovery, and upon termination of this period, the dual parental responsibility mandated by section 513 of the Family Court Act reasserts itself.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

3. Article 5 of the [***3] Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that no provision is made concerning the father's ability to enter a compromise concerning the support of the mother or child, since section 516 of the Family Court Act, which enables the mother to enter into such a compromise, was initiated as a device to enable a mother to compel the support of her illegitimate child by the natural father, and it would be superfluous and illogical to provide a means for the father to enter such an agreement under section 516 since the entire thrust is toward a recalcitrant parent whose aim would be to avoid support of his dependents; moreover, such a provision is unwarranted since a father who wishes to voluntarily support his offspring may do so by either initiating judicial proceedings himself (Family Ct Act, § 522) or by entering into a private compact with the mother.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

4. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that venue is not provided for in a county where a mother "is found" although it is for a father, since section 521 of the Family Court [***4] Act, dealing with venue for paternity proceedings, includes within its purview the counties where either the mother, putative father, or child is found.

Statutes -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

5. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional on the ground that no provision is made for a mother to pay for a blood-grouping test, although such a provision is made for a father to do so if he is financially able, since the essence of section 532 of the Family Court Act, which provides for blood-grouping tests of principal participants in filiation proceedings, is to afford some measure of protection primarily for the putative father; in a contested paternity proceeding, exclusion of the alleged father certainly benefits him and it is inequitable if a mother is compelled to pay for a test which may defeat her cause of action. Additionally, under section 532 of the Family Court Act the tests may be had on motion of any party, and the party requesting the test bears the expense ( Matter of Carol B., 94 Misc 2d 1015); therefore it is conceivable that a mother would be ordered to pay for blood-grouping tests.

Statutes  [***5] -- Constitutionality -- Paternity Proceedings

6. Article 5 of the Family Court Act, paternity proceedings, is not unconstitutional in light of Orr v Orr (440 U.S. 268), which held the Alabama alimony statutes unconstitutional since the statutory scheme created a constitutionally suspect classification in that distinctions made therein were gender-based without serving important governmental objectives; article 5 does not place child support obligations solely upon one class of people, nor does it discriminate on the basis of sex, since both parents are held responsible for the support of their child (Family Ct Act, § 513), and additionally, section 561 of the Family Court Act squarely places support obligations upon the mother involved. The legislative rationale is to secure support for the child, and the purpose of article 5 is to provide a process to help identify the putative father involved so that he may assume his equitable share of the underlying responsibility toward the child; in no way can either the statutory objective or the means provided to accomplish such be labeled violative of basic constitutional guarantees.

 

2120 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Legum v. Goldin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 654; 416 N.Y.S.2d 712; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2310



May 11, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons stated above, all other aspects of the petition are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee brought an application under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, in which he sought relief from the enforcement of N.Y. City Charter § 822.


OVERVIEW: The employee was required, as a condition of employment with the city, to sign a statement by which he agreed to pay an amount equivalent to the income tax owed by a resident, should he ever cease to become a resident. The employee had not complied with the requirement and for a time the city did not enforce the obligation, until it threatened the employee with dismissal for failure to file the appropriate tax form. The employee brought an action to prevent the imposition of which he considered to be an illegal tax. The court denied the employee's petition with respect to the enforceability of the contract and his allegations that the payment amounted to an unconstitutional tax. The court granted his petition to the limited extent of protecting the privacy of his state and federal tax returns. The court held that the employee did not have standing to argue the constitutionality of the tax, because he was not a citizen and was not subject to the tax. His complaint related to a contractual provision, which the court ruled was not unconscionable and was enforceable.


OUTCOME: The court granted the portion of the employee's petition that sought to protect the privacy of the employee's federal and state income tax returns. The court denied the remaining relief sought by the employee.


HEADNOTES

Actions -- Constitutionality of Statute -- Proper Form of Action

1. Although an action challenging the constitutionality of a statute should properly be brought as an action for a declaratory judgment, the court will treat a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the constitutionality of a statute as if maintained in the proper form, since all the necessary parties are present, in furtherance of the interests of justice and judicial economy ( CPLR 103, subd [c]).

Statutes -- Constitutionality

2. Courts act with extreme caution when asked to determine the constitutionality of a statute, and issues of constitutionality are examined and decided only where raised by one personally aggrieved thereby, and clearly necessary to proper disposition of the litigation before the court.

Parties -- Standing

3. Petitioner, an employee of the City of New York who did not reside in the city, and who signed an agreement, as a condition of his employment, pursuant to section 822 of the New York City Charter whereby he agreed to pay the New York City income tax, does not have standing to challenge [***2] the constitutionality of section 822, since he is not aggrieved by the operation of section 822, but rather by the terms of the contract in which he agreed to comply with the provisions contained in the statute, and petitioner is not subject to or threatened with involuntary and arbitrary enforcement of section 822.

Taxation -- Nature of Tax

4. The obligation to pay a tax is not dependent upon a contract, nor can it be assumed by contract; taxes are forced contributions imposed upon citizens to pay the expenses of government, and are in no way related to the will or contract, express or implied, of the persons taxed.

Contracts -- Employment Agreement

5. An agreement voluntarily signed by petitioner, an employee of the City of New York who did not reside in the city, as a condition of his employment, whereby he agreed, pursuant to section 822 of the New York City Charter, to pay the New York City income tax, is an enforceable contract, is authorized by statute, is not unconscionable, and is not an indirect involuntary tax, since section 822 is a valid exercise of powers granted to every city in New York State and each city has full authority to establish conditions [***3] of employment for its employees (see NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c], par [1]; General City Law, § 20).

Contracts -- Employment Agreement -- Enforcement

6. The only way to enforce an agreement signed by petitioner, an employee of the City of New York who did not reside in the city, whereby he agreed to pay the New York City income tax, absent voluntary compliance with the agreement by petitioner, is by an independent plenary action for breach of contract, in which action the court may order disclosure of petitioner's tax returns, since the agreement cannot properly be enforced without reference to petitioner's Federal and/or State income tax returns, and section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code (US Code, tit 26, § 6103) and subdivision (e) of section 697 of the Tax Law prohibit the disclosure of Federal and State tax returns and the particulars thereof, except as specifically authorized by law. Although there is no proof that respondents, certain officials of the City of New York and the city, have or are about to obtain petitioner's tax returns without benefit of court order in a separate plenary action, this possibility is not expressly denied by respondents,  [***4] and, accordingly, the petition, which seeks to prohibit respondents from enforcing the agreement and to prohibit them from seeking any information concerning petitioner's tax returns for the purpose of enforcing the agreement, is granted to the extent of permanently enjoining respondents from so proceeding in excess of their jurisdiction and authority ( CPLR 7803, subd 2).

 

2121 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Club Winks, Inc. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 787; 417 N.Y.S.2d 178; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2335



May 11, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiffs' motions for a preliminary injunction are, therefore, granted, and the cross motions are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff cabaret operators filed three actions against defendant city and sought to have an ordinance, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-297.1, which regulated the operation of adult cabarets, declared unconstitutional. The cabaret operators filed motions for preliminary injunctions to prevent the city from enforcing the ordinance and the city filed cross motions to dismiss the actions for lack of standing and the failure to state a claim.
