OVERVIEW: The city argued that the cabaret operator's lacked the requisite standing to challenge § B32-297.1 because they had not applied for licenses under the ordinance. Further, the city argued that the cabaret operators had failed to state a cause of action. The court disagreed and held that the cabaret operators had stated a proper cause of action and that they had standing to challenge the ordinance because they faced criminal prosecution for failing to obtain the licenses required under the ordinance. The court further held that the ordinance was unconstitutional on the following grounds: it invalidly acted as a prior restraint; it vested excessive discretionary power in the commissioner of consumer affairs of the city in the issuance and renewal of cabaret licenses upon grounds that were impermissible and overly broad; and its disclosure requirements were violative of the right to freedom of association and anonymity. Accordingly, the cabaret operator's motions for preliminary injunctions were granted and the city's motions to dismiss were denied.


OUTCOME: The cabaret operators' motions for preliminary injunctions were granted and the city's ordinance was declared unconstitutional. The city's motions to dismiss were denied.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Standing to Challenge Licensing Ordinance

1. Plaintiffs, lessees and operators of cabaret premises facing criminal charges for operating their cabarets without licenses (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-297.1), have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the licensing ordinance even though they have not applied for cabaret licenses since parties faced by an unconstitutional licensing law are not required to show that their conduct could be regulated by a properly drawn law or that the deterrent effect of the law on their First Amendment rights is both real and substantial in order to challenge or resist the validity of the ordinance or statute.

Constitutional Law -- Cabaret Licensing Ordinance -- Overbroad Discretion of Administrator

2. Providing live dance entertainment in a cabaret is an activity included within the protective umbrella of the First Amendment and a licensing statute which attempts to regulate protected expression and provides for prior restraint must be precisely drawn and is subject to a [***2] strong presumption that it is constitutionally invalid; accordingly, a licensing ordinance which authorizes the New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs to deny or refuse to renew a cabaret license based upon a broad general listing of various types of criminal convictions, many of which are unrelated to the use of the premises and/or the qualification for operating them (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-297.1), invalidly acts as a prior restraint and unconstitutionally vests overbroad discretion in an administrator; statutes which pertain to unfair discrimination against persons previously convicted of a crime (Correction Law, §§ 752, 753) do not remedy any of the constitutional deficiencies of the ordinance.

Constitutional Law -- Cabaret Licensing Ordinance -- Disclosure Requirements

3. Provisions of a cabaret licensing ordinance requiring disclosure of all stockholders holding a minimum 10% stock interest and the source of their money (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-297.1) are violative of the right to freedom of association and anonymity; defendant city has shown no compelling governmental interest such as public health, welfare [***3] or safety necessitating the procurement of the information sought.

 

2122 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mason


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Richmond County


99 Misc. 2d 583; 416 N.Y.S.2d 981; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2282



May 8, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Codefendants were indicted for the crimes of robbery in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law §160.15, and robbery in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law §160.10, each as a juvenile offender. At the time of the alleged commission of the crimes charged, defendants were 15 and 14 years old. Both defendants requested that the court declare unconstitutional the statutory scheme under which they were indicted and that the court dismiss the indictment.


OVERVIEW: 1978 N.Y. Laws ch. 481 made 13, 14, and 15 year-olds criminally responsible for certain enumerated felonies. Robbery in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 160.15, and robbery in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 160.10(2), were felonies for which 14 and 15 year-olds were criminally responsible. Defendants contended that the legislation was unconstitutional in that it deprived them of consideration for youthful offender treatment. They argued that since 16-, 17- and 18-year-old defendants, who were convicted of the same crimes that these defendants are charged with, were eligible for such treatment, subject to certain limitations, the statutory scheme was violative of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11 as depriving defendants of the equal protection of the laws. The court disagreed. Applying the traditional rational basis approach, the court found that the Legislature had not acted arbitrarily or capriciously in establishing the juvenile offender category. The court noted that there were ameliorative provisions in the legislation designed to protect the juvenile.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- Juvenile Offenders

1. The recent legislation (L 1978, ch 481) which makes 13, 14, and 15 year olds criminally responsible for certain enumerated felonies for which 16, 17, and 18 year olds may be eligible for youthful offender status is not unconstitutional on the basis of the equal protection clause since the strict scrutiny test is not the proper standard of review because age is not a suspect classification and because no fundamental interest or right is involved as youthful offender treatment is not a fundamental right. The proper means of analysis is the rational basis test, and since the Legislature did not act arbitrarily or capriciously in establishing the juvenile offender category, there are ameliorative provisions to protect the 13-, 14- or 15-year-old defendant, all the basic rights available to adult offenders are possessed by the juvenile in this category, and there is a rational basis of protection of public safety and deterrence of crime, the discrepancies in treatment between 13-, 14-, and 15-year-old defendants and 16-, 17-, and 18-year-old defendants do not amount to denial of equal protection.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality

 [***2] 2. A court of first instance should not set aside a statute as unconstitutional unless such conclusion is inescapable.

 

2123 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Myles


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


99 Misc. 2d 501; 416 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2268



May 4, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the application is denied and the cross motion is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, the remaindermen of a trust that had been a part of one of respondent trustee bank's common trust funds, sought to the court fix the date of valuation for the purposes of withdrawal of those funds from the common trust fund, under N.Y. Banking Law § 100-c(8) and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 3, § 22.43(a). The bank filed a cross-motion for summary judgment dismissing the petition.


OVERVIEW: Under a decedent's will, one half of the residuary trust was to remain in trust for the life of the wife of decedent's son and upon her death the remainder was distributable to the remaindermen, who were the son's issue. The wife died on September 28, 1978. Notice of her death was given to the bank on September 29, 1978. The trust was withdrawn from the common trust fund as of a November valuation date. The remaindermen sought to fix September 29, 1978 as the date of withdrawal. In granting the bank's motion for summary judgment, the court ruled that under § 100-c(6) and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 3, § 22.50(a), notice for withdrawal of funds from a common trust fund was required to be give to a bank at least five days before the valuation date. The notice given to the bank on September 29th was insufficient to comply with the five-day requirement. The court rejected the remaindermen's claim that the September 29th notice was timely because the bank was not required to compute the values until 15 days after the valuation date, pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 3, § 22.43(a), and bank had done so within 10 days but no earlier than 5 days of that notice.


OUTCOME: The court denied the remaindermen's petition and granted the bank's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Bank and Banking -- Withdrawal of Funds from Common Trust Fund -- Five-Day Notice Requirement before Valuation Date

Notice for withdrawal of funds from a common trust fund must be given to a bank at least five days before the valuation date (Banking Law, § 100-c, subd 6; 3 NYCRR 22.50 [a]) and the fact that the bank is not required to compute the values until 15 days after the valuation date ( 3 NYCRR 22.43 [a]) does not render notice received on the valuation date sufficient to comply with the statutory five-day requirement even though the five-day period expires before the fund is actually valued and the withdrawn share determined; the provision for a stated period of time between a decision to withdraw funds from the common trust fund and the time of actual withdrawal is for the protection of the beneficiaries and deprives no one of substantial rights and is not unconstitutional.

 

2124 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Michael D.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


99 Misc. 2d 816; 417 N.Y.S.2d 604; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2342



April 30, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a juvenile who was 15 years of age at the time of commission of an alleged crime, sought to set aside the sentence imposed on him on the ground that the controlling statute was violative of his rights under the equal protection and due process clauses of the United States Constitution.


OVERVIEW: The court reviewed the juvenile youthful offender statute under which defendant was sentenced. The court noted that the provisions of such statute drew a distinction based solely on the date of birth of the juvenile defendant and stripped out of the court the discretion to grant youthful offender treatment to juveniles even in cases where the "ends of justice" would best be served by allowing such treatment. The court found that the statute was unconstitutional in compelling a court to impose a more severe penalty on a 14 or 15-year-old juvenile offender compared to a penalty imposed on his 16 to 19-year-old counterpart. Moreover, the court found no rational basis for discrimination against, and heavier penalties for, those in a lower-age group as penalties should be less severe for those in the "tender years." Thus, the court held that defendant, who was 15 years of age at time of commission of the crime, was denied due process and equal protection by the stringent provisions of the juvenile offender statute.


OUTCOME: The motion to vacate the sentence was granted, and defendant was resentenced to a term of probation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Juvenile Offender -- Denial of Equal Protection

The new statutory scheme for "juvenile offenders" (L 1978, ch 481), which imposes a more severe penalty on a 14- or 15-year-old "juvenile offender" than one afforded to his 16- to 19-year-old counterpart, stripping the courts of discretion to grant youthful offender treatment to a juvenile even in those cases where the ends of justice would best be served by allowing such treatment, is violative of equal protection under the strict scrutiny test for a "suspect" classification or fundamental right which requires that the legislative purpose for the disparity of treatment be so compelling as to justify the means utilized, since there is no legislative policy which would afford beneficient youthful offender treatment to a 16- to 19-year-old offender while denying same to a 14 or 15 year old; even applying a rational basis standard, the classification must nevertheless fall since there is no rational basis for treating youths under the age of 16 more severely than their 16- to 19-year-old brethren.

 

2125 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Community School Board v. Macchiarola


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


99 Misc. 2d 219; 415 N.Y.S.2d 776; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2234



April 25, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion of the respondents to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner school board filed an action against respondent city educational authorities and a lower court chancellor (chancellor) for the declaration that the provisions of N.Y. Educ. Law § 2590-1 were unconstitutional and to have restrained the chancellor from suspending or removing the school board. The city educational authorities and the chancellor filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: There was a dispute between the school board and the city educational authorities relating to the collection and supplying of ethnic data about the pupil and staff population for the school board's district. When the school board refused to deliver the required data during a school year, the chancellor removed the school board and collected the data through his designated trustee. The school board was later restored to its position. The school board again refused to provide the data and was directed to have done so by the chancellor. The chancellor and the city educational authorities argued that the school board lacked standing, had failed to state a cause of action, and had no basis for proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7803. The court granted the motion to dismiss. The court held that the legislation in question did not impose punishment of a kind found in an unconstitutional bill of attainder and the legislature properly delegated authority. The city education authorities were legislatively authorized to have taken such reasonable steps as were necessary to have effected compliance with its policy.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city educational authorities and the chancellor's motion to dismiss the action brought by the school board in the dispute between the school board and the city educational authorities regarding the collection and supplying of ethnic date about the pupils and staff.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Removal of Community School Board -- Standing

1. Petitioner community school board has standing to challenge the statute which permits respondent Chancellor of the New York City school system to remove the board (Education Law, § 2590-l) in view of the fact that respondent has taken steps preparatory to removal of the board due to the board's refusal to provide ethnic data about the pupil and staff population for petitioner's district and the further fact that similar action was taken earlier with regard to the same dispute; the fact that petitioner has no basis for proceeding under CPLR 7803 does not warrant dismissal since questions as to the form of action or proceeding under which the issue is before the court cannot provide a basis for dismissal where a jurisdicable issue is pleaded and all the necessary parties are before the court ( CPLR 103, subd [c]).

Schools -- Removal of Community School Board -- Bill of Attainder

2. The statute permitting the Chancellor of the New York City school system, an appointed official, to remove an elected community school board (Education [***2] Law, § 2590-l) is not an unconstitutional bill of attainder (US Const, art I, § 10), which is a legislative act which inflicts punishment upon named or easily identifiable individuals without judicial trial, since, while the statute is aimed at readily identifiable recalcitrant boards, it does not impose punishment of a kind found in unconstitutional bills of attainder.

Schools -- Removal of Community School Board -- Procedural Due Process

3. The statute permitting the Chancellor of the New York City school system to remove a recalcitrant community school board (Education Law, § 2590-l) does not violate procedural due process by failing to require notice and a formal fact-finding hearing before an unbiased tribunal or to delineate the length or duration of the period of removal since general constitutional standards of procedural due process do not necessarily apply to disputes between governmental agencies; while community school boards have been granted a kind of tenure, they remain subject to the control of the Chancellor who is required to make efforts at conciliation with the board and may supersede or suspend the board only when that board refuses to comply [***3] with any applicable provisions of law, by-laws, rules and regulations or directiveness and agreements, taking only such reasonable steps as may be necessary to effectuate compliance with the law.

Schools -- Removal of Community School Board -- Collection of Ethnic Data

4. The fact that a school board which is the primary educational authority in the district can only be removed by a formal hearing (Education Law, § 2559) does not prevent the Chancellor of the New York City school system from removing a community school board for refusing to provide ethnic data about the district's pupil and staff population without such a formal hearing (Education Law, § 2590-l) since the community board is part of the city-wide educational district and is subject to the rules and regulations of the central administrative authority which determines educational policy; since there is no constitutional bar to the collection of such ethnic data, respondent Chancellor is legislatively authorized to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to effect compliance with the previously determined policy to use such data in connection with certain policies arranged between the board of education [***4] and Federal Office of Civil Rights.

 

2126 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


French v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


99 Misc. 2d 882; 417 N.Y.S.2d 389; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2353



April 25, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioner's applications are denied and his petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer applied for an order restraining respondent library board of trustees (trustees) from continuing to construct a new wing of the library and an order restraining respondent school district from making any further payments to the library. Respondents contended that the library was a free association library not subject to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 101.


OVERVIEW: The library was a non-public, free association library which, pursuant to a contract, provided library services to the school district residents pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 256. The library advertised for bids on the erection of a new wing. The taxpayer contended that the advertised bid failed to comply with the provisions of N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 101 in that the library failed to request separate bids for plumbing, gas, heating, air conditioning, and electrical wiring. The court denied the taxpayer's application and held that the library was not one of the specified entities controlled by the mandate of § 101. The court found that the library owned the land, would own the addition to the land, would completely control the construction and payments therefor, and would end up owning and controlling everything. Because the matter did not involve a lease with the school district, the court found that N.Y. Educ. Law § 1726 could not be construed to require respondents to comply with § 101. The court also held that the fact that the library was supported by taxes by way of a contract with the school district was irrelevant to whether the library was a political entity bound by § 101.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayer's applications and dismissed his petition.


HEADNOTES

Libraries -- Nonpublic Free Association Library -- Separate Bidding Requirements

1. A nonpublic free association library, which used funds properly appropriated by respondent school district for the support of the library (Education Law, § 256) to pay the financing charges on a mortgage of the library's property in order to undertake a construction project to expand its facilities, may lawfully put out a single bid for a general contractor to do the entire job and is not bound by the separate bidding requirements applicable only to a "political subdivision" (General Municipal Law, § 101) since the school district's credit is in no way affected by the mortgage given by the library which owns the land, will completely control the erection of the building and the payments therefor and will end up owning and controlling everything; the fact that the money used by the library to cover the cost of mortgage financing originated with "tax dollars" by way of a contract with the school district to furnish library privileges does not make the library an entity subject to the separate bidding requirements [***2] and, in addition, the bidding requirements for the lease-purchase of a building to be erected on the district's property (Education Law, § 1726) are inapplicable.

Schools -- Appropriation to Free Association Library

2. A grant of moneys by a school board for the support of a nonpublic free association library (Education Law, § 256) used by the library to pay the mortgage financing charges in connection with a construction project to expand the library's facilities does not constitute an unconstitutional gift or loan of property or credit of the school district (NY Const, art VIII, § 1) since an appropriation to a free association library as consideration for the maintenance of public library service does not constitute a gift or donation.

Municipal Corporations -- Public Construction Contract -- Separate Bidding Requirements

3. Separate bidding requirements applicable to public construction contracts requiring the preparation of separate specifications and separate and independent bidding thereon (General Municipal Law, § 101) are intended primarily for the protection of the taxpayers and municipalities as opposed to private interest contractor associations [***3] and, accordingly, in view of respondents' allegations that petitioner is associated with such an association and the fact separate bidding of construction contracts generates higher bid prices, respondent free association library was justified in putting out a single bid for a general contractor to do the entire construction job.

 

2127 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re R.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


99 Misc. 2d 114; 415 N.Y.S.2d 613; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2218



April 10, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Movant adoption petitioner filed a motion for reargument of the court's denial of her application for a direction to the Finance Administrator of the City of New York to pay the cost of service by publication of the citation upon the natural mother in her action for a private placement adoption.


OVERVIEW: The child's mother left her with petitioner and never returned. Petitioner was named guardian and later sought a private placement adoption. Being indigent, petitioner applied for the city to pay the cost of service by publication on the natural mother to complete jurisdiction. The court denied the application. On petitioner's motion for reargument, the court granted reargument and affirmed its decision to deny the application. The court found that petitioner had an alternate means of adopting the child through the department of human services (department) and, thus, was not deprived of access to the courts by her inability to pay the costs. The court distinguished cases from other states that allowed payment of costs where there was no other way to achieve an adoption. The court ruled that, although petitioner preferred a private proceeding, she could surrender custody of the abandoned child to the department for it to conduct a public adoption proceeding. The court concluded that the possibility that the department might decide it was in the child's best interest for someone else to adopt her did not give petitioner a constitutional right to the city's payment of her costs.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner's motion for reargument and, upon reargument, adhered to its original determination and denied petitioner's application to have the city pay the cost of service by publication upon the child's natural mother.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Private Placement Adoption -- Cost of Service on Natural Mother

In a private placement adoption proceeding, an indigent person is not entitled to have the costs of service by publication upon the natural mother paid by a city; her due process right of access to the courts is not violated by the city's failure to pay the costs of access since private placement is not the exclusive method available for adoption of an abandoned child and since the Commissioner of Social Services would bear the cost of freeing the child if the alternative method of adoption through the department were utilized.

 

2128 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Johnsen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


103 Misc. 2d 823; 430 N.Y.S.2d 904; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2947



April 10, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the court grants the petition of the conservator.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner conservator sought approval and authority to execute contracts with third-party author and third-party publisher for the publication of the story of convicted criminal where the third-party publisher would advance a sum to petitioner on the signing of the contract.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner conservator was appointed for a convicted criminal. Petitioner was given the requisite powers to create a fund in which money could be deposited for potential literary or dramatic works for respondent Board to receive. Petitioner sought to execute contracts with a third-party publisher and a third-party author in order to sell the literary rights of the events. Petitioner sought the court's approval and authority to execute the contracts. The court found that the contracts of sale of the literary rights were contracts of the court and not that of the convicted criminal or of respondent. Based upon petitioner's position, the court stated it was its duty to carry out those engagements through petitioner. The court declared N.Y. Exec. Law §632-a was constitutional and that it encompassed the office of petitioner and the jurisdiction of the court over the moneys earned by terms of the contract.


OUTCOME: The court found that the contracts of sale of the literary rights were contracts of the court and not that of the convicted criminal or of the respondent.


HEADNOTES

Conservators -- Distribution of Moneys Received as Result of Commission of Crime

1. In a proceeding involving the distribution of moneys received as a result of the commission of a crime, pursuant to section 632-a of the Executive Law, a contract of sale of the literary rights to the "exploits" of the perpetrator of the crime is a contract of the court and not of the person convicted of the crime or of the Crime Victims Compensation Board, which must maintain an escrow account for the benefit of victims; a conservator, as a statutory receiver, is an officer of the court and subject at all times to its discretion and control and has no stake in the fund, cannot personally profit from the contract, and may only receive such compensation for services as is fixed by the court in accordance with statute; although the conservator must not be exposed to a substantial potential liability for failure, as a fiduciary, to report to the Internal Revenue Service the royalties payable under the contract, so long as the aid and jurisdiction of the court is required to effectuate the purposes of the statute, the office and [***2] functions of the conservator must continue.

Literary Property -- Constitutionality of Statute Requiring Distribution of Moneys Received as Result of Commission of Crime

2. Section 632-a of the Executive Law, governing payments to be received from newly acquired moneys owing to the person convicted of a crime and the deposit thereof by the Crime Victims Compensation Board in an escrow account for the benefit of any victims of the crimes, is declared constitutional and as encompassing the office of a conservator for one under a legal disability who is unable to act for himself, the jurisdiction of the court over the moneys which would otherwise, by the terms of such contract, be owing to the person so convicted, and the stewardship of the conservator to bridge the gap between payment by the publisher and turnover to the Crime Victims Compensation Board. Accordingly, in a proceeding involving the management and distribution of substantial proceeds derivable from the sale of literary property and other rights arising from the story of David Berkowitz, the "Son of Sam", the application of the conservator for approval and authority to execute a contract with the author and publisher [***3] and a collateral agreement with the former attorneys for Berkowitz, is granted.

 

2129 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Polli v. Connelie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


98 Misc. 2d 1012; 415 N.Y.S.2d 198; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2183



April 4, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, the petition is granted and the petitioners are permitted to take the examination.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners were persons who desired to take the competitive written examination for New York State troopers but who had already attained the maximum allowable age of 29 years for state troopers. Petitioners brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondent, the Superintendent of the New York State Police, seeking an order permitting them to take the examination on the ground that the age limit was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The applicable statute, N.Y. Exec. Law § 215(3), and the applicable regulation, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 475.1, established the 29-year-old age limit for state troopers. However, the statute and regulation also gave the Superintendent unlimited and undefined discretion to extend the age limit to 35 years without regard to merit or fitness. Petitioners contended that the discretionary age limitation contained in the statute and in the regulation but not mentioned in the notice of examination was arbitrary, discriminatory, and unconstitutional. The court agreed with petitioners' contentions and held that petitioners could take the examination. The court held that the fact that the Superintendent had the discretion to extend the maximum age up to 35 years violated the Equal Protection Clause of N.Y. Const. art I, § 11 in the absence of a regulation setting forth the criteria or standards, such as a given number of years of prior police experience, to be followed or used in its application by the Superintendent.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition and ordered that petitioners be permitted to take the examination.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- State Police -- Maximum Age

The Superintendent of the New York State Police may not use his undefined discretion (Executive Law, § 215, subd 3; 9 NYCRR 475.1) to extend the maximum age of applicants permitted to take the competitive examination for New York State trooper from 29 to 35, since that violates the equal protection clause of the State Constitution (art I, § 11) in the absence of a regulation setting forth the criteria or standards to be followed by the superintendent.

 

2130 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Navagata v. Navagata


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


99 Misc. 2d 90; 415 N.Y.S.2d 372; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2213



April 4, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In all other respects, the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant wife made an application in a matrimonial action for an order adjudging plaintiff husband in contempt for failure to comply with an order awarding temporary alimony to the wife.


OVERVIEW: The husband relied on the Orr decision of the United States Supreme Court as a bar to the enforcement of the alimony order since a literal reading of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236 appeared to contain a sex distinction which the Supreme Court in the Orr case had struck down as unconstitutional. The alimony order at issue here was granted prior to the Orr decision. The court granted leave to the wife to enter judgment and have execution for a particular sum. The court held that the Orr decision should not be given retroactive effect. The court further utilized the principle authorizing it to construe the statute so as to avoid an unconstitutional interpretation. No violence was done to either the purpose or intent of the statute with respect to the award of temporary alimony in appropriate matrimonial actions by construing and interpreting the statute so as to equalize the eligibility of a spouse, irrespective of sex or gender, to the benefits thereof. The court so construed § 236.


OUTCOME: The court granted the wife's application to the extent of granting leave to the wife to enter judgment and have execution for a particular sum in arrears as of a particular date, without prejudice to an application for relief as to any arrears accruing after such date. Counsel fees upon the application were also awarded. In all other respects, the application was denied.


HEADNOTES

Evidence -- Hearsay Evidence -- Attorney's Affidavit

1. In opposition to an application for an order adjudging a husband in contempt for failure to comply with an order awarding temporary alimony to his wife, the affidavit of the husband's attorney, averring that the husband is unable to comply with said order, is hearsay and insufficient to serve as an answer to the moving papers.

Husband and Wife -- Alimony and Allowances

2. An award of temporary alimony to a wife, granted pursuant to section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, is valid in light of the United States Supreme Court's holding in Orr v Orr (440 U.S. 268), in which a similar statute was struck down as being unconstitutionally based upon a gender distinction because the Orr decision should not be given retrocative effect and because the court may construe a statute so as to avoid an unconstitutional interpretation; accordingly, the statute is construed so as to equalize a spouse's eligibility for alimony under said statute, irrespective of gender, and the wife is granted leave to enter judgment for the sum in arrears.

 

2131 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Siebert


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


99 Misc. 2d 32; 415 N.Y.S.2d 589; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2209



April 3, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Applicant Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York (superintendent) sought a final order confirming the exercise of her discretion in taking possession of a bank and her actions to dispose of the bank's property by merger. An order to show cause was issued and the bank filed an application seeking injunctive relief and a direction that the superintendent surrender possession. The court consolidated the applications for hearing.


OVERVIEW: The superintendent's application for a final order, included a certificate executed pursuant to N.Y. Banking Law § 606 which stated that she had taken possession of the bank and a statement that pursuant to § 618 she sought to dispose of the bank's property by merger. A show cause order was issued, and for "hearing" purposes, the court consolidated the superintendent's application with the bank's application for injunctive relief. The court held that the bank was not entitled to injunctive relief and confirmed the superintendent's actions. The court concluded that under § 612 the statement and certificate were regarded as presumptive evidence of the facts stated therein. The court merely had the right to review the superintendent's act of "taking possession" from the judicially limited perspective of whether she acted arbitrarily, capriciously, without good cause, and or whether there had been an abuse of her discretionary prerogative. The court determined that § 606 of the Banking Law did not require a finding of "insolvency" before permitting the "taking possession." The court held that the merger was in the best interests of the public welfare and the interests of justice.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the superintendent's discretion in taking possession of the bank and her plan for disposing of the bank's property by merger. The court denied the bank's application for injunctive relief.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Banks and Banking -- Superintendent's Taking Possession of Bank -- Judicial Review

1. The State Superintendent of Banks has complete discretion to take possession of any banking organization whenever it appears that such banking organization is conducting its business in an unauthorized and unsafe manner, is in an unsound or unsafe condition to transact its business and cannot with safety and expediency continue business ( Banking Law, § 606) and the court merely has the right to review the superintendent's act of "taking possession" from the judicially limited perspective of whether the superintendent acted arbitrarily, capriciously, without good cause or whether there has been an abuse of discretion and, once the court determines the propriety and justification of the superintendent's determination to take possession based upon the banking organization's activities coming within the purview of the statute, then it is not for the court to substitute its own opinion for that of the superintendent and to then revoke the superintendent's discretionary act.

Banks and Banking -- Superintendent's Taking Possession of Bank -- Certificates to be Recorded and Received in Evidence

 [***2] 2. Section 612 of the Banking Law, which provides that the duly subscribed and acknowledged "statement and determination" of the State Superintendent of Banks reciting the determinations made and acts performed in connection with the taking possession of a banking organization for good cause ( Banking Law, § 606) "shall be presumptive evidence of the facts therein stated" in "any action or proceeding", entitles the superintendent, in a proceeding brought by the bank to enjoin the superintendent from continuing in possession ( Banking Law, § 607), to rest upon the certificate alone and not be required as part of the prima facie case to justify the facts therein stated since, to hold to the contrary, would impair or destroy the presumption and circumvent the plain purpose of the statute.

Banks and Banking -- Superintendent's Taking Possession of Bank -- Due Process

3. Section 612 of the Banking Law, which provides that the duly subscribed and acknowledged "statement and determination" of the Superintendent of Banks reciting the determinations made and acts performed in connection with the take-over of a banking organization ( Banking Law, § 606), is "presumptive evidence [***3] of the facts therein stated", does not violate the bank's right to due process so long as the statement contains the factual information upon which the determination by the superintendent is based since the bank, at a hearing following the take-over ( Banking Law, § 607), has a full opportunity to offer proof that the acts of the superintendent in taking possession were "arbitrary, capricious and without good cause"; in addition, the bank has failed to meet its burden of demonstrating the invalidity of the statute "beyond a reasonable doubt" or to rebut the strong presumption of constitutionality that attaches to all legislation.

Banks and Banking -- Superintendent's Taking Possession of Bank -- Requirement of "Insolvency"

4. Section 606 of the Banking Law, which authorizes the Superintendent of Banks to take possession of a banking organization whenever it appears that such banking organization is conducting its business in an unauthorized and unsafe manner, is in an unsound or unsafe condition to transact its business and cannot with safety and expendiency continue business, does not require a finding of "insolvency" before permitting the "taking possession" by the superintendent [***4] and, since the statute does not include "insolvency" as one of the grounds for "taking possession", the court does not have the right to "judicially legislate" and read into the statute any requirement of "insolvency".

Banks and Banking -- Superintendent's Taking Possession of Bank -- Confirmation of Merger

5. Although the Superintendent of Banks, without court approval, can "transfer, assign, consolidate or otherwise dispose of all or any part" of the assets of a banking organization which has been taken over by the superintendent to a Federal savings and loan association ( Banking Law, § 634), since court approval was made a condition precedent to the approval by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of a merger arranged by the superintendent and since liquidation would present loss and hardship to many of the bank's depositors and creditors, the merger is confirmed in the best interests of the public welfare and "in the interests of justice".

 

2132 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re R.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 994; 414 N.Y.S.2d 997; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2182



April 3, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner district attorney moved to amend respondent juvenile's petition for unlawful imprisonment by designating it as a felony act petition under various sections of the Family Court Act. Respondent and the law guardian opposed the motion.


OVERVIEW: Respondent juvenile was accused of committing unlawful imprisonment. Petitioner district attorney moved to amend the petition by designating it as felony act petition under the Family Court Act (Act), §§ 731(2), § 712(h)(v), (amended by the Juvenile Justice Reform Amendment of 1978, L. 1978, ch. 478, Sept. 1, 1978). Respondent and law guardian claimed that this violated respondent's right to a fair and impartial fact finder, that § 750 of the Act conflicted with §§ 117(b), 254-a, and 731(2) of the Act, and that § 712(h)(v) was unconstitutional as an ex post facto law. The court allowed petitioner to amend only after a fact-finding hearing because the trial judge's knowledge of respondent's prior criminal history would not affect respondent's right to a fair and impartial trial, § 712(h)(v) did not violate the prohibition against ex post facto laws, and §§ 750, 117(b), 254-a, and 731(2) did not conflict.


OUTCOME: Petitioner's motion to amend was granted after a fact-finding hearing because trial court's knowledge of respondent's prior criminal history would not affect respondent's right to a fair and impartial trial, predicate offender law did not violate prohibition against ex post facto laws, and various sections of the Family Court Act did not conflict.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Fair Trial

1. A minor charged with unlawful imprisonment in the first degree and whose record includes two prior felony findings is not denied a fair and impartial fact finder by marking a petition in a fact-finding hearing in Family Court a "designated felony act petition" (Family Ct Act, § 731, subd 2) since the Trial Judge's knowledge of a respondent's criminal history does not, per se, affect the respondent's right to a fair trial.

Constitutional Law -- Ex Post Facto Laws

2. If a minor's actions would constitute a felony had they been done by an adult and if there have been two prior felony findings against the minor, it is constitutional to designate the action a "designated felony act" (Family Ct Act, § 712, subd [h], par [v]) since recidivist statutes are not violative of the prohibition against ex post facto laws, as the increased punishment prescribed by such statutes is for a present crime not the past ones.

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Designated Felony Acts

3. It is improper to place the term "designated felony act" on a petition under section 712 (subd [h], par [v]) of the Family Court Act [***2] in a fact-finding hearing in Family Court against a minor (Family Ct Act, § 750, subd 1) since the intent of the statute is that a Judge shall not be advised of a respondent's record prior to the completion of a fact-finding hearing as even the appearance of prejudice must be avoided and as the minor's prior conduct is immaterial to the fact-finding process; therefore, the term "designated felony act petition" must be prominently marked on petitions alleging such acts pursuant to section 712 (subd [h], par [v]) of the Family Court Act only after a fact-finding hearing has established that the minor has committed a felony act, and only for the purposes of a dispositional hearing, when the prior record of the minor becomes pertinent.

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Designated Felony Act Hearings

4. A minor who stands accused of a designated felony act because he has committed a felony act and his record contains two prior felony findings (Family Ct Act, § 712, subd [h], par [v]) must have a fact-finding hearing in a regular part of the Family Court without requiring a court order to have the hearing in a regular part since there is no authority to try such matters [***3] in a special "designated felony act" part (Family Ct Act, § 117, subd [b], par [i]) and since the Judge must not be advised of the accused's prior record so that the appearance of prejudice will be avoided; should the minor be found to have committed a felony act, the petition shall then be marked "designated felony act petition" and the dispositional hearing may be heard in a special part for designated felonies.

 

2133 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Lewis v. Commissioner of Correction


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


100 Misc. 2d 48; 417 N.Y.S.2d 377; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2411



April 2, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner fugitive brought a writ of habeas corpus proceeding to contest his rendition to the State of Alabama to answer an indictment for securities fraud, Ala. Code § 8-6-17. He asserted that the indictment was invalid under N.Y.C.P.L.R. 570.08, 570.18 without a date of the alleged offense. He further alleged that the acts alleged did not constitute a crime in Alabama.


OVERVIEW: The fugitive brought a petition for habeas corpus to prevent extradition to Alabama on an indictment charging him with securities fraud under Ala. Code § 8-6-17. The indictment did not contain any date for the commission of the alleged offense. He asserted that the indictment was deficient without a date because it prevented him from resisting extradition on the ground that he was not in the demanding state. He also asserted that the acts alleged were not a crime in Alabama. The trial court denied the petition. It held that the requirements of N.Y.C.P.L.R. 570.08, 570.18 were satisfied because the date of the alleged offense was supplied by the demanding state in another official document. The court held that establishing that the alleged acts were not a crime depended on showing that: (1) statutes or decisional law of Alabama did not establish the act as criminal; or (2) making the act alleged criminal would violate the Constitution of the United States. It ruled that the count alleging disclaimer of a civil debt was not a crime, but that the remaining two counts were crimes. As the indictment contained both valid and invalid counts, the valid counts supported rendition.


OUTCOME: The trial court denied the application for denial of rendition and dismissed the petition for habeas corpus. The court ordered the fugitive returned to the demanding state, but continued the fugitive on bail for two weeks to obtain a stay from the appellate court or to apply for an investigation by the governor.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Extradition -- Presence in Demanding State at Time of Crime -- Specific Date of Crime

1. Although a reasonably specific date of the alleged commission of the crime is essential for the demanding State to successfully extradite a fugitive from an asylum State so that the fugitive can contest his rendition by claiming he was not present in the demanding State at the time of the alleged crime, it is not essential that the date be in the indictment, rather the date may be supplied in any official document of the demanding State to effectuate the purpose of extradition proceedings; accordingly, the failure of an indictment to supply a date of the alleged crime in an extradition proceeding does not warrant the discharge of the alleged fugitive if the date is supplied by the demanding State in another official document such as a sworn "application for extradition" by the prosecutor of the demanding State.

Extradition -- Scope of Judicial Review

2. The statutory requirement that the demanding State "substantially charge" the person demanded with a crime ( CPL 570.08) does not allow the courts of the asylum State to review the finding of probable cause made by a judicial [***2] officer in the demanding State; once the Governor grants extradition, the scope of judicial review in a habeas corpus proceeding is limited to whether the extradition documents on their face are in order, whether the petitioner has been charged with a crime in the demanding State, whether the petitioner is the person named in the request for extradition, and whether the petitioner is a fugitive.

Extradition -- Scope of Judicial Review -- Inquiry Whether Acts Constitute Crime

3. The courts of an asylum State, in an extradition proceeding, have the power and obligation to inquire as to whether the acts of which the alleged fugitive is accused constitute a crime; CPL 570.08, which requires that the demanding State "substantially charge" the person demanded with a crime, requires that the accused be advised of the specific acts constituting the crime alleged and, if the penal statute itself is vague, the accusatory instrument must describe the offense in greater detail.

Extradition -- Inquiry Whether Acts Alleged Constitute Crime

4. Where there is a "reasonable possibility" or a "nice question" as to whether an act is a crime in the demanding State, extradition [***3] must be granted; however, when an alleged fugitive in an extradition proceeding claims that the act of which he is accused does not constitute a crime, he must, in order to prevail, establish conclusively that statutes or decisional law of the demanding State do not establish the act as criminal or that making the act alleged criminal would be unconstitutional; accordingly, since the allegations against petitioner, the inventor of a patented baseball glove and tethered ball device, of defrauding an investor in Alabama and misrepresenting the return on an investment could arguably form the basis of a criminal prosecution under Alabama's "Blue Sky" securities laws and the Alabama criminal statutes, and petitioner has not come forward with any Alabama law indicating that the alleged acts are not criminal, the application for denial of rendition must be denied and petitioner ordered returned to Alabama where questions concerning the criminal nature of petitioner's acts should properly be raised.

 

2134 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Klimek v. Ghent


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Columbia County


98 Misc. 2d 893; 414 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2161



March 28, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] To the extent that Local Law No. 1 of the Town of Ghent requires additional requirements of the prior service of a written notice of unsafe conditions, it is unconstitutional (see F. T. B. Realty Corp. v Goodman, 300 NY 140, 148; Schiavone v County of Nassau, 41 NY2d 844), and the plaintiff's motion is therefore granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the father of an injured infant, filed a negligence action against defendant town. The father then filed a motion for an order dismissing a second affirmative defense of the town on the ground that the local law on which said defense was predicated was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The injured infant was hurt while operating a tractor on a road in the town. His father commenced an action against the town claiming damages resulting from negligent construction and maintenance of the road, shoulders, and drainage system, and appurtenances thereto. The father filed a motion for an order dismissing a second affirmative defense of the town on the ground that the local law on which the defense was based was unconstitutional. The court granted the motion. The court held that a comparison of the relevant provisions of N.Y. Town Law § 65-a and N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e with Ghent, N.Y., Local Law No. 1 showed that different requirements concerning the prior service of a written notice of unsafe condition were set forth. The local law additionally required notices of the unsafe condition of any other property owned by the town. The local enactment was thus inconsistent with the General Law because it prohibited that which was found acceptable under the General Law. To the extent that Local Law No. 1 of the town required additional requirements of the prior service of a written notice of unsafe conditions, it was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Prior Written Notice of Defective Condition

A local government has the power to adopt laws regarding the presentation and discharge of claims against it, provided such local laws are consistent with the provisions of any general laws on the subject; therefore, a local law which imposes a requirement of prior service of written notice of an unsafe highway, bridge or culvert "or other property owned, operated or maintained by the Town" is unconstitutional to the extent that it exceeds the specifically enumerated provisions of the general laws regarding tort claims against towns (Town Law, § 65-a; General Municipal Law, § 50-e), and prohibits that which has been found acceptable under those general laws.

 

2135 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Robert v. Ford Motor Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, St. Lawrence County


100 Misc. 2d 646; 417 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2521



March 28, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The requested amendment as set forth in the proposed amended complaint is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the adult daughters of a couple killed in an automobile accident, filed a motion to amend their complaint to assert a wrongful death cause of action claiming punitive damages and seeking additional discovery of defendant automobile manufacturer. Defendant automobile manufacturer filed a cross-motion for a protective order against plaintiff's motion to discover and inspect.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs' parents were burned to death when their automobile was involved in a collision and caught fire. Plaintiffs brought suit against defendants, the manufacturer, retailer, and repairer of their parents' vehicle and the driver of the other vehicle involved in the collision. Plaintiffs filed a motion to amend their complaint to assert a wrongful death cause of action, claiming punitive damages and seeking additional discovery of defendant automobile manufacturer. The court noted that New York's wrongful death statute did not deny punitive damages but that judicial precedent disallowed any award of punitive damages in a wrongful death cause of action. The court applied the middle tier scrutiny test to analyze whether the preferential treatment of tort-feasors whose negligence resulted in death compared to tort-feasors whose negligence injured their victims could withstand an equal protection challenge. The court held that the preferential treatment did not further any legitimate articulated governmental purpose and had obvious detrimental effects which outweighed its benefits. The court granted plaintiff's requested amendment.


OUTCOME: The court granted permission to plaintiffs to amend their complaint to include a wrongful death cause of action and to claim punitive damages against defendants. The court held that the state's policy of denying punitive damages to wrongful death claimants while allowing them where negligence resulted only in injury could not withstand middle tier scrutiny in relation to an equal protection challenge.


HEADNOTES

Damages -- Punitive Damages in Wrongful Death Cases

The New York wrongful death statute ( EPTL 5-4.3), which limits damages to the fair and just compensation for the pecuniary injuries resulting from the decedent's death to persons for whose benefit the action is brought, does not abrogate the plaintiff executrix' right to seek punitive damages from the defendant car manufacturer, in a wrongful death action commenced after plaintiff's parents were killed in an automobile accident; alternatively, insofar as the wording, application and interpretation of New York's wrongful death statute deny the recovery of punitive damages in a wrongful death case, while they are permitted in personal injury and property damage cases in New York, they are violative of the equal protection of laws as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and section 11 of article I of the New York Constitution. Depriving wrongful death claimants of punitive damages does not serve or enhance the State's public policy of allowing punitive damages in proper cases to deter egregious conduct [***2] of tort-feasors.

 

2136 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Durham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Sixth District, Suffolk County


98 Misc. 2d 927; 415 N.Y.S.2d 183; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2168



March 26, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all the foregoing reasons, the defendant's application to dismiss the information, on the grounds that section 58-2 of the Code of the Town of Brookhaven is unconstitutional, is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed an application to dismiss an information charging him with having a sign larger than legal size posted with gas prices in front of the station in which he worked.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with a violation of Brookhaven, N.Y., Code § 58-2. He applied to the court for dismissal of the information on the ground that § 58-2 violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 8, 11. The court agreed that by singling out gas stations for proscription of price signs, other than those affixed to gas pumps, the town created an arbitrary classification. The court found that the ordinance improperly singled out speech of a particular content, i.e., gasoline prices, and while not preventing its dissemination completely, there was left open no ample alternative channel of communication, as reflected by the drastic reduction in sales when this means of advertisement was foreclosed. The court observed that the frustrated gasoline consumer had a right to know that there was a dealer whose product was being sold at a discount price within the town.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's application.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Commercial Speech

1. Although commercial speech is protected under the First Amendment of the United States Constitution, a municipality may enact reasonable regulations governing the dissemination of commercial advertisement, and the curtailment must be justified without reference to the content of the regulated speech, and in so doing there must be left open ample alternative channels for communication of the information.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Gasoline Price Signs

2. A local ordinance prohibiting gas stations from displaying price signs other than those affixed to gasoline pumps is unconstitutional, since the classification created by the ordinance is arbitrary and without justification and leaves no ample alternative channel of communication.

 

2137 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schwartzman v. Berle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


98 Misc. 2d 936; 415 N.Y.S.2d 187; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2171



March 26, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application, accordingly, is denied in its entirety and the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 that sought to annul the determination of respondent, the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, which denied his application for a "party permit" type of deer-hunting permit. The applicant also sought a declaration that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law §§ ECL 11-0913, subd. 1, para. b, and 11-0913, subd. 2, para. f were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: After the commissioner denied the applicant's request for a "party permit" for deer hunting, the applicant brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, on behalf of himself and others similarly situated, that sought to annul the commissioner's determination. The applicant also sought a declaration that that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law §§ ECL 11-0913, subd. 1, para. b, and 11-0913, subd. 2, para. f were unconstitutional and other related relief, including attorneys' fees. The court found that the applicant acknowledged in his application that he did not belong to a group. The court held that it was apparent that the applicant was not an "owner" as that term was defined in N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 11-0913, subd. 1, para. c. The court ruled that the commissioner's regulation of the number of individuals required to join in an application for a "party permit" was within the State's police power, and did not constitute an unconstitutional infringement of the applicant's rights. The court held that it was reasonable for the commissioner to have granted a permit preference to landowners within the specific unit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the commissioner's denial of the applicant's request for a "party permit" and dismissed the applicant's petition in its entirety.


HEADNOTES

Animals -- Deer Hunting

In order to effectively manage a healthy deer population, the State may exercise its police power to issue "deer management permits" which authorize a group of licensed hunters holding such a permit to take one deer of either sex in addition to the limit of one deer per licensed hunter for a license year; such permits may constitutionally be issued preferentially to groups containing a person who owns at least 50 acres of land in one parcel in the specified hunting area to which the permit applies, since this preference serves a legitimate State interest in having the greatest amount of area possible open to licensed hunters, for landowners assured of receiving permits will be less likely to close their land to other hunters. ( ECL 11-0913, subd 1, pars a, b.)

 

2138 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. William R. v. New York State Family Court


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


99 Misc. 2d 427; 416 N.Y.S.2d 960; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2306



March 23, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated proceeding, petitioner agency sought termination of parental rights and a transfer of custody and guardianship to the agency pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b. Petitioner father filed a writ of habeas corpus seeking the return of the children to his care, and petitioner commissioner filed a petition pursuant to § 1055 of the Family Court Act seeking an extension of the court's original placement order.


OVERVIEW: The agency filed a petition seeking termination of parental rights and a transfer of custody and guardianship to the agency, but did not name the father a respondent on the petition because the parents were not married. The trial court adjudicated the three children to be "abandoned" by their mother pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b(5), and the father filed a writ of habeas corpus seeking the return of the children to his custody. The court declared its intention of holding in abeyance its own decision on the agency's termination of parental rights petition until after the United States Supreme Court had spoken. The court noted that its decision was extraordinary, but that at the time of the deliberation, the rule as to the rights granted by New York State statutes to unwed fathers when their children were to be freed for adoption was under scrutiny by the United States Supreme Court and that a decision was expected within weeks. Therefore, the court determined that it would preserve the status quo and allow the children to maintain family stability with their foster parents without reaching the question of whether parental rights should be terminated.


OUTCOME: The court declared its intent to hold in abeyance its own decision on the agency's termination of parental rights petition until after the United States Supreme Court had spoken on the issue.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Rights of Unwed Natural Father

Notwithstanding the fact that the Court of Appeals has upheld the constitutionality of a statute which does not require the consent of an unwed natural father in an adoption proceeding stating that distinctions between wed and unwed fathers does not violate equal protection and that an adjudicated unwed father is entitled to no more than notice of the hearing and an opportunity to be heard (see Matter of Malpica-Orsini, 36 NY2d 568; Domestic Relations Law, §§ 111, 111-a; Social Services Law, § 384-c), the New York rule will not be blindly enforced to terminate the parental rights of the intervening unwed natural father until further clarification of the parameters of the rights of unwed fathers by the United States Supreme Court in a pending case in which the Court of Appeals ruling and New York statutory scheme are being challenged ( Caban v Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380) and, accordingly, the termination of parental rights petition will be held in abeyance until the Supreme Court has spoken; factors weighed by a lower court in determining whether current precedent is binding are substantial [***2] factual distinctions, recent trends in substantive judicial opinion favoring change in the rule, pending Supreme Court review of a similar case, presentation of new legal as well as factual issues not reviewed earlier and the weight and constitutional dimension of the rights at issue.

 

2139 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Loretto v. Teleprompter Manhattan CATV Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 944; 415 N.Y.S.2d 180; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2173



March 14, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In light of the foregoing the remaining application (No. 90) which seeks relief bearing on the class action nature of this litigation has become academic and, considered as such, is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord instituted a class action against defendants, a city and a cable company, to test the constitutionality of N.Y. Exec. Law § 828.


OVERVIEW: Section 828 barred landlords from interfering with the installation of cable television facilities upon their property and limited payment for such use of the property to the amount awarded by the Commission on Cable Television. The landlord argued that the virtually free installation of cable television components on private property authorized by § 828 amounted to an uncompensated trespass and condemnation of property that constituted a taking without due process. The court held that § 828 represented a reasonable and justifiable exercise of the police power of the State both with respect to cable television components placed directly on premises serviced by the cable company and premises on which equipment was placed to service another building. The landlord failed to meet the heavy burden imposed on a party seeking to overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality inherent in every statute enacted by the legislature. In the absence of compelling circumstances making a declaration of unconstitutionality unavoidable, it was not the province of a court of first instance to strike down a statute as invalidly adopted.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of the city and the cable company.


HEADNOTES

Trespass -- Cable Television Facilities

 Section 828 of the Executive Law, which prohibits a landlord from interfering with the installation of cable television facilities upon his property and limits payment therefor to the amount awarded by the Commission on Cable Television, is constitutional in that it represents a reasonable and, therefore, justifiable exercise of the State's police power both with respect to those facilities placed directly on the building receiving the service, and those placed on the premises of one landlord in order to service other buildings more removed from the source of transmission; the obvious public advantage fostered by the statute greatly outweighs the insignificant nature of the permissible use of the private property.

 

2140 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Roth v. Roth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Queens County


98 Misc. 2d 618; 414 N.Y.S.2d 485; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2123



March 13, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner wife commenced a proceeding for child support and for spousal support, pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 412, and respondent husband cross-petitioned for contribution to child support and to school tuition, pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 416.


OVERVIEW: With a child in college and another in private school, the wife brought an action against the husband to recover child support and to recover spousal support, pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 412. In response, the husband cross-petitioned for contribution to child support and to school tuition, pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 416. In denying the wife spousal support and granting the husband contribution, the court initially calculated the wife's earnings and liquid assets and the husband's annual income. Thereafter, the court held it would be equitable for the wife to contribute 20 percent of the child support and for the husband to contribute 80 percent of the child support. In so holding, the court took judicial notice of the increased value that society placed on higher education for its own sake as well as a vehicle for success in the world. In denying the wife spousal support, the court noted that sex could not be a proxy for need, despite N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 412's requirement that a husband support a wife. Accordingly, the court held that the wife, who was in good health, financially astute, skilled, and unencumbered by children, was the antithesis of a needy spouse.


OUTCOME: Notwithstanding the New York law charging a husband with the support of a wife, the court denied the wife's application for spousal support and found that it would be equitable for the wife to contribute 20 percent of the children's support and for the husband to contribute 80 percent of the children's support, in light of the wife's earnings and liquid assets and the husband's annual income.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife -- Support

1. Petitioner wife, who earns or is capable of earning $ 15,000 per year and controls liquid assets in excess of $ 80,000, is not entitled to support since only a spouse in actual need is entitled to support (see Orr v Orr,    U.S.   ).

Parent and Child -- Support -- Mother's Obligation to Contribute to Support

2. Petitioner mother is to contribute 20% toward the support of her two children, neither of whom reside with her, and respondent father is to contribute 80% toward their support,  [***2] including tuition fees for private school and college, in view of the facts and circumstances, including the facts that petitioner earns or is capable of earning $ 15,000 per year and controls liquid assets in excess of $ 80,000, and respondent earns $ 60,000 per year, since both spouses are responsible for the support of their children according to their respective means, capital is not exempt from invasion, and tuition fees are a necessary element of support.

Husband and Wife -- Counsel Fees

3. In a proceeding for support for petitioner and her two children, petitioner's application for counsel fees is denied inasmuch as she has ample resources to pay her attorney; in addition, her application for an allowance for accountant fees, after she retained an accountant to examine the books and records of her husband's business, is denied, as there is no statutory provision for it.

 

2141 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lief v. Hynes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


98 Misc. 2d 817; 414 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2149



March 9, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought to have a grand jury subpoena issued to him quashed or, in the alternative, to have the subpoena modified by permitting his counsel to be present with him in the grand jury room despite the absence of a waiver of immunity.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was issued a subpoena to appear before a grand jury. Petitioner challenged the subpoena on the ground that it was defective since it made no provision for permitting an attorney for a witness, who did not waive immunity, to represent his client before the grand jury. Petitioner also alleged that the purpose of the prosecutor in seeking petitioner's appearance before the grand jury was not to secure information but to obtain a perjury indictment. The court denied petitioner's application to quash the subpoena or to modify it. The court concluded that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.52, which permitted a witness who had waived his transactional immunity the right to be represented by counsel in the grand jury room and conversely denied that right to one testifying under a grant of immunity, did not deny the equal protection of the laws to a person appearing before the grand jury who did not waive immunity. The court noted that the distinction between grand jury witnesses was reasonable. The court further concluded that the evidence was not sufficient to support petitioner's allegation that the purpose of his grand jury appearance was to obtain a perjury indictment.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's application to quash the grand jury subpoena or, in the alternative to modify it, holding that the subpoena was not constitutionally defective and that there was insufficient evidence to support the allegation that petitioner's grand jury appearance was based on the prosecutor's desire to obtain a perjury indictment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws

1. Equal protection of the laws is not denied when all persons are treated alike under like circumstances and conditions, both on the privileges conferred and the liabilities imposed; a classification must be reasonable, not arbitrary, and must rest upon some ground of difference having a fair and substantial relation to the object of the legislation.

Grand Jury -- Witness' Right to Counsel

 [***2] 2. CPL 190.52, which entitles a person appearing as a witness before the Grand Jury who has waived his transactional immunity to the assistance of counsel in the Grand Jury room, does not deny the equal protection of the laws (US Const, 14th Amdt) to a person appearing before the Grand Jury who does not waive immunity since, under the rational basis test, which requires that a classification be reasonable, not arbitrary and have a fair and substantial relation to the object of the legislation, so that all persons similarly circumstanced shall be treated alike, the distinction in treatment between Grand Jury witnesses who waive immunity and those who do not is a rational one, in that immunized witnesses may not be prosecuted for crimes revealed by their testimony, and the purpose of the statute was to lessen the danger of a nonimmunized witness being prosecuted for substantive crimes; the fact that a nonimmunized witness may, by virtue of the statute, also enjoy a degree of protection against possible perjury does not establish discrimination since the classification is reasonable and does not offend the Constitution simply because it is not made with mathematical nicety or results [***3] in some inequality, and an immunized witness does not require the assistance of counsel in order to know when to tell the truth.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

3. There is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted by the Legislature is constitutional, and for a court to declare a law unconstitutional, the invalidity must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt.

Grand Jury -- Appearance for Purpose of Securing Perjury Indictment

4. Where a subpoena ad testificandum was issued to petitioner on behalf of a Grand Jury inquiring into certain hospital operations, evidence that a representative of the State Attorney-General indicated that he did not find petitioner's explanation of certain events to be credible and that the Special Prosecutor subsequently refused to furnish the reasons for this conclusion is not sufficient to support petitioner's allegation that the purpose of his Grand Jury appearance was to obtain a perjury indictment, and there was no indication that the Special Prosecutor intended to ask questions not relevant to the Grand Jury investigation.

 

2142 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Colwin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 676; 414 N.Y.S.2d 469; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2131



March 8, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State of New York and the City of New York City sought to judicially settle the priority of their tax claims against the executor of an insolvent estate.


OVERVIEW: An insolvent estate owed the State unpaid income taxes and owed the City unpaid income and unincorporated business taxes. The State and the City sought to determine the priority of their respective tax claims. The State asserted that it had priority on its entire claim, but the City asserted that its tax claims were on a parity. The court noted that the City's income and business taxes were a means of balancing the budget for the costs of local government. Unlike emergency relief taxes, the revenues from the City's business and income taxes were not held separately. Further, if income taxes were a delegation of the authority to tax a subdivision of the State such tax might be an unconstitutional unequal state tax because all municipal residents were to be treated equally. Thus, the City's income tax was not a delegation of authority for the State's revenues, and the City was not collecting the funds in question as an agent of the State. Moreover, under N.Y. Surr. Ct. Proc. Act Law § 1811(2)(a), a fiduciary had to first pay debts entitled to a preference under the law of the United States and the State of New York.
