Thus, the State enjoyed priority over the City for the tax debts.


OUTCOME: The court held that the State enjoyed priority over the City for the tax debts, irrespective of when the claims were filed. Nevertheless, the City was not in parity with all other creditors, but had a priority as against them.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Executors and Administrators -- State's Priority for Unpaid Taxes

Since the sovereign right of the State to priority for its taxes may not be restricted or abridged without a specific statutory provision and since SCPA 1811, which requires a fiduciary to first pay debts "entitled to preference under the laws of the United States and the state of New York" does not include "debts of any subdivision of the state" or similar language, the State's claim for unpaid income taxes against the insolvent estate is entitled to priority over the claim by the City of New York for unpaid income taxes and unincorporated business taxes; the right of the city to impose an income tax (General City Law, § 25-a) is not a "delegation of the State's authority" to tax so as to give the city an equal priority with the State for unpaid income taxes but is instead a way for the city to collect its costs of local government and consequently the city is collecting the funds for its own purposes and not as an agent of the State.

 

2143 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Harris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


98 Misc. 2d 766; 414 N.Y.S.2d 612; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2144



March 7, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed an application for letters of administration in decedent's estate and was the guardian of the property of an infant who was the out-of-wedlock son of the mother and the decedent. The question presented was whether under the facts here present, the mother's ward had the status of a distributee of the decedent's estate so as to confer upon the mother her right as his guardian to letters of administration.


OVERVIEW: When the infant was born his parents were living together. It appears that they continued to cohabit for many years thereafter. After the parents separated, an order of filiation and support was entered in the family court against the decedent. On the date of the order the infant was approximately eight years of age. Thereafter the decedent regularly made the ordered support payments, visited with his son, purchased clothing for him, gave him gifts, opened a small bank account for his benefit, and named him as a beneficiary on a life insurance policy. He died and the mother of the child filed her petition. The court granted the petition. Although N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law 4-1.2(a)(2) provided for legitimacy if the order of filiation was instituted within two years from the birth of the child, the court followed the consistent pattern of the courts of New York of allowing an illegitimate, whose relationship to his father had been established by a filiation order, to inherit from his father no matter how long after birth the filiation order was entered, so long as it was entered during the lifetime of the father.


OUTCOME: The court granted the mother's application for letters of administration upon her duly qualifying according to law. The infant ward of the mother whose paternal relationship with decedent was established by a duly rendered order of filiation, had a right to inherit from decedent.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Statutes -- Effectuating Legislative Purpose and Intent

1. Although ordinarily courts may not legislate and must give literal effect to unambiguous statutory language, an overriding rule is that in applying statutes the court must effectuate the purpose and intent of the legislation and to carry out this function the courts have latitude in not blindly adhering to the literal language of a statute if such language fails to express the clear overriding purpose of the legislation.

Children Born Out of Wedlock -- Right of Illegitimate to Inherit from Father -- Two-Year Limitation

2. Notwithstanding the requirement that an order of filiation be made during the lifetime of the father in a paternity proceeding instituted "within two years from the birth of the child" for an illegitimate child to inherit from his father ( EPTL 4-1.2), in order to effectuate the legislative intent of the statute of granting to "illegitimates in so far as practicable rights of inheritance on a par with those enjoyed by legitimate children" and to avoid a finding of unconstitutionality for a denial of equal protection if the two-year limitation is given literal and stringent effect, an illegitimate [***2] whose relationship to his father has been established by a filiation order is entitled to inherit from his father no matter how long after birth the filiation order is entered so long as it is entered during the lifetime of the father; the two-year limitation fails to bear a substantial relationship to the State exercising its power to establish legitimate procedural safeguards and is inconsistent with other statutory provisions extending the two-year limitation where the father has acknowledged paternity in writing or furnished support (Family Ct Act, § 517, subd [a]) thereby creating disparate classifications between parties similarly situated without a rational basis.

 

2144 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Farias v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


101 Misc. 2d 598; 421 N.Y.S.2d 753; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2728



March 1, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, parents and guardians of minor circus performers, filed an action for a declaratory judgment that the children were not prohibited by law from performing in the circus, or that N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 3229, 3231-a were unconstitutional, and for an injunction restraining defendants, the City and State of New York and the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children (SPCC), from proceeding against them in family court under §§ 3229, 3231-a.


OVERVIEW: The SPCC charged plaintiffs with abuse, neglect, and alleged violations of N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 3229, 3231-a in the family court. Plaintiffs filed an action in the supreme court seeking a declaratory judgment that the circus performance violated no laws, or that §§ 3229, 3231-a were unconstitutional, and injunctive relief. The court granted plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The court held that although amendments deleted provisions of the laws that plaintiffs contended were unconstitutional, the action was not rendered moot because plaintiffs were still subject to criminal and abuse and neglect charges. Plaintiffs were entitled to an injunction because they showed a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits of their claim as the statute appeared to contain an unconstitutional and improper abuse of the police power by completely prohibiting performances by children instead of reasonably regulating them, and apparently unconstitutionally delegated authority to the SPCC. They also showed irreparable injury because the children would not have been paid if they did not perform and the public would have been deprived of the performance.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief against defendants, restraining them from legal proceedings under the Education Law for the children's performance in the circus.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Jurisdiction

1. Although pursuant to section 3232 of the Education Law the Family Court has exclusive jurisdiction to determine charges of alleged violations of sections 3229 and 3231-a involving child performers, the Supreme Court has the power to grant an injunction to prevent inequities and threatened irreparable injury and also has the power to grant declaratory relief where plaintiffs, a circus company and the parents and guardians of 10 children who perform in the circus, risk violating the law and subjecting themselves to criminal penalties if they permit the children to perform as well as the economic loss if they prohibit such performances.

Infants -- Abused or Neglected Child

2. Plaintiffs, a circus company and the parents and guardians of 10 children who had been performing as gymnasts, trapeze artists, horse and elephant riders, acrobats and unicycle riders, are entitled to preliminary injunctive relief regarding legal proceedings commenced by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children charging them with abuse, neglect and misdemeanors for alleged violations of former sections 3229 and 3231-a of the Education Law where plaintiffs [***2] have shown a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits with respect to their contention that both sections contain unconstitutional provisions and there has been a showing of irreparable injury; the fact that during the pendency of this action both sections were amended to avoid the constitutional infirmities that plaintiffs contended existed does not render this action and the motion for a preliminary injunction moot inasmuch as plaintiffs are still subject to criminal charges as well as charges of abuse and neglect for past performances.

 

2145 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Blum


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


98 Misc. 2d 373; 414 N.Y.S.2d 960; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2084



February 27, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, city and city officials, brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondent state officials challenging the validity of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 381.9, and requesting that the state officials be ordered to restore disallowances from welfare advance checks and pay the funds allocated for the reimbursement of the amount paid under the aid to dependent children (ADC) program to eligible recipients.


OVERVIEW: The city and the city officials submitted a reimbursement claim to the state officials for the amount they paid under the ADC program to eligible recipients. The state officials determined that the submitted claims were improper, resulting in the city and the city officials receiving excess reimbursement. The state officials began recouping the overpaid amount by deducting money from the welfare advance checks issued to the city and the city officials. The city and the city officials initiated a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to stop the recoupment process. The court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 381.9 was valid and that suit should have been brought under N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 601.1, which was a procedure by which a municipality alleging it had been mistreated could assert a claim to that effect. Nonetheless, the court ordered the state officials to pay the city and the city officials the amount of federal funds made available for reimbursement as required by N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 153(1)(a). The state officials were, however, free to withhold the matching reimbursement from their own funds pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 20(3)(f).


OUTCOME: The city and the city officials were granted the right to assert their claim for reimbursement of the amount paid under the ADC program under an alternate regulation within 20 days. The state officials were directed to pay to the city and the city officials that portion of the funds made available by the federal government which represented their share of the retroactive reimbursement. All other requests for relief were denied.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Jurisdiction over Challenge to State Regulation

1. Special Term has jurisdiction to entertain a suit by the City of New York challenging the validity of an administrative regulation issued by the State Department of Social Services (18 NYCRR 381.9) which limits the share of aid to dependent children assistance reimbursable by the State, as being inconsistent with a statute either under CPLR 3001 or 7803 (subd 3); petitioners' standing can be grounded either in their status as officials of a municipality affected by State action or as taxpayers and the absence of jurisdiction to award monetary damages in the proceeding ( CPLR 7806) has no bearing on standing or other jurisdictional questions and does not provide a basis for the dismissal of the entire petition.

State -- Validity of Administrative Regulation

2. If a regulation of an administrative agency is out of harmony with the statute, it must fail notwithstanding the great weight which attaches to the regulation by virtue of its being adopted by an agency charged with its promulgation.

Social Services -- State Reimbursement to Localities

 [***3] 3. Although the statutory authority given to the State Department of Social Services to promulgate regulations to implement the statutory requirement that the State reimburse a locality 50% of the amount the locality expends for public assistance "after first deducting therefrom any federal funds properly received or to be received on account thereof" (Social Services Law, § 153, subd 1, par [d]) does not authorize the Social Services Commissioner to limit the per centum of State reimbursement established by statute, subdivision 7 of section 131-a of the Social Services Law does, however, provide statutory authority for a regulation limiting State reimbursement to localities for vendor/restricted aid to dependent children payments to an amount "established by the department to insure full federal participation" (18 NYCRR 381.9) and the State is further authorized to recoup overpayments made for excess vendor/restricted payments by deducting these sums from welfare advance checks issued to the locality.

Social Services -- Limitation on Reimbursements for Vendor/Restricted Payments

4. The action of a State agency is not arbitrary and capricious merely because the effect [***4] of that action is to cause greater monetary loss to a petitioner than if the State chose an equally legitimate alternative course of action which had a more favorable financial impact on a petitioner; accordingly, since the State Department of Social Services, in calculating the amount of over-reimbursement paid to the City of New York for vendor/restricted payments made by the city, is authorized by Federal regulations to apply the 10% limit on reimbursements for vendor/restricted payments either on a district-by-district or State-wide basis (45 CFR 234.60 [b] [2] [ii]), the fact that the State's application of the 10% limitation on a district-by-district instead of a State-wide basis might result in the city's losing a greater share of Federal and State reimbursement, does not render the State's choice of formula arbitrary and capricious.

Social Services -- Authority to Withhold Federal Reimbursement to City

5. The State Commissioner of Social Services has no authority to refuse to make claim or to withhold Federal reimbursement to a city for noncompliance with State regulations since the State is required to claim and pay "federal funds" to a city as reimbursement [***5] when the Federal Government makes such funds available (Social Services Law, § 153, subd 1, par a); however, the State may withhold the State matching share of reimbursement which accompanies the Federal share for noncompliance with State regulations (Social Services Law, § 20, subd 3, par [f]).

 

2146 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Friedman v. Gerax Realty Associates


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


100 Misc. 2d 820; 420 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2555



February 23, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant mortgagor filed a motion for an order vacating a prior order appointing a receiver without notice in a mortgage foreclosure action. Plaintiff mortgagees filed a cross motion for a contempt order for failure to comply with the prior order.


OVERVIEW: By prior order, the court appointed a receiver ex parte at the request of the mortgagees. The mortgagors refused to comply. The mortgagees filed a motion for contempt. The mortgagors filed a motion to vacate the prior order. The court denied both motions. The court ruled that the mortgage provided that the holder of the mortgage was entitled to the appointment of a receiver without notice as authorized by N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 254(10). Thus, the prior ex parte order was not in violation of New York law. The court ruled that due process was not violated by the ex parte order. The court ruled that the mortgagees' motion for contempt was defective on its face for failure to notify the recipient that failure to appear could result in imprisonment for contempt.


OUTCOME: The court denied both motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Mortgages -- Foreclosure -- Receiver

1. In a mortgage foreclosure action, where the mortgage provides for the appointment of a receiver, notice pursuant to subdivision 10 of section 254 of the Real Property Law is not unconstitutional as violative of due process, in view of the facts that the appointment of the receiver is based upon sworn ex parte documents under judicial supervision and that the law provides for an opportunity to an aggrieved party for an immediate hearing on the validity or probable validity of the underlying claim.

Contempt -- Application to Punish for Contempt

2. A motion to punish for contempt is denied without prejudice where the movant failed to have typewritten or printed on the face of the motion papers, as required by section 756 of the Judiciary Law, a warning to the effect that a failure to appear in court may result in immediate arrest and imprisonment for contempt of court.

 

2147 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Simmons v. Sheridan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 328; 414 N.Y.S.2d 83; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2075



February 22, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner maternal grandmother filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus seeking a determination on whether she was entitled, pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 72, to visitation with her grandchild, who had been adopted by respondent paternal grandparents.


OVERVIEW: The grandmother's grandchild was adopted by the paternal grandparents and she sought the right to visitation. She filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus and the court sustained it. The court found that if the child's adoption by the paternal grandparents were to cut off the grandmother's right to seek visitation, then the purpose of § 72 would be frustrated. The court held that an adoption by a child's paternal grandparents did not preclude the maternal grandmother from asserting her right to seek visitation under § 72. The court also found that the paternal grandparents' challenge to the constitutionality of § 72 was without merit because while it was true that a parent's right to bring up his or her children as each saw fit was a right protected by the United States Constitution, a parent's right to be free of interference had to give way to valid legislation in the child's best interests. The court held that the grandmother had made a showing sufficient to warrant a hearing at which it could be determined whether granting her visitation rights was in the best interests of her grandchild.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the writ of habeas corpus to the extent that it was set down for a hearing on the issue of whether visitation by the grandmother was in the best interests of her grandchild.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Visitation Rights of Grandparents

A maternal grandmother is entitled, pursuant to section 72 of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides a procedural vehicle through which grandparents may obtain visitation rights in certain circumstances, to seek visitation with her 11-year-old grandson who was born out of wedlock to her deceased daughter and was adopted by his paternal grandparents, since the purpose of section 72 would be frustrated if the child's adoption by his paternal grandparents were to cut off his matenal grandmother's right to seek visitation; although the paternal grandparents are now the child's parents and a parent's right to bring up his or her children as each sees fit is a right protected by the Constitution, a parent's right to be free of interference must always give way to valid legislation in the child's best interest, and the burden of demonstrating the unconstitutionality of section 72 has not been met.

 

2148 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wellsville v. AFSCME, N. Y. Council 66 etc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Allegany County


103 Misc. 2d 151; 425 N.Y.S.2d 441; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2939



February 15, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner village filed a motion to stay arbitration of a grievance filed by respondent state, county, and municipal employees union and its affiliated local.


OVERVIEW: For over 40 years, the village charged employees of its water and light department the minimum permitted amount for water rent regardless of the amount of water consumed. Later, the same practice was followed with respect to sewer charges. When the practice was discontinued by village officials, the employees protested, alleging that the discontinuance violated their collective bargaining agreement. They sought arbitration of the matter, and the village filed a motion to stay. The court found that the agreement clearly established that any grievance, controversy, or dispute involving the application, meaning, or interpretation of the agreement could proceed to arbitration. The court held that the continuance of the practice offended public policy because the free rentals were nothing more or less than a gift by the municipality to its employees, which was prohibited by N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1. The court also held that arbitration should proceed to determine whether the free rentals for were a protected benefit and, if they were so protected, that the arbitrator should grant only such relief as was consistent with the legal and constitutional prerogatives of the village.


OUTCOME: The court denied the village's motion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Arbitration -- Matters Arbitrable

1. Under a collective bargaining agreement which provides that "any grievance, controversy or dispute" involving "the application, meaning or interpretation" of the agreement may proceed to arbitration, a dispute as to whether discontinuance of "past practices" of the employer village, which charged employees of the village water and light department who resided in the village only the minimum charge permitted for water and sewer rent regardless of the amount consumed, violates an article of said collective bargaining agreement between the parties dealing with maintenance of benefits, is an arbitrable matter; moreover, a clause in the agreement reserving management rights to the village is not a bar to arbitration of said dispute, since the question of whether the minimum charge for water and sewer rent is a protected benefit to employees or a management prerogative is a question of contract interpretation to be resolved by arbitration.

Municipal Corporations -- Reduced Water and Sewer Rent as Compensation to Employees

2. A practice by a village in charging employees of the village water and light department who live in the village [***2] only the minimum charge permitted for water and sewer rent regardless of the amount of water consumed does not contravene statutory provisions contained in section 11-1118 of the Village Law or section 452 of the General Municipal Law, since those statutes speak only to the obligation of the village to establish and charge equal rental charges to consumers as consumers and do not address the question of whether reduced rentals may be a proper means of compensation to municipal employees; however, where the free water and sewer rentals are not treated as compensation either by the village or the employee, such rentals are a gift by the municipality to its employees in violation of the provisions of section 1 of article VIII of the New York State Constitution. Accordingly, where said practice is the subject of an arbitrable dispute concerning whether it is a past practice protected under the department employees' collective bargaining agreement with the village, arbitration should proceed to determine first, whether the free rental for water and sewer services is a protected benefit under the terms of the collective bargaining agreement and, in the event that it is determined to be [***3] such, and only in that event, the arbitrator should proceed to grant only such relief as is consistent with the legal and constitutional prerogatives of the village; labor arbitrators, even in the public sector, are not strictly limited to remedies requested by the parties, but, on the contrary, arbitrators in this context are, in the final analysis, empowered to do justice and the award may well reflect the spirit, rather than the letter of the agreement.

 

2149 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nissen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Suffolk County


97 Misc. 2d 1000; 412 N.Y.S.2d 999; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2030



January 31, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss an indictment charging them with criminal possession of approximately 14,000 pounds of marihuana in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 221.30.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with criminal possession of marihuana, which was found on a large sailboat of foreign registry manned by defendants and travelling within territorial waters of the United States. Defendants moved to dismiss the indictment on the basis that the vessel was in distress and seeking safe harbor at the time that the drugs were seized. Defendants also urged that the warrantless search violated their rights under U.S. Const. amend. IV and 14 U.S.C.S. § 89(a). The court denied defendants' motion, holding that defendants were entitled to assert the defense of safe harbor during a jury trial. The court concluded that the Coast Guard could act as customs officers under § 89(a) and conduct a warrantless customs search, due to observations that defendants' boat was moving without sufficient lights and was riding heavy in the water. The court determined that the subsequent discovery of an odor typical of marihuana and the observations of the drugs in plain view justified a seizure and arrest. The court concluded that the customs search constituted a border search, due to evidence that the boat had come from waters outside of United States territory.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion to dismiss, since the marihuana was seized pursuant to a valid customs search.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Defense of Safe Harbor

1. A foreign vessel [***2] has the right to enter the territory of a State when such entry is necessary for the safety of the vessel or persons aboard and to leave the territory once the conditions that made the entry necessary have ceased to exist, such right of entry entitling the foreign vessel to claim, as of right, an entire immunity from the local jurisdiction; the necessity for entry must be urgent and not merely a matter of convenience and the entry must be bona fide and made without intent to evade the laws of the host State.

Crimes -- Warrantless Safety and Document Check of Vessel by Coast Guard

2. Title 14 (§ 89, subd [a]) of the United States Code, which empowers the Coast Guard to make warrantless safety and document inspections of a vessel so long as there is some articulable basis for that inspection, is constitutional since the warrantless boarding of a vessel entering United States waters to ensure compliance with customs laws, safety standards and antismuggling statutes is reasonable in view of the mobility of a vessel, the public interest in its contents when moving from foreign waters into United States jurisdictional waters and the interests of safe navigation; accordingly,  [***3] observations by the Coast Guard that defendants' large sailboat was moving under power and sail at night without green starboard or masthead lights and with an extremely dim stern light, coupled with the fact that the vessel was "riding heavy" in the water, justified the warrantless boarding and once on board, the discovery of the strong odor typical of marihuana and the observations of the contraband in "plain view" justified the seizure and arrest.

Crimes -- Warrantless Customs Search of Vessel

3. A customs search of a vessel (US Code, tit 19, § 1581, subd [a]) which has made a foreign entry need not be based upon "reasonable or articulated suspicion that criminal activity is involved", rather, the customs search is permissible so long as the search is at a border or its functional equivalent and there is some suspicion or reasonable belief that the vessel has entered from foreign waters; accordingly, even if the safety stop and document check of defendants' vessel by the Coast Guard (US Code, tit 14, § 89, subd [a]) was merely a pretext to board the vessel and search for contraband, the direction of movement and the registry of the vessel supplied a reasonable [***4] basis for the belief that the vessel had come from foreign waters and passed across a functional border into the jurisdictional waters of the United States and thus no pretext was necessary for a customs search of the vessel's cargo.

Crimes -- Possession of Marihuana -- Presumption of Validity of Statute

4. Section 221.30 of the Penal Law, which makes possession of more than 10 pounds of marihuana a class C felony carrying a maximum prison term of 15 years, does not unconstitutionally violate the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment; defendants have failed to rebut the strong presumption of validity which attaches to all legislation.

 

2150 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lugo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


98 Misc. 2d 115; 414 N.Y.S.2d 243; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2052



January 25, 1979 



DISPOSITION: Therefore,  [***2] the motion is denied in all respects and defendant is ordered held for the Grand Jury.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for removal of his armed felony case in the interests of justice.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and charged with robbery in the second. A preliminary hearing was held and at the conclusion thereof this court found that there was reasonable cause to believe that defendant committed the crime of robbery in the second degree while displaying an imitation. Immediately thereafter, defendant renewed its motion for removal of the case in the interests of justice to the Family Court. The prosecutor stated that the district attorney would not consent to removal of this armed felony and that, therefore, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75, the court had no authority to remove the case and no discretion to make an inquiry respecting removal. This court denied defendant's motion in all respects. This court held that that the statute in question did deny defendant due process of law and/or deprive him of the equal protection of the law.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion for removal in the interests of justice was denied in all respects.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Violent Juvenile Offender -- Removal to Family Court on Consent of Prosecutor

1. CPL 180.75 (subd 4, par [b]), which denies a juvenile offender charged with an armed felony the right to have the criminal action removed from the criminal court to the Family Court "in the interests of justice" unless the District Attorney consents to removal, is not violative of due process or equal protection since juvenile offenders are afforded the full panoply of due process rights possessed by adult criminal defendants and can only be incarcerated in separated facilities that provide special "services" to juvenile offenders ( CPL 510.15; Executive Law, § 515-b); a decision of the United States Supreme Court holding that the judicial determination as to whether a juvenile shall be charged and adjudicated in juvenile court or in the adult system is a "critical stage" in the proceedings entitling the juvenile to due process protection where the right to be treated as a juvenile is granted by statute (see Kent v United States, 383 U.S. 541) is inapplicable to New York's statutory scheme [***3] under which the determination of original jurisdiction is a legislative rather than a judicial one and, since there is no constitutional right to juvenile treatment, the removal provisions are a matter of legislative grace and, thus, an "in the interests of justice" judicial removal is not constitutionally mandated; a decision of the Court of Appeals invalidating a statute making youthful offender treatment after conviction dependent upon the seriousness of the crime originally charged rather than on the crime for which the juvenile was convicted (see People v Drummond, 40 NY2d 990) is likewise inapplicable since the juvenile offender, although initially charged with an armed felony, is not forever foreclosed from having his case removed to the Family Court and being treated as a juvenile and, thus, "mere allegations" cannot determine whether the juvenile will ultimately be placed under the jurisdiction of the juvenile court.

Crimes -- Violent Juvenile Offender -- Removal to Family Court on Consent of Prosecutor

2. The prosecutor's power to condition removal of an "armed felony" charge against a juvenile offender from the criminal court to the Family Court on his consent [***4] ( CPL 180.75, subd 4, par [b]) does not constitute an infringement upon and a usurpation of the court's power to hold an "in the interests of justice" removal hearing where the defendant is charged with an armed felony since the prosecutor possesses the discretionary power to determine whether an offender should be prosecuted as a juvenile or as an adult and, thus, the prosecutor's power to deprive the juvenile court of jurisdiction in the first instance through the use of his charging discretion without holding a hearing is consonant with due process; the consent decision is but another of the prosecutor's widely recognized powers and need not be preceded by a hearing.

Crimes -- Violent Juvenile Offender -- Removal to Family Court on Consent of Prosecutor

3. Since the removal provision of CPL 180.75 (subd 4, par [b]), which denies a juvenile offender charged with an "armed felony" the right to have his case removed from the criminal court to the Family Court "in the interests of justice" without the consent of the District Attorney, is not a "fundamental interest" for equal protection purposes, the defendant only being deprived of his liberty if found guilty of a crime [***5] for which he is criminally responsible, and removal is a privilege and a matter of legislative grace in any event, the standard of reviewing the constitutionality of the statute under the equal protection clause is the "rational relationship" rather than the "strict scrutiny" test and since the rationale behind the legislative action in distinguishing crimes involving both operable and inoperable guns from crimes involving other types of weapons is reasonable and appropriate, reflecting the rational belief that armed felonies are inherently more threatening to society and, accordingly, require a more significant response, the statute, which carries the strong presumption that the Legislature has found facts indicating a need for the enactment, is constitutional; because of "overcharging" by prosecutors, the Legislature should study the new law more thoroughly and amend it so as to insure that only those who commit truly serious crimes are initially treated as adults in the criminal courts.

 

2151 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Overton v. Director of Cent. New York Psychiatric Center


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oneida County


99 Misc. 2d 1116; 418 N.Y.S.2d 254; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2405



January 25, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate filed an application for a writ of habeas corpus pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 70, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(9), which provided an emergency procedure for a temporary administrative transfer of mentally ill prisoners from a correctional facility to a psychiatric center without prior judicial determination of such mental illness.


OVERVIEW: While the inmate was a resident of a correctional facility the facility's superintendent applied for the inmate's readmission to a psychiatric hospital on an emergency basis pursuant to the newly enacted N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(9). After the inmate was transferred, the superintendent immediately commenced a N.Y. Correct. Law § 402 proceeding to make to judicial determination of mental illness. Thereafter, the inmate applied for a writ of habeas corpus under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 70, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(9). The court held that where immediate action was necessary for the protection of others, be they fellow inmates or correction officers, or for the welfare of the allegedly mentally ill inmate himself, due process did not require notice or hearing as a condition precedent to valid temporary transfer of the inmate to a psychiatric hospital. However, the inmate had to be afforded substantially the same procedural safeguards as those afforded in civil commitment proceedings. An inmate, unlike a citizen, was not deprived of his freedom in a significant way by transfer to a hospital. Accordingly, § 402(9) did not violate due process guarantees.


OUTCOME: The court denied the inmate's application for release from the psychiatric hospital and dismissed his petition.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Prisons and Prisoners -- Transfer of Inmate from Correctional to Mental Health Facility

1. The transfer of an inmate of a correctional facility to the Central New York Psychiatric Center on an emergency basis without prior judicial determination of mental illness pursuant to subdivision 9 of section 402 of the Correction Law is not a deprivation of the inmate's due process rights, as the procedural safeguards of a judicial determination shall be commenced upon the inmate's delivery to the hospital, and the Legislature can constitutionally provide for such emergency transfers which are necessary for the protection of the inmate or those with whom he interacts and due process does not require notice or a hearing as a condition precedent to such an emergency, temporary transfer.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Transfer of Inmate from Correctional to Mental Health Facility

2. An inmate of a correctional facility must be afforded substantially the same procedural safeguards as those afforded in civil commitment proceedings when he is transferred to the Central New York Psychiatric Center, and since an emergency civil commitment does not require prior judicial scrutiny (see [***2] Mental Hygiene Law, § 9.39), the procedure prescribed in subdivision 9 of section 402 of the Correction Law permitting an inmate transfer based on the recommendations of two examining physicians, is a valid means of rendering immediate necessary treatment for the protection of the inmate and those around him, especially since he is not deprived of his freedom in a significant way by transfer to a hospital, and such a procedure is not inconsistent with subdivision 1 of section 402 of the Correction Law.

 

2152 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rosello


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


97 Misc. 2d 963; 412 N.Y.S.2d 975; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2024



January 24, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of the crime of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, a class D felony. The district attorney requested that defendant be sentenced as a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.20.


OVERVIEW: Defendant opposed being sentenced as a persistent felon. He claimed that one of his previous convictions was constitutionally infirm. However, the court found that defendant offered no evidence that defeated the presumption of regularity or that upheld a claim of deprivation of due process. The court held that the requirement of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10(1), that a persistent felony offender was a person who stood convicted of a felony after having been previously convicted of two or more felonies, and the requirement of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.20(6) that the convictions were constitutionally obtained, had been satisfied. The court also found that defendant's history and character warranted the conclusion that he was a confirmed criminal and that an extended incarceration and lifetime supervision of defendant was in the public's best interest. The court rejected defendant's contention that § 400.20 was unconstitutional and determined that defendant's due process rights were not violated. Because there was no question that by legally sufficient proof beyond a reasonable doubt defendant was a persistent felony the court sentenced him accordingly.


OUTCOME: The court sentenced defendant in accordance with its finding that he was a persistent felony offender within the statutory meaning.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Persistent Felony Offender -- Constitutionality of Prior Felony Conviction

1. Two prior felony convictions, including a 1960 conviction when defendant was 17 years old and thus eligible for youthful offender treatment, coupled with defendant's long history of violent criminal behavior, authorize sentencing him as a persistent felony offender to extended incarceration and lifetime supervision (Penal Law, § 70.10); the fact that defendant was eligible for, but did not receive youthful offender treatment, does not render his 1960 felony conviction constitutionally infirm ( CPL 400.20) since mere eligibility for youthful offender treatment does not mandate that it be given, and, in the absence of any evidence sufficient to overcome the presumption of regularity in court proceedings, a lack of adequate representation by counsel or a lack of due process based on a silent record cannot be assumed; since defendant had received youthful offender treatment in 1958 after a conviction for assault and possession of a weapon, it is as reasonable to suppose that this was in the sentencing Judge's mind as it is to surmise that the Judge did not consider the possibility of sentencing [***2] defendant as a youthful offender.

Crimes -- Persistent Felony Offender -- Hearing

2. CPL 400.20, which provides for a separate hearing before a defendant may be sentenced as a persistent felony offender (Penal Law, § 70.10), on its face, complies with procedural due process requirements by affording a defendant an opportunity to be heard, to be confronted with witnesses against him and the right to cross-examine and offer evidence of his own (see Specht v Patterson, 386 U.S. 605); accordingly, whether the proper constitutional standard of proof of a defendant's history and criminal character under a recidivist statute should be "clear, unequivocal and convincing evidence" or a "preponderance of the evidence" as required by CPL 400.20, defendant's previous felony convictions, indicating a 20-year involvement with violence and weapons, justify sentencing him as a persistent felony offender to extended incarceration and lifetime supervision and the fact that 20-year-old convictions were considered in determining defendant's history and criminal character does not violate due process since it is defendant's long and unbroken history of violence that forms the basis of [***3] the persistent felony offender finding.

 

2153 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Builders' Council of Suburban New York, Inc. v. Yonkers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


106 Misc. 2d 700; 434 N.Y.S.2d 566; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2966



January 19, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the City of Yonkers (New York) and related entities, filed a motion for summary judgment against plaintiff landlords' association in the suit for a declaratory judgment that Yonkers, N.Y., Local Law 3-1978, which governed the collection of money from landlords, was unconstitutional. The landlords' association also filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance created a commission to collect money from rent and to hold it for emergency situations involving rental units. If payment was not made, an application was made to a city court for the appointment of a receiver. The court granted the motion for summary judgment by the landlords' association. The court held that the ordinance was unconstitutional in part because it conflicted with state law. N.Y. Real Prop. Acts Law § 769 created a proceeding for emergency situations of tenants. Thus, the local ordinance was preempted. Further, the appointment of receivers was beyond the jurisdiction of a city court because such appointments were prohibited by the Uniformed City Court Act. Moreover, the ordinance allowed the commission to designate representatives without qualification, which was the unconstitutional delegation of legislative power to a private party. Further still, the ordinance violated due process by giving the commission the power to appoint a receiver without notice and a hearing. Finally, the law created a type of strict liability by assuming that a landlord was a violator before he even collected rent.


OUTCOME: The motion for summary judgment by the landlords' association was granted. The motion by the City was denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Local Laws -- Pre-emption by State Law

Local Law 3-1978 of the City of Yonkers, creating a multiple dwelling commission empowered to collect money from multiple dwelling owners and to hold that money in case an emergency condition arises in the future is unconstitutional in violation of article IX (§ 2, subd [c]) of the New York Constitution, which prohibits a municipality from enacting legislation which is inconsistent with State legislation, and such legislation has in fact been enacted in the form of article 7-A of the Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law, which provides for a special proceeding by tenants of multiple dwellings directing the deposit of rents into court to be used to remedy conditions dangerous to life, health or safety. Aside from being pre-empted, the statute unconstitutionally permits an abdication of legislative power to a private party in that no qualifications are specified for the designees of the commission who are to carry out the duties of inspection; the provision for the appointment of receivers by the city court imposes an obligation beyond the court's jurisdiction, and, further, the local law denies to owners their right to procedural [***2] due process by determining the amount due without affording the owner an opportunity to be heard.

 

2154 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Len's Amoco, Inc. v. Gates


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


97 Misc. 2d 900; 412 N.Y.S.2d 770; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2017



January 16, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] It is the court's opinion that the plaintiffs have proved the unconstitutionality of the ordinance beyond a reasonable doubt, and the plaintiffs' request for a permanent injunction against the two-attendant rule is hereby granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff proprietors filed an action against defendants, a town, its town board, and others, seeking a declaration to declare unconstitutional a two-attendant ordinance that was passed by the board and seeking a permanent injunction to enjoin defendants from enforcing said ordinance. Defendants had passed an ordinance requiring two attendants to be on duty at self-service stations during working hours.


OVERVIEW: A city's town board passed an ordinance that required two attendants to be on duty at self-service gas stations. The "primary" function of one of the attendants was to supervise, to observe, and to control the dispensing of gasoline. Certain proprietors sought a declaration that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it was passed illegally, it was an unreasonable regulation passed for improper reasons, and it deprived them of property without due process of law, and sought to enjoin its enforcement. The court held that: (1) the colloquy between the town board and a person, who attended a public hearing before the ordinance was passed and who had spoken in favor of the ordinance, was merely an informal and an un-scheduled discussion, and thus no notice was required to be afforded to the proprietors as to when such discussion would resume; (2) the ordinance, which had fire prevention and fire safety as its purpose, was within the powers delegated to the town board under N.Y. Town Law § 130(15) because it was passed to promote the "public welfare;" and (3) the ordinance was unreasonable because the "manifest evil" apprehended by the town board was not warranted.


OUTCOME: The court declared the ordinance to be unconstitutional and granted the proprietors' request for a permanent injunction.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Notice of Public Hearing

1. Where a town board, at a public hearing, tabled the discussion of an ordinance which plaintiffs opposed, and permitted a person to speak out in favor of the ordinance at a later meeting, this was merely an informal and unscheduled discussion and no notice was required to be afforded the plaintiffs; although the wisdom of this practice by the board is questionable, it would not be sufficient, standing alone, to invalidate the subsequent passage of the ordinance.

Municipal Corporations -- Ordinances

2. A validly passed legislative enactment is presumed constitutional and this presumption can only be rebutted by proof of unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt, but, to withstand judicial scrutiny, a municipality's ordinance must be within the ambit of the powers delegated by the Legislature to promote the public welfare, which include the health, safety, morals or general welfare [***2] of the community (Town Law, § 130, subd 15), and must not be arbitrary; rather, it must be reasonably related to some manifest evil which, however, need only be reasonably apprehended. Accordingly, although an ordinance which has fire prevention and fire safety as its purpose is clearly within this broad legislative grant, a town ordinance which requires two attendants to be on duty at self-service gasoline stations during working hours is unconstitutional where no danger has been demonstrated and there has been no showing of how a second attendant would accomplish the desired ends, since, while a municipality need not wait until a disaster occurs before curing a dangerous condition, the exercise of police power should not be extended beyond the evil sought to be curbed.

 

2155 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


North Hempstead v. Exxon Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


98 Misc. 2d 194; 413 N.Y.S.2d 562; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2065



January 16, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Any motions not otherwise specifically decided herein are deemed denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff town filed an action to enjoin defendant corporation's operation of self-service gas stations, and the corporation filed an action to enjoin the enforcement of the town's law prohibiting self-service stations.


OVERVIEW: The town enacted a law prohibiting the operation of self-service gas stations within its unincorporated limits. Prior to the enactment, the corporation operated such stations within the town limits. The court granted the town an injunction. The court found that the legislative thrust was to deem customer handling of gasoline so potentially dangerous as to warrant statutory prohibition of the self-service form of sale. The court determined that the record contained ample testimony and other proof that self-service dispensing incorporated those devices, systems, and mechanisms, both required and optionally added, sufficient to safeguard the user from the obvious perils which could arise from both the normal filling procedure and detected misuse. The court also determined, however, that it was precisely because of human and mechanical imperfection that public protection had been imposed. The court concluded that the balance of considerations favoring the protective local law was not outweighed by the corporation's case, and the local law was a proper exercise of the town's police power and constitutionally valid.


OUTCOME: The court granted the town an injunction to prevent the corporation's operation of self-service gas stations.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Self-Service Dispensing of Gasoline

1. Section 328-a of the General Business Law, which requires the presence of an attendant where gasoline is sold from coin-operated dispensers, may not be equated with or imply recognition by the State of self-service sales of gasoline so that the State's municipalities remain free to legislate upon the subject of self-service dispensing of gasoline pursuant to power granted them by the State ( Town Law, § 130, subd 5) within the permissible limits of constitutional criteria that the legislative intrusion upon private interests in the name of public interest not be arbitrary or oppressive and that the means of accomplishment be reasonably necessary to the legislative objective; the two tests to be applied when the question of legislative interference arises are whether there is a real evil, reasonably to be anticipated and to be guarded against and whether there is a reasonable relation between the evil and the proposed remedy.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Self-Service Dispensing of Gasoline

2. The exercise [***2] of police power is to be upheld if any state of facts, known or reasonably to be assumed, affords support for it and it is unnecessary that the legislative body have actual knowledge of the incidence of danger or that it defer enactment until faced with the actuality of injury to its citizens, rather, it is entitled to act upon reasonable apprehension of danger; accordingly, a local law enacted by the Town of North Hempstead, which prohibits the operation of self-service gasoline stations, is a proper exercise of the police power and constitutionally valid even though defendant oil companies have presented adequate evidence to raise debate concerning the presence of danger in the self-service dispensing of gasoline since such evidence merely questions the wisdom or appropriateness of banning self-service gasoline dispensing but fails to rebut the strong presumption of constitutionality carried by legislative enactments and the concomitant presumption that the legislation is supported by necessary factual support; it is not the province of the court, absent arbitrariness, to countermand the underlying justification of the enactment and interpose its own policy determination in place [***3] of the legislative judgment to limit the handling of an innately dangerous commodity to fewer and more skilled hands.

 

2156 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Trotman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Kingston, Ulster County


98 Misc. 2d 340; 413 N.Y.S.2d 829; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2077



January 16, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion seeking a declaration that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(7) was unconstitutional as depriving them of a jury trial.


OVERVIEW: Section 340.40(7) required a single judge nonjury trial for a defendant who was accorded mandatory youthful offender status in a local criminal court proceeding. However, a discretionary youthful offender was entitled to a jury trial and could be sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment up to four years. Defendants, who were accorded mandatory youthful offender status, sought a declaration that § 340.40(7) was unconstitutional because it deprived them of a jury trial unless they waived the right to benefits conferred by mandatory youthful offender treatment and on equal protection grounds. The court found that § 340.40(7) had to be read in conjunction with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.20(1)(b) and N.Y. Penal Law § 60.02(b), which limited the period of incarceration after a mandatory youthful offender adjudication to six months. The court ruled that the classification with respect to jury trials in mandatory and discretionary youthful offender cases was valid because it complied with the principle that offenses punishable by up to six months incarceration were not within the ambit of the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of a jury trial in criminal cases.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion for a declaration that the state statute was unconstitutional on the ground that it deprived them of a jury trial.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- Youthful Offenders -- Nonjury Trial

1. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which requires nonjury trial by a single Judge for a defendant who is accorded mandatory youthful offender status in a local criminal court proceeding, does not violate the defendant's right to a jury trial in all criminal cases since the maximum period of incarceration after a mandatory youthful offender adjudication is six months (Penal Law, § 60.02, subd [b]), which limitation fully complies with the pronouncement of the United States Supreme Court in Baldwin v New York (399 U.S. 66), wherein it was held that offenses punishable by a maximum of six months' imprisonment were "petty" and thus did not fall within the ambit of the guarantee of a jury trial in all criminal cases under the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution; the fact that defendants may be placed on probation for a term longer than six months does not change this, since traditionally probation can be and often is of a longer duration than the prescribed period of incarceration for the crime, and the sentencing Judge is limited to six months' incarceration of the mandatory youthful offender whether the sentence is meted [***2] out directly after conviction or plea of guilty or after a violation of the terms of probation.

Infants -- Youthful Offenders -- Equal Protection of Laws

2. The difference in the type of trial and the sentence afforded a mandatory and discretionary youthful offender is a valid classification by the Legislature which denies the mandatory youthful offender a jury trial but gives him a "first chance" before a single Judge with a six-month limitation on the sentence that Judge may impose, which sentence limitation is not afforded to a discretionary youthful offender who is permitted a jury trial. Accordingly, these differences do not violate the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution.

 

2157 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Paperno


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 99; 413 N.Y.S.2d 975; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2049



January 15, 1979 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the motion to dismiss the indictment is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss his eight-count indictment for criminal contempt in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 215.51 (1970). Defendant alleged that § 215.51 was not directed at contempt of the evasive sort and that the statute, as applied to evasive contempt, was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was called to testify, under immunity, before a grand jury that was investigating allegations of official misconduct. Defendant gave evasive, equivocal, conspicuously unbelievable, and patently false testimony in three appearances before the grand jury. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment, finding that § 215.51 could properly be applied to such evasive answers. The court found that the statute was neither vague nor unconstitutional, noting that, in addition to the plain meaning of the statute, defendant received actual notice of his rights and duties as a witness and that he was further advised that his immunity did not extend to prosecution for perjury or contempt. The court also found that defendant acted willfully and that his intentional refusal to give responsive answers had a foreseeable obstructive effect on the grand jury process. Finally, the court held that the prosecutor did not abuse his discretion by electing to proceed by way of indictment for criminal contempt rather than choosing a lesser remedy.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment for criminal contempt.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Criminal Contempt -- Evasive Contempt

1. The criminal contempt statute (Penal Law, § 215.51), which provides that a "person is guilty of criminal contempt in the first degree * * * when after having been sworn as a witness before a grand jury, he refuses to answer any legal and proper interrogatory", is constitutionally specific, provides fair notice and intelligible standards as applied to evasive contempt by an immunized Grand Jury witness who gives evasive testimony that is either patently frivolous or "so plainly inconsistent, so manifestly contradictory and so conspicuously unbelievable" as to make it apparent that the witness has deliberately concealed the truth and has given answers which are replies in form only; the responses alleged to be evasive must be examined in light of the questions asked, so that the witness is not held criminally liable for his interrogator's imprecision or confusion and the questions must be relevant to the scope of the Grand Jury's investigation and "free from ambiguity" and so plain as to call either for a direct answer or a refusal [***2] to answer on grounds of privilege; the mens rea element of testimonial criminal contempt is the intentional violation of the duty to answer and no proof is required of a specific intent to obstruct justice, the witness who refuses to testify without articulating a reason or asserting a legal basis for refusing to answer being assumed to have acted deliberately and not out of misapprehension of his legal rights.

Crimes -- Criminal Contempt -- Evasive Contempt

2. The prosecutor did not abuse his discretion by electing to proceed against a Grand Jury witness who gave evasive testimony by way of indictment for criminal contempt (Penal Law, § 215.51) rather than by pursuing the less "drastic alternative" of a summary proceeding for contempt (Judiciary Law, § 750) since the two contempt procedures serve different purposes; summary criminal contempt serves to vindicate the authority of an individual court whereas the crime of criminal contempt serves to vindicate the public's interest in the administration of justice generally, public justice being particularly vulnerable to frustration by witnesses who intentionally conceal evidence of wrongdoing; there is no constitutional [***3] impediment to a legislative scheme that allows the prosecutor to pursue alternative remedies for the same wrongful conduct.

 

2158 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Waskiewicz v. Waskiewicz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Oneida County


98 Misc. 2d 144; 413 N.Y.S.2d 560; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2055



January 10, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent mother filed a motion for an award of counsel fees after petitioner father's application for an award of custody of two of the parties' children was denied.


OVERVIEW: The mother and the father were divorced and each received custody of two of their children. The divorce decree provided that the family court would have exclusive jurisdiction over the issue of custody of the parties' four children. The father filed an application for custody of all four children. The father's application was denied. The mother thereafter filed a motion for an award of counsel fees. The court granted the mother's motion but ordered her attorney to submit an affidavit detailing his services. N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 652, which conferred upon the family court jurisdiction to determine custody issues, and N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 237(b), which allowed an award of counsel fees during a custody proceeding, taken together clearly indicated that the family court had jurisdiction not only to pass on the issue of custody but also to award counsel fees. The statutory basis for awarding such fees under § 237(b) was applicable whether the proceeding was in the supreme court or in the family court.


OUTCOME: The court held that the mother's request for counsel fees was reasonable after the father's application for an award of custody was denied. The mother's attorney was required to submit an affidavit detailing his services, such that an amount could be set.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Custody -- Counsel Fees

The Family Court has the power to order a father to pay counsel fees to the attorney for the mother in a proceeding to modify custody provisions of a divorce decree where that decree confers exclusive jurisdiction on Family Court as to all future questions of custody, support and visitation of the children of the marriage, since section 652 of the Family Court Act, pursuant to which the proceeding should have been brought, confers upon the Family Court the same powers as possessed by the Supreme Court in a proceeding to modify custody provisions of a divorce decree, and subdivision (b) of section 237 of the Domestic Relations Law provides for the award of counsel fees in applications to modify a judgment of custody.

 

2159 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pitrowski v. Pitrowski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


97 Misc. 2d 755; 412 N.Y.S.2d 316; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1998



January 5, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant ex-wife filed a motion to dismiss a portion of plaintiff ex-husband's complaint, which sought custody of their infant children, for lack of jurisdiction or, in the alternative, on the grounds of forum non conveniens.


OVERVIEW: The parties were married and resided in the state. After the parties entered into a separation agreement, which provided that the ex-wife would have custody of the children and that the ex-husband would have visitation, the ex-wife and the children moved to another state. The ex-husband filed an action for divorce and the ex-wife appeared for the limited purpose of challenging the jurisdiction over her on the issue of custody. The court granted the ex-wife's motion to dismiss the portion of the complaint that sought custody of the children. The court held that under case law in existence prior to the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (Act), N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 75-1 et seq., the court lacked jurisdiction over the ex-wife. The ex-wife was not domiciled in the state as required by N.Y.C.P.L.R. § 313 and N.Y.C.P.L.R. § 302 was not applicable because the ex-wife was not a resident of the state at the beginning of the divorce action. The court held that it did not have jurisdiction over the ex-wife under the Act because there was no clear expression of legislative intent for the statute to have retroactive effect.


OUTCOME: The court granted the ex-wife's motion to dismiss the portion of the ex-husband's complaint that sought a judgment regarding custody of their children.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Personal Jurisdiction over Nonresident Defendant Wife

1. In an action for divorce commenced prior to September 1, 1978, the effective date of the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act ( Domestic Relations Law, § 75-a et seq.), in which the plaintiff husband seeks custody of the children of the marriage, defendant wife's motion to dismiss that portion of the complaint is granted where she had custody of the children pursuant to a separation agreement executed by the parties, removed the children to Minnesota and was served personally with process in that State, since the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act may not be retroactively applied to an action commenced prior to its effective date, and there is no common-law jurisdiction to make an initial determination respecting custody inasmuch as the children were not within the State and the court did not have personal jurisdiction over the nonresident defendant; there is no personal jurisdiction over defendant under CPLR 313, which provides that out-of-State service of process gives the court personal jurisdiction over a domiciliary or a person subject to jurisdiction under CPLR 301 or 302,  [***2] since she was a nondomiciliary and thus was not subject to jurisdiction under CPLR 301, and neither was she subject to jurisdiction under CPLR 302 (subd [b]), which provides that in a matrimonial action involving a demand for support or alimony a court may exercise personal jurisdiction over the nondomiciliary defendant if the party seeking support is a resident when the demand is made and New York was the matrimonial domicile of the parties before their separation, since in New York a husband cannot be the party seeking support because New York law prohibits the award of alimony or support to a husband ( Domestic Relations Law, § 236).

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Child Custody Jurisdiction

2. In an action for divorce commenced prior to September 1, 1978, the effective date of the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act ( Domestic Relations Law, § 75-a et seq.), in which the husband seeks custody of the children of the marriage, defendant wife's motion to dismiss that portion of the complaint seeking custody is granted where the defendant had custody of the children pursuant to a separation agreement executed by the parties, removed the children to Minnesota and [***3] was served with process personally in that State, since there is no common-law jurisdiction to make an initial determination respecting custody because the children were not present in New York and there is no personal jurisdiction over defendant, and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, which would give the court jurisdiction over the question of custody, and provides that a court may make a determination as to child custody when New York has been the child's home within six months before commencement of the action, the child is absent from the State due to removal by a person claiming custody, and a parent continues to live in this State ( Domestic Relations Law, § 75-d, subd 1, par [a], cl [ii]), may not be retroactively applied to an action commenced prior to its effective date and does not operate by relation back to confer upon the court jurisdiction it did not possess at the time of the commencement of the action; although procedural statutes are generally to be afforded a retroactive effect, a movant may not apply procedural changes embodied in the statute to actions previously taken in the proceeding unless language evidencing a clear legislative intent to do so [***4] is present in the statute, and such language is not present in the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act.

 

2160 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. J. W. Productions


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 67; 413 N.Y.S.2d 552; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2043; 4 Media L. Rep. 2235



January 5, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a consolidated motion to dismiss the criminal complaints against them for operating a motion picture theatre without the required license.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with operating a motion picture theatre without the required license in violation of the movie licensing statute (the statute), New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-24.0 et seq. Defendants filed a consolidated motion to dismiss the criminal complaints alleging the unconstitutionality of the statute. The court granted the motion and dismissed the complaints holding that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-26.0 was unconstitutional on its face. The court further held that § B32-26.0, which required the denial of a movie-operating license upon the applicant's conviction of certain enumerated offenses, was unconstitutionally overbroad. The court also held that the statute, by the mandates of § B32-26.0, interfered with defendants' freedom of speech rights. Finally, the court held that there was no reasonable relation between the qualifications of an applicant to operate a movie theatre and any past conviction of any of the crimes listed in § B32-26.0.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' consolidated motion to dismiss the criminal complaints against them for operating a motion picture theatre without the required license.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Standing to Challenge Movie Licensing Statute

1. Operators of motion picture theatres need not apply for an operating license in order to have standing to challenge the constitutionality of a movie licensing statute (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-24.0 et seq.) since they will sustain a direct and immediate injury as a result of the enforcement of the statute and a person [***2] being criminally prosecuted or threatened with such prosecution is not required to show that his own conduct could not be regulated by a narrow construction of the statute under attack nor is such person required to demonstrate that the statute's deterrent effect on legitimate expression is both real and substantial.

Constitutional Law -- Movie Licensing Statute -- Vagueness

2. A movie licensing statute (Administrative Code, § B32-24.0 et seq.), which clearly and precisely delineates the regulated activity, the method and procedure for obtaining a license and the specific grounds upon which a license may be denied, is not unconstitutionally vague on its face since a citizen who operates within the ambit of the statute should reasonably understand that his contemplated conduct is proscribed.

Constitutional Law -- Movie Licensing Statute -- Infringement upon First Amendment Freedoms

3. A movie licensing statute (Administrative Code, § B32-24.0 et seq.), which places inordinate emphasis on prior criminal convictions for sex and other enumerated crimes in the issuance, renewal and revocation of licenses to operate movie theatres, unconstitutionally infringes [***3] upon First Amendment freedoms, there being no reasonable relation between the qualifications of an applicant to operate a movie theatre and any past criminal convictions, which may not, as a matter of law, have any bearing on the ability of a license applicant to operate a movie theatre; participants in the constitutionally protected business of distributing and displaying motion pictures require no special expertise unlike doctors, lawyers or school teachers whose past criminal convictions are often directly related to their occupational qualifications and may therefore reasonably be invoked to bar them from practicing their professions and preventing persons convicted of crimes from operating movie theatres serves neither the interests of public health and safety nor the maintenance of integrity, honesty and fair dealing; in addition, the requirement that the license applicant furnish financial information and records concerning the source of funds used in the operation of the business goes far beyond what is reasonable to determine whether the applicant is financially responsible.

 

2161 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re A.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


97 Misc. 2d 670; 412 N.Y.S.2d 96; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1991



January 4, 1979 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant juvenile admitted to charges that he committed acts that, if done by an adult, would constitute the crime of assault in the third degree, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 120.00. Prior to a dispositional hearing, the amendment to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 756(b) (1978) became effective, and its application to defendant's case was presented for determination.


OVERVIEW: A petition was filed in the family court alleging that defendant committed acts, which, if done by an adult, constituted assault in the third degree, under § 120.00. A finding of fact was made on defendant's admission to such acts, a misdemeanor, and the matter was transferred for a dispositional hearing. Prior to the hearing, N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 756 (1978), as amended, which provided for a maximum initial placement of one year for misdemeanor acts, became effective. The court held that: (1) under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 752, an adjudication of delinquency could only be made at the dispositional hearing when there was a judicial determination that all the allegations had been established; (2) the limitations on placement for a misdemeanor act under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 756 (1978) applied to defendant because the actual adjudication occurred after the amendment's effective date; and (3) § 756(a), which allowed the family court to authorize a direct placement of defendant in a secure facility without an additional administrative hearing by the division for youth during the first 60 days of placement, applied, although the acts admitted occurred before its effective date.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the applicable statutory amendment applied to defendant, who was found to be in need of supervision.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Placement

1. Subdivision (b) of section 756 of the Family Court Act, as amended, which reduces to one year the maximum initial placement of a juvenile who has been found to have committed an act which, if done by an adult, would be a misdemeanor, applies to a case where the actual adjudication of juvenile delinquency occurred after September 1, 1978, the effective date of the amendment, although the act alleged and admitted to by the juvenile occurred prior to that date, since the statute applies after an adjudication of delinquency, which may only be made at the dispositional hearing when there is a judicial determination that all of the allegations of the petition, as mandated by section 731 of the Family Court Act, have been established (Family Ct Act, § 752).

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Placement

2. Section 756 (subd [a], par [iii], cl [1]) of the Family Court Act, as amended, which permits direct placement of an adjudicated juvenile delinquent by the Family Court in a secure facility without a further Division for Youth hearing during the first 60 days of placement, is applicable where the act alleged and admitted [***2] to by the juvenile occurred prior to September 1, 1978, the effective date of the amendment, but the adjudication of delinquency was made after that date. Although prior law did not permit direct and immediate placement in a secure facility (except on an emergency basis), unless the act committed was a designated felony and a disposition for restrictive placement was made, without a separate hearing before a Division for Youth Hearing Examiner within seven business days of the placement, the amendment does not have an unconstitutional ex post facto effect, since the Legislature has merely provided the additional forum of the Family Court to avoid duplication of efforts by the court and the hearing officer, without changing the standards or increasing the punishment; the amendment does not take away the right to a direct admission hearing, nor does it take the ultimate decision on whether the juvenile should be sent initially to a secure facility from the Division for Youth, since the court's order pursuant to section 756 does not mandate that the division follow such authorized order.
