2162 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Phillips


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


97 Misc. 2d 665; 412 N.Y.S.2d 94; 1979 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1990



January 3, 1979 



DISPOSITION: For all the foregoing reasons the motion is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion to vacate his judgment of conviction on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder, which had been upheld on appeal, based on an alleged prior grants of transactional and use immunity by a United States Attorney.


OVERVIEW: The defendant asserted that he had been granted transactional and use immunity by a U.S. Attorney in return for his testimony before the Knapp Commission on police corruption. He claimed that the entire prosecution was barred under transactional immunity as a product of his commission testimony, and under use immunity because the prosecution improperly used evidence obtained as a result of his testimony. Defendant offered an affidavit from a counsel to the commission stating that he assured defendant that immunity would be granted, but not from the attorney who allegedly granted it. The court denied defendant's motion. The court doubted that immunity had in fact been granted, in light of the fact that it hadn't been raised previously, but held that in any event, immunity was a defense N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(d) which must be made prior to trial, and if not timely raised, may be denied summarily.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to vacate his judgment of conviction on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder, which had been upheld on appeal, based on alleged prior grants of transactional and use immunity by a United States Attorney.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Immunity from Prosecution -- Federal Immunity

1. Although a grant of immunity by Federal authorities is binding upon the States, the latter cannot be bound to give any greater degree of immunity than the Federal authorities themselves can give. Accordingly, a defendant's claim of immunity from State prosecution based upon an [***2] alleged grant of transactional immunity by a United States Attorney must be rejected where the Federal immunity statute in effect at the time of the supposed agreement permitted a United States Attorney to grant only use or testimonial immunity, not transactional immunity (US Code, tit 18, §§ 6002, 6003); nor is anything more required by the United States Constitution.

Crimes -- Immunity from Prosecution -- Untimeliness

2. Timeliness in attack on indictments or suppression of evidence is essential to the orderly administration of justice, and a claim of transactional or testimonial immunity must be timely made since there is no sound reason or policy which indicates that a belated claim of immunity, raised after the conviction has been affirmed on appeal, although it could have been raised at the outset of the prosecution, should be treated differently than other claims where the failure to assert constitutional privileges and rights in a timely fashion precludes subsequent challenges.

Witnesses -- Impeachment -- Admissibility of Unconstitutionally Obtained Tape Recording

3. A tape recording that is used to impeach a defendant's testimony when he takes the stand [***3] and identifies it as being his voice is admissible for impeachment purposes, even if it was obtained by the prosecution through unconstitutional means, on the theory that constitutional rights should not be used to protect a defendant from the consequences of blatant perjury.

 

2163 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Slewett & Farber v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


97 Misc. 2d 637; 412 N.Y.S.2d 292; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2847



December 29, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The branch of the motion requesting renewal is granted, and upon consideration of the additional facts presented, is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Board of Assessors and Board of Assessment Review of Nassau County (county) sought reargument and rehearing of the court's determination that granted petitioner taxpayers' motions for partial summary judgment in proceedings to review assessments levied against real property, and directed the ratio to be applied at the trial for the tax years at issue as those promulgated by the New York State Board of Equalization and Assessment.


OVERVIEW: The county requested a rehearing in the taxpayers' action for review of assessments levied against real property, based on the circumstance that the legislature, following the court's decision to grant partial summary judgment for the taxpayers, amended N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 307, 1978 N.Y. Laws 476. The branch of the county's motion for renewal was granted, and upon consideration of additional facts presented, was denied by the court. Insofar as 1978 N.Y. Laws ch. 476 authorized a system of assessment under which the State Board of Equalization and Assessment was left without guidelines for determining the major types of property, and the assessor was empowered, at his discretion, to select the ratios at which different categories of real property could be assessed, it was an unconstitutional delegation of a basic legislative function. The lack of uniformity in the system resulted in the deprivation of due process and the equal protection of the laws to property owners. Further, the attempt to make the of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 307(5), which made the substantive legislation retroactive, applicable to pending proceedings constituted a denial of equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court granted the county's motion requesting renewal in the underlying action brought by the taxpayers for the review of assessments levied against real property, and upon consideration of the additional facts presented, the motion was denied.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Assessment by Class of Property

1. Section 307 of the Real Property Tax Law (L 1978, ch 476), which grants to certain assessing units an exemption from the requirement that all real property be assessed at 100% of value in accordance with the statutory direction ( Real Property Tax Law, § 306; see Hellerstein v Assessor of Town of Islip, 37 NY2d 1, remittitur amd 39 NY2d 920) until December 31, 1980, constitutes an unconstitutional delegation of a basic legislative function by authorizing fractional assessment by class as determined by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment during the transitional period in which assessment at 100% is delayed, without providing the board with any guidelines for determining the major types of property to be included in each class, and by empowering the local assessor to select the ratios at which the different categories may be assessed, thereby resulting in a discriminatory system of taxation; the indefiniteness and the lack of uniformity and equality inherent in such a taxing [***2] system, which leaves to the assessor the determination that one class of property shall be assessed at a specified percent and at another percent in a contiguous taxing unit, necessarily results in the deprivation of due process and equal protection of the laws to property owners.

Taxation -- Assessment -- Retroactive Application of New Standard of Assessment in Tax Inequality Proceedings

2. Section 307 of the Real Property Tax Law, a substantive enactment, which, in attempting to insulate municipalities from the fiscal impact of tax inequality proceedings resulting from the higher level of assessment imposed against commercial properties, establishes a new standard of assessment providing that inequality can only be shown by establishing that the subject parcel is assessed at a greater ratio than property of the same class, pre-existing law having required that real property be assessed at a uniform ratio ascertained by comparing the total assessed valuation of all categories of property in the taxing district with the aggregate of their full value, with inequality being established when the subject parcel was assessed at a ratio higher than the average so determined,  [***3] denies equal protection by making the new standard of assessment retroactively applicable to all pending tax inequality proceedings; the statute, by substituting a class ratio for over-all ratio, increases or decreases the amount at which property could be initially assessed, the net effect of which is to give approval to a change in assessments made long ago for the improper purpose of cutting off refunds to taxpayers who filed protests claiming they were excessively taxed when the assessments were levied and paid; the consequences of past deficient assessment procedures long disregarded cannot be cast upon a select group of property owners who resorted to litigation to enforce their rights in reliance on the pre-existing law, and may not be divested of a remedy or compelled to bear an unequal share of the tax burden imposed many years ago.

 

2164 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tamburai Mndange-Pfupfu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Tompkins County


97 Misc. 2d 496; 411 N.Y.S.2d 1000; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2826



December 27, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motions of said defendants are denied in all respects.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss their indictments for rape.


OVERVIEW: Defendants filed motions to dismiss their indictments for rape based on the denial of certiorari of the United States Supreme Court of a case about statutory rape. Defendants alleged that singling out males as the only perpetrators of the crime of rape with only females as the victims was unconstitutional, and that gender-based classifications violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. 1, § 11. The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss. It held that a higher level of scrutiny was appropriate than the traditional rational basis equal protection test when dealing with gender-based classifications. The court held that N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.25(2) and 130.35(3) served an important governmental objective and did not violate the equal protection clause of the state or federal constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss their indictments for rape.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection Test -- "Middle Tier" Approach for Gender-Based Legislation

1. Gender-based legislative classifications are subject to a "middle tier" equal protection test requiring a higher level of scrutiny than the traditional rational basis equal protection test which only requires some rational and articulable reason in order to pass constitutional muster, but less stringent scrutiny than is applied under the "strict scrutiny" test for "suspect" classifications such as race, alienage or nationality which requires that the statute accomplish some legitimate State objective by the least restrictive means possible; classifications by gender must serve some important governmental objective and must be substantially related to achievement of those objectives.

Crimes -- Statutory Rape -- Equal Protection

2. Statutory rape statutes, which define rape as an exclusively male crime perpetrated only against young females without any concomitant provision for commission by a female ( Penal Law, § 130.35, subd 3; § 130.25, subd 2), are constitutional under the "middle tier"  [***2] equal protection test applicable to review the constitutionality of gender-based legislative classifications since protecting young females from physical and psychological damage and from getting pregnant serve important governmental objectives and the gender-based classification is substantially related to those objectives. Since most of the problems encountered by females when pregnant do not accrue to males who engage in sexual intercourse, the sexes are not similarly situated and the argument that males receive unconstitutional unequal treatment therefore lacks merit.

 

2165 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Anderson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


97 Misc. 2d 408; 411 N.Y.S.2d 830; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2812



December 14, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress the identification testimony emanating from the photographic and lineup procedures conducted by the police in an action charging defendant with murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested for robbery, photographed, and fingerprinted. The proceeding was dismissed. The trial judge ordered that defendant's photographs be returned to him forthwith and the other records sealed. Thereafter, the police conducted a homicide investigation and displayed defendant's photograph to an eyewitness, who identified defendant as the perpetrator. Defendant was then placed in a corporeal lineup and identified. Defendant was arrested and charged with murder. Defendant moved to have the photographic testimony suppressed because the identification procedure was tainted, as the photograph was unlawfully obtained. The court found that the five week interval between the trial court's order and the police display of defendant's photo was a reasonable period within which the sovereign could comply with the trial court's order. However, the court found that the eyewitness's testimony was reliable, trustworthy, and admissible because it was not conducive in any manner to a likelihood of irreparable misrepresentation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress the pretrial photographic and lineup identification and the in-court identification because the witness's identification was certain and unequivocal, as the witness had an opportunity to clearly observe defendant for a lengthy period of time during their confrontation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Return of Photographs upon Favorable Termination of Criminal Action

1. A defendant has no inherent or constitutional right to the return of any photographs, fingerprints or other indicia of an [***2] arrest where the charges are dismissed, but rather such a remedy is statutorily mandated ( CPL 160.50); such a remedial statute being designed to place a successful defendant in the same position that he occupied prior to his arrest and to remove the "stigma" of the alleged criminal activity and its adverse affect on an accused and not to immunize a defendant from the operation of a law enforcement official's investigatory display of a photograph, albeit in contravention of statute.

Crimes -- Return of Photographs -- Identification Based on Retained Photograph

2. The word "forthwith" set forth in a statute requiring that a defendant's photograph, fingerprints and other indicia of arrest be returned to him "forthwith" pursuant to court order upon the favorable termination of a criminal action ( CPL 160.50) means not only immediately, but "within a reasonable time and with reasonable dispatch" and is not to be equated with instantaneous delivery of the photograph so that compliance should be measured by whether the police returned the photograph within a reasonable amount of time and in a reasonable manner. Accordingly, a five-week interval between the court order requiring [***3] the police to return defendant's photograph to him following the dismissal of the robbery charge for which the photograph was taken and the police display of the photo to an eyewitness to a homicide who identified defendant from the photograph as the perpetrator and then later selected defendant from a corporeal lineup, was a reasonable period within which the police could comply with the court order and, in the absence of any proof of bad faith, deliberate or intentional withholding of the photograph as a maneuver to circumvent the remedial purpose of the statute, the failure of the police to return defendant's photograph to him cannot be deemed to have tainted the subsequent identification procedures so as to warrant suppression of the identification testimony.

Crimes -- Return of Photographs -- Identification Based on Retained Photograph

3. Since the mere retention and use of defendant's photograph by the police in violation of a statute requiring that such photograph be returned to the defendant "forthwith" pursuant to court order upon the favorable termination of the criminal charge against him ( CPL 160.50), does not constitute a denial of defendant's constitutional [***4] rights, a subsequent identification emanating from the "illegal" photograph should not be suppressed. In any event, even assuming a violation of the statute and that said violation was of constitutional proportions, the identification testimony of an eyewitness to a homicide who identified defendant as the perpetrator from his photograph and then later selected defendant from a corporeal lineup, would still not be suppressed since the photo and lineup identification procedures were not unnecessarily suggestive and the identification possessed "sufficient aspects of reliability" under the "totality of circumstances" to be admissible in that the eyewitness had ample opportunity to clearly observe the defendant at "eyeball" distance for a lengthy period of time during their confrontation and his identification of defendant was certain and unequivocal, resulting more from his mental recall of his encounter with defendant during the commission of the criminal act rather than from the viewing of defendant's photograph.

 

2166 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dubendorf v. New York State Education Dep't


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


97 Misc. 2d 382; 412 N.Y.S.2d 260; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2809



December 14, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school owners sought a declaratory judgment against defendants, the state education department (department), the commissioner, and the director of the budget, alleging that the reduction of the rates charged by the school owners for tuition and maintenance in connection with the care and education of handicapped children was invalid. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The school owners and the department entered into a contract whereby the department obligated itself to pay to the school owners an agreed upon tuition rate and maintenance charge as approved by the commissioner and the director. The rates were reduced and the school owners sought a declaratory judgment that the reduction was invalid. The court held that the school owners failed to meet the burden of demonstrating a constitutional infirmity. However, the commissioner did not comply with the legislative mandate directing and empowering him to promulgate the necessary rules and regulations pertaining to tuition and maintenance rates. Because the department was attempting to recoup overpayments already made, the school owners were entitled to a hearing with respect to the 1976-1977 tuition and maintenance rates. In view of the fact that a hearing was ordered with respect to the 1976-1977 rates, the same hearing should also inquire into and determine the factual questions that affected the prospective rates as well.


OUTCOME: The court held that a hearing was necessary with respect to the 1976-1977 rates and that until such a hearing was held and a determination made, it was premature to decide whether the conduct of the commissioner in retroactively reducing the rates was arbitrary and capricious.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Education  [***2] of Handicapped Children

1. The decision by the State Education Department to adopt the findings of the Division of Audits and Accounts as to the reasonableness of the tuition and maintenance costs charged by plaintiffs in connection with the care and education of handicapped children at plaintiffs' schools (Education Law, art 89) constituted a final determination by the department which operated to exhaust plaintiffs' administrative remedies. Additionally, a declaratory judgment action is the proper procedure by which to review a determination of an administrative agency fixing rates.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children

2. The Board of Regents, which must approve all rules and regulations of the Commissioner of Education before they can become effective, is not a necessary party to an action challenging the reduction by the State Education Department of the rates charged by plaintiffs for tuition and maintenance in connection with the care and education of handicapped children at plaintiffs' schools (Education Law, art 89) since the board did not play a substantial role in any of the matters at issue and they will not be adversely affected by any determination.

 [***3] Statutes -- Delegation of Authority to Administrative Agency

3. Legislation delegating to an administrative agency the authority to set rates need only prescribe standards and safeguards in so detailed a fashion as is reasonably practicable in light of the complexities of the particular area to be regulated since necessity fixes a point beyond which it is unreasonable and impracticable to compel the Legislature to prescribe detailed rules or furnish a precise or specific formula.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children

4. Article 89 of the Education Law, which delegates to the Commissioner of Education the power to determine tuition and maintenance rates for the care and education of handicapped children in nonpublic schools without setting forth specific guidelines and precise standards for the commissioner to follow, is constitutional since the complexities of the area and the constant change and expansion of the techniques utilized require fairly broad and necessarily imprecise statutory standards which will enable the State Education Department to carry out its statutory responsibility to "stimulate all private and public efforts designed to relieve, care [***4] for or educate handicapped children and * * * formulate such rules and regulations" as are deemed to be in their best interests to provide for their physical and educational needs (Education Law, § 4403), such general directions being sufficiently precise to carry out the intended beneficial purpose of the legislation. In any event, plaintiffs have failed to meet the burden of demonstrating the invalidity of the legislation beyond a reasonable doubt.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Tuition and Maintenance Rates

5. A memorandum of agreement between the State Education Department, the Department of Audit and Control and other State agencies involved in the education of handicapped children, setting forth a "common set of standards to be used in establishing tuition rates and maintenance rates for conducting field audit examinations" for private institutions for handicapped children, including uniform standards for allowable administration and leasing and rental costs, has no legal validity or effect as a rule or regulation since the agreement, as a statement of "general applicability" which "prescribes the procedure requirements of an agency", is intended [***5] to function as if it were a regulation and not merely as an internal auditing procedure, and, as such, it must be promulgated (Executive Law, § 101-a; State Administrative Procedure Act, § 202) and then filed with the Secretary of State (NY Const, art IV, § 8; Executive Law, § 102; State Administrative Procedure Act, § 203) in order to become effective and binding.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Recoupment of Overpayments

6. The absence of precise rules and standards pertaining to the establishment of tuition rates and maintenance rates for private schools for handicapped children (see 8 NYCRR 200.11, 200.13) does not prohibit the recouping of claimed overpayments made pursuant to interim rates since the Commissioner of Education has the power to approve maintenance expenses and determine tuition costs, with or without regulations (Education Law, § 4401). The commissioner acted properly in relying upon an audit conducted by the State Comptroller in retroactively decreasing plaintiffs' tuition and maintenance rates since all rates were provisional and conditioned upon an audit and, thus, plaintiffs had no final and vested ownership in the sums authorized [***6] or received prior to the audit. In addition, plaintiffs, in the agreement with the State Education Department, acknowledged that their accounts were subject to audit and that any overpayments would be reimbursed.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Hearing on Recoupment of Overpayments

7. Although plaintiffs, the operators of private schools for handicapped children, had no final or vested ownership in sums received from the State Education Department (Education Law, art 89) prior to an audit, since substantial property rights are at stake with respect to the recoupment of claimed overpayments made pursuant to interim tuition and maintenance rates, due process requires that plaintiffs be granted a prompt hearing with respect to such prior tuition and maintenance rates notwithstanding the absence of any express statutory or regulatory requirements for such a hearing. Although due process does not require a hearing for prospective rates in the absence of such a requirement by statute or regulation, the hearing with respect to the prior rates should also inquire into and determine the factual questions which will affect the prospective rates as well as involving [***7] the appropriate measure by which to establish the correct formula for determining rent, the nature of the relationship between plaintiffs and their landlord, by what percentage plaintiffs' salaries should be increased and any other matters of existing disagreement between the parties.

 

2167 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mandell v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


97 Misc. 2d 480; 411 N.Y.S.2d 827; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2823



December 12, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff teacher filed an action against defendant board of education seeking to declare the by-laws of the Board of Education of the City of New York, § 492(A) unconstitutional in connection with the denial of her application for salary credit for the three years of teaching experience she acquired when she moved out of state and after her resignation, and the parties had filed cross-motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: A teacher appointed by a board of education in New York to teach in a school, resigned to move to another state. Later, she returned to New York, and she received permission to withdraw her resignation and resumed service as a regular teacher. She applied for salary credit for her teaching experience while she was out of state, and the board denied the request under § 492(A), under which teachers, who resigned and later withdrew their resignations, were denied salary credit for teaching experience gained during their absence. She then sought a declaration that § 492(A) was unconstitutional alleging violation of equal protection. The court held that: (1) any penalty exacted on the teacher's mobility was purely economic, which did not affect a fundamental interest; (2) hence, the test to be applied was the rational basis test, or whether the challenged classification bear a reasonable relationship to a legitimate legislative objective; and (2) section 492(A) was valid and constitutional because it bear a reasonable relationship to the legitimate legislative objective of attracting qualified teachers and of discouraging equally qualified teachers from leaving the school system.


OUTCOME: The court denied the teacher's motion for summary judgment and granted the board's motion for summary judgment. The court declared the applicable provision of the by-law to be constitutional and valid.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Teachers -- Salary Credit for Out-of-State Teaching Experience

A provision of the by-laws of the Board of Education of the City of New York which denied to former New York City teachers who have resigned and subsequently withdrawn their resignations, salary credit for teaching experience gained during their absence does not violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution, since the strict scrutiny test is inapplicable because the only "penalty" which could be said to be exacted is purely economic and does not reach the fundamental significance espoused by case law, and in applying the rational basis test, the strong presumption of constitutionality must be overcome and unconstitutionality must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt; a statutory discrimination will not be set aside if any state of facts may reasonably be conceived to justify it, and the by-law at issue passes constitutional muster inasmuch as it serves to attract qualified teachers and to discourage equally qualified teachers from leaving the school system.

 

2168 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. James H. Northrop, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Suffolk County


97 Misc. 2d 606; 412 N.Y.S.2d 83; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2843



December 12, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant charged with renting out property that defendant owned without a rental permit. Defendant brought a motion to have the Town of Islip Code ch. 27 declared unconstitutional because it required him to submit to an involuntary search in order to be issued a rental permit.


OVERVIEW: Defendant owned rental property that was subjected to a town ordinance regulating residential rental property, which provided that a rental permit would not be issued unless a voluntary inspection and search of the premises was allowed. Defendant refused to allow an inspection and was charged with renting his property without a valid rental permit. Defendant moved to declare the ordinance unconstitutional. Defendant claiming that the town could not conduct an involuntary search absent authority to do so without a warrant issued for probable cause. Thus, requiring a voluntary inspection as a condition precedent to issuance of a rental permit transgressed defendant's right to be free from warrantless searches. The court ruled that the inspection was totally voluntary. Furthermore, defendant failed to overcome the strong presumption of the constitutionality of the ordinance where it was shown that the ordinance was reasonably related to the protection of the community's interest in the upkeep of its neighborhoods and the safeguarding of the lives and health of those persons who live in rented premises.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion and found defendant guilty of renting property without a valid rental permit.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Administrative Inspection

There is a strong presumption of the constitutionality of a validly enacted local ordinance and a court of original jurisdiction should not resort to statutory interpretation of constitutional dimensions absent the most compelling circumstances. Accordingly, although it is constitutionally impermissible to make the refusal of an administrative inspector's request for a general search of premises an offense (US Const, 4th Amdt), a town ordinance which requires a voluntary search and inspection of the premises as a condition precedent to the issuance of a rental permit to a property owner, but does not make the refusal to permit an inspection an offense, is reasonably related to the protection of the community's interest in the upkeep of its neighborhoods and the safeguarding of the lives and health of those persons who live in rented premises and is not unconstitutional.

 

2169 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


De Milia v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


96 Misc. 2d 77; 412 N.Y.S.2d 953; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2556; 100 L.R.R.M. 2625



December 11, 1978 



DISPOSITION: The motion for an injunction is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff association sought an injunction prohibiting the enforcement of 1978 N.Y. Laws ch. 201, and defendant State of New York sought a declaration that the legislation was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: 1978 N.Y. Laws ch. 201, including § 23(3)(a)-(h) thereof, provided that any report or recommendation of an impasse panel established pursuant to the New York City Collective Bargaining Law or finding of the Collective Bargaining Board that provided for increases in wages or fringe benefits to city employees must, in addition to other criteria, give "substantial weight" to the city's ability to pay such increases without requiring an increase in the level of city taxes existing at the time. The association argued that § 23 violated several provisions of the New York Constitution. In denying the association's motion for an injunction and declaring the legislation constitutional, the court held that the reasonableness of the legislation in holding down arbitration awards to amounts that the city could afford within existing revenue sources was manifest. The court further held that the legislation did not violate equal protection principles because classification distinctions between New York City and up-state police and firemen were reasonable.


OUTCOME: The court denied the association's motion for an injunction, and it granted the State's motion to have the legislation declared constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- State Financial Emergency Act for City of New York -- Wage Increases Based on City's "Financial Ability"  [***2] to Pay

1. Chapter 201 (§ 23, subd 3, pars [a]-[h]) of the Laws of 1978, which amends the State Financial Emergency Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 868) by imposing a new limitation on the bargaining and arbitration provisions of the New York City Collective Bargaining Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 1173-7.0, subd c) based on the city's "financial ability" to pay the cost of any increases in wages and fringe benefits to city employees "without requiring an increase in the level of city taxes", does not unconstitutionally preclude the city from asserting its prerogative to tax up to its constitutionally permissible real property tax limit (NY Const, art VIII, § 10) in order to provide for such increases since the constitutional tax limit provisions does not restrict the powers of the Legislature to "further restrict" the powers to levy local real estate taxes or to fix a lower limit of permissible taxation or limit the Legislature's "absolute discretion" to impose, amend or repeal most local taxes. Chapter 201 does not restrict the city from levying taxes up to the permissible tax limit and there is nothing in the act which precludes city officials [***3] from voluntarily increasing the level of taxation within the constitutional limit so long as consideration has been given to the city's financial ability to pay. The reasonableness of holding down arbitration awards to amounts the city can afford within existing resources is manifest.

Municipal Corporations -- State Financial Emergency Act for City of New York -- Wage Increases Based on City's "Financial Ability" to Pay

2. Chapter 201 (§ 23, subd 3, pars [a]-[h]) of the Laws of 1978, which amends the State Financial Emergency Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 868) by imposing a new limitation on the bargaining and arbitration provisions of the New York City Collective Bargaining Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 1173-7.0, subd c) based on the city's "financial ability" to pay the cost of any increases in wages and fringe benefits to city employees without the necessity of increasing taxes, does not violate equal protection by placing plaintiff police organization in a different position than that of other police organizations throughout the State since there is no inequality of treatment among the city's municipal unions in that the city's [***4] collective bargaining procedures are applicable to all municipal unions with which the city bargains, the classification distinctions between New York City and up-State police and firemen being reasonably related to a legitimate State purpose. Furthermore, the fact that voluntary wage and benefit agreements are also subject to the city's "financial ability" to pay, insures equity and equal protection to all municipal unions.

Municipal Corporations -- State Financial Emergency Act for City of New York -- Wage Increases Based on City's "Financial Ability" to Pay

3. Chapter 201 (§ 23, subd 3, pars [a]-[h]) of the Laws of 1978, which imposes limitations on the bargaining and arbitration provisions of the New York City Collective Bargaining Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 1173-7.0, subd c) based on the city's "financial ability" to pay the cost of any increases in wages or fringe benefits to city employees without increasing taxes, does not vitiate the binding arbitration provisions of the Taylor Law ( Civil Service Law, § 209, subd 4) so as to remove the restrictions on strikes by public employees since the strike prohibition is not contingent upon procedures [***5] employed in the collective bargaining process. There can be no trade-off or "balance" since it is the State's long standing policy to prohibit strikes by public employees.

Municipal Corporations -- State Financial Emergency Act for City of New York -- Wage Increases Based on City's "Financial Ability" to Pay

4. Chapter 201 (§ 23, subd 3, pars [a]-[h]) of the Laws of 1978, which imposes limitations on the bargaining and arbitration provisions of the New York City Collective Bargaining Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 1173-7.0, subd c) based on the city's "financial ability" to pay the costs of any increases in wages or fringe benefits to city employees without increasing taxes, does not contravene the home rule provision of the State Constitution which requires that an act "in relation to the property, affairs or government" of a local government be requested by two thirds of the members of the Legislature (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [b], par [2]), since the existing financial emergency in the city which prompted enactment of chapter 201, is a matter of "substantial and imperative" State concern of far wider scope than the "property, affairs or [***6] government" of local government and therefore a home rule request was not required.

 

2170 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


CC&F Buffalo Development Co. v. Tully


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


97 Misc. 2d 320; 411 N.Y.S.2d 178; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2795



December 11, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Defendants' motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state tax commission moved to dismiss the action of plaintiff taxpayer for declaratory judgment upon the ground that the action should have been brought either as a N.Y. C.P.R.L. art. 78 proceeding or a proceeding before a court of claims. In the alternative, the commission sought a transfer of venue.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer paid a mortgage tax under protest and then filed for review by the commission. Eight years later, the commission determined that the tax had been illegally collected and ordered the amount of the tax refunded to the taxpayer. The taxpayer was not awarded any interest on the funds. The taxpayer sought a declaratory judgment that it was entitled to interest and injunctive relief. The court concluded that the taxpayer was properly seeking a determination in a declaratory judgment proceeding as to whether it was entitled to interest on the illegally collected mortgage tax. The taxpayer's means of redress did not have to be framed in a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding because such a method of review was not the exclusive remedy available and there was no prior decision on the matter to review in an art. 78 proceeding. As to the change of venue request, it was denied because the court of claims did not have sole jurisdiction in appeals from determinations of the commission.


OUTCOME: The court denied the commission's motions.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Mortgage Tax -- Procedure for Review

1. A declaratory judgment action against the State Tax Commission rather than an article 78 proceeding is the proper remedy to determine whether plaintiff is entitled to interest on a refund of an illegally collected mortgage tax since a declaratory judgment action is proper to determine the application of a tax statute where it is claimed that the imposition of the tax is inapplicable to the situation and the statutory provisions dealing with appeals in mortgage tax matters (Tax Law, §§ 251, 263)  [***2] do not mandate that an article 78 proceeding be the exclusive method of review; furthermore, since the State Tax Commission, in finding that the mortgage tax was improperly collected, did not undertake to make any decision on the issue of interest on the mortgage tax refund, there is no determination per se to review in an article 78 proceeding.

Taxation -- Mortgage Tax -- Venue of Declaratory Judgment Action against Tax Commission

2. A declaratory judgment action against the State Tax Commission to determine whether plaintiff is entitled to interest on a refund of an illegally collected mortgage tax, is not required to be transferred to Albany County pursuant to CPLR 506 (subd [b], par 2) since the statute is only concerned with the venue of "special proceedings", such as article 78 proceedings, and not with declaratory judgment actions.

Taxation -- Mortgage Tax -- Jurisdiction over Appeals

3. The Court of Claims does not have sole jurisdiction over a declaratory judgment action against the State Tax Commission to determine whether plaintiff is entitled to interest on a refund of an illegally collected mortgage tax since the fact that the commission's action [***3] may be reviewed in an article 78 proceeding (Tax Law, § 251) demonstrates the legislative intent not to limit or restrict such appeals to the Court of Claims even though any refund would involve a monetary judgment against the State; moreover, the Court of Claims is specifically restricted from considering declaratory judgment actions.

 

2171 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


County of Niagara v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


97 Misc. 2d 421; 411 N.Y.S.2d 810; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2814



December 11, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Summary judgment is granted to defendants dismissing plaintiff's complaint upon the ground the causes of action alleged therein are without merit as a matter of law.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff county and defendants, a comptroller, a transportation authority, and the authority's chairman, filed motions for summary judgment in an action to challenge N.Y. Transp. Law § 18-b(c)(5), which required the county to contribute to the operating expenses of a state transportation authority.


OVERVIEW: The legislature created the transportation authority to provide public mass transit. N.Y. Transp. Law § 18-b(c)(5) stated that if the county failed to make its contribution for the authority's operating expenses, the state was to deduct the payment from the county's state aid allotment. The county brought an action to challenge the contribution requirement. The county claimed that § 18-b(c)(5) violated N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 and it did not apply to the county because it conflicted with N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1299-f(3), which stated that the authority was self-sustaining. The court dismissed the county's action. The state had the authority to require the county to contribute to the authority because the authority was a public transportation service that provided a valid public purpose to the county. N.Y. Transp. Law § 18-b(c)(5) did not conflict with N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 because the county was not incurring any indebtedness, especially where the county did not directly pay the contributions where the state withheld the amount of the contributions from state aid. Also, the contributions were not a gift but consideration for a public benefit.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Counties -- State-Wide Mass Transportation Assistance Program -- Mandated Financial Assistance to Transportation Systems

 Section 18-b of the Transportation Law, which, because of the "energy crises" and the need to develop mass transportation systems, mandates that Erie and Niagara Counties, as part of a State-wide mass transportation operating assistance program, contribute towards the operating expenses of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, a public benefit corporation created for the purpose of developing and improving transportation and other related services within the two counties ( Public Authorities Law, § 1299-d), is constitutional since public transportation services have a recognized county purpose and the State can, therefore, lawfully obligate a benefited local municipality to financially support such services without violating constitutional provisions prohibiting a county from making a gift or loan of money or extending credit to an individual or private group (NY Const, art VIII,  [***2] § 1) or incurring any indebtedness for nonmunicipal purposes (NY Const, art VIII, § 2). In addition, since the authority does provide mass transportation services for the residents of Niagara County, no joint support arrangement between the county and the authority is required in order to make the provisions of the statute operative; the statute merely requires that a transportation system either provide mass transportation services "or" contract to provide these services in order to be eligible to receive operating assistance.

 

2172 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Barr v. Syracuse


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


97 Misc. 2d 453; 411 N.Y.S.2d 814; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2820



December 11, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Syracuse, N.Y., General Ordinances Nos. 29 and 30 (1978), were enacted as amendments to the Traffic Code of the City of Syracuse to regulate mobile food vendor stands in a congested traffic area. Plaintiff vendor brought an action against defendant city seeking a declaratory judgment that the ordinances were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Within certain special assessment districts, the ordinances regulated the time and place in which mobile food vendors could park or stand for extended periods. Plaintiff claimed that the ordinances were illegally discriminatory, arbitrary, and enacted under an improper motive. The court dismissed the complaint because plaintiff did not rebut the presumption of constitutionality of the ordinances beyond a reasonable doubt. The court found that the ordinances were not discriminatorily directed at plaintiff's business, but were applied to all mobile vendors as a general class, all of whom were treated alike in the privileges conferred and in the liabilities imposed. The court also found that there was a reasonable basis for the ordinances and that they were directed toward legitimate legislative objectives of traffic congestion, access to parking, and public safety. The court ruled that the time restrictions imposed by the ordinances were not unreasonable and that defendant had the authority to regulate the use of metered parking areas to achieve what it felt to be in the public interest.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiff's complaint for a judgment declaring unconstitutional city ordinances that regulated mobile food vendors.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. A strong presumption exists in favor of the constitutionality of legislative enactments, including municipal ordinances, and it is incumbent upon the one challenging the enactment to rebut the presumption of constitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt, the primary concern upon a claim of unconstitutionality being whether the statute as written and applied, constitutes a valid exercise of the police power and whether the means adopted by the statute are reasonably related to the purpose intended to be accomplished; the validity of the statute or ordinance is to be determined from its general purpose and its efficiency to accomplish the end desired in cases which may be expected to arise, and not from its effect in the particular case which is before the court. The necessity and advisability of the ordinance is for the legislative power to determine and not for the court and, if a statute appears on its face constitutional and valid, the courts cannot inquire into the motives of the members of the municipal legislative body nor can the influence under which they act be shown to nullify an ordinance duly passed in legal form within [***2] the scope of their power.

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Regulation of Mobile Vendors

2. While a city cannot by ordinance prohibit peddling in certain sections of the city where conditions in the restricted section are not dissimilar from those existing in many other areas and where the ordinance bears no rational relation to the welfare of the public but is instead designed for the convenience and interest of a special class, it may, however, validly prohibit vending in restricted areas and streets in order to prevent interference with traffic where discrimination is based on traffic conditions; accordingly, municipal ordinances of the City of Syracuse which regulate the time and place in which mobile vendors may park or stand for extended periods in the most heavily traveled downtown area of the city by prohibiting retail sales from any vehicle occupying a metered parking space or from any zone where parking, standing or stopping is prohibited and by designating four locations as mobile vendor stands for retail sales which may only be utilized by the same mobile vendor for a 60-minute period, are valid, being based on legitimate concerns of public safety and convenience of preventing [***3] interference with traffic, avoiding undue congestion in the public streets and providing all mobile vendors with an equal opportunity to use the designated stands at some time.

 

2173 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gray


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


97 Misc. 2d 285; 411 N.Y.S.2d 170; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2788



December 7, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion seeking a trial by jury after being charged with misdemeanors.


OVERVIEW: Defendants' felony charges were reduced to misdemeanors when their cases were transferred due to their age. The court held defendants were not entitled to a jury trial because they were youthful offenders. The court held a youthful offender had to be tried by one judge, pursuant to statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' request for a jury trial because the statute only provided for trial by judge for youthful offenders.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Mandatory Youthful Offender -- Denial of Jury Trial

1. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which requires that a "mandatory youthful offender", a person at least 16 years old but less than 19 who has not previously been convicted of a crime or been adjudicated a youthful offender ( CPL 720.10), be tried by a single Judge without a jury, is constitutional since the maximum aggregate period of imprisonment, including incarceration for any probation violation, for a "mandatory youthful offender" cannot exceed six months ( CPL 720.20, subd 3; Penal Law, § 60.02), making the offenses for which such youthful offenders are tried "petty" rather than "serious".

Crimes -- Mandatory Youthful Offender -- Denial of Jury Trial

2. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which requires that a "mandatory youthful offender" ( CPL 720.10) be tried by a single Judge without a jury, is not unconstitutional as applied to defendants, whose cases were returned to the lower criminal court with felony charges reduced to misdemeanors upon the motion of the prosecutor ( CPL 180.40) thereby requiring that defendants be treated as mandatory youthful offenders and thus deprived of the right to a jury trial, since the action [***2] of the prosecutor was fully authorized by statute and was not done solely to deny defendants a jury trial. By returning defendants' cases to the criminal court, the prosecutor has foregone any possibility of convicting defendants of a felony or of any crime at all. If defendants are desirous of a jury trial they may move to have their cases presented to the Grand Jury which is then authorized to indict them for felonies if the evidence presented so warrants. ( CPL 170.25, 190.65, subd 2.)

 

2174 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Strutt v. Mont


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


97 Misc. 2d 744; 412 N.Y.S.2d 245; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2856



December 4, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner moved for a turnover of escrow funds held by respondent's attorney pursuant to respondent's breach of a stipulation entered into between the parties and their attorneys before a Housing Court judge. The motion was commenced by show cause order signed by the Housing Court judge before whom the stipulation was negotiated and entered, but made returnable to the Civil Court judge presiding in the Housing Court calendar and motion part.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner filed a motion for a turnover of escrow funds pursuant to respondent's breach of a stipulation entered into between the parties in open court before a Housing Court judge. In response to the Housing Court judge's show cause order, which was made returnable to the Civil Court judge presiding over the Housing Court calendar and motion dockets, respondent contended that the Housing Court judge lacked authority to sign such show cause orders and, therefore, argued that the motion was improperly brought. The court held that, notwithstanding the 1975 administrative directive, which directed that show cause orders pertaining to summary proceedings to recover possession of real property be signed only by judges presiding in the calendar part of the Housing Part, the legislature had authorized any Housing Judge, as well as any Civil Court or Acting Civil Court Judge, to grant concurrent Housing Court relief including the signing of show cause orders returnable before Housing Judges. Accordingly, the court found that the challenge to the show cause order was insufficient as a matter of law.


OUTCOME: The court found respondent's challenge to the show cause order signed by a Housing Judge to be insufficient as a matter of law, and referred the motion to Housing Court Judge as a continuing jurisdictional matter properly before him involving these parties for final disposition for all purposes.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Judges -- Housing Court Judge -- Authority to Sign Show Cause Order

Notwithstanding a 1975 Civil Court administrative directive requiring that show cause orders "pertaining to summary proceedings to recover the possession of real property * * * be signed only by the Judges presiding in the calendar part of the Housing Part * * * and by no other Judge", such administrative directive being merely a nonbinding judicial guideline not calculated to interfere with the customary discretion accorded Civil Court Judges, appointive Housing Court Judges, formerly designated as hearing officers, by virtue of a subsequently enacted statute conferring upon them the same broad judicial powers as Civil Court Judges to "hear, determine and grant any relief within the powers of the housing part" except for jury trials (CCA, § 110, subd [e]), have the authority to sign show cause orders returnable before Housing Judges; although the State Constitution requires that Civil Court Judges be elected (NY Const, art VI, § 15), the appropriate procedure to adjudicate the validity of the statute creating the new appointive judicial office of Housing Judge is an action for a declaratory judgment in [***2] the Supreme Court, a lower court of limited jurisdiction such as the Civil Court, having no authority to grant that relief.

 

2175 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Lewis v. Safeco Ins. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


98 Misc. 2d 856; 414 N.Y.S.2d 823; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2896



December 1, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff New York Superintendent of Insurance commenced action against defendant insurers to compel them to continue to conduct business as insurance carriers in the state of New York. Defendants sought to terminate their business activities in the state due to increasing underwriting losses.


OVERVIEW: Defendant insurers underwrote automobile, homeowners, marine, and dwelling fire policies and related forms of coverage in the state of New York. Defendants had 74,000 policies in New York, and sought to terminate their business activities due to increasing underwriting losses. Plaintiff New York Superintendent of Insurance commenced an action against defendants to compel them to continue to conduct business as insurance carriers in the state. The court held that defendants could terminate their business in the state, because to force them to operate a business against their wishes would violate their due process rights under the New York and United States Constitutions. The court also ruled that plaintiff had the power to ameliorate the consequences of defendants' termination by providing that the rights of existing policyholders would remain otherwise unimpaired, while permitting defendants to phase out their business in an orderly fashion.


OUTCOME: The court ruled the defendants had the right to terminate their business in the state, since, pursuant to the New York and United States Constitutions, a state could not compel a corporation to conduct a business against its choosing.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insurance -- Insurer's Right to Terminate its Business in State

1. The Motor Vehicle Financial Security Act (Vehicle and Traffic Law, art 6), which requires that all motorists maintain liability insurance with a duly licensed insurer or other security for damages resulting from the use of a motor vehicle, does not justify compelling defendants to continue doing business as insurance carriers in the State since defendants' surrendering of their licenses will not immediately and automatically subject their insureds to all of the penalties of the act, as the Superintendent of Insurance has the power to ameliorate any adverse consequences by providing that the rights of existing policyholders remain otherwise unimpaired while permitting defendants to phase out their business in an orderly fashion.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Automatic Renewal Provision

2. The decision made by defendants insurers not to opt out of their automobile insurance policies prior to the effective date of the requirement in the no-fault law that all automobile policies in effect before August 1, 1973 be automatically renewable for three successive one-year periods (Insurance [***2] Law, § 167-a) without notice of three subsequent extensions of the automatic renewal provision through 1978, does not constitute a perpetual waiver of defendants' rights to cease doing business as insurance carriers in the State nor was such a procedure reasonably calculated to afford defendants due process in view of the subsequent extensions.

Insurance -- Surrender of License to Conduct Insurance Business

3. The potential adverse consequnces to holders of homeowners and fire policies which may result from defendants' surrendering their licenses to do business as insurance carriers in the State does not justify compelling defendants to continue doing business in the State since the Superintendent of Insurance has broad authority which would permit defendants to operate with a license/authority for an interim transition period during which appropriate safeguards would be adopted and existing policies would be deemed to comply with the relevant statutory and contractual requirements; similarly, the requirements that an insurer be licensed in order for insureds and claimants to be protected by the Property and Liability Insurance and Security Fund (Insurance Law, §§ 333,  [***3] 334) and that an insurer accept assignments under the assigned risk plan and issue three-year coverage to motorists who cannot find placement in the voluntary market (Insurance Law, § 63) does not warrant compelling defendants to continue doing business in the State since the Superintendent's interpretation would unreasonably prevent any insurer from ever terminating its business in the State in spite of the fact that there is no express legislative policy warranting such a drastic result.

Insurance -- Insurer's Right to Terminate in State

4. The power of the State to regulate insurance companies is subject to an insurer's entitlement to due process which prohibits a de facto taking of private property for public use, without just compensation, which may consist of regulations which arbitrarily, unreasonably and without sufficient public purpose, deprive the owner of the benefits of his property; the validity of the no-fault law and the automatic renewal provisions contained therein (Insurance Law, § 167-a) do not warrant compelling defendants to continue doing business as insurance carriers in the State since defendants are not seeking to reap the benefits of doing [***4] business here while "dumping" unprofitable automobile policies while retaining other more profitable areas of insurance coverage but rather are seeking to withdraw completely from conducting any insurance business in the State.

Insurance -- Insurer's Right to Terminate its Business in State

5. Compelling defendants insurers to continue doing as insurance carriers in the State at a loss without a just and reasonable connection with the public welfare, violates defendants' rights to due process since an insurer must retain some choice as to how it will conduct its business and the fact that defendants once submitted to government control by applying for licenses which gave them the privilege of engaging in the insurance business in the State, does not mean they must be forever in bondage, subject to such control; accordingly, defendants have the right to terminate their business in the State and the Superintendent of Insurance has the obligation to assure that such termination is orderly and not unnecessarily disruptive by developing a viable plan for defendants' speedy withdrawal from business in the State with assurances that current policyholders will not be unduly, adversely [***5] affected.

 

2176 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McGee


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Amherst, Erie County


97 Misc. 2d 360; 411 N.Y.S.2d 514; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2803



November 29, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss a uniform traffic information charging him with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 397 on the grounds that that statute was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The information charged defendant with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 397 by equipping a motor vehicle with a radio receiving capable of receiving signals on the frequencies allocated for police use. Defendant maintained that the statute was unconstitutional because the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) had exclusive licensing power. The court held that the applicable portion of the statute did not deal with regulation of the airwaves in any manner. The statute was an exercise by the State of its police power by legislating against the equipping of motor vehicles with a certain type of radio device; therefore, the legislature did not infringe in an area pre-empted by federal law. The court also determined that the term signals had been sufficiently defined; therefore, it was not unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information against him.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Radio Capable of Receiving Police Signals

 Section 397 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which proscribes equipping a motor vehicle with a radio receiving set capable of receiving signals on the frequencies allocated for police use without a permit, for the purpose of preventing criminals from listening to police broadcasts in their automobiles, does not represent an unconstitutional infringement in the area of regulation of airwaves pre-empted by Congress since the statute only proscribes equipping motor vehicles with a certain type of radio device and does not apply to duly licensed radio amateurs, prohibit broadcasting or deal with regulation of the airwaves in any manner. The term "radio receiving set capable of receiving signals" is not so vague as to be unconstitutional since the term "signals" must mean voice messages.

 

2177 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Williams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


97 Misc. 2d 24; 410 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2745



November 28, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, the motion to dismiss the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss his indictment as an adult on criminal charges for certain violent crimes on the grounds that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75 was unconstitutional as a denial of due process and equal protection. Defendant had been denied removal of the charges to family court for treatment as a juvenile under an "interests of justice" standard.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a 14-year-old charged with multiple felonies resulting from entering the home of an elderly woman and robbing and raping her. Defendant was arraigned and the court conducted a hearing authorized under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75 to determine if the case should be removed to family court in the interests of justice. The arraigning court found sufficient proof to hold defendant for the grand jury and found that the case was appropriate for criminal prosecution rather than transfer to family court. Defendant subsequently moved to dismiss the indictment claiming that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.75 was unconstitutional because the "interests of justice" standard provided no guidance to the arraigning court. The court denied the motion to dismiss, citing numerous statutory provisions that included the "interests of justice" standard and cases in which that standard was applied. The court noted that there was no basis for a due process claim because defendant was afforded an adversarial hearing that included the right to counsel, the right to confront witnesses, the right to present testimony, and the right to cross-examine witnesses.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment because defendant was afforded due process in the hearing to determine whether to remove his case to family court. The interests of justice standard was constitutional because it resulted from an informed judicial decision and a hearing that included due process rights.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Juvenile Offenders -- Removal to Family Court "in Interests of Justice"

1. CPL 180.75 (subd 4, par [a]) which authorizes the local criminal court, upon the arraignment of a juvenile offender charged with a violent felony (Penal Law, § 10.00, subd 18; § 30.00), to conduct an "inquiry" to determine whether to retain the action and thus treat the juvenile offender as an adult or remove the action to the Family Court "if it is determined that to do so would be in the interests of justice", without providing any further standard for removal, is constitutionally sufficient to afford a defendant due process and equal protection since the informed judicial removal decision is made in an atmosphere of fair treatment in that the defendant is afforded the right to counsel, confrontation and speedy arraignment and is otherwise given every right which adults suspected of criminal offenses receive. An "interests of justice" standard is not incompatible with due process or tantamount to vagueness since statutes permitting courts to make a variety of profound determinations "in the interests of justice"  [***2] or "in furtherance of justice" are an integral part of the criminal procedural process and have been upheld by appellate courts.

Crimes -- Juvenile Offenders -- Removal to Family Court "in Interests of Justice"

2. CPL 180.75 (subd 4, par [a]) which authorizes a local criminal court, upon the arraignment of a juvenile offender charged with a violent felony (Penal Law, § 10.00, subd 18; § 30.00) to retain the action and treat the juvenile as an adult, reflecting the legislative conclusion that the parens patriae role of the Family Court was not meeting public needs in all cases, and that more severe measures for young violent offenders were needed as a means of deterrence in view of the level and number of violent crimes committed by individuals of this age, does not capriciously "single out" a particular group of individuals for distinct treatment. Such proceedings in the local criminal court to determine whether the juvenile offender should be treated as an adult or a youth should be open to the public absent extenuating circumstances since the interests of privacy and the avoidance of stigmatization are subordinated to and give way to the community's legitimate [***3] need to observe the workings of its justice system with regard to accusations of violent crimes and to learn whether the charges are borne out.

 

2178 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Weaver


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Rensselaer County


97 Misc. 2d 72; 410 N.Y.S.2d 777; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2750; 42 A.F.T.R.2d (RIA) 6427



November 24, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner United States of America filed a claim against respondent administrator of the estate of a decedent to all personal property of the decedent pursuant to 38 U.S.C.S. §§ 5220, 5221 and § 3202 when decedent died intestate while a patient in a Veterans' Administration hospital. Claimant State of New York filed claims for non-veterans derived assets, for an estate tax pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law art. 26, and lodged objections to account.


OVERVIEW: The decedent, while serving in the United States armed forces in World War I, was permanently and totally disabled in 1918. In 1931, he was adjudicated an incompetent and was almost continuously hospitalized in a Veterans Administration hospital until 1972, where he died as a patient. The decedent died intestate and left an estate in excess of $ 100,000, almost all of which was derived from veteran's benefits except for $ 8,177 from an estate of his sister and a small amount from two insurance policies. The court determined that all of the property of the decedent vested immediately upon his death in the United States as trustee for the sole use and benefit of the General Post Fund, pursuant to 38 U.S.C.S. §§ 5220, 5221. The court held that none of the property of the decedent was subject to the New York estate tax under N.Y. Tax Law art. 26.


OUTCOME: The court granted the claim asserted by the United States and dismissed the claims and the objection to account filed on behalf of the State of New York.


HEADNOTES

Escheat -- Estate of Intestate, Heirless Veteran Passing to United States

1. A Federal statute which provides that "all" property of an intestate, heirless veteran who dies "while a member or patient in any facility, or any hospital while being furnished care or treatment therein by the Veterans' Administration", including nonveteran derived assets, "shall immediately vest in and become the property of the United States as trustee for the sole use and benefit of the General Post Fund" (US Code, tit 38, § 5220) is constitutional since, although the devolution of property is [***2] an area normally left to the States, it is not immune under the Tenth Amendment from laws passed by the Federal Government which are necessary and proper to the exercise of a delegated power. Congress has the power to take all the property of such a veteran and devote it "to the comfort and recreation of other ex-service people who must depend upon the Government for care". (See United States v Oregon, 366 U.S. 643.)

Escheat -- Estate of Intestate, Heirless Veteran Passing to United States

2. Property of an intestate, heirless veteran passing to the United States when the veteran dies "while a member or patient in any facility, or any hospital while being furnished care or treatment therein by the Veterans' Administration" (US Code, tit 38, § 5220) is not subject to State estate taxation since the statute, by providing that "all * * * property * * * shall immediately vest in and become the property of the United States", without using the phrase "escheat" under State law, or including an exception for State estate taxes to be paid from such property, evinces Congress' intention to preclude any State estate tax taxation of veterans' estates passing to the United States.

 [***3] Taxation -- Estate Tax -- Estate of Intestate, Heirless Veteran Passing to United States

3. The State Tax Commission cannot challenge a final Federal determination which allowed the value of the property of an intestate, heirless veteran escheating to the United States (US Code, tit 38, § 5220) to be deducted from the decedent's gross estate for Federal estate tax purposes since it has presented no extrinsic evidence of facts to demonstrate that the Federal determination was erroneous by a preponderance of the evidence. (Tax Law, § 961.) Accordingly, none of decedent's property shall be subject to a New York estate tax.

 

2179 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Albany County


97 Misc. 2d 115; 411 N.Y.S.2d 146; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2757



November 21, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against him on the ground that subdivision 1 of section 130.25 of the Penal Law is unconstitutional as violative of equal protection of the laws is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with the crime of rape in the third degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.25(1). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment against him on the ground that § 130.25(1) violated his right to equal protection of the law guaranteed by U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.25(1), which stated that a male was guilty of rape in the third degree when he engaged in sexual intercourse with a female who was incapable of consent by reason of some factor other than being less then 17 years old. Defendant contended that the statute created a constitutionally impermissible classification based on sex. Defendant argued that because only males were subject to criminal liability under § 130.25(1) and only women were protected under it, the statute constituted an arbitrary discrimination based solely upon sex. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against him because § 130.25(1) was based not on sex but on physiology, and was substantially related to and reasonably tended to further important and legitimate state interests. The state had a legitimate interest in protecting mentally incapacitated females incapable of consenting to sexual intercourse, in recognition of the extremely great potential harm that could have been suffered only by female victims, their offspring, and society.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against him, for rape in the third degree, on the ground that the applicable statute was unconstitutional as violative of equal protection of the laws.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Rape Third Degree -- Equal Protection

1. Subdivision 1 of section 130.25 of the Penal Law, which provides that a male is guilty [***2] of rape in the third degree when he "engages in sexual intercourse with a female who is incapable of consent by reason of some factor other then being less then seventeen years old", does not violate equal protection by creating a constitutionally impermissible classification based solely on sex since the classification, making males susceptible to the proscriptions of the statute but not females, is based not on sex but on physiology and is substantially related to and reasonably tends to further important and legitimate State interests and is in no way intended to be and is not in actual practice, invidious or unreasonably discriminatory. The failure to directly include potential female violators within the confines of rape statutes does not violate a fundamental interest of men since females are subject to prosecution under the rape statutes for accessorial conduct. (Penal Law, § 20.00.)

Statutes -- Presumption of Validity

2. A strong presumption of validity attaches to statutes and the burden of proving invalidity rests upon those who challenge their constitutionality to establish this beyond a reasonable doubt. There is a further presumption that the Legislature [***3] has investigated and found the facts necessary to support the legislation.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection

3. Equal protection of the law does not prohibit the State from treating different classes of persons in different ways; however, statutory classifications for purposes of according different treatment must always rest on a difference which bears a fair, substantial, natural, reasonable and just relation to the object or purpose of the statute in order that all persons who are similarly situated are treated in the same way.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection -- Standards for Judicial Review

4. Under "traditional" equal protection analysis, a legislative classification will be sustained unless it is patently arbitrary and bears no rational relationship to a legitimate governmental interest. Where a statute affects a "fundamental interest" such as voting, travel and procreation, or employs a "suspect" classification such as race, national origin and alienage, the "strict scrutiny" test is applied requiring that the legislative purpose be so compelling as to justify the means utilized. The appropriate standard for judicial review with respect [***4] to classifications based upon sex is a "middle tier" standard requiring that classifications by gender serve important governmental objectives and be substantially related to achievement of those objectives. (See Craig v Boren, 429 U.S. 190.)

Crimes -- Rape Third Degree -- Equal Protection

5. Subdivision 1 of section 130.25 of the Penal Law, which provides that a male is guilty of rape in the third degree when he "engages in sexual intercourse with a female who is incapable of consent by reason of some factor other then being less then seventeen years old" is constitutional, constituting a classification by gender that substantially relates to the important governmental interest of affording special protection for females mentally incapable of consent to sexual intercourse, without equal application to their male counterparts, in recognition of the extremely great potential harm that may be suffered only by female victims, their offspring, and society. The classification, based solely on physiology, not sex, is neither by design nor result in any way invidious, nor violative of any fundamental interest of men.
