Without any evidence that female offenders constitute [***5] a criminal problem of any importance, the presumption that the Legislature has investigated and found the facts necessary to support the legislation prevails.

 

2180 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Prainito


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Bronx County


97 Misc. 2d 66; 410 N.Y.S.2d 772; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2749



November 20, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Motion to dismiss both counts of the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss an indictment charging him with statutory rape and endangering the welfare of a child on grounds that the statutes defining the offenses, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.25(2) and 260.10, unconstitutionally deprived him of the equal protection of the law on the basis of sex, in violation of U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a male, was charged with rape in the third degree, commonly known as statutory rape, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.25(2), and endangering the welfare of a child, N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10, for allegedly having sexual intercourse with a girl less than 17 years old. He moved to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that the statutes were unconstitutional in that they deprived him of the equal protection of the law since they differentiated on the basis of sex and only a male could engage in sexual intercourse with an underage female. In denying the motion, the court ruled that the statutes did not deprive males of equal protection of the law. Whereas only a male could be prosecuted under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.25(2) as a perpetrator, a female could also be prosecuted under that statute as an aider and abettor, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 20.00. Moreover, both statutes had a valid rational basis for protecting vulnerable young females from the potential adverse effects of intercourse, including unwed pregnancy.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss was denied because both statutes had the rational basis of protecting young females and neither was violative of equal protection. While only a male could engage in sexual intercourse with an underage female, a female could be prosecuted as a principal for aiding and abetting such statutory rape.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Statutory Rape -- Equal Protection

1. Since females may be prosecuted as principals for aiding and abetting in the commission of a rape (Penal Law, § 20.00), there is no denial of equal protection where a rape statute only provides [***2] that a male 21 years or older is guilty when he engages in sexual intercourse with a female less than 17 years of age. (Penal Law, § 130.25, subd 2.)

Crimes -- Statutory Rape -- Equal Protection

2. Subdivision 2 of section 130.25 of the Penal Law, which provides that only a male 21 years or older is guilty of rape in the third degree when he engages in sexual intercourse with a female less than 17 years, is not violative of equal protection since the gender based classification bears a rational relationship to a legitimate State end of protecting young females from sexual intercourse and such a statutory classification based upon a valid distinction between the sexes is not constitutionally defective. Only females can become pregnant and the adverse effects to the unwed mother of tender years, to the illegitimate child and to society at large are reasons enough for the desirability of the legislation. Equality of the sexes does not preclude legislation which deals with a physical characteristic unique to one sex.

Crimes -- Endangering Welfare of Child -- Age Distinction between Male and Female Child

3. Subdivision 1 of section 260.10 of the Penal Law, which [***3] provides that a person is guilty of endangering the welfare of a child when "he knowingly acts in a manner likely to be injurious to the physical, mental, or moral welfare of a male child less than sixteen years old or a female child less than seventeen years old", enacted primarily to protect young visitors who come to New York City, especially runaway girls under the age of 17, from being victimized and corrupted by undesirable adults, is not violative of equal protection since the age distinction between male and female children, based upon the degree of vulnerability of the female as compared to the male, bears a rational relationship to a legitimate State end, benefiting the individuals involved and the public at large.

 

2181 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Angelis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Nassau County


97 Misc. 2d 1; 410 N.Y.S.2d 521; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2792



November 17, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Objectant litigant filed a petition for letters of administration as decedent's daughter, alleging that he had died intestate. Petitioner widow, the surviving spouse and executrix named in the will of the decedent, offered such will for probate and challenged the litigant's status as an alleged daughter to file objections to the probate of the will.


OVERVIEW: It was conceded that the litigant's status as a distributee was based upon an order of paternity that was obtained during the lifetime of the decedent but not until 1966, which was some 16 years after her birth. The widow claimed the filiation order was not timely obtained as required by N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 4-1.2(a)(2). The litigant claimed the restriction found in § 4-1.2(a)(2), requiring the paternity proceeding to be instituted within two years from the birth of the child, was unconstitutional. The court found that certain judicial decisions had a distinct trend toward expanding the rights of illegitimates. The court held that the last 20 words of § 4-1.2(a)(2) had to be disregarded as patently setting up an unconstitutional invidious distinction, unequally protecting children depending upon their age at the institution of successful paternity suits. The court held that the difficulty of proving paternity and the related danger of spurious claims provided the basis for requiring an order of filiation during the lifetime of the father. Whether such order was obtained within two years of birth of the child or 16 years thereafter, as in the present case, did not matter.


OUTCOME: The court determined the litigant was a legitimate child of the decedent with status to file objections to probate.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Descent and Distribution -- Right of Illegitimate Child to Inherit from Father

 EPTL 4-1.2 (subd [a], par [2]), which provides that an illegitimate child may "inherit from his father if a court of competent jurisdiction has, during the lifetime of the father, made an order of filiation declaring paternity in a proceeding instituted * * * within two years from the birth of the child", does not absolutely bar an illegitimate child from inheriting from his father when an order of paternity is obtained more than two years after the birth of the child since the two-year period prescribed by EPTL 4-1.2 is a Statute of Limitations which may be lost by the failure of the putative father to invoke it or by his voluntary relinquishment of such defense. To permit the institution of paternity proceedings after two years from the birth of the child when paternity has been acknowledged by the father in writing or by furnishing support (Family Ct Act, § 517, subd [a]) and then to prohibit that child to whom paternity was established from inheriting from his father, creates an illogical situation, setting up an unconstitutional invidious distinction, unequally protecting children depending [***2] upon their age at the institution of successful paternity suits, which serves no legitimate State interest. The difficulty of proving paternity and the related danger of spurious claims provide the basis for requiring an order of filiation during the lifetime of the father and it does not matter whether such order is obtained within two years of the birth of the child.

 

2182 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Christian


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


96 Misc. 2d 1109; 410 N.Y.S.2d 513; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2737



November 16, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss the summonses charging them with various violations of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-503.0.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were street vendors, who were charged with violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-503.0(h) and § B32-503.0 as a whole. The court held that § B32-503.0(h) was unconstitutionally vague because it failed to give notice of the nature of the forbidden conduct and failed to set forth a standard by which police officers could determine who was in violation of the statute. Defendants argued that § B32-503.0 was an invalid exercise of police power because it prohibited a legitimate business and it was arbitrary. The court found that N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10 permitted New York City to enact local laws to promote the health, safety, and welfare of its citizens, including the power to regulate city streets. However, such power had to bear a reasonable relation to the public good. The court held that the remaining provisions of § B32-503.0 were reasonably calculated to keep the busiest areas of the city free from congestion and preserve them for public travel.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the summonses involving violations of a statute prohibiting sidewalk vendors from operating within 20 feet of another vendor. The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss the remaining summonses.


HEADNOTES

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Regulation of Peddling

1. Subdivision h of section B32-503.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York which provides that "no sidewalk vendor shall operate within twenty feet of any other vendor" is unconstitutionally void for vagueness since it "fails to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that his contemplated conduct is forbidden". The statute also improperly places "unfettered discretion" in the hands of the police to arrest suspected violators by failing to set forth a standard by which police officers can determine who is in violation, thus encouraging arbitrary [***2] and erratic arrests and convictions.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality

2. There is a strong presumption that all legislation is constitutional and it is also presumed that the Legislature, in enacting a statute, has investigated and found the facts necessary to support the legislation.

Municipal Corporations -- Police Power

3. New York City has broad powers to regulate the use of the city streets to promote the health, safety and welfare of its citizens under the police power (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10), "one of the least limitable of all governmental powers". However, legislation purporting to restrict an individual's freedom to pursue legitimate activity, in the name of the police power, must bear some reasonable relation to the public good, or it will be invalidated.

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Regulation of Peddling

4. A statute which regulates peddling, a legitimate activity and a "common and traditional use of the streets" (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-503.0), is constitutional where the legislation is enacted for the valid public purpose of maintaining the busiest areas of the city as free as possible [***3] from congestion, and of preserving them for their primary purpose of public travel and is not merely intended to "prevent unfair competition by itinerant peddlers with storekeepers who pay rent and various taxes", a purpose not within the city's constitutional power to promote.

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Regulation of Peddling

5. Subdivision d of section B32-503.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York which provides that no vending pushcart or stand shall be located within 20 feet from an entranceway to any "building, store, theatre, movie house, sports arena or other public place of public assembly" is intended to insure reasonably clear entranceways to buildings, which facilitates the public purpose of traffic control and is therefore valid.

 

2183 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Illardo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


97 Misc. 2d 294; 411 N.Y.S.2d 142; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2791



November 15, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of judgment which dismissed obscenity informations under N.Y. Penal Law §§235.05 and 235.15, as unconstitutional, in the City Court of Buffalo (New York).


OVERVIEW: Appellant state sought review of dismissal of obscenity informations against appellees based on alleged unconstitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law §§235.05 and 235.15. Appellees argued that the statute's affirmative defense portion, N.Y. Penal Law §235.15, was so vague it violated due process because common men of common intelligence were forced to guess at its meaning. The court rejected this argument and concluded the statute contained widely recognized reasons for viewing the obscene material including governmental, scientific, and educational purposes. The court found the "other similar justification" portion simply recognized certain valid reasons for possessing such material which might not fall within the enumerated categories. The court rejected the argument that the fact that the statute provided an affirmative defense to certain movie theatre employees violated equal protection principles. The court found the treatment of the theatre employee class satisfied the reasonable basis test because the legislature had a reasonable basis for the distinction based on the remote nature of exempted employees' contact with the obscenity and the restricted dissemination potential.


OUTCOME: Court reversed dismissal of obscenity indictments against appellees and remanded because affirmative defense portion of obscenity statute was not unconstitutionally vague where it recognized an additional legitimate basis for possessing obscene materials which did not fall within enumerated categories and was not violative of equal protection principles.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Affirmative Defenses

1. Defendants, charged with promoting obscenity, have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the statute providing for affirmative defenses in obscenity prosecutions (Penal Law, § 235.15) before their cases come to trial and thus before the time such affirmative defenses are raised.

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Affirmative  [***2] Defenses

2. Subdivision 1 of section 235.15 of the Penal Law, which makes it an affirmative defense in any prosecution for obscenity "that the persons to whom the allegedly obscene material was disseminated * * * consisted of persons or institutions having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing" such material, is not unconstitutionally vague since the words "scientific", "educational" and "governmental" have well understood and widely recognized general meanings and the average court or jury would not experience serious difficulty in determining whether a particular affirmative defense interposed by a defendant at trial would fit within one or more of these categories. The phrase "other similar justification" is likewise not unconstitutionally vague since the Legislature recognized the possibility that there may be justifiable reasons for the possession or viewing of obscene materials other than those within the three general categories specifically enumerated.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection

3. While the equal protection clause does not forbid the States from treating different classes of persons in different ways,  [***3] legislative creation of a special class must be based upon a distinction separating that class from others, and the distinction must rest on some ground of difference having a fair and substantial relationship to the object of the legislation so that all persons similarly circumstanced shall be treated alike.

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Affirmative Defense for Theatre Employees

4. Subdivision 2 of section 235.15 of the Penal Law, which affords an affirmative defense in obscenity prosecutions to only certain nonmanagerial or nonsupervisory employees of motion picture theatres while not providing the same protection to employees of bookstores, is not invidiously discriminatory and therefore not violative of equal protection since the difference in treatment between motion picture theatre employees and other employees is rationally based on the unique distinction between obscene motion pictures and other printed obscene material. The Legislature could have taken into consideration the remote nature of the contact of the exempted theatre employees with the showing of an obscene film as contrasted to the more direct nature of the contact of bookstore employees with the reading material [***4] sold therein, and could have further determined that the showing of obscene motion pictures is more restrictive and therefore less pernicious than the dissemination of other forms of obscenity.

 

2184 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Robinson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


97 Misc. 2d 47; 411 N.Y.S.2d 793; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2748



November 13, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was indicted for grand larceny, petit larceny, criminal tampering, and theft of services, brought an omnibus motion to inspect the grand jury minutes and dismiss the indictment due to insufficient evidence. The motion also sought to dismiss duplicated or inconsistent counts and to dismiss the theft of services counts on the ground that the presumption created by N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Theft of gas, a "property" under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.00(1) and a "service" under § 155.00(8), through defendant's installation in his buildings of by-passes that tapped into gas company lines, was a larceny under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.05(1) and a theft of services under N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15(6). A presumption under § 165.15(6) provided that when there was evidence of utility line tampering the person who received the service benefit had done so with knowledge of the tampering. Testimony existed that defendant attempted to bribe a serviceman away from turning him in. The presumption was found constitutional under a rational connection standard because it did not impermissibly shift the burden of proof to defendant or conclusively establish that the service recipient had knowledge of the tampering per se. The presumption merely provided a method whereby facts were deemed to be prima facie proof of other facts, permitting a reasonable inference to have been drawn against the person receiving the service, who then had the burden of coming forward to explain the situation. A jury was then allowed to find the presumed fact from the facts in evidence. Defendant's motion was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's omnibus motion to inspect the grand jury minutes; to dismiss the indictment due to insufficient evidence; to dismiss specific counts because they were duplications of and inconsistent with other counts; and to dismiss the theft of services counts. The theft of services presumption was found constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Theft of Gas -- Inconsistent Counts in Indictment

1. Separate counts in an indictment charging defendant with grand larceny in connection with the theft of gas through the installation of by-passes tapping gas company lines in his two buildings, are not dismissed for being duplications of and inconsistent with other larceny counts covering same common scheme or plan since the question of whether a series of acts constitutes only a single larceny in execution of a general fraudulent scheme or more than one is an issue of fact for the jury to determine.

Crimes -- Theft of Gas -- Larceny and Theft of Services

2. Separate larceny and theft of services counts in an indictment in connection with the theft of gas by defendant through the installation of by-passes tapping gas company lines in his two buildings, are not inconsistent since the taking of gas, classified as both a "service" ( Penal Law, § 155.00, subd 8) and a "property" ( Penal Law, § 155.00, subd 1), can lawfully constitute [***3] both a larceny, defined as the "wrongful taking" or stealing of "property" ( Penal Law, § 155.05, subd 1) and a theft of services, defined as the interference with the supplying of commodities of a public utility nature such as gas ( Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 6), the two crimes being essentially different and separate even though the same facts are alleged in both crimes.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

3. Legislative acts are afforded a strong presumption of constitutionality which demands that those attacking them demonstrate invalidity beyond a reasonable doubt. It is the obligation of a court to construe a statute to preserve its constitutionality wherever possible, striking down a statute only as a last unavoidable result.

Constitutional Law -- Criminal Presumptions

4. The basic premise, applied by Federal courts, is that a criminal presumption violates due process if there is no rational connection between the facts proved and the facts inferred or presumed. However, New York has a higher standard of rational connection, holding the constitutional standard to be whether, based on life and life's experiences, a rational connection between [***4] the fact proved and the ultimate fact presumed may be said to exist. The facts presumed must have a natural, not an unnatural, connection with facts proven and the connection must assure a reasonably high degree of probability that the presumed fact follows from the given evidence.

Crimes -- Theft of Services Presumption

5. The theft of services presumption ( Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 6), which provides that when there is evidence of tampering with utility lines, there is a presumption that the one who receives the use and benefit of the service has done so with knowledge of the tampering, is constitutional since there is a rational connection between the fact proved and fact presumed, permitting a reasonable inference to be drawn that the owner of the building receiving the service had knowledge of the tampering. The fact that defendant, the owner of two buildings which received free gas service through the use of by-passes which tapped gas company lines, was never actually caught installing a by-pass is irrelevant since direct evidence is not needed. In any event, defendant admitted having knowledge of the tampering when he attempted to "bribe" a gas company serviceman,  [***5] making the rational connection between the presumed fact and the proven fact even easier to demonstrate.

Crimes -- Theft of Services Presumption

6. The theft of services presumption ( Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 6), which provides that when there is evidence of tampering with utility lines, there is a presumption that the one who receives the use and benefit of the service has done so with knowledge of the tampering, is constitutional since there is no shift in the burden of proof, there being no requirement that the presumed fact flow from the proven fact beyond a reasonable doubt but only that there be a rational connection between the presumed fact and the proved fact. Given the fact of a by-pass, which tapped gas company lines, it is not unreasonable to presume that defendant, as owner of the building, knew of its existence.

Crimes -- Theft of Services Presumption

7. The theft of services presumption ( Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 6), which provides that when there is evidence of tampering with utility lines, there is a presumption that the one who receives the use and benefit of the service has done so with knowledge of the tampering, does not unconstitutionally [***6] shift the burden of proof from the People to the defendant since such a permissive, rebuttable presumption merely provides a method whereby certain facts are deemed to be prima facie proof of other facts, authorizing, but not requiring, the jury to find the presumed fact from the fact in evidence, and the ultimate question of whether the defendant had knowledge of the tampering despite the presumption must still be proven by the prosecution beyond a reasonable doubt. The presumption does not conclusively establish that the one who is receiving the service has knowledge of the tampering per se, but instead, it merely permits a reasonable inference to be drawn against the owner who then has the burden of coming forward and explaining the situation and even if he fails to satisfactorily explain the situation, the jury must still decide if the prosecution has satisfied its burden of persuasion in proving guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

Evidence -- Burden of Proof -- Burden of Persuasion and of Going Forward with Evidence

8. The burden of persuasion remains on the same party throughout a trial and never shifts, while the burden of going forward with the evidence shifts from [***7] one party to the other and is in no way related to the burden of persuasion. A criminal presumption, such as the theft of services presumption ( Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 6), which operates to aid the prosecution, does not affect the prosecutor's ultimate burden of persuasion to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, but instead places a burden on the defendant to come forward with evidence to explain away, destroy or rebut the inference to be drawn. The presence of a rational connection between the presumed fact and the proven fact prevents the burden of proof from shifting impermissibly to the defendant.

 

2185 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Zagarino


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


97 Misc. 2d 181; 411 N.Y.S.2d 494; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2768; 4 Media L. Rep. 1693



November 13, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with narcotic violations and movant reporter sought an order quashing both a subpoena ad testificandum and a subpoena duces tecum. The reporter argued that the information that she possessed was privileged pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2304, N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79-h, U.S. Const. amends. I, XIV, and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8.


OVERVIEW: The reporter interviewed an undercover police officer. A printed article quoted the officer several times, including specifically identifying defendant by name. Defendant argued that the subpoena for the reporter's notes and records were necessary to determine whether the officer's trial testimony would be consistent with the information that he related to the reporter. The reporter argued that she should have been exempted under the journalist's privilege. Because the officer planned to testify at defendant's trial, the court held that the privilege, which protected the anonymity of the source, was waived. The shield law, N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79-h, did not apply because it was expected that the identity of the undercover police officer would have been revealed and that his activities surrounding the investigation and arrest of defendant necessarily would have been part of the prosecution's case against defendant. The shield law did not protect that which had already been exposed to view. Accordingly, the motion to quash was denied.


OUTCOME: The reporter's motion to quash the subpoenas was denied.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Press -- Refusal to Divulge News Sources to Grand Jury

1. The First Amendment does not grant journalists an absolute privilege permitting them to refuse to divulge confidential sources when subpoenaed to testify before a Grand Jury. (See Branzburg v Hayes, 408 U.S. 665.) Requiring newsmen to appear and testify before Grand Juries [***2] does not abridge freedom of speech and press and newsmen are therefore not constitutionally privileged to withhold duly subpoenaed documents material to the prosecution or defense of a criminal case, the courts being available to remedy abuses of process on a utilitarian individual case basis. The issue of whether a First Amendment exemption exists when a journalist is subpoenaed to testify for a defendant in a criminal trial must be addressed on an ad hoc basis.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Press -- Refusal to Divulge News Sources

2. There is no need to determine constitutional priorities between a defendant's Sixth Amendment right to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his favor and freedom of the press where a reporter's constitutional claim to be exempt from producing her notes concerning the information she received about defendant from an undercover police officer has been waived by the officer's planned testimony for the prosecution at defendant's trial. A reporter is not aggrieved when the confidential relationship is dissolved by the party requiring the anonymity ab initio.

Newspapers -- "Shield Law"

3. The "shield law"  [***3] (Civil Rights Law, § 79-h), which prevents journalists from being held in contempt for refusing to reveal the sources of their information on material which they have broadcast or published, does not exempt a newspaper reporter from responding to a subpoena calling for production of her notes and memoranda concerning information she received about defendant from an undercover police officer in connection with an investigation of drug suppliers and illegal gun dealers in order to impeach the credibility of the officer before the jury, since the identity of the undercover police officer will be revealed when he testifies for the prosecution at defendant's trial and it is not the intent of the "shield law" to "protect that which has already been exposed to view". Accordingly, if material and relevant inconsistencies between the testimony of the undercover police officer and information concerning the defendant attributed to the officer in the newspaper article are revealed, movant will be required to produce her notes and memoranda for in camera inspection by the court and should the court rule that the notes and memoranda give rise to defendant's Sixth Amendment right to produce [***4] testimonial inconsistencies before the jury, movant will then be required to testify concerning her notes and memoranda under pain of contempt.

 

2186 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Goodman v. Liebovitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


96 Misc. 2d 1059; 410 N.Y.S.2d 502; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2729



November 6, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner County Clerk of New York County initiated a proceeding to punish respondent prospective grand juror for contempt pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 751 for her refusal to submit to fingerprinting as a prospective grand juror pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 16. The prospective grand juror moved to dismiss the petition pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 404(a), based upon an objection in point of law.


OVERVIEW: The prospective grand juror complied with all the requirements to qualify as a grand juror, including answering the grand juror questionnaire, as required by N.Y. Jud. Law § 513, objecting only to the required fingerprinting. The prospective grand juror contended that N.Y Jud. Law § 514 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. 620.6 constituted an improper invasion of privacy and a denial of equal protection of the law. The court determined that the purpose of the fingerprinting requirement was to lessen the chances of premature disclosure of grand jury proceeding by eliminating ex-felons and persons of questionable character from sitting as grand jurors. The court held that the arguments in favor of fingerprinting greatly outweighed those against it and rejected the prospective grand juror's claim that the procedure violated her Fourth Amendment rights. The court also found that the statute was not unconstitutional merely because it did not include other similarly situated classes of persons, such as petit jurors and witnesses. However, the court determined that once grand jurors' fingerprints had served their stated purpose, they were to be expunged or returned to the individuals.


OUTCOME: The court denied the petition to punish the prospective grand juror for contempt and dismissed the petition without prejudice to subpoena again the prospective grand juror as a grand juror at some future date following the instituting of procedures to expunge grand jurors' fingerprints once their stated purpose was served, unless they were already on file, or to allow such fingerprints to be returned to the individuals.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- Fingerprinting of Grand Jurors

1. The requirement that all potential grand jurors subpoenaed to serve be fingerprinted (Judiciary Law, § 514; 22 NYCRR 620.6), under penalty of contempt, as part of the screening process to prevent ex-felons and persons of questionable character from sitting as grand jurors and thereby protect the security and confidentiality of Grand Jury proceedings, does not constitute an unreasonable search and seizure [***2] in view of the overriding public purposes for fingerprinting grand jurors. Since fingerprinting is only a means of verifying the existence or nonexistence of a prior criminal record, involving none of the probing into an individual's private life and thoughts that marks an interrogation or search, the actual intrusion and inconvenience being minor, and is widely used in noncriminal contexts and no longer carries a stigma or any implication of criminality, the factors in favor of fingerprinting greatly outweigh any violation of a grand juror's rights of privacy.

Grand Jury -- Fingerprinting of Grand Jurors

2. The fact that both petit jurors and witnesses are asked under oath whether they have committed crimes but are not fingerprinted, while potential grand jurors are required to be fingerprinted (Judiciary Law, § 514; 22 NYCRR 620.6) does not deny equal protection to potential grand jurors since the failure to include all other possible groups within the scope of the fingerprinting requirement does not render unconstitutional an otherwise proper legislative requirement. The fact that the fingerprinting requirement has resulted in the screening out of a significant number [***3] of persons with prior convictions from the list of qualified grand jurors is sufficient to show that the requirement is fulfilling its purpose.

Grand Jury -- Fingerprinting of Grand Jurors

3. While the requirement that potential grand jurors be fingerprinted (Judiciary Law, § 514; 22 NYCRR 620.6) is constitutionally permissible, serving a valid purpose in obtaining vital information as to the qualifications of prospective grand jurors, the privacy rights of potential grand jurors mandate that the fingerprint records be expunged or returned to the individuals once the fingerprints have been taken and checked against other files since there is no sound public policy served by the retention of fingerprint records once they have served their stated purpose. Accordingly, in order to properly safeguard the individual's constitutional rights, the procedures established for fingerprinting should be accompanied by the right to the return of such prints when no longer needed.

 

2187 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wnek Vending & Amusements, Inc. v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


96 Misc. 2d 983; 410 N.Y.S.2d 255; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2716



November 3, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After its application for a license was denied by defendant license director, plaintiff amusement company sought injunctive relief from the enforcement of Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinances ch. VII, § 27, which prevented the company from operating pinball machines within the limits of defendant city. The company's request was denied and it again sought an injunction on the grounds that the ordinance was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The company contended that the language of the ordinance was so vague and loose that it left those required to apply it so wide a discretion as to allow for arbitrary and capricious decisions. The company also argued that it was not afforded a hearing and that the ordinance was defective for failing to provide it with procedural due process. The court found that while the power to exercise discretion had to be accompanied by certain standards, the enactment was not required to specify details and only had to provide a general guide for the licensing director. The court held that the ordinance was not unconstitutionally vague. The court conceded that the company did not receive a hearing, but held that because its license applications were denied for requesting the licensing of two "pinball machines" which were specifically declared illegal by Buffalo, N.Y. Ordinances ch. VII, § 27(1)(b), the licensing director's action was purely administerial and no hearing could be implied because the determination was not judicial in nature.


OUTCOME: The court denied the company's request for a preliminary injunction against enforcement of an ordinance prohibiting the operation of pinball machines within the city limits.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- Legislative Standards in Licensing Ordinances

1. The due process criteria of legislative standards in licensing ordinances is not that all be informed by a statute as to what it commands or forbids and that all men of common intelligence, experience and understanding must not be forced to guess at its meaning, but rather is only to afford a reasonable guide to the licensing authority. While the power [***2] delegated to a licensing authority in a licensing ordinance must be accompanied by certain standards, the ordinance need only provide a general guide for the licensing agent and need not specify details.

Licenses -- "Gambling Devices" and "Pinball Machines"

2. A municipal licensing ordinance which, in prohibiting the operation of any "gambling device", including "pinball machines" within the City of Buffalo, uses the phrase "element of chance" to define a "gambling device" without further prescribed standards to aid the licensing authority in granting or refusing a license application, is not unconstitutionally vague, arbitrary or unreasonable since the ordinance provides a reasonable general guide for the licensing authority. The standards or guides in a licensing ordinance need only be prescribed in so detailed a fashion as is reasonably practicable in the light of the complexities of the particular area to be regulated since necessity fixes a point beyond which it is unreasonable and impracticable to compel the legislative body to prescribe detailed rules. Such an ordinance aimed at the use to which gaming devices are put rather than their inherent characteristics [***3] that motivated their interdiction does not violate due process. (See Albert Simon, Inc. v Myerson, 36 NY2d 300.)

Licenses -- "Gambling Devices" and "Pinball Machines"

3. Although an administrative authority must provide a license applicant a fair hearing, even though the delegating statute does not mandate a hearing, when the applicant's property rights will be adversely affected by an administrative determination which is judicial in nature, plaintiff is not entitled to a hearing on the denial of its application for the issuance of licenses to operate "pinball machines" pursuant to a municipal licensing ordinance which prohibits the operation of such "gambling devices" within the City of Buffalo, since "pinball machines" are specifically declared illegal by the ordinance, making the licensing director's action in denying plaintiff's applications purely administerial for which no hearing is required rather than judicial or quasi-judicial in nature.

Licenses -- "Gambling Devices" and "Pinball Machines"

4. Plaintiff is not entitled to a hearing on the denial of its applications for licenses to operate "pinball machines" pursuant to a municipal licensing ordinance [***4] which prohibits the operation of such "gambling devices" within the City of Buffalo, since any municipality, as a valid exercise of its police powers, has the right to prohibit or regulate trafficking in gambling, making the issuance of the license requested by plaintiff a privilege to which plaintiff had no clear legal right. Although generally, a license applicant seeking to conduct an ordinary occupation or business has an initial right to be granted a license, failing a showing by the licensing authority that the applicant has forfeited that right, thereby entitling such applicant to a hearing to contest the denial of a license, such is not the case where, as here, the applicant's occupation is not one of an ordinary nature to which many individuals aspire.

Licenses -- "Gambling Devices" and "Pinball Machines"

5. A municipal licensing ordinance which prohibits the operation of "gambling devices", including "pinball machines" in the City of Buffalo, does not violate due process by failing to provide a hearing for a license request since the issuance of a license to operate a gambling device is a privilege, not a legal right, for which no hearing is constitutionally [***5] required. If the ordinance has outlived the legitimate concern of the proliferation of gambling and gaming devices that it originally set out to guard against, it is for the Buffalo Common Council to investigate and legislate accordingly.

 

2188 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Pleva


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


96 Misc. 2d 1020; 410 N.Y.S.2d 261; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2722



November 3, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the instrument presently before the court is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the present court's judgment to deny his motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument for a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traff. Law § 1192 subd. 3.


OVERVIEW: The defendant was charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traff. Law § 1192 subd. 3. Defendant sought to dismiss the accusatory instrument, which the present court denied. Subsequently defendant indicated to the court that it failed to consider his replying affidavit in rendering that order and accompanying opinion. Defendant requested the court to reconsider the motion and to take into account the reply. The court admitted upon reading the reply the court had a better understanding of defendant's motion. Construing this request as a motion to reargue, the motion was granted and the accusatory instrument was dismissed. In his reply defendant argued that the misdemeanor complaint did not mention the source of the information and belief. The court held that a misdemeanor complaint, based upon information and belief without disclosing the source of the information and belief was not sufficient on its face within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.40 (subd. 4).


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the accusatory instrument for a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traff. Law § 1192 subd. 3.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Accusatory Instruments

Although a statement of the sources of information and belief is not explicitly required by CPL 100.40 (subd 4) where a misdemeanor complaint is based upon information and belief, such a statement is necessary to provide the reasonable cause required before interference with a person's liberty is permitted. Accordingly, a misdemeanor complaint based on information and belief which does not disclose the source of the information and belief is not sufficient on its face within the meaning of CPL 100.40 (subd 4).

 

2189 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re D.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Richmond County


96 Misc. 2d 870; 410 N.Y.S.2d 36; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2695



November 2, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner state sought a final determination by the family court as to whether the court had authority to fix bail for a juvenile respondent removed from the criminal court to the family court on charges of third degree battery, assault and criminal possession of stolen property.


OVERVIEW: Respondent was charged as a juvenile offender in criminal court with burglary, assault and criminal possession of stolen property. At his preliminary hearing, he was remanded in lieu of bail. His charges were reduced and he was removed to the family court. Upon removal, the criminal court revoked his bail. The family court determined that it was empowered to fix bail for juveniles. In its most literal meaning, the amended Family Court Act specifically authorized the family court to act on the matter of bail when a juvenile respondent appeared before it after a removal and was free on bail, as fixed by the criminal court. Since a statute must be construed, if at all possible, to preserve its constitutionality, the court was required to interpret the language of the law so as not to conflict with constitutional guarantees of equal protection. In light of the fact that the family court had presumptive authority to fix bail for juveniles initially appearing before it, and because a distinction could not be made between juveniles removed to family court with existing bail, as opposed to those with bail revoked by the criminal court, the family court granted bail.


OUTCOME: Under the Family Court Act, the family court had authority to grant respondent bail. Under the law, it was reasonable to imply that if the family court was authorized to release juvenile respondents pending their return date in court, the court was also empowered to determine the condition of that release to insure their appearance on said return date.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Power of Family Court to Fix Bail

1. The Family Court has the power to fix bail for juvenile respondents pursuant to subdivision (a) of section 739 of the Family Court Act notwithstanding the fact that [***2] the statute, on its face, only authorizes the court, after the filing of a petition, to either release the respondent or direct his detention and subdivision (c) of section 739 only authorizes it to act on the matter of bail when a juvenile respondent appears before it after removal from a criminal court and is free on bail as fixed by that court, since any interpretation of the statutory scheme which would afford juvenile respondents whose cases have been removed from criminal court, an opportunity to be free on bail solely because of their expedition in meeting the bail conditions established by the criminal court while limiting the Family Court to the choice of remand or parole in all delinquency cases which originate within its jurisdiction or have been removed with the respondent still in detention, would be violative of equal protection in that the reasons for different treatment of juvenile respondents, based on speed and timing, bears no rational relationship to the concerns of section 739 of assuring the respondent's appearance in court on the return date and preventing the risk of his committing another delinquent act in the interim. Accordingly, subdivision (a) of section [***3] 739 must be read to include a grant of bail powers since a statute must, if at all possible, be construed to preserve its constitutionality.

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Power of Family Court to Fix Bail

2. Subdivision (a) of section 739 of the Family Court Act, which, on its face, only authorizes the court, after the filing of a petition, to either release the respondent juvenile or direct his detention, must be interpreted so as to include a grant of bail powers under the well-established rule of construction that all powers necessary and proper to accomplish the purposes of that authority expressly given are to be implied, since it is reasonable to imply that if the Family Court is authorized to release juvenile respondents pending their return date in court, it is also empowered to determine the conditions of that release to insure their appearance on said return date. Furthermore, the propriety of setting bail for this purpose must be conceded, given its statutory recognition in this State ( CPL 500.10 et seq.).

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Power of Family Court to Fix Bail

3. Since the Family Court is required to read the entire Family [***4] Court Act as a whole and to harmonize all of its parts, subdivision (a) of section 739 of the Family Court Act, which, after the filing of a petition, authorizes the court to either remand or parole a respondent juvenile, must be read together with section 153 of the Family Court Act, which empowers the Family Court to "issue a subpoena or * * * a warrant or other process to secure or compel the attendance of an adult respondent or child or any other person whose testimony or presence at a hearing or proceeding is deemed by the court to be necessary, and to admit to, fix or accept bail, or parole him pending the completion of the hearing or proceeding", and section 738 which authorizes the court to "issue a warrant, directing that the respondent * * * be brought before the court, when a petition is filed * * * and it appears that * * * a respondent on bail or on parole has failed to appear", so as to include the power to fix bail for juvenile respondents.

 

2190 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nagelberg


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


97 Misc. 2d 514; 412 N.Y.S.2d 77; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2828



November 1, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant urged a finding of not guilty to the charge of violating N.Y. Veh. and Traf. Law § 1210(a).


OVERVIEW: Defendant exited from his automobile, leaving the engine in operation. As he walked away from the vehicle it reversed itself, hit a curb, mounted a sidewalk, and struck some bushes and a mailbox. No person was injured but there was some property damage. Defendant was charged with violation of N.Y. Veh. and Traf. Law § 1210(a), which prohibited drivers from allowing a vehicle to stand unattended without first removing the key. Defendant argued that there was a defect in the mechanism for which he was not responsible and that § 1210(a) was unconstitutionally vague. The court determined that: (1) newspaper articles about certain defects in cars were inadmissible; (2) the statute was not unconstitutionally vague; and (3) whether or not the car was defective was immaterial since the law clearly prohibited the leaving of the car unattended without first removing the key from the car.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant violated the statute at issue.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Unattended Motor Vehicle

A statute making it a traffic infraction for a person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle to permit it "to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key from the vehicle", except for "keys hidden from sight about the vehicle for convenience and emergency" (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1210, subd [a]), is not unconstitutionally vague or unenforceable since it is totally clear that it is incumbent upon the person driving or in charge of the vehicle not only to refrain from leaving the vehicle unattended without first stopping the engine but also that if he does so and fails to lock the ignition and remove the key "from the vehicle", he will be in violation of the statute. Whether defendant's car reversed itself because of a defect in the mechanism does not affect his guilt under the statute for leaving his car unattended while the engine was running since issues of negligence and liability are not totally consistent with or coterminous with the questions of violation of the statute and such issues will have to be determined in other actions and proceedings.

 

2191 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Duverney v. State


Claim No. 60332


Court of Claims of New York


96 Misc. 2d 898; 410 N.Y.S.2d 237; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2699



October 29, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a state and others, sought summary judgment in plaintiff individual's action alleging liability of the state when a police officer was held personally liable to the individual for unlawfully arresting and then physically abusing the individual.


OVERVIEW: A state police officer was held personally liable to an individual for unlawfully arresting and then physically abusing him. The individual also sought damages against the state on the theory of respondeat superior. Defendants argued that the action was precluded by collateral estoppel and they sought summary judgment. The court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment. The court held that there were substantial differences between the Civil Rights Act and the elements of the cause of action alleged in the claim. Thus, the court held that the application of respondeat superior would depend on the facts, and the facts must be presented in a plenary trial. The court held that the actions of the state and other defendants appeared to have been excessive and was sufficient to fasten liability upon the state.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion for summary judgment by the state and other defendants, because the actions of the defendants appeared excessive and were sufficient to fasten liability upon the state. The application of respondeat superior depended on the facts, and the facts had to be presented in a plenary trial.


HEADNOTES

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel

1. The doctrine of collateral estoppel, a fundamental principle of jurisprudence which applies when issues of fact have been previously decided in a former action and were judicially determined in such a manner that they may not be litigated in a subsequent litigation, may only be invoked where there is an identity of issue which has necessarily been decided in the prior action and where there has also been a full and fair opportunity to contest the decision now said to be controlling. (See Schwartz v Public Administrator, 24 NY2d 65.) Testing the fairness of the earlier litigation requires an exploration of the various elements which make up the realities of litigation including such considerations as the size of the claim, the forum of the prior litigation, the use of initiative, the extent of the [***3] litigation, the competence of counsel, the availability of new evidence, indications of a compromise verdict, differences in the applicable law and foreseeability of future litigation.

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel -- Prior Federal Court Civil Rights Action

2. Substantial and fundamental differences between a prior Federal court civil rights action (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) in which a jury held a State police officer personally liable to claimant based upon a finding that the officer, while acting under color of State law, unlawfully arrested and then physically abused claimant in violation of claimant's constitutional rights, and an action against the State based on the same alleged acts of police brutality, prevent the prior Federal action from being used by claimant as collateral estoppel in the action against the State. The existence of any reasonable doubt as to what was decided by the prior civil rights action will be resolved against using the prior judgment as an estoppel. Besides the inherent differences between the civil rights cause of action in the Federal court and the claim against the State, the inconsistent jury verdict, holding only one of the two [***4] officers involved in the incident liable, while the claim against the State alleges wrongs committed by both officers, is another factor which casts a shadow upon the use of the doctrine of collateral estoppel.

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel -- Prior Federal Court Civil Rights Action

3. A prior Federal court civil rights action (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) in which a State police officer was held personally liable to claimant for unlawfully arresting and then physically abusing claimant, may not be used by claimant as collateral estoppel in an action against the State based on the same alleged acts of police brutality since the State, which initially appeared for the individual officers involved pursuant to section 17 of the Public Officers Law but then properly withdrew from the defense of the two officers because of the existence of a possible conflict of interest between the codefendants themselves and between the codefendants and the State, did not have a full and fair opportunity to contest the jury verdict in the Federal court. The doctrine that a party who had the right to control the conduct of the litigation can be estopped from relitigating the issues even though [***5] not a party or privy to the prior suit only operates against those who will be directly responsible, vicariously or by agreement should judgment go against the party defendant.

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel -- Pendency of Appeal

4. While the pendency of an appeal does not preclude the judgment's use as an estoppel, the requirement that a party have had a full and fair opportunity to contest the prior judgment before collateral estoppel may be invoked against such party mandates consideration of the existence of an appeal as one factor to be considered before the prior judgment can be used as an estoppel.

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel -- Prior Federal Court Civil Rights Action

5. The Eleventh Amendment to the United States Constitution, which bars Federal courts from ordering States as defendants to give monetary relief or to enter judgments for money damages and which bars civil rights suits (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) not only against the State when it is named as a party, but also when it is the party in fact, as where the suit seeks to impose a liability which must be paid from public funds in the State treasury, prevents a prior Federal court civil rights [***6] action, in which a State police officer was held personally liable to claimant for unlawfully arresting and then physically abusing claimant, from being used by claimant as collateral estoppel in an action against the State based on the same alleged acts of police brutality.

Estoppel -- Collateral Estoppel -- Offensive Use

6. Although the fact that claimant may not use a prior Federal court civil rights action (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) in which a State police officer was held personally liable for unlawfully arresting and then physically abusing claimant, as collateral estoppel against the State in action based on the same alleged acts of police brutality, does not preclude the State from using collateral estoppel offensively as a sword to avoid a finding of vicarious liability as an employer based on the prior award of punitive damages indicating that the officer was acting outside the scope of his employment, the substantial differences between the civil rights cause of action and the elements of the cause of action against the State require that a plenary trial be held to determine the application of respondeat superior and whether the State can be held liable for [***7] the acts of the police officer.

 

2192 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re M.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


95 Misc. 2d 581; 409 N.Y.S.2d 638; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2469



October 26, 1978 



DISPOSITION: The application is in all respects denied and the petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner adoptee filed an application under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 114 for a court order unsealing the records of her adoption. She claimed that no showing of good cause was required for unsealing the record of a private placement, or, if any cause was required, that good cause existed. She also alleged that the statutory scheme denied her equal protection of the law contrary to U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: An adoptee argued that §114 applied only to agency adoption records and ceased to apply once she became an adult. She claimed that good cause existed for unsealing the records because a psychological problem interfered with her artistic skills, she was fearful of contracting an incestuous marriage, and she was desirous of learning her natural mother's religion in order to establish the faith of her son and herself. She also alleged that § 114 created a suspect classification by imposing restrictions on adoptees' access to birth records that were not placed on nonadopted persons. The court held that § 114 applied to both agency adoptions and private placements and required that records remain sealed forever unless good cause was shown. The evidence failed to show a medical or psychological need for genetic data; the adoptee was merely curious about her natural parents' identities. The statute was a legitimate exercise of the state's police power reasonably related to the goal of promoting adoptions. It protected the privacy interests of natural parents and the adoptee had no constitutionally protected interest that required the unsealing of her adoption record.


OUTCOME: The court denied the application and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Sealing Adoption Records

1. The provisions for the sealing of adoption records allowing disclosure only by court order upon a showing of "good cause" set forth in section 114 of the [***2] Domestic Relations Law, which is part of title 2 of the law entitled "Adoptions from an authorized agency", are, by reference, equally applicable to both private placement and agency adoptions by virtue of subdivision 4 of section 116 of the Domestic Relations Law, which explicitly makes the sealing provisions of section 114 applicable to private placement adoptions.

Adoption -- Sealing Adoption Records

2. Pursuant to the well-established principle of separation of powers that the judiciary may not, under the guise of construction, legislate by amending, modifying, extending, or otherwise creating a statutory provision alien to the clear language of that which has been enacted by the Legislature, but may only construe a statute to determine legislative intent in those situations where the language of the statute is either subject to more than one interpretation or is otherwise unclear, the statute governing the sealing of adoption records, which provides that all records of adoptions are sealed forever unless opened by a court order upon a showing of "good cause" (Domestic Relations Law, § 114), cannot be construed as not being applicable to an adoption record where the [***3] adoptee has become an adult since there is no statutory language limiting the period in which an adoption record remains sealed nor any other possible basis for concluding that there exists an unexpressed legislative intent that the sealing provisions not be applicable to adoptees who have reached their majority. Since adoption statutes are in derogation of the common law, they must be strictly construed.

Adoption -- Sealing Adoption Records

3. In order to establish "good cause" sufficient to open sealed adoption records (Domestic Relations Law, § 114), the petitioner must show a present need to view the sealed records rising above mere desire or curiosity such as where access is necessary for a current medical or genetic reason or for a present psychological problem. Accordingly, since petitioner failed to show that her lack of artistic achievement in the fields of poetry and music is in any way connected with her need to view her sealed adoption records or that her psychological problems are related to her adoptive status or that genetic data is needed for any medical treatment or that she or her son harbor any religious belief which would sustain a need to unseal [***4] the records to learn the religious faith of her natural mother, the sole motivating cause for the application must be petitioner's curiosity as to her natural forebears which cannot constitute "good cause" or else every application to unseal adoption records would have to be perfunctorily granted thus ignoring the clear provisions of the statute.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality Attaching to Statutes

4. A strong presumption of constitutionality attaches to all legislation and from this presumption flows a further presumption that the Legislature in enacting a statute, has investigated and found the facts necessary to support a need for the legislation. A party seeking to declare a statute unconstitutional must demonstrate its invalidity beyond a reasonable doubt.

Adoption -- Exercise of Police Power

5. The development of statutory procedures which will promote, encourage and facilitate the adoption of children, involving the moral needs and welfare of the State's citizens as well as the physical welfare of the children involved, is an area subject to the State's legitimate exercise of its police power, the least limitable of all the powers [***5] of government extending to promote the moral, intellectual and spiritual needs of its people as well as physical or material interests.

Adoption -- Sealing Adoption Records

6. Section 114 of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides that all records of adoption are sealed forever unless opened by court order upon a showing of "good cause", does not unconstitutionally deprive petitioner, an adoptee, of her right to her "personality" and "privacy" and "to receive information about her origin" since there is no such constitutional right to a "personality" or an unfettered right to receive any information one might desire. The statute does not exceed the legitimate exercise by the State of its police powers in the area of adoption.

Constitutional Law -- "Strict Scrutiny" Test -- Sealing of Adoption Records

7. The "strict scrutiny" test in determining the constitutionality of statutes, requiring a showing that a statutory classification has been drawn with sufficient narrowness so as to limit individuals to the minimum extent that is required to effectuate a legitimate State interest, is to be applied only when the classification impermissibly interferes with the [***6] exercise of "fundamental rights" which, in matters relating to the "family", include procreation, marriage and divorce, or operates to the peculiar disadvantage to a "suspect class" saddled with such disabilities or subjected to such a history of purposeful unequal treatment, or relegated to such a position of political powerlessness as to command extraordinary protection. Accordingly, since adoptees do not constitute a "suspect class" and an adoptee's right to learn the names of his or her natural parents is not a "fundamental right", as the right to view sealed adoption records does not affect the enjoyment of the fundamental liberties required to freely pursue any activity basic to a full life, the more lax "rational basis" test rather than the more stringent "strict scrutiny" test is to be employed in testing the constitutionality of the statute providing for the sealing of adoption records. (Domestic Relations Law, § 114.)

Constitutional Law -- "Rational Basis" Test

8. Under the "rational basis" test to determine if a statutory classification is offensive to the equal protection clause, a classification having some reasonable basis is not unconstitutional merely [***7] because it is not made with mathematical nicety or because in practice it results in some inequality and will not be disturbed if any state of facts can reasonably be conceived to sustain the classification with the one assailing the classification having the burden of showing that it does not rest upon any reasonable basis but is palpably arbitrary.

Adoption -- Sealing Adoption Records

9. Section 114 of the Domestic Relations Law, which, as part of the legitimate legislative goal of encouraging the adoption of children, provides that all adoption records are sealed unless opened by a court order upon a showing of "good cause", is constitutional since petitioner, an adult adoptee, has failed to sustain her burden to establish that the need for confidentiality has no rational basis. The fact that other States allow adult adoptees open access to their adoption records has no bearing on the constitutionality of the New York statute since the subject is for legislative not judicial determination.

 

2193 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ferber


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


96 Misc. 2d 669; 409 N.Y.S.2d 632; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2661; 4 Media L. Rep. 1706



October 24, 1978 



DISPOSITION: The motion to dismiss the indictment on constitutional and all other grounds is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted for violations of N.Y. Penal Law § 263.10, promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child, and N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15, promoting a sexual performance by a child. Defendant brought a motion to dismiss the indictment, challenging the constitutionality of article 263.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child and promoting a sexual performance by a child. Defendant brought a motion to dismiss the indictment, challenging the constitutionality of §§ 263.10 and 263.15, claiming that they were overly broad, vague, irrational, arbitrary, served no legitimate state interest, were penalty excessive, and violated the doctrine of equal protection of the laws. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, finding that the statutes were constitutional. The court held that the primary purpose of the statutes was the protection of children. The purpose was to eliminate the sexual exploitation of children by establishing strict criminal sanctions against individuals who induced children to participate in sexual performances and who profited from the distribution of such material. This was a valid legislative purpose, reasonable and rational, as was the escalation of penalty for those who abused or profited from such exploitation. The court stated that the impact on limiting legitimate free expression was remote, hypothetical, and speculative.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on constitutional and all other grounds.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Obscenity

1. Obscene material has no constitutional sanction [***2] or protection. New York's definition of obscenity (Penal Law, § 235.00) properly follows the guidelines of the United States Supreme Court (see Miller v California, 413 U.S. 15) which are "whether the average person, applying contemporary community standards would find that the work, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest * * * whether the work depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, sexual conduct as specifically defined by the applicable state law; and whether the work, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value".

Constitutional Law -- Protecting Welfare of Children

2. The State's legitimate interest in protecting the welfare of children and in seeing that they are safeguarded from abuses which might prevent their growth into free and well-developed citizens, may properly restrict what otherwise would be constitutionally protected conduct. Even where ordinances have been struck down as facially invalid, the right of a Legislature to enact laws to protect children vis-a-vis sexual material has been sustained.

Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performances by Children

3. Article 263 of the Penal Law,  [***3] which proscribes promoting sexual performances by children under the age of 16 years, describing the prohibited forms of sexual conduct with anatomical precision and requiring a "scienter" limiting liability to those who know the character and content of what is being promoted, is not unconstitutionally vague since the statute clearly provides "reasonably ascertainable standards of guilt" affording a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice of what conduct is forbidden.

Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performances by Children

4. Defendant, the principal owner of bookstore charged with promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child and promoting a sexual performance by a child (Penal Law, §§ 263.10, 263.15) in connection with the sale of two "Kiddie films" to an undercover police officer, lacks the requisite standing to challenge the constitutionality of the special affirmative defenses available to projectionists, librarians, ushers, etc. (Penal Law, § 263.20, subd 2), but not to similarly situated nonmanagerial employees in other types of establishments such as bookstores, since he is not of the class affected by the application of the statute and a person to whom a [***4] statute may constitutionally be applied will not be heard to challenge the statute on the ground that it may conceivably be applied unconstitutionally to others.

Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performances by Children

5. Section 263.10 of the Penal Law, which proscribes promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child under the age of 16 years, escalating punishment for promoting obscene material from a misdemeanor to a class D felony with a maximum of seven years for the legitimate purpose of eliminating the sexual exploitation of children by the establishment of strict criminal sanctions against individuals who induce children to participate in sexual performances and who profit from the distribution of such material, does not carry an unconstitutionally excessive penalty since the escalation of penalty for those who abuse or profit from such exploitation of children neither shocks the conscience nor offends the court's sense of fundamental fairness.

Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performances by Children

6. Section 263.15 of the Penal Law, which proscribes promoting a sexual performance by a child under 16 years of age even if the performance is within a constitutionally [***5] protected context, primarily intended to make the inducement of children to engage in sexual performances and the promotion of such material absolutely prohibited making material containing children in sexual performances against the public policy of the State regardless of whether the material is obscene or has a literary, artistic, political or social value, is constitutional, being properly enacted for the legitimate purpose of curbing the pernicious practice of profiteering in the sexual exploitation of children, since the protection of children against sexual exploitation must prevail over the right of freedom of expression, the statute's impact on limiting free expression being remote, hypothetical and speculative. If it were important for literary or artistic value, simulation outside the prohibition of the statute could provide another alternative to the utilization of juveniles under 16 years of age.

 

2194 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Weidiger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Oneida County


96 Misc. 2d 978; 410 N.Y.S.2d 209; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2715



October 13, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the indictment on constitutional grounds is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss, on constitutional grounds, his indictment for rape in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.30, and endangering the welfare of a child.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for rape in the second degree under § 130.30 and for endangering the welfare of a child, an 11-year-old female. The court dismissed defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on constitutional grounds. The court held that § 130.30 did not violate equal protection because it was limited to males who had sexual intercourse with females under 14-years-old. The court found that the distinction between the sexes was based on the physiological reality that only females could be raped and rationally served the valid state interests of protecting young females from their own immature discretions, pregnancy, and sexual exploitation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment for statutory rape and endangering the welfare of a child.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Statutory Rape -- Equal Protection

1. The equal protection clause does not not deny the States the power to treat different classes of persons in different ways as long as the classification is reasonable so that a statutory classification which reasonably furthers a State policy based on a valid distinction between the sexes, such as a statutory rape statute focusing upon sexual intercourse between males and minor females, will be upheld since the protection of minor females from rape is a legitimate and essential legislative objective, the limitation of culpability to males constituting a rational classification directly related to the objective of the criminal penalty since only males can perpetrate that crime. The Legislature could rationally have concluded that the danger of sexual exploitation by adult males of minor females and the resulting shame attendant on such activity in our society were so severe that this activity should be specially proscribed in a separate statute.

Crimes -- Statutory Rape -- Equal Protection

2. Section 130.30 of the Penal Law which provides [***2] that a "male is guilty of rape in second degree when, being eighteen years old or more, he engages in sexual intercourse with a female less than 14 years old", does not unconstitutionally discriminate against males and does not, therefore, violate the equal protection clause by limiting culpability to males since a statutory classification which reasonably furthers a State policy based on a valid distinction between the sexes, such as a statutory rape statute designed to further the legitimate State interest of protecting the morals of young girls even from their own immature discretions, will be upheld. A case in the Federal courts which found a New Hampshire statutory rape statute to be unconstitutional (see Meloon v Helgemoe, 436 F Supp 528, affd 564 F2d 602, cert den 436 U.S. 950) is not binding upon a New York court and undue importance should not be attached to it.

 

2195 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Victoria


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Queens County


96 Misc. 2d 926; 409 N.Y.S.2d 937; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2703



October 12, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] They have, therefore, imposed criminal liability on only those persons truly responsible for the dissemination to the public at large and therefore, since there does exist a rational relationship between the statute enacted and the State's interest in the social welfare of its citizens, the court holds the statute as constitutional and does not deny the defendant equal protection as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment and, therefore, the defendant's application is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the charge against him for the crime of obscenity in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05, which resulted from his knowingly promotion of obscenity by selling an obscene film to another.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and charged with the crime of obscenity in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05, for his sale of an obscene film to another. Defendant moved to dismiss upon grounds that the information was defective in that the statute, as applied, violated his constitutional rights insofar as it denied him equal protection of the laws as guaranteed by U.S. Const. amend. XIV. Defendant contended that N.Y. Penal Law § 235.15 specifically exempted a motion picture projectionist from prosecution for obscenity but did not afford the same protection for a cashier in a bookstore.
